text: We went there yesterday afternoon and naturally it was a rather unique experience.  There's lots of interesting material posted on the walls at frequent intervals and there are self-guided audio tours (there are also guided tours at 2:00 p.m., but we were there later).  Irrespective of the reasons for the inmates having been imprisoned, there were two rather poignant things:  a tiny synagogue (one of the very few prison synagogues) which was built & maintained by volunteers in Philadelphia, and a framed prison newsletter article beautifully written by an inmate about the long-time prison doctor (who was originally there for many years on a voluntary basis).

This store is definitely a store for high schoolers who need books off their book list for the semester. (They also have a used book section that is quite limited - more mystery and romance books than straight up lit.) The books are organized just like the bookstore I used to grab books at when I was a high school student. I still would have bought a book anyway (some books that high school students are assigned are great books! Amerika by Kafka? Never read it. Should read it.), BUT they are cash only! At a book store!! Where a typical purchase is probably more than $10! But cash only. So I put my books back, apologized for not having cash, and walked out (probably never to return). If you're a high school student near Franklin or a parent of such a student, this store is probably great (so long as you have cash on you), but for regular readers/book lovers, it's not a great store. B&N in Cool Springs or Landmark Booksellers are probably better options.

Great diner-esque food with a huge pastry bakery case up front. My friend and I were getting hungry and I've seen signs all over for Ponzio's and thought it would be a great time to check it out.

Our first server was a little..odd. But she had to leave half-way through and the next server was ok, but she was semi staring at us once in awhile. This was about 5pm on a Saturday and it was packed. 

To start out, the green bean fries were tasty and the philly cheesesteak spring rolls were super hot, crispy and flavorful. Being as hungry as I was, and knowing I can't actually eat that much I wanted something I could easily heat up the next day as well. Answer- chicken parm with a side of angel hair pasta. Huge portion! Everything was cooked perfectly with a really nice tomato sauce. My friend got a Reuben and loved every bite.  

The menu was large with a copious amount of options. I was deciding between shrimp scampi, strip steak, blackened chicken wrap.. I was on the point of being hangry, but the chicken parm hit the spot.

When I go on vacation, I like to treat myself like it's my birthday!

First step - Make A Reservation! 

This place fills up fast and they will send you reminder text too. I know this is seafood in Nashville but it was literally the best food experience I had while visiting. 

My friend and I arrived from a long flight from NY and had a couple cocktails at Skull's Raimnbow Room before heading over. Yet, Maci our waitress, sold me on this gin, blueberry, egg white cocktail, called Negative Space. Mind Blowing! It's like this girl could read my mind. I am a sucker for gin and egg white cocktail. I could not have been happier. 

The restaurant itself felt modern, clean and spacious. I like to not be elbow to elbow when I am splurging on a meal. 

We started with a dozen oysters. The oyster menu was perfect. It explained the flavor notes for each, of course some of the obscure ones were sold out. Our dinner was pretty late. I would say come as early as you can for the full menu. Also remember to check the boxes for mignonettesauce, horseradish, cocktail sauce and lemon. This was the best way to start the meal. 

They suggested 4-5 plates to share. We ordered 4 after the oysters and it was a lot. But happy we got to try so many of the dishes. 

Poppy's Caviar - was a delicious and light dish 
Octopus salad - So good with the grapes, avocado and crunchy pepitas
Crab Dip -  A really meaty one of the dishes, rich and comforting. Loved the cast iron skillet it was served in
Smoked Trout - a lovely layering of flavors. With the potatoes it became a lot heavier too

We ended up taking some of the crab dip and smoked trout home and it made for the perfect morning chilled breakfast. 

Thanks to our lovely waitress for helping us through the menu and making our experience so enjoyable. I have been singing your praises Henrietta Red, until we meet again!

I am a connoisseur of ALL THINGS CRAWFISH... and while this CAJUNS is not my 1st choice, it does ok to come in 5th.

The crawfish were nicely flavored, not too spicy where you're sucking on ice after sucking each head & not too bland where you're reaching for the Tony Chachere's, #IJS.  

The corn, turkey-necks and pig feet are prepackaged, so to speak.  I guess to be more expeditious while filling orders, the staff has pre-bagged those items.  Not a bad Idea, I guess, but for me I like to have my pig feet, turkey necks and corn sitting in the juicy juices, yeahhhhhh baby!!!!!! 

This day in particular, this Cajun's restaurant's crawfish were about .50 cent cheaper that one of the others that I frequent & the line wasn't too long either.  As at other Cajun restaurants there's a line for cooked seafood & a line for the food that has to be prepared.

All in all this place was there for me in a time of crawfish-feining, I got my fix & i was good!!!!

I suppose I'm reviewing the location of this Best Buy just as much as the store itself, but this entire sprawling Brentwood shopping center that includes Whole Foods, REI, Trader Joe's...I mean, amazing.

This Best Buy is like the cookie cutter versions of itself all around the country.  Identical layout, high likelihood that you'll find what you need and more, and staff that are more friendly than what they are getting paid.

Schenk's Family Bakery on Veree Avenue in the Fox Chase neighborhood of Philadelphia, has been in the flour, water and yeast business since the early twentieth century when their first generation started baking in Germany before immigrating to Germantown  and opening their shop in 1938. Both the family and the bakery have moved around, but always remained Philly centric. Their recipes travelled well.

Today, their storefront is small and lined with glass display cases and shelved walls, all full of their classic cookies, doughnuts, cupcakes, custom iced cakes and amazing pound cake. My small sample of half dozen doughnuts (glazed, vanilla iced, cinnamon sugar and powdered sugar) were all fresh, lightly yeasty and full of sweet flavor. They were perfect for accompaniment with hot coffee. 

The vanilla pound cake was dense, moist and was solidly superior to any commercial effort I have eaten. Better even than Starbucks, which has been on my pedestal for a long while. It would have been great heated with a scoop of ice cream, but stood unapologetically on its own. Why they loaded it up on three sides with copious amounts of white icing is a mystery. It was truly an amazing sugar coating, but unnecessary given the quality of what it covered. Diabetic overkill. 

That shelf of large Eagles playoff cakes looked great and gave comfort that they would be the hit of any party or cold afternoon tailgate at the Linc. Unfortunately, the sweetness would not be enough to change the outcome of the game to come.

(Shaking my fist at Camay's review!!)
She went in with the details...lol
But seriously.. This bar almost brings a tear to my eye.. 
(I said almost, dammit!!)
This reminds me of the bars from back in the day.. Smoking is allowed.. The bar and cooler is stocked with plenty of affordable drinks and beer.. Please don't walk in asking for your favorite craft beer...
People sitting at the bar and tables telling the same stories you've might have heard the last time you were there... But it's still entertaining.. 
A jukebox full of good music.. and a kitchen in the back that I've heard have some really good food, although I can't confirm it.. Apparently lunchtime opening isn't an option.. 
Bring a few bucks.. Say hello to Jasmine the bartender. She was pretty pleasant and attentive. and enjoy.. Bars like these are fading and you'll miss them when they're gone..
UYE anyone??
But first, somebody send an I Love Yelp sticker to put on this bar's door..

There's something about thrifting and finding treasures that gives me goosebumps! The thrill of finding the hidden treasure is hard to explain unless you yourself are avid thrifter, a dumpster diver and a price checker! 

I had bookmarked my stops before traveling to Northern Liberties. And Once Worn was definitely in the to do list. As I walked up I could see a SALE rack! Those discounted racks can be the quick fix for sure. It  was my lucky day. I saw it hidden...it was a ..Catherine Malandrino dress!!! Wow! And in black! I tried to contain my glee for the true test. 

Then....dun dun dun...dressing room! The place that is the true decisions maker in my book.  I closed the curtain and the clerk remarked the Velcro that connects the curtain to the wall. Brilliant! I hate it when there's a little gap and people can see in. And then when I slipped the dress on..it was easily a Va-Va-Voom dress!! Fit like a glove! And I have to wear black at work some days. It was also work appropriate, flattering and feminine. There was black on black leopard pattern in the front section down. Gorgeous. 

I felt the need to pay and try to not tempt myself to buy the whole store. The clerk and I chatted for like 15 minutes! She was a total sweetheart! 

I had so much fun I told my friend who's into vintage to check it out! And from what I hear she made out like a bandit! Lulu Guinness was amongst the loot. Another one of my faves! This place is on my list for all future visits!! And I almost wanted to not review and keep it alllllll to myself but I'm too nice! Enjoy and find some treasures!

In spite of many hipster references on Yelp to this business, I ventured to it late on a weekend night on a simple quest for good pizza.

That actually reminds me of one of my favorite hipster jokes: Why did the hipster burn his tongue on the slice of pizza? Because he wanted to eat it before it was cool.

Lee's pizza is tasty, made with care and the toppings you order on a custom pie are plentiful. And from what I saw while waiting for my pizza, the wings looked good as well. Those came out to a small group sitting near me at the bar that included a man who clearly needed some food in his stomach.

In my opinion, two people can easily fill themselves on this small size pizza while enjoying a drink or two to wash it down. 

There are plenty of beer options, most of which are available in coolers appropriate for a small and older grocery store. There are a handful of craft beers on draft as well and apparently they do pour some wine too...or those wine bottles are just to hold big fake roses and throw people off.

Unfortunately for people like me who drink "crap on tap," as Mr. Dunderbak calls it, Lee's has none of that. Not even "crappy crap" in cans or bottles like PBR or The Champagne of Beers. Which is fine, I get it. They kindly offer Coke products for us old souls who do like French toast, but want the actual breakfast and not a huge brown bottle at an 8.8% ABV.

Obviously, they keep it real simple here: Pizza, wings, craft beer. Seems like they know what they're doing and the employees openly appreciate their customers.

As I finish this review, the Yelp survey questions below include "Good for Dancing: Yes, No, Not Sure." I marked "No" because the only folks dancing here have had way too much of that French toast beer or ABV equivalent and not enough of their quality pizza.

If you are a fan of Dali, this is a must see. To me it is one of the best museums in Florida, because I am a huge fan of the artist. Some of his work is sick and twisted, and the rest is just genius. The one drawback is the admission is steep.

This event is preceding and culminating over Labor weekend and is one of the best barbecue gatherings on the West Coast.  There are around thirty different competitors and barbecue restaurants, which means a great opportunity to sample or eat at so many different restaurants all in one place.  It is a little crowded of course but there seems to be enough available parking.  The lines are reasonable given the type of event but it's worth the wait.  Overall, the barbecue ribs were outstanding at many of the competitors and restaurants.

Do you ever feel like sometimes you were born inside The Matrix? While everyone one else's brain is receiving signals that say the food is juicy and delicious, all you taste is 'a single cell protein combined with synthetic aminos, vitamins, and minerals... everything the body needs' but taste buds don't desire.


THE SCENE

I read the reviews and came here with the highest of expectations. Immediately this place began to sweet talk me. I saw the meat smoker, which was a huge turn on! The sides were open exposing delicious pink meats being slow cooked right in front of my eyes like a sexy dance! I also saw the real wood stacked out back below a large tree with branches full of REAL LIVE chickens... yes I said chickens! (BTW the way, did anyone else know chickens climb trees or am I still inside the Matrix?) As a final act of foreplay, the interior decor was just right, like candles burning around a hot bubble bath. It had that seductive gritty down home feeling I like when enjoying BBQ. The only thing missing from this BBQ romance was blues music playing live!

The chef allowed me to sample several items since I just couldn't decide what I wanted my sides to be. They'd run out of mac n' cheese, which would have been my first preference, however, the collard greens and chicken n' rice were amazing! This took my BBQ expectations even higher as I anticipated a foodgasm once I got my hands on the pork ribs I ordered. Unfortunately, this romance was not meant to be.


THE FOOD

The ribs were smoked to the point of tasting like cigarette ashes. I've learned since being  an active yelper than many people crave this type of smoky flavor, but it was just too much for my extremely picky BBQ palette. I would much rather have well seasoned meat with just a kiss of smoke than eat meat that should probably have a surgeon general warning label!

I also don't care for BBQ sauce. If the meat is well seasoned, to me sauce is unnecessary. Yet I found myself drowning these ribs in sauce to hopefully compensate for the ashy flavor. I emptied an entire table bottle on my order, and still with little desire to eat them, I threw away my leftovers later that evening. Other items to my disliking include the potato salad and baked beans. Growing up my mother used brown sugar to sweeten her beans and that is the flavor I'm used to, but these beans tasted of syrup or molasses, which I did not enjoy. They were also practically as thick as peanut butter.


FINAL THOUGHTS

I'm not sure why people find this place to be worthy of 5 stars, but I most definitely do not. This brief encounter felt very much like being in a relationship where everyone tells you how great the person is before you meet them. When you finally do meet them, they are presentable, attractive and say all the right things. However, in the end, they just don't perform!

I'm breaking up with you Al's Finger Licking Good Bar-B-Que I didn't lick my fingers, not even once.


SIDE NOTE - This review should really be a 2.5, but I really liked the staff. They were accommodating, hospitable and kind. Not to mention the chicken n' yellow rice was simply amazing! So I have chosen to round up instead of down.


2016/4

When I tell people in Philadelphia that I'm Greek-American, invariably one of the first questions I'll get is "What's your favorite Greek restaurant in Philly?" which is quickly followed by "What do you think of South Street Souvlaki?" I have always been at a loss to answer either because I don't eat out often, and when I do it's almost never at a Greek restaurant. Also, as a vegetarian, I just wouldn't go to a restaurant whose name celebrates meat. 

So when my friend Brad mentioned that he'd heard about a new Greek restaurant and would I check it out with him, I was immediately interested. From the initial reviews it sounded legit, more like the food I'd grown up eating at home rather than Greek food catering to American tastes (the many complaints about the lack of lettuce in the Greek salad were a good sign). The menu does still lean more towards the preferences of meat-eaters (gotta give the market what it wants) but there are several vegetarian options. No fish entrees, which seemed like a pretty major omission for a Greek restaurant, but the garidomakaronada sounds like the shrimp Santorini I used to love, which isn't something you find often. 

But anyway, for my first visit the seafood test was the xtopodi (grilled octopus). Because if a Greek restaurant can't do THAT well, it'll never be great. The verdict? It has potential, but I have to admit it's not the way I'm used to having Greek-style octopus. Usually it's cut into pieces (thus more thoroughly cooked), and here the tentacles were served pretty much intact. The flavors were right though, and maybe this is the way it's actually served in Greece? It's tasty so still worth getting, but it's a huge portion so you probably want to have at least 4 people in your party who love octopus if you're going to order this.

I chose the spanakopita as an entree, and that was definitely excellent. The pita was clearly house-made (not ready-made phyllo-dough) and delicious, and the spinach filling was really well done. This definitely stacked up against plenty of the better homemade spanakopita I've had. Brad got the meat-eater's version, the kreatopita (which had chicken, pork and lamb). I've never seen that in a Greek home or restaurant before, so I'm guessing this was made, again, for American tastes. But it must work, because he liked it. Both dishes came with the horiatiki salad - yes, this is what Greek salad is supposed to be like!

Moving beyond the menu, the decor reminded me a lot of the more minimalist Greek tavernas I've been to, though still with a good dose of Greek art and elements (wall tiles, prints, statuettes, etc.) I could heard traditional Greek music over the loudspeaker but the noise level mostly obscured it - the restaurant was PACKED. Lots of big parties, families, etc. Everyone seemed like they were having a great time, and the hosts and servers ran around frantically to make sure that was the case.

So I'm happy to now know a great Greek restaurant in Philly! Well, close enough - a Philly suburb. Since most of the Greeks I know seem to prefer the suburbs anyway, this actually makes sense. In the meantime, I still need to find a good Greek restaurant in the city itself (eventually).

Great place to buy costume jewelry, especially trendy pieces that won't be in style in a few months.  There are TONS of pieces to choose, plus hair accessories and some handbags.   The prices aren't bad, either.

Staples is my go-to store for all office supplies. I generally will buy printer cartridges and paper from one of the big discount clubs, but everything else comes from Staples. The selection in the store is tremendous, but the customer service is spotty (they got dinged a star for that). It's best to know what you want, and have some idea where things are located or else you'll wander the aisles for a while before an associate will offer to help.

They generally have everything in stock, and if not they will offer to order online and ship to you or pickup at the store.

I've used their in-store copy center in the past, but found them to be so-so on quality and service.

Stick to the office supplies, and you'll be fine.

Made my way here with the recommendation from a close friend.  Even on a weekday, this place was hustling and bustling - always a positive sign! The tables are pretty cramped, so it does create an intimate but noisy setting - part of the charm.  I had ordered the short rib pasta, kale salad, and a goat cheese mushroom toast.  Everything was to-die for, especially the kale salad and the goat cheese and mushroom toast.  Normally, I am not a big goat cheese or kale guy, but every last bite was had here.

Highly recommended! Great food and great service.

My boyfriend won a football bet and his prize was to choose dinner. He wanted to go to Seoul Kitchen, but after reading Isabella J's SK review, we decided to try Kimchi Time instead and we're so glad we did! 

The tables were full at 8 pm, which is a testament to their popularity and solid food. The servers were very friendly, but not the most attentive. I did have to flag them a few times but they were especially responsive. 

We ordered the mandu, spicy Korean wings, dolsot bi bam bap, and grilled gal bi - all dishes I highly recommend! They serve everything piping hot, maybe too hot. The wings weren't too spicy in my opinion (I can barely do hot cheetohs). I loved my sweet delicious gal bi. They also provide 5 sides including different kimchi vegetables and sweet mashed potatoes (I asked for extra).  Finish your meal with red bean ice cream and I guarantee you'll leave with a happy belly.

The Rocky Statue and the Rocky Steps are one of the most famous attractions in Philly, both located at the Philadelphia Art Museum. 

Before Rocky III came out, Sylvester Stallone had his character, Rocky Balboa made in bronze. Originally this statue was placed at the top of the stairs of Philadelphia Art Museum for the movie and then left there as a gift from Sylvester Stallone. However the museum did not consider this to be art and more of a "prop" from the movie and refused to allow the statue to be kept here. So eventually this statue was placed at the bottom of the stairs, to the right of the museum, where it lays now. 

With both arms raised, this statue gives that feeling of hope since Sylvester Stallone's Rocky Balboa was that underdog who took on the boxing champion of the world and went all 15 rounds in Rocky I. What a movie!

Just as other fellow Yelp members had mentioned, there will most likely be a line to get a photo with this free attraction, any time of the day (even if the weather is not the most desired). But the line does move kind of quickly. Although you do see some people over do it and take more than a few photos with the statue, which will hold up the line. We saw several people doing that, which was a little annoying. 

But anyways, definitely a nice keepsake photo for your travels.

Please note that if you decide to come here, there is limited street parking. Right at the bottom of the museum are loading zones only so just be sure to be aware of the signs so you don't get a ticket.

Our friend took us on an eating tour of philly, and this was one of our first stops.

The line looked long but it moved super quickly, this restaurant is tiny and we ended up taking our food to dizengoff to eat. I wish there was more seating inside because this restaurant is so popular.   Prices are decent for the food, we ordered a 3 piece, every order comes with a fresh donut!! We also ordered 2 of their flavored donuts. 

We chose the ranch powder flavoring, and got some extra spicy sauce on the side. Sometimes when you order fried chicken, you end up with a soggy mess because of the sauce. Not here!! The chicken is crispy and super tender inside. I could have used more ranch powder though. I wasn't a huge fan of the donuts because  I only like yeast donuts. These cake donuts are super fresh though, since they are made to order!!

This restaurant is a must go in Philly!!

I don't normally patronize Channelside, nor do I normally bowl. Frankly, I can't honestly remember when was the last time I was in Channelside or when I bowled. I am a germaphobe when it comes to wearing bowling shoes and using balls that everyone and their brother has touched. 

It was not my night to pick out our outing, so I was told we were going to Splitsville. After cursing myself for not overriding the decision, I armed myself with Lysol wipes and hand sanitizer and mentally prepared myself to go. 

The business has disintegrated so much in Channelside that Splitsville is only open on Thursdays through Sundays. After psyching myself up to go bowling for the first time in years, I must admit I was a bit disappointed tonight that Splitsville was closed. 

I cannot blame Splitsville for only being open on select nights. After all, these Channelside businesses need to make some sort of profit. I only pray Jeff Vinik's bid gets approved by the end of this week so that there is some sort of revitalization of Channelside. 

We plan on returning soon so I will need to stock up on my Lysol wipes and hand sanitizer and start mentally preparing myself again. I will update my review upon our next visit!

I highly recommend going kayaking in the swamps! It's a nice and quiet getaway from all the drinking and music on Bourbon Street. 

There are 2 swamp tours to choose from:
1. Manchac Mystic ($59 not including tax)
2. Honey Island ($65 not including tax)
- Use promo code ONLINE to get a discount

N.O. Kayak Swamp Tour provides the option of getting picked up in the French Quarter for an additional $20 per person but my group of friends decided to rent a car for the day to partake in other adventures. Super cheap option by the way! If you are driving, make sure to have someone navigate how to get there. There isn't an exact address but the instructions they send you are accurate so you won't have a problem. 

The kayak tour starts with a brief introduction and tips on kayaking. My friend and I were lucky to be the only ones that got the single person kayak and the rest were double riders. Some of my friends struggled with coordination so it's probably a good idea to let the staff know beforehand that you want a single rider. The swamp (Manchac Mystic) was beautiful! We learned a ton about alligators and other wildlife. We were lucky enough to go on a semi sunny day so we were able to see at least 4 alligators. I have to admit I was a bit scared at first but our tour guide advised us that 'gators are actually pretty dormant and since they're cold blooded, they try to conserve as much energy as possible. Also, the ones we saw were adolescents so they weren't too big. 

The tour altogether was 2 1/2 hours and it was a great arm/shoulder workout but it won't completely burn you out. Make sure to take water, mosquito repellent, sun block, and cash for tip. I'd definitely try this again at Honey Island!

Although Mike's made my list of Nashville must-trys on a recent trip, we accidentally stumbled upon this place on a walk of Broadway on a recent trip--and boy, are we glad we did! Mike's is a small ice cream parlor, one that barely fits the patrons and its popularity. There is some effort that went into decorating this place like an old school ice cream parlor, with it's small tables and chairs, counter tops, and unique wall décor. 

Mike serves a wide selection of handmade ice cream in a variety of different ways and they are extremely generous on their scoops. Between the two of us, we shared a single scoop of pralines and cream on a waffle cone and it was almost too much--and we're both like our ice cream! The ice cream is very creamy and incredibly delicious. In this particular flavor, there were generous amounts of praline--a few in every bite, and lots of caramel swirls. Our ice cream was truly divine and it seems like everyone else's ice cream was also delicious as no one could make it to the register without first taking a bite! 

Although we didn't venture this way, I noticed a few cool things that could spice up your ice cream treat here, such as a cookie cone or a Nutella sundae...but who needs spicing to this already delicious treat? Definitely a must try and completely worth the calories!!!

Ahhhh I like crepes but not empty crepes lol.

Came here during my stay back in 2018. I've been to the food court at West Edmonton Mall many times, and never really gave this place a thought in the world until one day when I was craving a snack that would keep me full for a few hours. I noticed this place while the rest of my family members were fixated on Subway and thought, eh, why not?

Pros:
- In the food court near Galaxyland so it's definitely that spot for dessert or even a savory snack.
- Serves both savory and sweet crepes, with their creations nicely presented as plastic representations at the front for you to see. Each crepe has its own name and pricing available.
- Accepts cash and card.

Cons:
- Overpriced for dwindling quality.
- Crepes do NOT look as nice as their plastic menu shows them to be. They're lackluster and skimpy in terms of the filling. 
- Workers do not greet you, and they look like they don't even want to be there.

I ordered #11 I believe which is whipped cream, strawberries. and chocolate drizzle. What I got was loads of crepe that had no filling, and probably a few strawberry slices with heaps of whipped cream and barely any chocolate. Prolly wouldn't come back if ever I'm back in Canada.

Why 5 stars? Because this was my first experience with the wonderfulness of Guatemalan food!

   ---   ---   ---

I say it every time... I think I was meant to be Spanish. 

Yelp celebrity Gerardo L took me here today for a little look at what Guatemalan food is all about. After one visit, I am completely sold. Everything I ate was amazing. The tamale was the best I've ever had. The bread was amazing. My meal was a uniquely seasoned pork dish called Cafe Adobada. 

It was 50% familiar, and 50% unique... which I realize sounds weird. So allow me to explain. The taste was similar to other great Latin dishes that I've had, but at the same time, it also had a one-of-a-kind feel to it. It also had this really buttery sour cream that accompanied it... that was almost worth the price of the meal alone!

For dessert, I had a concoction of warm corn milk. Sounds gross, right? Well, it was not. It was actually pretty great. Definitely not your typical dessert, but I liked it.

The bottom line - this place absolutely rocks... and you should absolutely check it out soon!

Ok fine,,, I'll give it to you. I always thought that this chain was a bit too tourist trap-ish... BUT I can't just let my bias get the better of me. So we're here and we're going to smash.

Let's begin shall we.

Waffles:     I really enjoyed the texture, soft and crispy that's not painful to consume. The syrup was perfect accompaniment to the whole dish.

Mac & Cheese:     This side is fire yo, I adore the depth and meaty flavors. This dish definitely came to slay.

Greens:     I can't believe I'm eating greens from a chain and it's actually phenomenal. We definitely enjoyed every bit of this dish.

Chicken Quarter (HOT):     WEAK, I was expecting my mouth to be on fire but it didn't. I feel as if an amateur spicy food eater can handle this level of heat. Plus the flavor was a bit lacking.

3 stars, just because the opening acts should never EVER out do the main event. This spot definitely scored high marks on the side show category. High enough to forgive that excruciating wait to be seated. Anyways, it's whatever. I gave my score because I was not impressed by whatever food you're known for. People will still flock to you. Your marketing is definitely on point.

Thank you so much for reading my review. I hope this helps with your decision making experience. Enjoy your awesome yelptastic day!!

Yes I stopped here and although I wasn't blown away I did enjoy looking through the vast amount of stuff. The name really overstates and hypes the experience somewhat in my opinion but I applaud the creativity. I understand volume is the attraction for many but when the business model includes consignment items the quality can somewhat get diluted and I feel that's the case here. I'm not saying there aren't any treasures here it's just going to take a little more time to find them if they does exist. There was no interaction with the staff which is actually a positive for me I just want to explore on my own at my my own pace. I'm sure if I needed assistance it was readily available I could hear their conversation ring throughout the shop and they seemed friendly during the greeting upon my arrival. The bathroom was very clean...

I love flowers, so, therefore, I love Longwood Gardens.  You can easily spend most of your day here viewing the 20 outside gardens and fountains and the 20 inside gardens.  I'll spare you from naming all the flowers that you can see.

Land that was originally owned by William Penn and then sold to an Amish Farmer and then finally sold to the Dupont family in 1906.  

Wear comfortable shoes.  This place should be visited at different times of the year, when the days are warm and sunny and you can see it all, inside and out and then again around the Christmas season, when it is breath taking, with decorations.

Two Restaurants, one a casual cafe and the Terrace restaurant were you can relax with a bit more upscale and flair.

Get there early is all I can recommend. Getting there 2 hours before close, most of the items were sold out. Which speaks well of the food, and the adage of being early.

I had gotten into St. Pete that day and while hanging with friends, was debating on what to eat. We ended up talking for a while and debating food spots. All I really wanted was something I can't get good back in California - barbecue! This had great reviews, a huge menu, and a parking lot. Works for me.

We arrived, and from the menu in the door there were already items crossed off. When we got to the host, he mentioned they had closed off sections already and for the quickest service would be the bar. My friend and I didn't have a problem with that, but still a weird thing to say.

As we were checking out the menu, we asked the bartender for his recommendations. He gave us a bunch, but then it turned into a sad state of "Uh oh, we're out of that."

Stick ribs? Sold out.
Mac & Cheese? Sold out.
Pork Belly? Sold out.
St. Louis Ribs? Sold out.

With what options were available, we went with the following:

What's Caulilini - Fried cauliflower in a light oil. I know, not what you would expect to order, but with a big dinner, figured something light and roughage would be solid. And these are tasty!

My friend and I each got a Texas Two Step. Mine came with Sliced Brisket, Pork Brisket, Sandi's Bacon Blue Cheese Slaw, and Fries. The sliced brisket is excellent, really enjoyed that. The pork brisket was okay. The fattier pieces were more enjoyable, but required a lot of chewing. The slaw and fries were both great. 

My friend got the Burnt Ends, aka Meat Candy. GET THOSE! So tasty.

All in all, I would definitely come back to Dr. BBQ, just at an earlier hour so I could get everything I wanted. Definitely those burnt ends.

My best friend who lives in Nashville has Glazee Artisan Ice Creams programmed into her GPS as a favorite.  This helps to expedite the process of getting there most effectively.  And yes the day we went it was a chilly 60 something degrees outside with misty rain.  Sunny weather not required to crave this stuff.

If you ever go in and see a tall, boyishly good looking 40-something man with tousled dark hair and one blue, one brown eye who looks like he just stepped off his surf board at Zuma Beach then you've met the owner, Mike.  And he makes this ice cream in house every single day.

To say Glazee Artisan Ice Creams is incredible would not be giving it full credit.  It is more than that.

It is truly a very sweet ice cream which for me means that I can only eat a small amount.  Those who are more experienced ice cream eaters can handle the bigger cups.  The base for his ice creams is brown sugar and this is most effectively tasted in his masterpiece Banana's Foster.  You need Banana Foster.  In fact, what you really might need is to mix your cup with both Banana Foster and the Cinnamon vanilla.  Yes, I believe this will do the trick.

Fear not because Mike will let you sample his creations free of charge.  Sometimes he does a buy one get one free.  Most importantly is that you come here immediately and partake in this Nashville treasure.  And tell all your friends to do the same.

The seats in the theater seem a bit older and more worn than the AMC locations on the Eastbank.  If you are on the Westbank and want to watch a movie this will certainly work.  Personally I think I like the Elmwood AMC better as it seems everything is in better shape generally along with having a few more screens of options to choose from.  Prytania Theatre is always more fun to me than any of the AMC's but they are local and local is always better.

Very disappointed!!! My day job gives me the opportunity to travel around the world.  My night job is a certified Master BBQ Judge.  So when I travel I always try to find the best time BBQ joint in the city.  Coworkers in St Louis said Pappy's was the best and the brisket was thier specialty.   I eagerly drive through rush hour traffic to Pappy's.  What a disappointment!  Don't get me wrong, the people were friendly and the restaurant was interesting, but the brisket was some of worst brisket I have ever tried.  The ribs were average.  The baked beans was probably the best item.  I could only eat 2 small bites of the brisket.  The second bite was to confirm that the first bite was as bad as I thought.  It was.  Maybe I caught Pappy's on a bad night, but I fear I didn't.

Beignets were better than Cafe Du Monde but lacks the atmosphere/experience that Cafe Du Monde provides. I don't really know the criteria to judge beignets but I liked the texture more, they didn't have a big mushy center like those you find at CDM. I also had the crawfish omelette and it was pretty good but I thought it was slightly overpriced and it came with a side of grits that were just terrible, dry and bland. Their courtyard was nice but not spectacular - simple patio furniture, lots of trees, and a view of the street for people watching.

We purchased a new pickup a while back from Andy Mohr Chevorlet in Plainfield. The salesman worked within our budget, took into consideration exactly what my husband asked for in a new vehicle. The salesman wasn't pushy and noted upfront the price listed on the internet and it was the bottom dollar price. The price was very reasonable and fair to my husband. The service was excellent and the salesman placed my husband's requested changes immediately before we took possession the next day. The following day everything was handled as requested and on time.

We've since taken the vehicle in for maintenance and found the service department excellent. Very honest, friendly, calls with estimate before repairing a part and we've never encountered a problem. We have been pleased with both the sales and service department.

This girl loves to cook, so I also took a tour through Philadelphia's Italian Market. You can tell you arrived when you see the storefront's selling (and smelling the) roasted meats, street side veggie stands, spice markets, knick knack stores and casual eateries.

Walking down the street, I thought to myself this is where I would shop. I am more of a gatherer than a "big box store" kinda girl, I like going to the butcher, the specialty market and the produce market to get my special items for my special recipes.

I bought spices, kitchen gadgets and stockings from the local dollar store. I stopped for coffee, a hoagie and was on my way. It was fun and a little something different off the touristy trail.

Went here for an early Monday Indian dinner (buffet style of course).  First time coming here and have to say it won't be my last!

The place is absolutely massive - they have a separate section for banquets/parties/events and then the main dining section (by the buffet). So back to the food.  Best part - dinner buffet is only $14.95! So cheap. Food is actually really tasty and hot. There are a few salad/fruit selections but I was saving my appetite for the main dishes.

There were 12 dishes (8 vegetable and 4 meat):

- Rice
* Lemon rice (yummy)
- Palak paneer
* Aloo gobi (delicious cauliflower, potatoes and interestingly this one came with slices of tomatoes and cilantro)
- Vegetable pakora
- Chickpeas
- Lentils
- Guferati (green beans)

- Lightly battered fried fish
* Goat curry (perfectly tender)
* Butter chicken (nice and creamy and perfect sauce to complete my naan) 
- Mysore chicken

Note: * means you should eat these dishes for sure.

Really like the wide selection of choices and how there are lots of vegetable dishes to choose from.  Service is super friendly - staff take your dishes and fill your water/tea constantly.  

Naan is made fresh to order and was delicious.  Nice, fluffy and warm with perfect crunch to it.  Music is hilarious - top 40 DJ remixes but it is in the background and isin't too intrusive.  Just not what I would expect at an Indian restaurant.

Stuffed as always from buffet but we were able to get a few bites in for dessert. They had gulab jabun (mini honey soaked donuts), mango custard (EAT this - nice and light) and kheer (rice pudding).

All in all, really good quality and tasty Indian buffet! Go and check it out.

This is an alternate to the highly popular Cafe du Monde, since it's literally 1/2 block away and has much shorter lines.  You are less likely to be standing in the rain here.  They have more savory items on their menu, and are counter service, unlike their conpetition.

The beignets reminded me more like croissants than beignets.  I also tried the pig in a beignet and sausage and grits.  Didn't really like those though since the sausage was a little weird.

I'd prolly stick to the CDM line next time.

Had a lovely Saturday afternoon experience here. I'm not one to get pedicures often but this one felt especially relaxing and comfortable. My biggest complaint with pedicures is the pain that comes from hack job cutting of the nails, bleeding, etc. the gentleman who gave me my pedicure was very gentle and gave a great foot massage. Upon entering, we were quickly greeted and selected our nail polishes. The wait was about ten minutes which was fairly short given how busy they were. 

The basic pedicure kicks off with a foot soak followed by a scrub, short massage, nail trimming/maintenance and painting/drying. I appreciated the offer of water/soda and all in all the experience took about 45 relaxing minutes. The basic (non gel) pedicure will run you $32 before tip. V Nails is located in a strip mall so parking can easily be found out front.

La Tour has moved to the funk zone and their space is leaps and bounds bigger than the old space. Even the restroom alone is bigger than their old space.

Also, expanded open times! Now it's 6 days a week, 11 am - 2 am (closed Monday). Liquid lunch, afternoon break, the "happy hour", night cap...covered.

They are sharing 222-4 Helena with The Pub, and the interior is sleek and industrial, and a little rock and roll. La Tour's side still serves up European wines by tasting flight (5 for $10), glass, or bottle, and now they also have charcuterie plates. Big yums. 
The cured meats are made locally by another chef, and the afternoon I stopped by my selection was duck prosciutto and duck rillettes. 
The cheeses came from C'est Cheese, another local shop, and my selection was Brillat-Savarin, and Epoisse. They'll change the cheese depending on mood, request, or what you're drinking.
My plate also came with housemade mustard and pickles. And little toasts and wafers. It cost $12 and was excellent, complemented by La Tour's wines.

With the increased space, they now have two certified sommeliers on staff, and I'm told there is no other business in town that has this. These guys are serious about knowing their wine and making recommendations for you. Yet, they are super friendly and approachable. They are both local boys, too.

My girlfriend went with a glass of Burgundy, recommended by the staff to complement our cheese selection. I was in a celebratory mood and started with a tasting, but didn't get past the first sip of a fresh bubbly prosecco and ended up with a glass of that, which was fitting for not only their opening weekend, but the weekend Fiestas. Viva!

On another visit, a Saturday night, the shared space was hopping busy. This makes La Tour better for being a social wine bar. If you want a quieter time for serious tasting with an eye to buy, it's better to go during the daytime.

In joining the Funk Zone, they're just a hop away from many other spots along the Urban Wine Trail, and bars like Reds, and a, uh, juice bar like the Spearment Rhino. This could make for interesting evenings indeed, and parking will probably get tight. Then again, maybe you shouldn't be driving.

I love historical buildings, and the old world charm associated with them, so when my friend said he actually found an affordable bed & breakfast that is more like a hotel (and supposedly haunted!), I was really stoked. We'd have the best of both worlds: a concierge available for questions and issues like you would have in a hotel, and the coziness of a B&B, both working side by side. They call these types of places boutique hotels for their small size, and their independent character.  We had no idea that they would operate in such an odd manner, though -- nothing like a traditional hotel.  For starters, there is a check-in time, and if you are unable to meet it, they send you this rather terse email with instructions as to where to find your room key, and you're not really told much about the parking.  

We had no choice but to arrive late, considering St. Petersburg is 5 hours away and we were coming on a Friday night, which means, we had to wait until the workday was over to head on the road.  Sure, I feel bad about checking in late, but I had never had it become an issue anywhere, because I normally stay in hotels or motels, and there is someone on-site 24-7.  It was also something out of my control, living all the way in Miami Beach.  My friend and I parked in the lot next door, and we suddenly realized you had to pay to park.  By the way, parking in that lot is not guaranteed, if it's full, find somewhere else to park along the street and lug your bags.  We had never experienced this, ever.  There wasn't even valet parking.  We could not pay for parking any later than 6 a.m. because that was the limit on the machine, and the lot had a tow-away sign, leaving my friend with no option but to set his alarm to 5:30 a.m. and go out to speak to staff and resolve the parking situation...except there was no staff yet at that time, so he was stuck paying by the hour once again.  Eventually, we did sort the parking issue when staff arrived later in the morning, but $10 a day for parking seems steep.  We were also told the minute we checked out, the car had to be removed.  We could not stay parked in the lot for a single minute or we'd get towed.  

The hotel itself is very cute and charming.  There is jazz music playing outside on the porch, so you can sit on the rocking chairs and relax.  The dining room is pretty, and classy, though small, but it is a small hotel after all, so it is meant to be cozy.  Breakfast is included and it is decent: muffins, cereals, tea, milk, orange juice, and other goodies. Don't expect omelettes, bacon, sausage, or a full carving meat station though.  The place is clean, and well-decorated.  We excitedly pushed into our room to check it out, and it was extremely cozy and homey, unlike the typical hotel.  You felt like you were staying in someone's guestroom.  The transom windows and doorknobs were from a time past, and they successfully integrated modern touches like the chandelier decal behind the bed and the flat screen TV.  

The bathroom was my favorite part.  I find it interesting how many people complain about the bathroom being "small", but I did not find it small at all.  Maybe that is because I am not a fan of large bathrooms in the first place, as that means a smaller bedroom, and I don't know about you, but I spend more time in the bedroom than the bathroom, so what is the point of a large bathroom and tiny bedroom? I had no issue with the bathroom, and in fact, was grinning ear to ear when I saw the clawfoot tub because I knew I would enjoy it later.  In fact, the next day I ran out to CVS and bought bubble bath and took a luxurious bath, to the sounds of Ella Fitzgerald on Pandora.  Very classy! All that was missing was the champagne! By the way, if you do want to use the tub, you will need to ask the concierge for a plug for it, but the plug doesn't quite seem to fit the tub.  Also, our cold, moist towels were never replaced and we had to reuse them, so there is definitely room for improvement.

The bed was comfortable, as were the pillows and sheets, but there was this loud "drip drip" sound.  I found the noise was coming from the window unit a/c (the cheap way to provide air conditioning, rather than central air).  I tried to make it colder, change the temperature, the speed, nothing.  I put in earplugs, and I could still hear it, to give you an idea of the loudness.  To say this was irritating is an understatement.  The next morning when I mentioned it to the concierge, he said it was the water dripping from the unit above our room.  When I asked what the solution was, he said none, unless I make him stand outside our window all night long holding a cup.  I understand they underwent an extensive renovation, but they forgot the most important detail a hotel should have: no noise while sleeping.  That is, after all the purpose of a hotel, is it not? It would behoove them to also get central air conditioning in there, to prevent the pesky dripping sounds.

Have you seen the movie Tampopo?

It's an old Japanese movie from 1986 and the main theme is about making good Ramen. Everything starts with the broth, and you can tell a broth is good is by watching whether if a customer finishes the whole bowl or not. In Japanese society, it's also very polite to slurp your noodles as this is another sign that the Ramen is good. 

However, in the west, it's very impolite to slurp your noodles as I caught myself doing after receiving my bowl of Ramen. 

Before getting to the good stuff, let's rewind a little bit. 

Found this gem of a place thru Yelp (surprise) as Wifey was searching for a place to eat. Since we were in downtown Reno and we already drove past Sparks, I quickly bookmarked the place to try the next day. That was this Sunday, and we went here on Monday during Memorial Day. Glad they were open since their secondary location was closed. I called them first just to make sure they were open.

Located a couple of miles North of John Ascuaga's Nugget, it was easy to find. It's tucked in a corner of an unassuming strip mall that hasn't been updated since the 70's. It's not much to look at from the outside, but you never judge a book by it's cover...you already know that. 

Once you set foot inside, everything just lightens up as you get whisked away in some part of Japan. The walls are decorated with bamboo panels and the tables and chairs are in perfect harmony with one another. From the decors to the paintings on the wall and even the fine chopsticks that are arranged in a bamboo holder on every table. They even have a section of traditional Japanese tables on a tatami mat where you have to remove your shoes to eat at. The place had a Zen-like vibe to it, and I was digging the tranquility.

Our server, Jackie, was superb as she was warm, friendly, efficient and fast. We had a party of four (Me, Wifey, Son and Mother-in-Law) as we got seated and checked out the menu. I noticed a note on the menu describing the place was established by Chef Yoshi from Japan, who has also worked in China and France perfecting his craft as he wanted to bring the first authentic Ramen experience to Reno. 

Boy has he succeeded. 

We ordered three bowls of Tonkatsu ($7.75) with extra Chasu/Pork ($2.50) and one bowl of vegetarian ($7.75). I also ordered a bowl of Chasu Salad for starters. The broth is described as white, light and creamy extracted from bone marrows that are slowly simmered. (Did your mouth just water?)

Salad was a mixed green with chopped pork, corn, bamboo shoots, soy beans balanced together by a sesame sauce. It was light, tasty and a nice starter course. 

Then came the Ramen. The extra Chasu comes in separate bowl and I quickly realized that all sides comes in their own separate bowls, which made for a nice visual reference. You can also control the portions of how much you want to add. 

Fast forward to me slurping like a slobbering pig.

The broth was light yet tasty. For me, it was an excellent broth since it wasn't too salty unlike some other Ramen places where they sodium content is thru the roof. It was a perfect balance of richness, creaminess and deliciousness, and you can always add some soy sauce or chili powder to your liking. I choose not to add any condiments as I was enjoying the flavor as it was meant to be. The pork was also superb as it was tender and meaty with all the porky goodness that a Bacon-lover would approve of. 

The only negative thing on the Ramen would have to be the noodles itself - some were clumpy and chunky. Ramen noodles are supposed to separate easily and not get stuck together. However, it was a minor detail that I was willing to overlook as I was thoroughly immersed from the broth with my head down slurping like a Nihonjin. 

Like the movie Tampopo, I finished the broth as well as my wife's bowl.

If driving, enter small parking lot on N Sierra st that is shared with Canes. There is some street parking, but overall, parking can be tight.

I'm comparing this location to the Scottsdale one and its about the same set up. Great ingredients with emphasis on Vegan ingredients. Fast and friendly service. Clean toilet.

There is a .75 cent employment surcharge.

Yelp check-in is a bag of chips!

My recent date-night at Irwin's was everything I wished it to be and more! It was definitely worth the wait! 

Fun fact: Irwin's is named for the architect, Irwin T. Catharine, who designed for The School District of Philadelphia from 1920 - 1937. He is responsible for over 80 school buildings in Philly including Masterman, Palumbo, Overbrook, and this stunning art deco inspired building, BOK!

This space located inside the (somewhat) newly repurposed BOK school is so eclectic. They left graffiti on the walls, kept some other original features and mixed it with mid-century modern pieces, lots of candles, greenery and a breathtaking, dramatic crystal chandelier at the entrance. I TOTALLY dig the vibes! Excellent design details! It's absolutely a place for a romantic evening out and an awesome addition to ever flourishing South Philly. 

We actually wound up switching our reservations to an earlier time to catch a movie afterwards and walked into the space just as an electric sunset was taking place. That unexpected bit of magic set the tone for the rest our our evening here. (Try to come for sunset! Between the outdoor space and all of the large open windows, you'll have an awesome, impressive view!)  

We were seated at a quiet, corner, candlelit table by large windows. It was perfect for cozying up and sharing these delectable small plates that are inspired by the cuisines of Turkey, The Mediterranean and the Middle East. The dishes that brought my tastebuds right back to some of my recent trips around the world were memorable...the sea bass, the lentil rice cake, the baked haloumi with dukkah, the sweet potato hummus topped with sweet pomegranates, even the simple the seeded crackers and perfect grilled pita. Everything was so flavorful and complex...except the baba ganoush. It just wasn't as smoky and garlicky as I'm used to or how I make it. Definitely not bad by any means, it just didn't have that punch I crave in the classic eggplant dish. Other than that, I would absolutely order all of the plates again. They were excellent. (They say 2-3 per person is recommended and I would say that's accurate. We left satisfied but not stuffed, which on a sexy date night, I feel is key!) 

The drink list is impressive. Unique beers, solid wines and cocktails ranging from classics to innovative. The cocktails we had were stellar! Their namesake, 'The Irwin', was strong and sexy. It was a deep with the walnut bitters and garnished with a thin slice of orange peel and a soaked dark cherry at the bottom of the highball glass. The pink 'Aviation' was a sweeter, lighter, more "girly" drink, shall I say. Both good. Very different. 

Our server was very welcoming and super attentive throughout the evening, and the hostess was kind and was gracious, snapping a few photos of us in the super cool space. 

It's really a special place, one I enjoyed immensely. It's reservations only and it felt very exclusive with the check-in at ground level and the guided elevator ride up to the top floor. 

Off season, just as they opened was a neat way to experience Irwin's (especially for the very first time) and when we could have the place basically to ourselves. I cannot wait to return. I would definitely like to come in warmer weather and sit outside, although popping out there on a chilly night was still spectacular as I believe this is the best views of the city. I would die if they started opening for Sunday brunch (Hint, hint if anyone capable of making that happen is out there reading this!). 

Irwin's is not for everyone as the portions are on the smaller side and priced higher according to effort, but it's certainly for us. I cannot praise Irwin's design team, staff and chef enough! 

Excellent date choice! 

*The parking lot directly in front of front door belongs to Irwin's and is free to use for patrons.

Lots of fun to poke around the old-time-feeling Booth's Corner's Farmers Market.  Not as much produce and food as I expected - and alot more gift and knick-knack shops - even a LAWYER has a stall here.

I especially like Esh's Eggs and Stoltfuz meats and produce.

Only open Friday - Sunday.
Wish they had more days open.

Amazing hike, and well worth the effort. I think you could actually break this hike in parts. The first to the waterfall and then if course to the summit. The first part is fairly easy hike. The views are nothing less than spectacular. Hiking past Tamarack Lake with it's clear mountain blue tint, amazing. There is plenty of shade along the first half as well. Obviously available of water is awful handy, as halfway on the hike are  the waterfall. The second half of the hike is a lot more challenging, but so worth the effort. It's s extremely well maintained trail. The views are the continued to get my epic as I made my way all the way to the summit. Just a overall knock your socks off kinda day. Go for it, you won't regret it.

When you talk about hidden gems, Goleta Red Distilling Company immediately comes to mind. It's hidden inside a Goleta industrial business park off Castilian and Cortona Drives. Often the owner Michael will put out a sign at this intersection mentioning tastings that are happening. You'll find a door next to a window with an awning, enter there, then follow the guided signs to their tiny tasting room connected to a massive distillery. 

I originally found out about Goleta Red at a past Official Yelp Event thrown by my predecessor Stephanie W (https://www.yelp.com/biz/oye-sips-samples-and-sweaters-goleta-red-distilling-company-goleta?hrid=a6i2sWY0wVSZElPv8pX4og&utm_campaign=www_review_share_popup&utm_medium=copy_link&utm_source=(direct)). Since then, Michael has been active at local festivals, on social media (Instagram and Facebook) and even offers a deal on Axxess card for 2 x 1 spirits! The minute you enter the door, rosy-cheeked Michael befriends you with his wonderful energy and one man show. While this happens to be his business, it is more of his hobby and passion. He provides tastings of all his liquors: Sterling Silver Rum, Solid Gold Rum, Cacao-flavored Rum, Orange Java Overproof Rum, Fiesta Agave Spirit "Tequila," and Goodland Gin. I'm normally not a fan of gin, but the Goodland Gin possesses a beautiful botanical/herbal flavor profile that stands out in any drink. You can even find it at some bars around town! Once you have tasted a pour of each, then Michael offers one of his creative boozy concoctions made with his own spirits.

This past Halloween, my partner and I came in here while he was open for pre-Trick-Or-Treating. We wanted to make that custom a bit more tolerable with the hoards of kids. Michael mixed up a Ghostly Pumpkin and Corpse Reviver 2. Both were super unique and went down easily by being well-balanced. Michael is fun to chat with and is extremely knowledgeable about distilling given that he loves to educate himself and explore novel techniques--whether or not he succeeds or fails. If you haven't already checked this place out, be sure to!

All things considered, I enjoyed the food at Capri as well as the customer service. I stayed at the adjacent Budget motel that for two nights while on business in Boise (that's another story) and tried Capri for breakfast during BSU's graduation weekend this year. This location is quite festive in the morning, given its proximity to the motel and other businesses on Fairview Avenue. 

Starting with the food, I would rate it 8/10. It was pretty good (slightly greasy), yet palatable. I was so hungry that I really didn't want to waste time eating fast food anywhere on Fairview Ave, so I chose the meat lover's omelette along with a side of hashbrowns and a cup of coffee. I think that I paid a total of $11 before the tip. Very filling, which served its purpose in not keeping me hungry for several hours.

The seating is not bad at all. There is a bar area (where I sat at), as well as side tables on the far left of the dinner wall as well as within the front and toward the right of the venue. The bar area had some very "interesting" conversation from travelers and locals alike, which actually lightened up the mood. The servers were attentive and very sweet, and made sensible recommendations on the food items listed within the menu. 

If the decision came to choose fast food versus this location, I'll take the latter for $500, Alex.

This is one of two Dottie's locations in Philadelphia and it's fabulous. This small donut shop offers a wide variety of all-vegan donuts that will knock your socks off. I brought a dozen to my non-vegan quasi-in-laws and all of them loved the donuts, including the picky children.

In particular, the chocolate pistachio ($3), the Boston Creme ($3) and the coffee cake (which is one of the few non-donut offerings they have) were wonderful.

These donuts also hold up well. They still tasted good even 48 hours later, whereas I've found most other donuts are stale within a few hours.

If you've had the vegan donuts at places like Donut Friend or Donatsu in LA, or Glam Doll in Minneapolis, expect similar quality at Dottie's. 

Also, Dottie's is way better than famous (but mediocre) places like Voodoo Donuts, Mighty-O and Dun-well in Portland, Seattle and NYC, respectively.

Hot Oatmeal with Brown Sugar and Walnuts......5 Stars

Toasted Everything Bagel  ................................ 5 Stars

Hot Coffee ......................................................... 2 Stars

Intangibles (Facility, staff, atmosphere) ............ 4 Stars

Cumulative Score .............................................. 4 Stars

I liked Garden of Eatin, had a favorable first impression, and certainly would not hesitate to return when in the area.

Like getting a Philly Cheese Steak Sandwich so greasy the paper bag becomes translucent and you can feel your arteries clogging, the Liberty Bell is a must-see for those visiting the Philadelphia area. Located near downtown and a short walk from our hotel, Miss Sarit and I walked to The Liberty Bell to take in the sweet sounds of freedom (at least for wealthy white land-owners of the time - but let's not get caught on semantics.) 

Encased in a beautiful (albeit small) enclosure, the Liberty Bell stands with all her might at the epicenter of this beautiful park. With posters, pictures and quotes on the wall it is a sight not to be taken lightly. Take in history with this landmark.
In the same park is also the remnants of the slave-quarters of President Washington, as well as a beautifully done TV-setup showing reenactments from colonial times sharing history and personal accounts. There are several TV's spread around a small area with benches to sit and listen or lay down on and gaze at the stars while American history is shared in the background.

All-in-all, a beautiful park with a lot of history packed into it. Independence Center is located across the street, along with museums nearby. Make it a day trip and you're sure to "ring" in a good time!

Is it fair to rate a place strictly on your first visit and one slice of pizza? Maybe not, but if you go to Paulie's for no other reason, go for the General Tso pizza. 

My friend was raving about it so of course we had to give it a shot. At the time of our arrival, there wasn't any General Tso slices available to pop in the oven and serve. Despite the fact that our group didn't want to buy an entire pie, they happily made one up and let us buy individual slices. 

So the General Tso slice is unique and combines two of my loves: pizza and Chinese food. Just an aside, I could only imagine the amazingness of this combo as cold leftovers. Back to the slice, it was large, and covered with General Tso's chicken, extra sauce, broccoli and pepper flakes. It was sweet, spicy, carby and cheesy. Now that's a synergy!

I loved every unique bite of my experience. I could go back to Paulie's to sample their other menu options but they certainly have a show stopper with the General Tso.

I was torn between rating PF Changs 3 or 4 stars.  The food is good, but it's a far cry from real Chinese food. The service varies depending on the server... We've had great service, horrible service, and a lot in-between. The cocktails are horribly overpriced so my husband and I normally just order a pot of hot tea, which is incredible. Since we live close by we typically grab our food to-go in the curbside pick up area.

This P.F. Changs is located at the Westshore mall so it's always packed. I'd highly recommend making dinner reservations on Friday and Saturday nights because it can be at least a 30 to 45 minute wait after 7pm. The bathroom is poorly located next to the bar so you have to fight a crowd every time you want to go to the bathroom.

As I mentioned earlier, the food is tasty; just not authentic. The lettuce wraps and dumplings are two of my favorite appetizers on the menu. There are many mild and spicy dishes on the menu depending on your spice preferences. We enjoy a lot of spice so we usually order the spicy green beans and the Cho's Spicy Chicken. The honey glazed chicken and the wonton soup are also quite good.

I have never ordered dessert here, but I have tried a handful of the cocktails and they are usually too sweet and fruity for my taste. Be cautious of ordering cocktails that aren't listed on the menu. The bartenders have disappointed me on numerous occasions with poorly made Dirty Martinis and Cosmos.

All in all PF Changs is nothing special, but the food is consistent so you are guaranteed a decent meal.

My friends and I stopped in here when we need a quick bite for lunch when we were wandering the French Quarter. Food and service are decent, nothing special.

Convenient location and okay food - I feel like some dishes are a hit or miss. Gumbo is a miss, the poboy was okay, but the burgers are pretty good, as are the fries.

Another awesome find in Chester County! The owner is so nice and very knowledgeable about the wines they have. My mom and I came here with a friend and we each did a wine flight. You can mix types of wine and you get 4 total, which equals about a glass and a half of wine. My favorite that I tried was the pinot grigio. We ended up getting a bottle of it and a bottle of the Reserve Cab Sav (which is not available in flights). I loved the Cab Sav too! 

The owner gave us some free samples of their wine slushie and OMG were they amazing! They were the perfect treat and not too sweet. I definitely want to come back and get them again.

Overall, this is a super fun and cozy winery! They do different events on the weekends, so be sure to check out their website!

While North is no longer owned by Fox Restaurant Concepts, they've maintained their formula/consistency, which is what I always appreciated  about  FRC restaurants. Knowing what to expect is nice, even for takeout the food is a-ok. I still have not dined inside of a restaurant but continue to support with takeout. We ordered online on a Saturday evening, the wait was about 35 minutes. They did not offer curbside pickup but I am sure it they would gladly accommodate the request. Our order included the calamari, meatballs, braised  short rib with polenta and the branzino. The meatballs and braised short rib are always good. The branzino was a touch overcooked but still good. And the calamar I think it best enjoyed at the establishment since it's fried. 

If you are comfortable with dining in, North is open for both indoor and outdoor dining. 

They are adhering to the Pima County guidelines regarding COVID19.

I'm going to be upfront about my dislike of the parking situation in Down Town Tampa.  So when I got to the location, finding parking was hard! I ended up across the street at the parking structure for the Glazer Children's Museum, which was charging a singular priced parking due to Phantom Of the Opera going on at the Straz. 

The walk to Anise wasn't bad, the lights were in my favor, and the scenery was nice with all the Christmas lights glowing in the early evening.  What I found distasteful, was the host- a young man in his early 20's, with light brown hair- wasn't paying attention to the door, he was head down over his phone, likely texting or checking Facebook. I had to speak up to get his attention. Only then did he let me know where my party was.  

My party was that, a company Christmas party, about 25 people in attendance, drinks and appetizers provided by the venue. I have to admit, though I was a bit concerned over the offerings, I was actually quite happy with the flavours! We had curried chicken wings, curried deviled wings with lobster and vegitarian paninin.  All were delicious! I -LOVED- the deviled eggs, there was just something about them, they were TOTALLY off the chart. 

The decor is amazing! I loved the bookcases in the bar area, the hydropinic greens in the lobby and the light fixtures that hung down from the high ceilings. This place has character! I can't wait to visit again, and am hoping that Anna will be my guide next time because I have a feeling I'd be out of my league!

Hats off to the Tender with the amazing dreads, Jarod(?) Sorry if I got the name wrong. He was really warm and friendly, totally LOVED his attitude!

Pizza is good, though the sauce is a little too salty. I love salt but it was a bit much for both the pizza sauce and sauce with the meatballs. Crab pasta is good, though a smaller noodle would be better than buccatini. The taste of the meatball was not quite for me but just a taste preference I think. Overall quality of the food is good. Food was ready quickly. This was a delivery order.

Great little spot in International Mall.  It's like many Bar Louies.  There are drink specials as well as food specials between the hours of 4-7 pm on weekdays. Our server was friendly and made sure we had everything!

Surely the best deli in the clearwater area. They specialize in breakfast and deli food. You will always get a big portion, and the quality is always tops. I used to work across us 19 from lenny's and ate there about once a week. It was always very consistently good. I drop in now when i am in town.

This service station is right at the New Jersey/Delaware border.  Forget about going to TCBY if it's too early in the morning; it was closed when we were there.

The guy filling our gas tank was also kind enough to clean our windshield.  The ladies room line got backed up but I apparently missed the worst of it.  Sadly, gas was a little cheaper in Delaware but for a service area it was all right.

Tootsie's Orchid Lounge is located at the Nashville Airport, Concourse C, near Gate C-7. 

My husband and I tried to get dinner here last night. The sign upon entering says to seat yourself. So we came in around 6:45 pm. We purposely picked a table that a server had briefly cleaned so that she can see that we have sat down. 

After waiting more than 15 minutes and trying to get a server's attention, we decided to leave. Being ignored for so long definitely does not deserve our serve and would never dine here. I am not surprised that the overall rating for this business is 2.5 stars, with over 250 reviews (At the time of this review). 

Don't waste your time and try to find something else (for some reason, most of the eateries at this airport is 2.5 stars and below. Only a handful have a 3 star rating but having seen too may above that).

A fun stop for a time, but, overall, less that I expected. I had hoped it would have the feel of a cultural festival, but that seems to be a thing of the past. It is now little more than a regular fair with a few unique venders, like the strawberry shortcake. Otherwise, expect the same ole hotdog stands and "turkey legs". The concert schedule looks like a deal though!

I've been to the different Park Ave coffee's and I do like this one. This one reminds me when I'm running, "you can make it, just one more mile, Park Ave is on the next street." Yeah. Yeah.  Call me Ms. Coffee Addict but I run for those lattes. Hmmm. I wonder if they have a shirt for that yet? The turtle lattes and raspberry mocha (keep in mind I loathe raspberry as well) these lattes are a coffee lovers dream. They are not overly frothy and cooled down like some other places I've been. The whole coffee is hot, almost needs to cool down a minute and remind me to savor every moment of that deliciousness. 


On to the next secret. Gooey Butter Cake. 75 flavors worth! Eeek! I think I can't even make 75 meals. So my secret is when people want a taste of home, I come here and mail them gooey butter cake. Sure I know how to make it, I am local after all, but mine does not taste like Park Ave. have fun enjoying your millions of combinations. I hope your not like my husband who can't decide quickly at all.

You can find Il Bel Lago at 11631 Olive Blvd, St Louis, MO 63141 in a suburb called Creve Coeur almost due West of St Louis as the crow flies. The restaurant is in a protruding part of a shopping center almost hidden by lit trees (not sure if it's due to the holidays or if they're always lit). Entrance is to the right as you go around the corner and parking is in the lot out front. The interior is upscale with an elegance usually reserved for fine dining, but the atmosphere had a younger, frenetic feel that I found quite refreshing. Apparently the restaurant's original name was Bellagio but there was some dispute with the owner's of the hotel that ended in a name change - lucky for me the food retained it's very good quality.

This is perhaps the best meal I've had throughout several visits to St Louis on business the last few years. Sue T (a friend and coworker) and  her husband Carl graciously took me to Il Bel Lago and introduced me to the chef, Frank Giovanni. Afterwards we were sent a nice "combo" style appetizer that featured a delicious lobster ravioli and a  veal tortellini with shitake mushrooms and peas. The flavors were both unusual and offered great contrast to each other.

As I always do, I tried some of the local craft brews rather than going with wine - in this case the Schlafly's Pale Ale won the lottery as my initial try - honestly I didn't care for it much, preferring the hoppy bitterness of an IPA - this was a bit too lagerish to me with a bit of an oily mouth-feel that didn't work for me. I also ordered a Caesar salad that had an anchovy nicely sandwiched in parmesan crustini. For my second brew I switched to a standby Ranger IPA.

For dinner I ordered the Spaghetti Gamberi, Cozze & Vongole - homemade spaghetti (almost an angel hair) with gulf shrimp, fresh mussels and clams in a white wine light san marzano sauce. This was quite delicious with a good amount of fresh garlic that provided little bursts of flavors as you eat the pasta and sauce. Also, the shrimp were quite large and filling - absolutely love this dish.

We forwent the dessert but ended up with these little chocolate and creme (with some type of booze) parfaits that were quite good. Not on the menu, I think they called them chocolate cows or something similar?

Service at Il Bel Lago is quite exceptional - our server was knowledgeable, courteous and quick to deliver. We couldn't have asked for or expected better. Thank you Sue and Carl for introducing me to this place - I hope to be back!

My husband & I walked over here for lunch. They had a hefty line and the cafe (inside & outside) was almost full, but seating had opened up pretty quick. I ordered a vegetarian sandwich (they were were out of veggie burgers) and a toasted marshmallow coffee slush. I understand the bit of a rush with getting orders in, so I didn't expect much from customer service (at the counter). The lady, who helped me was not super nice, but all others I encountered were great. My husband sat and enjoyed our drink and sandwich, which were both delicious. I love cafes like this, where there is hustle and bustle. Some would love to sit here and just people watch, too. There were many coffee options and decent food options. If I'm in the area again, I'd like to be back, especially to try the veggie burger.

My first time visiting Goldilocks Jewelry, and found it such a positive experience I thought I should write a review. Although they didn't have what I was looking for they certainly snd a fabulous collection of specialty pieces, very nice. There staff is extremely easy going and just a pleasure to be around. I'll certainly be back when looking for jewelry in the future

People know me for my high heels and penchant for expensive cookies. I like being just so fresh, so clean, and generally take my sangria on a Southern California patio with my ladies in maxi dresses and wedges. Don't hate. It's just how I work hard to roll. 

But, I grew up in the mountains and camping with my family. I can build a fire, I can build a fort, I can shoot a gun, and I'll bet I could chop some wood if I absolutely had to. If the apocalypse was upon us, you'd want my tasty cast iron pan skills all up in your shelter making mean ass cowboy stew. Just sayin. 

The girlfriends and I decide that we should take a break from our status quo and start a new tradition: Gourmet Camping once a year- and so, the 2014 crew of myself, The Polish Princess of P.O.P., The Master Chef Selary and The Sexy School Teacher took a trip up North for a couple days. We packed the car all by ourselves too. (Keep reading for actual campsite info-hey, story telling is a camping tradition right?) 

The menu? Gourmet indeed.
