From fire kissed meatballs wrapped in onions over bacon cheese hash followed by marshmallows stuffed with rolos toasted into cookie smores to crepes with blueberries and paninis with mozzarella and spinach: WE dines like the queens of the forest. We made campfire pie oven biscuits and corn on the cob with roasted tri tip stew and mini apple pies. 

Our tent was a virtual nest-we made micheladas and sangria and played card games by lantern light. We checked in Saturday and stayed till Monday AM. 

It all sounds lovely, and it was-except for a few things: 

The drought: Not the campsites fault at all-but it was dry as a bone out there. The allure of the creeks and rivers caused us to make a reservation there-but they were at least a 5 mile drive to find, a disappointing turn of events. The campsite this dry is very dirty and dusty. Any other time and with more moisture it would have been perfect because of the big oak trees and shade and greenery-but California just isn't surviving this situation very well. 

Expensive ass firewood. 6 dollars for a small bundle. They don't want you bringing in outside wood-so its a racket. 

There was a water pump, but no showers, bathrooms were okay. We could smell them though so EW.  About 20 miles inland from Santa Barbara so it was in the 80's and pretty humid-I dont suggest it at all for summer months. 

On the weekends it's full of peeps, but spaced out. Sunday night caused the grounds to empty and left us alone with just a few other campers. You can still have fires here as of July 2014-but I expect them to ban them shorty with how dry and crispy it is out there. 

Site # 25 is a good location that's mostly shaded and near the water, but downwind from the bathrooms. This campground is the 3rd one along Paradise Road and more spacious than the others. 

#gourcamping2014 ended up being just ok, kinda like this campground. Next year we might just pitch a tent next to the patio here in SD and call it good-but who knows? The adventure bug might bite me again. Just like the mosquitoes from this weekend. 

PS: those who know me IRL, ask me about the harrowing night #2 titled "Almost Dying In The Forest"

This store is huge Crate & Barrel and as a result has pretty much everything in stock, so there is no waiting around for shipments and orders. They have all kinds of patio, other furniture and home decorator items. 

This store also offers assistance of "Wedding Registry" experts and store experts in home furnishing and design though best to schedule an appointment in advance for such services. 

The quality of the goods seemed to me to be pretty good but they darn well should be for the prices being asked. In fact if I have one sort of sore point with Crate & Barrel in general it is with their prices. I certainly don't mind paying top dollar, but when I do I expect a top quality and a great design bang for my buck, and though their goods are of very high quality, nothing either super special in quality or of a design I would expect for the price.

This is a brand new Residence Inn by Marriott. It's located across the street from the beach and is beautifully decorated with a full kitchen all of the usual amenities. Pets are welcome at this hotel. 

The Residence Inn is connected to a SpringHill Suites with a shared lobby in the middle of both resorts. The breakfast area is spacious and offers about 8 waffle makers. This speeds up the morning process for those who love a do it yourself experience. The staff is amazing and readily available.

Who is going to turn down a hot fresh pretzel, plus for the cost of them? The answer is nobody.

Was doing some early morning shopping around 9th St decided to stop in and grab a strand. 3 best friends baked together for a buck,couple shot of some spicy mustard to the scene and we got a deal. They open at midnight and close 12 pm. I guess my 8 am craving for a pretzel for breakfast wasn't a bad option with the surrounding flavors. 3 fresh for a dollar, again how can you go wrong!

I am a pretzel fan not the biggest, but I do know some of my friends who are.

Good stuff coming out of this establishment , and you won't break the bank on this!

In true foody fashion, after I went and grubbed out on a Village Whiskey foie gras burger, I had to come here and get ... another burger. Because why? Because I LOVE Shake Shack!

I didn't even know they had Shake Shack in Philly, so when I passed by it after dinner I had to go in. I dragged my entire entourage of now 8 people to come with me, and also convinced them to have burgers because they had never tried it before even though they live in Philly.

O.M.G.

Sorry but I love Shake Shack. I think it's way better than In n' Out (I might get massively flamed for this ... ) and I loved it here with no exceptions. Just talking about it makes me miss it :(!

I went before lunch. Not necessarily a good idea. I went for specific things, yet I walked every aisle to see what was there . . . and found other things on sale.

It's not a bad idea to walk the aisles and find the clearance section.

AND, there's a bakery "We Made Too Much" section.

Produce is fabulous. Deli is immense. Salad bar is full.

Great hike with great views! Best part of it all is that it's dog friendly! Parking is terrible. You definitely want to be parked inside the white line to avoid a ticket. If you're ON the line, you're at risk for a ticket. The roads can be a little narrow so I understand the strictness around this.

You get a little everything: streaming water, great views of the mountains, lots of shade, tons of picture opportunities, and a meadow of flowers! We didn't quite make it up to the meadows because we were short on time. 

Great place and easy to find. There's no signal up here so plan accordingly.

Now here is a no-nonsense neighborhood bar that you might find impossible to leave once you plant your a$$ on a stool. 

You've gotta ring the door bell to be let in. This makes you feel kind of special, doesn't it? They like me, they really like me...

The drinks are cheap. The bartender is nice. The regulars will probably buy you a drink at some point. You can watch people play drunk darts from a safe enough distance. 

Bam! It's dawn...

Don't say I didn't warn you.

Tell Santa that I've been bad this year...

Our lazy Sunday brought us to KK, which I am a big fan. I knew I was getting myself into some trouble when I ordered a dozen donuts, but they are just so damn good. Glazed donuts, as well as cream filled soccer balls footballs, and chocolate glazed. They were very friendly and surprisingly not busy. Why didn't I get 2 dozen???

I found these guys outside of the Peabody opera house on the evening when I took Kid 1 to the Widespread Panic concert. They had a bit of a line so we walked around and came back when the line had diminished. As a result, we had our food within about four minutes of ordering.

I am glad that we gave them a shot! We both had asiago bagels with cream cheese. This is a New York style bagel food truck so the bagels were steamed instead of toasted. The results of steaming instead of toasting a bagel is that you wind up with a bit more chewy and flavorful delivery. The cheese on top does not scorch at all and remains in place. The cream cheese almost liquefies from the heat and seems to melt into the bagel a bit. End result...a great snack!

Why 4 stars?  Because this gym is awesome!!

   ---   ---   ---

Powerhouse was already a pretty good sized gym when I started there, but after its recent expansion, it is now ENORMOUS!  

I had no complaints about Powerhouse, but I did recently leave the gym after over 2 years of being a member.  I went to Harbour Island Athletic Club because of a group discount program that I was offered.  I have a feeling I will return to Powerhouse one day though, because I thoroughly enjoyed my time there.

All of the equipment is in great shape and mostly kept up nicely.  The staff is very friendly and helpful.  There is a kitchen/smoothie shop inside to make it impossible to avoid eating healthy.  There is a giant staircase in the middle of the gym, representing the famous Santa Monica stairs in California.  There are many other features that you can check out on their website, but I never did the group workouts or classes so I can't say much about them.

Jeff Trager aka The Knot Doctor has an office located in the back of the gym, which a huge bonus for me because I have been going to him for years now.  Jeff is the man for any kind of injury that could possibly require a standard or deep tissue massage.  He is ART (Active Release Technique) certified and is the team therapist for the Yankees when they are in town for spring training or playing the Rays.  I recommend him to everyone that has any physical ailment, because he has fixed several problems for me over the years.

If you live or work in the Downtown/Channelside/Ybor/South Tampa area, I highly recommend Powerhouse Gym.
Great spring festival concert series featuring local artists and great food.

Tucson, AZ (Rita Ranch): fantastic!

Awesome service and delicious food. We were seated immediately, arriving just before HH ended. When my House Margarita arrived in blended form instead of "over the rocks", the serving staff apologized, removed the erroneous drink, and promptly returned with my proper order, a simple but well composed drink where I could taste the tequila not in slushy form. Complimentary, house made chips, light and crispy, and salsa with a bit of kick, made for a great  start to our meal.

FOOD
Green Chili Pork Burrito w/rice & beans
Shredded Chicken Taco w/ rice & beans
Off menu Chorizo con Huevo 
Shredded Beef Chimichanga w/rice & beans

I was surprised at seeing just a 3.5 star rating. This was our friends' favorite Mexican restaurant. We had to agree it was good. The rice was savory and moist. The refried beans were creamy and topped with melted cheese. Hubby thoroughly enjoyed his breakfast for dinner, his chorizo con huevo (sausage with eggs). My chimichanga shell was crispy and the generous shredded beef filling very tender and flavorful. Both our friends' taco and burrito did not disappoint. Our server stopped by at least three times after our food arrived to see how we were doing, and even brought out a second bowl of chips. The water glasses and iced tea were continually refilled.There is a bar and Happy Hour (2-5pm every day) is also served in the dining room. Two separate non-gender specific restrooms. Excellent service, delicious food, located in a strip mall with a small lot, accessed from southbound Houghton, south of Rita. Would love to come back to try more of their menu.

In a few words: community staple, affordable, fresh, and healthy.

Lovely outdoor produce market in Webster Groves. We live in the city and therefore go pretty far out of our way to shop here. We typically go at the beginning of every week, either Monday or Tuesday, and it's never busy! Better yet, they are open 7 days a week and all year round. I imagine it's a little more crowded on Saturday and Sunday.

Their produce is local whenever possible. So, when you buy here, you're supporting big and small local farms... who wouldn't want to be a part of that? They are across the street from Webster University, so they provide affordable and healthy options for students, staff, and visitors. 

Not only do they have fresh produce, but depending on the season, they have different plants, flowers, and herbs. During the holiday season they have live trees you can take home to adorn your living room!

On top of all of these offerings and availability, the staff is incredibly friendly and helpful. They always know where their food comes from and are readily willing to share that information. Rogers has been open for 40 years and counting. They have the perfect thing going to keep their regulars and grow their business.

This place is ok and really more like a 2.5 star to me.  I've only ever ended up here after Wednesday's on the Square.  It is one of the few remaining real down and dirty dives in this area as most of the other places have gotten much nicer from all the Warehouse District development.  The crowd often seems a bit older than many of the other bars in this part of town.  I've never eaten here or known anybody local that did and I'm a pretty adventurous eater but I have no plans on eating here unless I hear a lot of great reviews from folks I know.

So first off, the Theater I was in did not have reclining chairs. I'm not sure if all of their movie rooms are like that or just some. 
 
It was kind of nice to be in a normal seat

I really like this location. It's easy to find. They have a lot of movies playing here at all times. Lately I have been feeling very frustrated with AMC. They tend to keep movies for shorter periods or times or not offer the movie at all. I found that this location had a lot of movies that the other places, closer to me... didn't have anymore. 

They could offer more staff at the snack lines. I couldn't get popcorn because I was already running late to the show. 

Not that I drink anymore, but I had to step over to the bar for napkins to clean the rain off of my glasses. There was no bartender in sight. 

Bathrooms could be cleaner.
Fresh baked goods and delicious snacks. Located on a busy intersection this grocery store has lots of parking. This Fresh Market has friendly staff, I recommend visiting.
Best apparatus in SB for the kids to play - just ask my 6 yr old.

Located directly across the Bird Refuge, Stella Mare's is this sort of shabby-chic--meets-a-greenhouse-meets-your-rich-aunt's-Santa-Barbara-living-room restaurant.

I got the grilled salmon club sandwich (with Canadian bacon, avocado, tomato, and a lemon horseradish aioli). It didn't blow my mind, but it was pretty tasty. The Tuesday & Sunday bistro menu sounds pretty enticing, and at $29 for a starter, entree, dessert, and a drink, it's a steal!

Warning: parking's a motherlover, and the place can be a bit awkward to locate.

I got the burger with the egg minus the bacon and it was a good burger but it didn't knock me out.  The service was a bit slow and I would've tried one of their soups and dessert too but things went so slow I ran out of time to order anything else.  Hopefully they are just still breaking things in and service speed will increase with experience.  The menu has too many pork things for my taste but they do have some tempting offerings and I look forward to returning for some of the other options.

Why O why do I do this to myself? My visits to Coyote Ugly (now numbering 3) make me th butt of some cosmic joke. Usually, I enter due to some weather-related event.  My first visit to a CU was in Atlanta. It was 95 degrees with 70 percent humidity. I would've entered a lava flow to cool off at that point. My second visit, I was walking through the streets of Chicago with an old friend navigating a near blizzard. We noted the flashing beer sign and took heed. It wasn't until we saw the questionable body shots that we'd realized we'd entered a CU. That brings me to the Fourth of July and the monsoon of 2009. As attractive as the fireworks were, looking up into a downpour, well, there's an old legend that turkeys are so dumb that they stare into the sky during a storm and die drowning.  Gobble, gobble.

So, in a move that still doesn't demonstrate we're much smarter than commercial livestock, we headed for the nearest bar.  That bar? Coyote Ugly. I should've known what to expect.  I'd forgotten what to expect.

In short, you get a long bar that tries desperately to capture the vibe of the movie. Does it manage to do so?  Not quite. It truly is hard to manufacture a party, even if you've got all the beer in there world.  You might get a party; you might get a bunch of angry drunks. Crap shoot really. That night, it was a bunch of sad, wet, drunken refugees seeking escape from the rain. The bar girls did their bar dance as per the movie only to be met with angry, rain-soaked eyes. As the rain subsided and the beer sank in, revelers tried their level best to catch Hepatitis by attempting body shots to the sound of frat boys yelling "Woooo!," but it all seemed so "The Accused" to me that I drew my wife closer and warily steered clear of any pinball machines. Finally, the rain slowed to a drizzle and we took our opportunity to leave. Yes, I'm old. Yes, I'm a hipster douchebag. Yes, I'm not their target demographic. And sadly, yes, most likely due to global climate change, I'll probably find myself in a Coyote Ugly some time in the forseeable future.

Two stars.

Updated shoutout to Craft, Ty, Brooke and the entire amazing staff for keeping this place filled with greatness and the service on point and COVID safe.

Let's face it. During this strange time, booze has played an important role in preserving sanity. I didn't do a lot of drinking, but I kept on collecting, and Craft made that incredibly efficient and easy with the great updates to their online store. On any given day you could visit the site and see most of the current inventory, add it to your cart, check out and then head to the store for pickup. Initially it seemed they did it simply because they weren't allowing the public inside, but they kept it up and it has remained current and a great way to shop here.

This is no small feat. Keeping an e-commerce site up is a lot of work, but Craft did it to keep us all hydrated.

During these strange times they have also been incredibly helpful with special requests. I've recently been interested in Irish whiskey and really wanted a bottle of the new Redbreast small batch cask strength, and Ty was able to get it and make sure I had a chance to get one. 

Lastly, the non alcoholic options are also fantastic. Picking up dinner nearby and needed some soda, so I figured I'd pop in, check out the whiskey selection and grab em! We picked up some great booch, cane sugar cola, and a sparkling martinelli's!

All perfect. Grateful for this store!

Well, I can knock this one off my Reno Bucket List. Came in on a busy Saturday night and luckily, my friends thought enough ahead to call and make reservations for us.  We were seated immediately, so I had time to see the old school charm of this place in all its fake bunch of grape glory. But one cannot judge a restaurant on its decorations alone!  

I couldn't decide on what to order, so I opted for the combination meatballs and ravioli with spaghetti ($15). The marinara sauce was thick and salty and just a bit tart and oh so good.  This is not your off the shelf jarred sweet Ragu sauce. I didn't think I could finish it, but I did (sadly) and NO REGRETS.

We enjoyed people watching the bar (lots of regulars, it seems) and the mix of friends and family gathering. But the cutest thing was seeing a high school couple have dinner in all their prom finery, holding hands and being all lovey dovey.  Oh, young love!  If the parking lot is full, park across the street and don't get run over.

The owners went on some insane rampage and fired all the long time staff in this once great joint.  The burger seems to have really slipped in quality and the meat portion has gotten smaller.  Everybody that knew what they were doing seems to be gone so the once fantastic burger seems to have died with the departing of the long term staff.  Another great thing that just ain't there no more :(

You all know Rosa J. loves her coffee.  The Nashville musician cousin recommended "Crema," out of many local coffee destinations.  

"Crema" is located near the Ascend Amphitheater, where the Tennessee Titans play.  When our group arrived at the Sunday morning at around 10am, this place was PACKED.  "Crema" has its own parking lot, beautifully-decorated outdoor patio, and comfortable indoor seating.  I was truly impressed by this wonderful piece of real estate and definitely looking forward to trying the coffee made by their in-house roasted beans.  

Since hubby and I were planning on getting back to Chicago as early as we could, we had our drinks to-go.  The staff seemed to know how to deal with the crowd; the team worked quite efficiently together.  One of the baristas was exclusively responsible for making the pour-over, while others shared other tasks to ensure all the orders were fulfilled in a timely fashion.  

By the way, they have an extensive pour-over menu.  Unfortunately I didn't think I had much time to wait for the coffee (10-15 min).  

I, therefore, opted for the iced Cuban, latte with sweetened condensed milk.  Unless you absolutely reject anything sweetened in a beverage, give this one a try because the sweetness was very subtle and sophisticated.  

Hubby, on the other hand, had the "coffee soda."  It essentially is carbonated coffee, mixed with Demerara sugar, and topped with orange peel.  I wouldn't say it was particularly tasty; it was rather interesting since it had an unexplainable "bitterness" when I had the first sip.  It was similar to drinking iced black coffee with a "punch."  

I could easily see why "Crema" is a popular hangout joint for the locals and visitors.  I also gave this place a high praise and hopefully will make it back at some point.

We loved our visit. This is a cool gourmet butcher shop and eatery with bigtime sandwiches, charcuterie, and other specialties. House made pork rinds. 

Nice decor. Comfy bar seating and some tables. High quality meats. The charcuterie plate is served on wood and is gorgeous. Very Instragrammable and tasty.

Friendly peeps. Go whole hog.
3 stars because this is the original and it is an OK place to stop for a beer. The food is pretty mediocre in my opinion. I just never liked anything on the menu.

Elbow Room is a nice spot along the Cultural Trail off the hustle and bustle of Mass Ave and downtown. It has a nice patio for seating in the warmer months and the place hosts many random events to get guests to enjoy the bar area throughout the week. 

Both times I've been here, service is great and friendly, but the wait time is so so so long. They're attentive and get you what you need, but it takes so long for them to come back. Our food (a salad and a veggie burger) took much longer than a normal time. 

I can't say I'd recommend this place to our-of-towners but it's a good place to stop by for a normal, average beer or bar food dinner experience.

Stopped in here to grab some things for a friend's house and we walked out empty handed even though we had quite a large list of things that we could have bought.  Selection and staff were lacking.  We ended up going to the other Home Depot location across town and had a far better experience.
Amazing tacos! Wonderful happy hour! $1.00 tacos 4pm - 6pm. A must try, even better than Lily's! Fast, friendly service. Perfect addition to Milpas St! Yum! Go get some!

Whether it was the old storefront on South Street, the Bainbridge Street location, or its new home on the starting point of East Passyunk; Philly A.I.D.S Thrift has always been one hell of a store. But its current location finally gives it the space to truly showcase their overall vision as a whole. And they do it with a creative gusto in their displays and amazing outdoor toy tree!

They still give to the good cause of funding A.I.D.S research. And they still give you some killer deals in the process, especially if its for clothing and books. But now you can scope out their furniture, electronics, media room, kitchenware, and then some without having to search through a tiny crowded area or go across the street; making the good deals even more obtainable. And they somehow manage to hook up even more sales while providing even more random and functional merchandise.

I admit it... I'm a bit of a South Tampa snob.  I like nice things and I don't venture out of my South Tampa bubble as much as I should.

The Citrus Park mall is really, really nice!  (Turns out International Plaza is not the only nice mall in Tampa!) The mall is clean, beautiful, has tons of great high-end and low-end stores, has a great food court and restaurants, and they have a movie theater.  This is what Westshore Plaza should strive to be!

If you haven't been to Citrus Park Town Center check it out for a nice surprise!

I love both Well Coffeehouse locations, but I think I like the downtown spot a tad better. More spaces to sit and stronger wifi. 

I got a cold brew and went to work on my laptop. The cold brew was good, but tasted watered down like it was maybe a day or two old? They do offer a handful of food options and those festive holiday focused drinks right now! 

This venue is great for working, but it does get loud in here with all the conversations and the in-house music. Need silence, They have a sound proof working booth with a stool and laptop shelf if you need to hop on the phone. I wanted to try it, but it was occupied during my visit. 

The parking here is awesome! There's a huge garage    right behind the venue with a ton of free parking with an on duty security guard.

I could eat one of these salads every few days. Crushed Red makes me want to make better salads at home.  The salads are the shining star at Crushed Red.  Flatbreads could be better.  

Ordering at Crushed Red takes work.  First flatbread orders are taken if you are getting one. After you place a flatbread order you walk to the salad station.  The mini salad is a lot more filling than it looks.  If you are getting a flatbread, appetizer, or soup...only get a mini salad.  If you are eating the salad as your meal, go for the regular.  The salad choppers will build you a salad of your dreams...just tell them what you want.  I always ask for my dressing on the side.  I love ordering the Create Your Own Salad which comes with four toppings.    

Then you go sit down...Parmsean Cheese?  Roasted Garlic?  Red Pepper Flakes?  Jump up and walk towards the front door.  You will see a small station with these items and small cups.

Super fast, ultra-casual.  Quality ingredients.  On-line ordering now available.

I've been to Absolutli Goosed a few times before for apps and drinks but today Yelp's School of Booze drug me through the door.

It was a great time with fellow Elites and Robin our personal mixologist and owner of AG.  We experimented with 3 delicious drinks; Elite Status (in honor of the Elites) which was a lightly sweet, citrusy mix consisting of Gin & Moscato.  Second we concocted The Kentucky Hug (my fav) and I'm not even a Bourbon fan but this was superb!  I love Merlot mixing fresh Cherries, Simle Syrup and Bourbon made this drink similar to an adult Capri Sun (less sugary though) .  Lastly, we sipped a traditional Sangria.  Delicious but more of a heavy taste with Dry Red Wine, Ginger Ale and Brandy.

This was a great afternoon lesson; can't wait to get Goosed again.

What a fun little cafe! I was meeting a friend for brunch on a Saturday morning and this is the spot we settled on. 

Our server was great, fun and friendly. I had the eggs florentine and bourbon milk punch. Super yummy and so filling. I didn't need to eat again for hours. 

Love the decor and that they have a full bar. Great spot!

Had an amazing experience last week with Big Shark. 

I was ensuring that Julia R and I's bicycles were ready for spring and noticed Julia's bike needed a wheel replaced and a quick tune up. 

We called ahead and they were pleasant told us to drop it by and gave us a price range based on what we were telling them was wrong with it. 

A half hour later we dropped it off, they said they'd have it ready later in the day. They did! They called, we went back and picked it up only a couple hours later and the bike was as good as new. Ready for riding! 

Affordable, quick, communicative team here. Appreciated the help!

My sister and I wandered over to Falls Taproom for an after dinner drink on Friday night. The downstairs bar was packed but we grabbed two newly opened seats at the bar upstairs. I love the dark wood and old timey light bulbs. Didn't really love/understand the TVs with black and white movies, which were on silent. I say sports or nothing! 

The cocktail menu is interesting and I was immediately drawn to the hot apple cider with rum. My sister opted for another boozy concoction but she switched over to the apple cider for her second round. I loved the cracked clove on top; it made the drink very fragrant. This is the perfect beverage for a chilly fall night. 

Our bartender was nice and we enjoyed chatting with him. We're already talking about our next visit!

We had to pass the bar chock full of Tammy The Bartender's "band of merry men" to get to the vacant hostess podium at the end of the bar and wait for someone to seat us.   They were drunken and loud.  Awkward.

Because of the noise from the bar, we opted for a seat in the small side room.  The restaurants decor and food are old school.  Dark rooms, white table cloths, a couple of big dusty metal knights and an empty fireplace were the primary features in our dining area.

The menu is old school, pricey, rich, and meat heavy.  I don't mind paying $25+ for food if it is special, but  it wasn't. 

We split a number of items.  The shrimp scampi was basically two shrimp on pasta with bland cream sauce. Not a traditional scampi presentation.  The crab cakes were decent, but also served on the pasta with the boring, rich cream sauce.  

We ordered the meat flight special ($30).  It was decent, but rich and overpriced.  The twice baked potato was old and nasty.  We finished with the recommended bread pudding, which was apple and peach soup with a few soggy bread chunks floating in the middle.  Overall, the experience wasn't good.  The food was rich and overpriced, the bar noise was obnoxious, and I left feeling sick from something I ate.  

Positives were that the entrees include salad/soup and sides and our waitress was very nice and split the food for us without charging or being asked to.  

Soulards needs a menu and restaurant makeover and they need to put the bar in its own room if they plan to keep the band of merry men around.

I couldn't take the debauchery of bourbon street anymore. The women, the beer, the loud music. 

Not that I didn't like it. It's just too much of a good thing. 

I needed a place to adjust. A place to give a different taste. That's where Irvin Mayfield's came in.

Here there were well made cocktails, smooth jazz music and classy burlesque for my pleasure. A nice changeup to what I was being exposed to on Bourbon Street all weekend. 

Not sure if you need to be a guest, I however am like a ninja and walked right in. (That or anyone can just come in) After that I approached the Jazz Playhouse and was instructed to finish my beverage before coming in. I complied and stepped on in. 

Very elegant setting. Came on a Friday, which is when they have burlesque to my understanding. Drinks were fairly priced, a bit more than some other spots but that's the whole point. 

If you're walking down Bourbon and need a taste of something different, make a stop here.

First time sitting in the bar area..

We were able to get our favorite server/bartender Heather.

First time ordering off the lounge menu..

Calamari steak-totally delish.. loved the nice cream sauce-

Combo flatbread- pepperoni and olives very good- but I like my crust crispier..

Shrimp cocktail- yum yum!

Dessert- sundae.. totally worth it..

You can also sit at the dining area and ask for the lounge menu..

Some friends and I had a pretty awesome Sunday Funday at The Industry yesterday. I was quite happy to be reunited with the Ghost of Mary, one of my favorite spin-offs of a Bloody Mary that I had long missed since the closing of Swift Half. After several of those, our table decided it was time to share the Mummer's Punch. The serving suggestion is for 4-6 people, and we had three with two latecomers. There was more than enough for everyone. 

Two people at our table were at The Industry long enough for brunch and dinner. I heard good things about brunch but can only report on dinner. The burger with bacon was good, not great. I'm not going out of my way for it, but it is a decent option. The pickle mayo (which I asked for on the side) provided a nice dipper for the fries. A lot of the menu consists of items for the more adventurous palate (sweetbreads, pig ears, bone marrow, lamb neck, etc.). I am most definitely not in that category but there were still plenty of things to choose from. I'm interested in trying the porchetta sandwich and the fried green tomatoes.

Our servers were great and very attentive throughout our long stay. The music selection was awesome (although the Internet jukebox provided for some say in the matter - not complaining at all, just an observation). I'm looking forward to my next visit.

On opening weekend, a certain amount of confusion and back-up should be expected. My boyfriend and I heard the news that entry was delayed by a couple hours. We were bummed, but accepting of the fact that we would be able to receive free tickets to attend at a later date. Since we were in the area anyway, we decided to walk over just to see if anything had changed from the earlier reports. Luckily, we picked the right time because we were able to get in only a half hour after our original appointment time. While we waited, a glass of wine and some live jazz helped pass the time. 

Once inside the collection, it was clear that we wouldn't be able to take everything in during the designated hour. But what we did see was absolutely incredible. And I'm pretty sure my buzz from the wine (and okay, the beers we had at a bar nearby before that) added to our enjoyment. We'll definitely return once the initial excitement wears off so that we can enjoy the works with less of a crowd. But in the meantime, a walk around the gorgeous grounds (that are actually still in-process) isn't out of the question.

I visited here upon seeing it on DDD (diners, drive-in, and dives) on Food Network. I don't always follow the Food Network trail, but I remembered this restaurant in particular was in Nashville, and we were headed to Nashville for the Fourth of July holiday weekend sooooo why not give it a try? After having Jamaican food in Athens, GA at Kelly's Jamaican Foods---I've been addicted to that jerk chicken.

Jamaicaway food is good, but not amazing. It's a bit overpriced in my opinion. I got the jerk chicken which was NOT spicy but was moist for the white meat. Cabbage lacked flavor. And the corn bread was extremely dry. It was good to dip in the jerk chicken sauce though. I did try the Johnny roll and wish I had ordered that over the cornbread. 

Butttttt I gotta stay true to my stomach. If you are truly looking for good jerk chicken that's spicy and full of flavor, bomb dot comb cabbage, and amazing cornbread---next time you are in GEORGIA try visiting Kelly's Jamaican Foods. YOU WONT REGRET IT. Jamiacaway is no comparison.

Sometimes a memorable meal can only be accurately described by resorting to poetry.

Therefore, I present you with a haiku, entitled: "So close, yet so far (Bibou)"

Charlotte: Faire la bise
Pierre: Pieds de porc au foie
Me: Forgot my wine!

[For those of you who have forgotten your high school French:

Faire la bise -- The French custom of greating by exchanging air kisses on the cheeks (can be either 1, 2, or 3 cheeks, depending on which region of France you are in).  If you are a regular, Charlotte will do this, so you had better practice beforehand (2 kisses)!

Pieds de porc au foie -- One of Chef Pierre's signature dishes, pig trotters stuffed with foie gras, which is about as French as you can get]

For my previous, slightly more in-depth but less poetic reviews of Bibou, click below...

Really unique place off the beaten path, where you can indulge while watching the food you eat being created through the large glass windows looking into the baking zone! 
Super exciting to watch and fun for the whole family! 
There is a cooking classroom in the back so take a class on making pizza's, I did and it was awesome!

We must have gone to this TJ's about 10 times during our weekend stay in Tucson. We were in an AirBnB in the Catalina Foothills, and made this our go-to for breakfasts and hiking snacks before heading out to Saguaro National Park. 

I've been in dozens of Trader Joe's' in my life, and this is easily one of the nicest. Great folks running the place, plenty of food in stock, and a airy, spacious layout so you're not constantly running into other shoppers. 

Parking is decent, but a little crowded, but the location of this store can't be beat. Love it!

Having been to New Orleans many times I try and search out a new spot on each subsequent visit.

This past weekend we chose Boucherie. I had read once that this was one of Anthony Bourdain's favorite NOLA restaurants, and from there decided to research further. Chef Nathanial Zimet previously started out with a truck he called The Que Crawl. And just like some of our most ambitious and creative young chefs/restaurateurs here in Southern California, he worked his way to a unique brick and mortar place of his own where he could better assemble a team to help with his vision and passion.

Unlike SoCal, Boucherie, like many other great NOLA restos is housed, well, in an actual house and not some random strip mall. Not only was the ambiance warm and inviting, so was the host and our waitress, and every other staff member that we encountered. 

Boudin Balls were mentioned in several other reviews, so after the refreshing amuse-bouche we requested an order. Loved the contrast in textures, with the fried crispy outer and soft slightly spicy inner of the mixture of pork and rice. They came with a tasty homemade garlic aioli sauce on the side for dipping. 

My entrée of choice was what was called Jerk Chicken. I have been to Jamaica twice and have had it several times here in the Lower 50, and this did not taste as though it had any traditional jerk seasoning. Semantics schemantics! Once my brain got over the fact that what I was tasting was unlike what I had before, twas a non-issue. Whatever seasoning that was used resulted in possibly the best chicken recipe in memory. Not only tantalizing to my taste buds, but so juicy and mouth watering. Will remember this for a long long time. Included alongside was a 'cheesy arepa, plantains, & wilted greens.'

We shared some wonderful collard greens that had grit fries resting atop, that we agreed were the best greens also in memory. 

Definitely worth the drive, or Uber fare, if you are staying in The Quarter, can't recommend highly enough. Now added to my NOLA must hit list for future trips to this incredible culinary city.

Pagano's has the worst Cheesesteak in Philly! I don't know how it got such a great reputation. Why is it so awful you ask? Well let me break it down for you. They use a very cheap grade of meat and when they cook it, they chop it up so fine that it becomes pulverised till it's like the consistency of baby food. It's chopped and grilled to death! Pagno's gives you a lot of meat-which is what the budget-minded consumer loves, hence the reputation. But again it's a cheap grade of meat so I'm definitely not feeling it. Then they use a regular Amoroso roll! And any Philly sandwich aficionado will tell you that this roll will not stand up to a lot of cheap meat. The result is a sloppy, gooey, smelly hot mess. I ripped it, so skip it!

Here's the trick to having a great D'Angelo's experience:

-Sit outside on a gorgeous, sunny day (is there any other kind?)
-Order a caffeinated beverage, your choice of bread (it is a bakery after all), and a side of Nutella (oh, yes).
-Bring a crossword or sudoku puzzle or a book.
-Enjoy.

You're welcome.

Gaetano!  Canele'!  

Gaetano was a previous yelp friend, ( you know the one with the pirate picture ) and I was fortunate enough to meet him in real life at the new year 'round farmer's market at the Piazza @Schmidt's, which is open every Saturday morning and early afternoon.
 
His nickname is Gil and he has been very busy indeed with these little bites of heaven called a canele'. Gil introduced me to these delectable treats that are golden caramelized cakes on the outside and form a rich rum custard on the inside.
 
The brass or copper fluted pans are coated with a thin layer of organic beeswax which helps to harden the outside, sort of like the topping a creme brulee would give and allows the rich custard to form its base within the center of the cake. This magical confection dates back hundreds of years from the Bordeaux region of France.
 
Made from milk, eggs, butter, flour, rum, homemade vanilla, rum ( did I say that again ), sugar and a bit of orange zest, the custard batter is baked in a mold, giving the canelé a caramelized crust and custard like center.
 
The Market Day Canele' makes them right here in Philadelphia when you can not get to Parisian patisseries or the Bordeaux region of France. They sell them at La Colombe at Rittenhouse, Pumpkin Market., sometimes Whole Foods on South Street has them, Clark Park Farmers Market, The Piazza and at Headhouse beginning in May. Folks can order them by contacting Gil@MarketDayCanele.com.   

My caneles' never made it home, but I can not wait to buy many more of these bite sized treasures to enjoy with an espresso, a cold glass of milk, a good wine or a glass of champagne. A gastronomical delight.  I want a canele' or three right now!

I'm always a fan of World of Beer and this location is no exception. This specific World of Beer location is much more upscale than all of the other locations I have visited. We enjoyed our drinks on the main floor since it was too cold to drink outside, but I look forward to the opportunity to check out the outside and upstairs areas.

We ordered some snacks during our visit. The giant Bavarian pretzel was amazing. Our group unanimously agreed that the housemade beer cheese sauce was better than the stone-ground mustard sauce. Unfortunately, the wings were dry and bland and our server forgot to bring us blue cheese so the wings were cold by the time we got to enjoy them. I'd have to try a few more items from the menu before I can determine whether or not to forgo ordering food here.

Amazing beer and cocktail list, but our party was disappointed to find out many items on the menu were sold out. My brother-in-law was super stoked to try out the Cask Ale, only to find out it was sold out. When my sister ordered a second Pineapple Ginger Punch she was told that the cocktail could not be made again because they just ran out of ginger beer. When she selected a beer on draft she was told that it was sold out as well. 

TIP: If you are waiting for a flight (the airport is only a 5 minute drive from the bar) you can watch your flight status on the flat screens at WOB.

Excellent carry out experience during stage 2 of the pandemic.  Ordered on-line, which was quick and painless.  Order was ready in 30 minutes, as promised.  Pulled up out front, walked in the door just a few feet where I was greeted by two friendly, helpful staff members who immediately confirmed and retrieved my order.  After a quick 6  minute drive home, we were dining on some of the tastiest Thai food in town.  The Tom Kah soup was delicious, and spicy enough at "medium"  to make my eyes water.  The cashew chicken was perfect.  Loaded with chicken, veggies and cashews.  My date usually chooses pad see ew, but since SukhoThai doesn't offer that particular noodle dish, opted for the drunken noodles.  She gave them 3-stars.  All in all, a great meal on Covid date night!

Much better cheesesteaks in Philly than this place.  The only reason I tried it was because it was walking distance from the hotel. They don't chop up the steak like other places do, which is not an issue but I ordered a Philly with wiz and it came out like 1 minute later.  You would think this is great service but the reality is they precooked all their steak and threw it on a sandwich.  Shit was tough AF.  If you bit into a slice of that meat you pulled the whole piece out of the sandwich.  Don't waste your time. 

If it was cooked to order, maybe it would have been better, but it wasn't therefore I would look elsewhere for a cheesesteak.

I wanted something Original, Local and Authentic. I found the Columbia Restaurant in Ybor city and insisted that we go for dinner. 

I love to cook and eat Latin food, so I really looked forward to trying it their way. They have in fact been open since 1905, with the recipes influenced by Cuban, Spanish, European, etc. I loved the stories behind the dishes in the menu. 

The Sangia is a must, the only question is which one to get. We went with the suggestion by our bartender and ordered the Red Sangria made from Imported wine, fruit and brandy. It's got a kick to it, but smooth enough to keep drinking. 

I was told by several people and saw in several reviews to try the 1905 salad. We ordered a side salad and split it. It was pretty big. The salad is pretty damn good and left us thinking why was it so damn good, was it the dressing or the olives, the cheese? I need the recipe. 

We ordered a Cubano to split, which was HUGE. It was very good and served with plantain chips. The bread was sweet, yet toasted and it was very filling.

We also ordered the Gambas Al Ajo which were these huge shrimp sautéed in garlic and chiles and served in a clay dish. This was served with fresh hot Cuban bread and butter. 

Although we only ordered a small salad, one sandwich and a tapa plate, we were stuffed. I loved the restaurant, the food, the service and would most definitely come back. 

Places like this need to stay around, so that newer generations can appreciate the Original, Local and Authentic food and establishments  that built Ybor City and Tampa Bay.

I'm not into bars since I don't drink, but I had a reunion with my cousin who now lives in New York, and an acquaintance from Reno a few weeks ago. We used to come here way back when it used to be called VISIONS. It's been 20 years since we've moved out of Reno. Time flies! They have updated the club, and they now have a patio in the back. I didn't like gay bars when I was younger, and I still don't like them now that I am older. I just find them very depressing.

I was just happy to find a little cozy BBQ joint called Voodoo, the food must be voodoo-licious!  I ordered everything off their menu, I was on vacation and deep in the South of Nawlins.  From chicken to ribs, everything fell off the bone.  The gumbo complimented the brisket.  Your choice of sweetened iced tea, help yourself.  Being Asian, I wasn't used to the sweet tea stuff, my mama would slap me if I added sugar to her hot tea LOL!  At the same time, I was overwhelmed with all the different foods and down to earth people.  I finally experienced Southern Hospitality, and they had football playing on every TV.  Luckily, the SF 49ers were on before the Saints that day!

If you're as old as I am you know the movie Rocky.  If you're not as old as me you would know Rocky starred as that old main guy from the Expendables.  

Anyway one of the best parts of this classic movie is when Rocky is training and he ends up running up a large set of stairs and puts his hands up while a panoramic view of the Philadelphia skyline shows in the back with this inspirational music.

So this is the place made famous by Rocky who happens to have a statue just around the corner by the way... This is the Philadelphia Museum of Art and faces towards city hall along Ben Franklin Parkway and towards Logan Square.

You will always see people coming here and taking photos with their arms in the air and in case you didn't know why, now you know.  

This place is a wonderful place to get a photo of the skyline of Philadelphia also by the way and at the other end of this road that leads towards city hall is a JFK park where the "Love" sign is that is also good for a photo opportunity looking towards the museum.

"Oh my God, we're so happy for you!!"

This is what they said to us when we decided to order the December pie for dessert... and they genuinely meant it.  They were actually happy that our night was about to be made SO much better by ordering this pie.

In short, Love & Honey is true to their name.  Delicious food served with a lot of love, and some honey.

The fried chicken was outrageously good.  Crisp, well seasoned skin, and moist on the inside.  The cornbread was superb as well.  And the pie, well I already covered that but it was gone so fast that there was no time for a picture.

Best fried chicken in Philly hands down.

I had a good 4 star and a lousy 2 star experience at the Old Nelson inside 30th Street Station (used to be a Saxby Coffee a few years ago).

The first time I cam I bought packaged goods (A cup of Haagen Dazs, actually) - paid and left.  No problem.  It was a 4 star day and nice to see the wide variety of products.

But TODAY I decided to order a breakfast sandwich.

FAIL.

For $2.49 (You order at the counter - she writes it on a colored post-it note and then you go pay a la manual Wawa) I chose egg & cheese on a bagel.  Sounds simple, right?

So they make it (and I swear I saw a microwave was involved and I immediately knew this would not be pretty), wrap it, bag it and I march off to my office.

5 minutes later I unwrap this steming hot MESS of wax paper (microwaved-glued to the bagel).  I spent a good 2 minutes trying to pick off pieces of soggy wax paper from the bagel.

Threw half out - it was unsalvageable.

Ate the egg and cheese insides with a kinife and fork - eggs were nuked and horrible.

NEVER again for an egg sandwich - but yes for a quick stop for "packaged" goods - and they have an expansive cold beverage selection.

Cashier and counter folks were friendly - but please, take heed - NO MORE NUKING the egg sammies, OK?

The magical lady working in the herbs department gave me magical herbs (stinging nettle & quercetin) that made my allergies go completely away. I haven't been breathing this well since I was a little tiny Aimee.

I AM SO HAPPY. 

The staff here is attentive, and as I know from personal experience, can change your life. All you sniffers and sneezers, get yourselves to the magic herb lady right away.

What a name box of Cubans, sounds like it might be a cigar store. But it's not. This place is a hidden hidden hidden g e m. Best Cuban sandwich in my current memory. And with all the places I go who knows about my memory. But I'm sure this is a top-level you got to try it you got to go there Cuban sandwich. Now first in order to find this place you drive down the street and it's a little tough. It's hidden inside a convenience store behind the gas station with the little green circle I think BP kind of gas station. Sign is on the big standard out front beneath the gas station stuff and as you walk up to the convenience store there's a smaller Circle that says box of Cubans on the right. Now that you know how to find it get out there and find it and have a great meal. Now back to our meal. Cuban sandwich at all the right attributes that a pure Cuban sandwich should have, including a Cuban family making it. Apparently this running a restaurant has been a dream and a passion for this man and his wife. They are living the dream, and we can participate and be part of that dream by coming on in and having another sandwich or their black beans or my gosh the green sauce that they made to put on the pork I got a little taste of it oh my God it was great. Now I also had an empanada and I have had a lot of empanadas around the country and this one was Far and Away the best. Finally something where the pastry on the empanadas was thin and balanced with the meat, unlike some of the ones I've had with quarter inch thick pastry. This place is where you need to go for lunch in fact I would say call ahead take 10 sandwiches back for the crew at work this is the way to have a meeting and a great lunch. These people are so nice and they're cooking is so loving get on down there and have a good time I did. And I'm going back next time I'm in town. I sure hope it's soon. I can meet up when you live 2000 miles away

Amazing drinks without the pretentious hipster vibe. Two thumbs up.

I live in Florida, because I am an old person at heart. I may be in my late 20s, but I don't like going to places where it is hip to be seen. However, I still want the offerings of a trendy bar. I want the creative drinks and the modern décor. I know, I'm a walking contradiction. Well, luckily Repeal 18 gets me. First of all, who knew that this bar existed in the heart of Westchase? A high end clothing store, or a coffee shop would make more sense (and those both exist in the same complex). You know this bar has to hold its own to survive here. There is no hopping to another bar. You come here and you stay here.

There is a lot to stay here for. As I mentioned earlier, the drinks are very creative. They have a Mexican Martini that is absolutely delicious. It has the right amount of kick. Also very good is their Pisco Sour. I don't think you can go wrong ordering off their cocktail menu. We came here at around 5:30 p.m. on a Saturday. Although that would be super early for a normal bar, it wasn't for here. There was a good amount of people already milling around. 

There's a dart board and a pool table. There is also outdoor and indoor seating. 

I really like this place. It is definitely a keeper.

In the age of Net Flix there's not too many reasons to rent at stores any more. But TLA always manages to give you rare reasons. their obscure themed racks are the perfect reason to walk around and give in to the cinema gods.

I also got to give it up to the staff. They're definitely the friendliest bunch of film snobs around. Definitely appreciate them for tolerating my random film choices, and having the decency to save laughing over my absolutely horrible choices for when I walk out the door. I might not always agree with their personal choices (I don't always agree with mine either) but the majority of times their dead on and know what they're talking about.

And if weren't for TLA things like the Philly Film Fest wouldn't be as fun. They work hard every year to bring in the most diverse selection from all over the globe, with plenty of debut directors, documentaries, and crazy horror. the end result might not always be the best. but just like the store it always celebrates the true diversity that is cinema. and this TLA is my personal favorite.

El Bar is a cool dive with plenty of endless possibilities. I mean what other bar out there lets you pick up a happy meal that includes 2 hot dogs, a PBR pounder, and a toy for 5 bucks?

The PBR and shot specials flow endlessly throughout this chill spot that lies under the El. But they also have a rotating Beer of the Month specials and a variety of drinks that go well above the average dive. 

But the best part of the El Bar is the eclectic offerings that you'll come across on any given night. Its small stage showcases plenty of random punk rock shows throughout the night. Foo Truck has started showing up on special nightly occasions giving you a chance to enjoy delicious yet healthy wraps and veggie offerings. With a table top Mrs. Pac Man, random arcade games, and ample -PINBALL ALERT- it provides some good drunken video game moments. And you'll find plenty of subtle perks like a decent happy hour, and a cool outdoor courtyard.

So when it comes down to it, El Bar is clearly a dive that gives you more to love!

I first tried this place five years ago and did not love my experience, but recently saw the great reviews and updated business name, so decided to try again.  I love that I could make my appointment online for the same day, and even pick what technician I wanted.

I made an appointment with Heather for both a pedicure and gel manicure.  When I arrived, I was told that someone else would do my pedicure, which turned out fine because while I was sat with Nancy at my toes, Heather started the gel removal process on my fingernails.

Heather was very friendly and chatty, and I could tell that she had a lot of regular clients in her salon, as she greeted many people by name.  Nancy did a great job on my toes, and I was pleased with the job Heather did on my nails.  Prices were comparable to other salons in the area, and I will definitely return here.

LIKES & DISLIKES @ RUSTY LION:

Likes-
1. Great roof top bar
2. $1 Mimosas @ Sunday Brunch

Dislikes-
1. My Margarita Pizza was almost the WORST pizza I have ever had. Everyone elses food that I saw-looked and smelled amazing. But my pizza... it tasted like it was from the freezer section of the grocery store and was totally undercooked. When I picked up the slice, all the toppings fell off and i had to eat it like a pile of slop. Just disgusting. We ordered 2 of these pizzas for 4 of us to share. Both were made the same way and both were gross. If you come here... take my advice and DON'T ORDER THE PIZZA!

I have to give Entergy some credit. My heat went out again on Sunday. And after the HVAC guy came out, he determined that there was something wrong with my gas feed. I called Entergy on a Sunday afternoon and the gas guy was at my house within 30 minutes. They diagnosed the issue together and my gas meter was swapped out and I have heat again.

PLUS I chatted with him about my gas issues on the other side of my rental and that problem should be resolved later this week.

Yay.

Yikes... As far as food goes this Wendy's is pretty consistent with most others but the location can feel pretty sketchy at times.

We usually come to this shopping centre (Northgate) for the Asian Market but man have there been a lot of times that police have been arresting someone in the parking lot and one time the person walking next to me had their purse snatched.

So I'm not sure this is where I would choose to "eat-in" but for running through the drive-thru for a frosty for the chitlins or a cup of chilli with extra hot-sauce, I'll be back.

This is a wonderfully beautiful park along the Hillsborough River in Temple Terrace. Gorgeous. Cypress trees grow in the river and along the shore. There's a boat launch and wooden dock. Lovely areas of shade and a playground. There are also a lovely boardwalk path along the shore, tennis courts and a gazebo.

There is a cross commemorating the one erected by Spanish explorers in the area in the 1750s. A historical marker is nearby.

There was pink goop at the base of the cypress trees along the shore and I found out they are apple snail egg deposits. There were also muscovy ducks, ibis, and some other birds in the area including some pretty "friendly" one that I think must get fed..

This is a terrific Tampa gem and great place to escape and relax or go for a walk.

I have never slept so well in my life. Ever since we had our Temp Pur Pedic - Cloud Select Queen size mattress delivered, I have experienced the most sound sleep. I think my dreams have even improved sleeping on this mattress. 

Our last mattress was bought only 3 1/2 years ago from one of those stores that sells closeouts, "as is". We thought we were getting a good deal. When actually we were taken. 
It did not take long before the mattress felt and looked like two Sumo Wrestlers had either slept or wrestled on it regularly. We suffered as long as we could. We had to break down and get a new mattress for the one that had broken down. 

We did our research and knew we wanted to go Temp Pur Pedic. It was Columbus Day weekend and the majority of the mattress stores were having their annual sale. In the mail we received a sales brochure for Mattress Firm and looked at the addresses and headed out. Our salesperson Sean was great, he listened to our wants and needs and recommended a couple different mattresses. He was not high pressure and knew when to step away so we could talk about our decision.  When he stepped back into the conversation, he let us know which ones were in stock and those that we'd have to wait for. We selected our mattress, added the protective mattress cover and applied for the 24 month same as cash. 

One week later our new mattress is delivered. When the young men making the delivery arrived I jokingly said, "Hey, you're not the guys on TV'. Without missing a beat, the spokesman replied, "No, we're better looking". He was right. The delivery guys were clean-cut, polite and professional. I was shocked how fast they brought the new one in, unwrapped it and had it positioned on our platform frame. We had them take our old mattress away to be recycled. They quickly wrapped the old one in the plastic wrapping from the new one with ease and went out the door. For those that are concerned, yes they put their little booties on at the door. 

We spoke with the customer service department at Temp Pur Pedic before shopping to find our who they recommend as a retailer and were informed that Mattress Firm is one of their "Elite" retailers.  This Elite Yelper recommends this Elite Temp Pur Pedic retailer.

Who on earth packs so many clothes on a rack with wooden hangers that you can't even look at them. 

It's a nice large store with great lighting. Enough employees to help you find things. But you can barely pull any item off the rack because so much is jammed onto each rack. Maybe I got lucky and a new shipment was unpacked and I had a lot to choose from. There was a lot of nice things. Sizes are odd, I needed a sale girl to help me convert a six to their 26. They even had jeans for $7. 

When I have more time I'll have to go back and really check out the place better

While I'm in the loop for Thai Food, I'm usually pretty loyal to the one around the corner. But tonight - I wanted to try something different. I also really wanted drunken noodles - the wide flat noodles, in which the other establish does not have. 

Pros:
1) Interior is more traditional and surprisingly pretty nice inside.
2) Won like a best STL Thai award in 2014!!
3) Drunken noodles is spot on and not greasy

Cons:
1) Tom Yum Soup. It's good, but it's has a lot of fish sauce. If you are not use to heavy fish sauce and a red Tom Yum with a more sour than sweet. This won't be for you. I prefer my Tom Yum from around the corner.
2) Pricing is slightly (but only very slightly more expensive than the others)

However, I am a believer that there are other amazing thai options in the area. I will def. eat in here and take advantage of the full menu next time!

For all you faithful Yelp friends who read my reviews, you know that I am a lover of high quality stationery, paper, pen and ink shops like this.  So like a moth to a flame, I was drawn into this beautiful shop in downtown New Orleans which also happens to be on one of my favorite streets in the French Quarter.

Let me start by saying that the owners are wonderful people.  This becomes almost immediately apparent upon entering.
They are welcoming, helpful and kind. 
Their store is irresistable and so lovely with eye-catching items everywhere you look.  There are beautiful writing implements, inks and ink wells, exquisite European stationery, wrapping papers, calligraphy sets, gorgeously bound journals and the like.

As I browsed around, I suddenly espied the sealing wax and seals.  Oh my.  Years ago when I was in junior high and high school in NYC, the ancient practice of affixing one's seal into a pool of colored wax on the outside of envelopes had been resurrected.
Seals and sealing wax were readily found in shops everywhere.
 
I still have my original initial seal that I used back then.  Nary an envelope left my hand for years without my seal across the flap.

The use of seals on letters and documents can be traced back to the Old Testament and I've always thought it a lovely way to close an envelope with a personal logo, totem or initial. 

Here, I found an array of Italian-made seals along with an assortment of richly colored waxes.  I fell hard once again.   
All things considered, given the things that I love and that interest me, I should have been born a few hundred years ago. 

Both the owners showed me some new sealing techniques which include using both wax and ink stamps.  I walked out with two new seals, an assortment of inks and quality wax sticks and I'm all set now to emblazon the envelopes on my soon to be written out Christmas cards and envelopes.   

If you're into beautiful pens and good inks as my husband is, this too is your place.
There is a wide variety from which to choose of both.
There are many things here that would make wonderful and unique gifts.

If you can't get to Royal Street in New Orleans any time soon, check out the website.
This is a small, local shop and any questions you might have I'm certain would be readily answered via phone call as well.

Stopping in this pretty shop can't help but remind us of the art and beauty of writing by hand and creating something lovely with quality materials.

My first ever Sonic experience...

A faux modern drive-in of sorts!? brilliant. Let us all forget the food is still dangerously unhealthy because someone brings it OUT to the car!

Happy hour without booze? Only if your slushies and shakes ROCK. And they do, so half off at Happy Hour. nice. 

My toaster, perfect. My companions ate a myriad of chili cheese dogs with random accompaniments. All eaten in our car, on a breezy evening in Louisiana...

Not bad. Not bad at all...

I've seen a number of reviews from folks who have held events at the Artsgarden and yes, they do have some legitimate criticisms about restrooms and access to a space suspended above the intersection of Washington and Illinois Streets.

But my review is based upon the main purpose of the the Artsgarden:  To showcase the local artists through a series of public performances and visual art exhibitions.  It also serves as a "cultural Concierge" providing information about that arts and cultural activities in the area, making it possible for visitors to take in the events when time and money allow it.

The Artsgarden is run by the Arts Council of Indianapolis.  There is a lunchtime music series several times each week called "Garden Jams".  Local professional musicians are scheduled to perform for the lunch hour Noon to 1 pm for no charge to the public.  So, whether you are just passing through the facility from one building to another or have grabbed a lunch and decided to take a seat, there is frequently music/entertainment available.  The Arts Council website has a list of performance dates and talent schedule for the month.

Each month, there is also a new visual exhibit, not limited to professionals, so you may find works from emerging artists, students, and  different cultural and social organizations.

And I would be remiss if I didn't mention this amazing physical structure soaring seven stories into the downtown sky.  Lots of glass makes excellent viewing for a birds eye view of downtown.  It's one of my favorite buildings in the area.

Next time you are downtown, especially for lunch, why not check out the Artsgarden for a cool place to check out the arts of Indy!

Review #484

It's okay. A great place to host birthday parties. The laser tag room is a bit small but nicely lit. The games are good and there's a two lane kids bowling area. Food was as expected for a game room. Once inconvenient aspect was having to go to the desk to purchase game cards. Other places have machines to purchase and refill cards which cuts down having to wait in line at the counter. It's okay and we'll probably be back.

I'm officially obsessed. I joined this gym a few weeks ago after trying them out during Yelp's In It to Thin It. My old gym (Weston Fitness, see review update) had lost it's luster and began charging extra for my favourite class, so we parted ways after 2 years of having a really good thing going. It felt serious.

Anyways, I never think about Weston anymore because Unite has totally swept me off my feet. The class format keeps things moving and helps you challenge yourself in manageable increments. I'm still sore after every class and constantly looking for more time in my schedule where I can squeeze in another class here and there. I can't get enough. I've done classes with Bill and Juliet and they are both incredible. I always end up dripping sweat and I'm not much of a sweaty person so that really takes a lot of effort for me. They are positive and motivational and great teachers.

Can't speak to the locker facilities much because I always go home beforehand to change and then go back home afterward, but they have lockers available with locks so I don't have to schlep my padlock anymore. Love that.

alright, let me give it to you this way... i LOVE steak! i LOVE meat, in general. so i was totally looking forward to bob's steak house as it is known as one of the best steak joints in tucson. my personal opinion, it's definitely not the best steak i have ever had in my life. my hubby and i still talk about how disappointed we are. we paid the same as other high end steak houses yet left feeling just not satisfied. 

overall, staff were nice. very courteous! food came out at a great pace. would i come back? no, as i have personally had better flavorful steak in my lifetime. i am however very thankful that they allowed us to bring our daughter with us. they also allowed us to be seated earlier than our reservation.

ordered:
*Lobster tail-tasted a bit fishy to me. Definitely had an after taste after every bite. 
*Cream corn- not very sweet. There really wasn't much flavor to it. I felt like I needed to add something to it to give it that omph factor. 
*Sautéed mushrooms- huge mushroom pieces. 
*Kids chicken tenders- came with a drink a side. Which we got fruits. 
*crab cakes- fell apart very easily. Not the typical crab cake I've had in the past. This was the best tasting item I've tried here. 
*cote de beouf bone in 22oz-$55 made perfectly medium. Lacked in flavor. I ended up dipping it in ketchup to make it go down. a good piece of seasoned meat should not need me to add any additional flavoring to it.

Free bread- holy cow us this thing humongous! It's like where do I even begin! Now eating it would result in one of the following: it won't look cool anymore, guilt as I ate way too much bread, guilt I didn't finish it and now they're gonna toss it and I am being wasteful. Either way a lose lose situation for me. 

bob, you are definitely a solid 3 stars. thanks for your hospitality! 

Tips:
* free self parking. 
*reservations accepted. 
*cash and credit card accepted 
*they have high chairs. 
*they have kids menu.
*restroom is available.
*dimmed lighting.
*full bar is available. 
*located on the golf course.

Just so you know, in case you want to stalk me.  
You will find me here getting crazy on some AUCE snow crab legs every Tuesday night.  It is not attractive.  In fact, it is downright primal.

963nd different cheesesteak in the last four years. The Fellas were guest eating, Mike, Adam and Kevin.  Kevin flew all the way from California to have a cheesesteak with me.  Mike insisted on going to LaSpada's and getting the Philly Special.  I still don't know why.  I think it is because the slabs of meat can hold a lot of ketchup.  I thought my cheesesteak was average at best.  I think it needed more of everything and to be mixed together better.

Bright, clean & fairly new Save On.

Save On has a couple perks that keep me popping in like Daryl's Deal of the Week - think high end loss leader and often an excellent cut of meat from the butcher block.

Another lovely thing about Save On is that they will give kiddos a free piece of fruit in lieu of the standard bakery cookie - love this!

They have an Save On Rewards cats for deals and points accumulation that thankfully the cashier can lookup with your phone number once registered (one less card to carry around and lose).

You need to know your price points when shopping here - there are deals to be had but many, many items are $1, $2, or even $3 more than what you find at Superstore. 

The washrooms at this location are located up front next to customer service - and I had to chuckle because the ladies was long like a bowling lane & there was a change table for wee ones :-)

Two thumbs up :-)

PS If you're on the hut for Halo Top, you'll find it here.

Still my favorite poke bowl in town! Why? The fish just tastes fresher. The vibe is brighter. The portions are hefty. The staff is friendly. The prices are just right! Oh, and it's just so damn delicious!

We came in for Reno Restaurant Week, and it was such a treat for so many reasons! First, I got to support one of my favorite local businesses. Second, Reno Restaurabt Week have me the perfect excuse to get out of my South Reno bubble and visit. Last,the deal was tough to pas on... $9 build your own regular sized bowls. That's exactly what I order, only a few dollars cheaper, so how could I resist. Well, I didn't, so I added a scoop of protein which made it the usual $12, but I'm not complaining at all because this was exactly what I'd been craving.

I could tell you all of what went into my bowl, but instead I need to make sure you know just how good their sauces are at Pola. Combining these with the fresh cut seafood is what makes these bowls next level. 

I usually stick to their traditional sesame shoyu, but Pola is always changing and they introduced a Yuzu Pepper sauce that was about the best thing I've had in a while. It made everything pop and it'll be my new go to every time.

Next... Crispy Garlic Chili Sauce - ooo la la. This goes on their spicy tuna, which isn't that chopped up stuff you get elsewhere. The sauce is like hot oil you find at Chinese restaurants, and a little goes a long way. I would add this to the sesame shoyu for kick but always add it on top of my bowl, along with spicy mayo to finish it off!

The possibilities are endless at Pola, and just love it! No photos because I was so excited to eat it!

This is for the food items near the Delta gates...I had a really good sausage and red beans and rice.  Delicious!    Getting through security was easy, everyone was very friendly.  Only knock is that the stand for the taxis isn't really well marked due to construction they are doing right now, but otherwise, this was an easy place to get in and out of New Orleans.   If USA Today were to review it, they'd probably say "We like it!"

I'm so glad that I got to visit this place a few days ago when I was passing through town! At lunch time on a Tuesday I managed to find a meter just on the next block. 

Upon entering I discovered that you place your order at the counter and they call your number when it comes out. There were only a few people in front of me, so the pressure was on to figure out what I needed to try. Luckily the guy at the counter was super helpful. In the end I went for a Burnt Cheeseburger with a Duck Patty and added bacon and a side of half Sweet Tots half Waffle Fries. 

Burger - Going with the Duck Patty was a solid choice! It definitely had that rich, buttery flavor that duck should. And I thought the burnt cheese was unique and had a deliciously sharp flavor. The bacon was thick cut and the pickles were obviously house made and fresh. Honestly, I'd probably just get this burger again on my next visit!

Tots and Fries - The tots had a mild sweetness, but you really do need a dipping sauce for them. The waffle fries had the perfect crunch and would be great on their own, but I loved dipping them in ranch. 

I also appreciated that this place doesn't up-charge you for everything. No extra charge for the fancy patty and no extra charge for any sauces. This place is great!!

Miller's is a good neighborhood stand by in an area where good dining options are few & far between.  Everything I have ever eaten here has been very good & very reasonable.  Great beer specials too (althought I wouldn't particularly recommend the mixed drinks).
I really like sitting outside...even if it is chilly they keep it nice & warm out there.  Solid spot!

We might come in a wrong time. It was almost 2:30pm, and they are closed at 3pm. The waitress seemed already ready to go. She was not really at tentative. 
Since it was our first time here. We didn't know that we needed to order at the counter and pour water by ourselves. She seemed like we don't serve that way, you should know. Anyways. I will just pour myself water.

The dish came in super super slow. We ordered an omelete with veggies and a french toast. I guess there might just be one chef working in the kitchen. And we were just starving. The omelet was ok, maybe shoulda ordered the lobster one. plate was huge though.

Maybe just because we came in a wrong time, we didn't enjoy that much, that's why I gave it 3 stars.

When I first caught eye of Kung Fu Hoagies elaborately colored dragon cart my interest was beyond piqued. But I waited for the perfect time to savor a bite from their all vegetarian menu, and after I picked up one of their vegetarian pork banh mi sandwiches I was whisked away to divine providence.

For a tiny food cart Kung Fu delivers a swift karate kick of options. from veggie pork banh mi, to ramen with tofu meatballs, and more. and they even have it nailed down to sides like dried fruits or vegetarian beef jerky. Next to the fabled tofu hoagie from Fu-Wah their veggie pork was the best vegetarian sandwich that I ever savored. their banh mi ingredients are nailed to to the vibrant and traditional, and they definitely manage to cater to your preferred level of spiciness.

Another plus is how well they travel between different areas of Philly. So whether you catch their Dragon cart across from B2 on Passyunk, find them in Clark Park during a West Philly farmers market, or other you best take note.

Ok, I took off a star because it is so darned expensive! Fortunately they have a deal where you can get an appetizer/soup/salad, an entree, and a glass of wine for $35 which isn't bad for the quality of food and service.

It's a small restaurant with a bar on the right as you enter, fine linens with fresh flowers and an open kitchen which is quite rare in fine dining joints. Our server Valerie was attentive but not overbearing.  I dined with three friends and we all got the special. First we had the hot sourdough rolls which were yummy and I love real butter! Then I ordered the crab cakes (which were yummy crab without breading-see my picture) and fried mirliton-delicious! One friend ordered the chargrilled oysters which I tasted and it was yummy, and another friend ordered the scallops which she enjoyed. For my main dish I ordered the tenderloin which had blue cheese on top and had shredded beef underneath. It came with snow pea pods (I think) and a potato side.it was tasty! My friends ordered the flounder and they enjoyed it. But dessert was the best with a creamy creme brûlée with whipped cream and fresh strawberries on the side-amazing! And we so had the flourless chocolate cake with strawberries and cream on the side which was good. I don't remember what kind of red wine my friends ordered but they all enjoyed it. And I liked the Pinot Grigio that I ordered as well.

It was a lovely experience and we closed the place out where they had to turn on the lights to kick us out! Hehe

Happy Dining!

Visited South Common theatres for the first time to treat myself to the new Harry Potter flick with some friends.
