I was so pissed but then I tasted the food and I swallowed...it was DELICIOUS, my mood was totally changed right after, I wasn't pissed anymore, I was so delighted with the way it tasted, and how great the food was. The salmon was really tender and just right, the eggs Benedict was perfectly cooked, and the bread under was a lightly sweet, buttered bread. it all went well, it was really good and that's the only reason this place got 4 stars, if it weren't for the food, it would gotten a 2 or 3. 

Definitely would come back, but now I know this place have horrible service, but great food. And to me, the food is worth it.

We had a splendid late-summer/early fall meal "just the gals" at T's next door (The European Side - not the Italian side).  My duck salad which contained delicious macerated cherries and a slab (yes a huge slice/slab) of honey chevre (the "gateway drug" to all soft cheeses) was perfect.

An $8 side of Brussels sprouts was large enough for 3 to share and contained more bacon than should be legal.

Mussels (Moules Frite) come with fries (Frites) and 7 different sauces to choose from.  A classic Provencale was ordered.

The booze selections are many and varied.  Pick your fave.

I'm gonna start by saying that I am NOT crafty at all, so I can't really give a review from a "crafters" point of view.

Michaels is a really cool store that has everything (or close to it) that a creative type could ever want.  Paints, beads, markers, crayons, and clay are just a few things you can get here.  What I really like about this store is, if you have a kid, you could take them in here and let them pick out a fun activity for them to do.  They sell things that you can paint and decorate, like wooden cutouts.  They have coloring books and crafts of all types.  If you get a child started with this kind of thing early, they will be creative for life.  It's also a good idea to pick up colors and crafts for a kids party or rainy days when a child needs something to do.

Michael's also carries frames and things like that.  Like I said, I'm not a person who is really into crafts, but if I were, this would be my spot.

I've been coming to Habit Burger since the early 90s in Santa Barbara. I prefer habit Over In and Out Burger and other Burger franchises that are in a similar category. Burgers are always cooked nicely and are juicy and tasty. A big reason I prefer habit over in and out is the selection of food. They have a lot more than just hamburgers cheese and French fries. They offer onion rings fries chicken sandwiches prime rib sandwiches Burgers bacon and More. If you've never tried have it definitely give it a try and I think you will like it much better than five guys or In and Out Burger.

I made the rookie mistake of not asking our server what she recommended and ended up regretting my entire meal. 

Ugh. 

I ordered the veggie burger and fries. I wasn't a fan of the consistency of the burger and my fries were burnt and crunchy (not crispy...yes there is a difference). I left more food on the plate that I actually ate and had to grab a slice of pizza when I left. 

This place is not on my list of places to return if I'm in town.

My least favorite Vietnamese place in the NOLA area so far.  They didn't bother to bring me my vegetable plate to go with my pho and they only had selections of beef pho with no chicken, seafood, or other options.  I've also heard this place is also a national chain so that seems a bit strange to me also.  They do take credit cards with a posted minimum of $10 but they allowed me to charge my $8 pho with no problems.  The service seemed a bit confused as there were two ladies that just served everybody haphazardly and then a guy from the back brought your food out to you so in all that chaos it is no wonder they forget my veggie plate.  The beef pho I had was good I just prefer other places with better ambiance, service, and more choices.

Health Mutt is a very awesome, neighborhood pet store featuring all natural pet treats and foods, along with some terrific pet toys, accessories, and grooming services for the Fido's and Fluffy's in your life. 

I am a huge lover of four-legged pets, but unfortunately I lost my favorite feline to degenerative kidney failure a while back. With my crazy travel and work schedule it's not fair for me to take on the responsibility of saving a new shelter pet, but then constantly be putting my little buddy into the kennel when I'm on the road. Instead I depend upon the generosity of my business partner to let me sit on the floor and play with his two dogs whenever we work from his house.

SIDE BAR COMMENT:  I recently purchased a Seminole Heights Unites "Fires Die - Community Lives" t-shirt to support the employees of Domani Bistro and A Modern Line furniture store, following the devastating fire which destroyed the restaurant and damaged the furniture store next door. 100% of the proceeds, after the raw cost of the garment, are donated to the employees, so this is a really good cause -- http://heightsunites.bigcartel.com/product/fires-die-community-lives-t-shirt. Earlier this week I received an email saying that the t-shirts were ready for pickup at Health Mutt in Seminole Heights. Turns out that the owner of the pet store is a big supporter of Seminole Heights' businesses, and was instrumental in creating the local team to support these two businesses and their staffs. Very cool!!!

OK, BACK TO OUR STORY:  Health Mutt sits just a few blocks east of Florida Avenue at the intersection of Hanna and Central Avenues, right in the heart of Seminole Heights. I parked out front, and wandered into the store to take a look around. My plan was to pick up my t-shirt, and also find some doggie treats for my business partner's two dogs, Izzi and Belle.

Bill likes to say that Izzi and Belle are sisters from different mothers since Izzi is a pomeranian, and Belle is a black Lab, but their personalities are like twin sisters. I'm often showered with dog love and affection the moment that I walk in his front door, and I have to play with them and give them treats before they let Bill and I get down to work.

Charlie from Health Mutt was a huge help in navigating my way through the myriad of dog treat options, and I ended up buying a box of all-natural Cloud Star "Wag more bark less" baked applewood-smoked bacon dog treats which will keep me on the good side of Izzi and Belle for the next few weeks. I also picked up some appropriately-sized Barkworthies Bully stick chew thingies which are much better than those nasty ol' rawhide chews.

While Charlie was getting my t-shirt from the back room, I had the chance to watch one of the staff bathing and grooming a few dogs, and was very impressed by her attention to the dogs and her gentle demeanor. 

The store is packed with healthy and great quality food and treats, and there were all sorts of toys, collars, harnesses, leashes, and bedding just waiting for you to take home. Super friendly people, and you can tell that they really enjoy working with pets and their owners. Great little find in the middle of Seminole Heights.

Cochon is one of those staples that you just cannot miss. This is one of the most important restaurants that serve up great New Orleans cuisine at it's finest. 

The wood-fired oysters are a must. The chili garlic butter is out of this world. These oysters are charred to perfection and have the smokey taste from the process being grilled. The garlic butter is melted throughout the oyster and is addicting!! I swear I can just pour all that butter into all my seafood platters and it'll do the job.

The alligator bites were amazing too! These were the best gator bites I've had in N.O. The texture is much tender and is fried to perfection and not that mushy breaded texture. This is crispy and golden. The dipping sauce of the chili garlic goes great too! So make sure you get two things here: Wood-fired oysters & gator bites!

THIS is why I love Yelp!! Local finds outside of the touristy places. While sating in Bywater we came across this gem. You wouldn't know it from the outside, but when you walk in you are immediately impressed by the warm decor. 

You walk straight into their beautiful wine store. They also have cheeses & meats which the manager explained can be made into a charcuterie board... YUM!

Once you walk through the store they have a HUGE patio area. Upstairs is the coolest bar! This is where we chose to spend our time. The bartender was AWESOME! She explained different drinks as well as specials, food, and local info. My husband had a gin fizz which he had never had before. He loved it!

They have weekly specials as well as entertainment. I would highly suggest a visit while visiting NOLA. I'm sure glad we did!

Ice cream in the dead of winter? Yes, it was a lot colder in Nashville than I thought it would be and I only packed t-shirts and yes I was freezing on Music Row but why not get in some ice cream, especially when it's cold? It's my version of joining the polar bear club.

The inside looks like an old school soda shop which is nice. I always wanted to see what one looked like and Mike's fits the bill, even the soda jerk mural on the wall.

Decor only goes so far though, if you come to a place that says it is an ice cream fountain you better have the goods to back it up. I got the pistachio and peanut butter in a cone. My friend for nutter butter and the raspberry cheesecake. My peanut butter scoop was a little too thick, it was really like frozen peanut butter, delicious but really heavy. However, my pistachio was dead on though I thought it was flavorful but still light.

I tried the butter butter and it was what I was looking for in the peanut butter flavor. After reading the reviews and finding it's one of their homemade flavors I know why it was so good. The raspberry cheesecake also stood out and was jealous of the choice she made.

I would normally award three stars but something stuck out to me during my visit, at the front of the store was a gentleman who obviously hadn't bought anything in a while and was disheveled looking. It was cold out and the staff and owners had it in their hearts to let this man stay out of the cold and warm up as long as their doors were open, that should stand for something.

A great place to stuck when it's pouring outside! 

Which is what happened to me, but talk about a happy accident. The staff here is super friendly and the coffee they serve is strong! This cozy hotel lobby coffee shop gives off fall European cabin vibes... or maybe it was just the pumpkins they had sitting outside? 

They also have a decent list of menu items to you're looking to snack or want a happy hour drink. Yes, they have booze! I believe they do a daily happy hour at 5 with wine and charcuterie boards. 

Definitely a repeat coffee shop for me!

I found this place when I was trying to waste time before my first "Take the Lead" latin dance party last week (feel free to check my review of that as well!).

It's located across from Clark Park, and is a perfect place to people watch.

I stopped in for a drink and decided to have an iced tea. The girl who helped me was extremely polite and even offered her opinion on the teas they had. 

I went with the raspberry tea, but they get 1 star off for not informing me that it was unsweetened.

The whole front half of the cafe is windows, so I sat by the window and people watched. It is a great little place with great service. :)

So I had taken a break from Deg Thai...not on purpose though. It was only because the stars didn't align for us to visit for a bit, but that recently came to an end.

I've always raved about how awesome this food truck is -- even during my time away. But like all things, one does start to wonder if the quality will diminish over time.

Great news...it hasn't! I've had the pleasure of catching up with the infamous green truck twice in the last few weeks. The food is still super fantastic, and served piping hot. I took a first-timer with me on one of those visits, and the super-picky eater loved it too!

It looks like they've added even more dishes to their menu, but I'm still sticking with my tofu Basil Stir Fry -- damn it's good.

It's good to see the owner, Jay, still cooking his native food. He even stopped long enough to say "hello". Plus his wife has rejoined the DT team, and she's always smiling.

Consistent and delicious food, and awesome customer service...what more could you ask for?!?

You NEED to know about their Cruel Shrimp.

It's an appetizer item on the menu.  $3.25. It says it's a single prawn with habanero paste and the menu states that it's "very hot!".

Wholly mother of god this was the hottest bite of food I have ever had.  Ever!  And I eat boiling crab xxx sauce and shiz.  I had tears flowing out of my eyes and sweat pouring out of pores I didn't even know I had.  My man tried one too and he was feelin' the fire.  We went through at least 10 napkins between the nose runnin' sweat pourin' and the tears flowin'.

Thank god they had a bitchin' beer list to choose from.  I had to pound down a few just to get rid of the heat.  We're talking maybe 20 minutes for it to finally subside.

Their beer list is awesome.  Total local hangout here with a dog friendly patio.  Their homemade chips and cheese was good.  But I will never, ever ever forget this place ... because of how hot that cruel shrimp was.  Jesus H Christ, Mother of Mary that shit is HOT.

One of the best parts of my trip to Tampa.

The sign said welcome so I walked on in. Evelyn, the Studio Manager found me a few minutes later, welcomed me and showed me around. She gave me a brief run down of the ovens and the 750 pounds of molten glass they use each week. She explained about the casts they use and the colors they add and what happens to all the broken leftovers. She even offered to show me how they "charge" the ovens, adding additional material after pieces have been made.

She was bright and energetic and friendly and capable of slinging 50 pounds sacks of chemicals easier than you'd ever suppose.

They were having an open house a couple days after I visited that the kids would have loved but sadly California to Florida is a pretty serious drive so we had to pass.

And peek behind the studio and take a look at that spectacular tree house. It was all I could do to resist running over for an inner child satisfying, up close and personal kind of a look.

A new Cambodian place is always a destination worth checking out.  And there is much about I Heart Cambodia to like.  But I was hoping to like it even more than I did. Everything started off fine. The space itself is bright and attractive and the friendly staff greets you right away. My first course of Fried Quail (kruche chean) was very tasty - especially with the fresh lime.  The main course though wasn't very impressive to me at all.  That was the well-known Cambodian dish - Prahok Ktis.  I found it on the bland side with little taste of spice.  And the dipping vegetables were okay but I like more variety.  I did improvise by changing it into a rice dish and used the various condiments provided on the table to jazz it up .... but of course in Phnom Penh they don't eat it this way. If I eat here again I will def opt for a different main course ... but I prob will first go to another Cambodian restaurant up the street from I Heart Cambodia which I really like even more.

La Familiga has been in operation since 1976. That's 40 years from 2016, math majors. Let me start by tipping my figurative hat to such success in a tough restaurant industry. 

Their 40th anniversary rollback menu and pricing was actually what drew me in for my recent visit. I had recalled enjoying my experience about a decade ago, but this restaurant is far from hip and trendy and has likely missed its way back on to my very deep "to-eat" list.

On the other hand, it is a traditionally, upscale experience. The main dining room has a nostalgic antique feel. In all honesty, so did a lot of the other clientele. I say this not as a slight but as an observation. During the course of our meal, my husband and I were discussing how odd it is that an establishment of such stature only has 87 (now 88) reviews on Yelp. The older, more classically dignified demographic may be a factor. 

The other reason for their staying power is that the food is damn good. Nothing else will keep you afloat like an exemplarily meal. 

Going off of other Yelper's recommendations, we started by picking a bottle of wine from the holy bible of vino. We ended up with a lovely Chianti that paired perfectly with our dinner. 

As millennials, we went a non-traditional approach in ordering and started with pasta dishes instead of salads. As others had mentioned the pesto gnocchi is excellent but different. I believe the difference is the potato and ricotta blend that causes the texture to be a little lighter. The pesto sauce was creamy but did not drown the dumpling blend. My husband's penne arribata was simple but exemplified what the dish should be. A little kick, some chunks of tomato and a top of fresh basil.

We decided to split two entrees: the Vitello Papa Sena (veal of the picante, mandolese and capri variety) and the Filetto all Familiga. I haven't had such tender veal cutlets in a while. Each sauce was different yet complimentary of each other. The white wine sauce paired with prosciutto and mozzarella for the mandolese was ultimately my favorite. Although the butter in picante and white wine with spinach and pepper topped with mozzarella of the capri were certainly enjoyable.  The Filetto was prepared in a wine sauce but more in a gravy styling. It put a nice Italian touch on a classic cut of steak. Of course, it was prepared to the temperature of our liking and completely on point.

Expecting a traditional dessert menu, we were a little surprised when a tray of three options (that we've had previously never heard of) were presented to us. The Zuppa Inglese (an Italian dessert layering custard and sponge cake...thanks, Wiki) was the most intriguing. Consisting of a rum soaked cake with a light, fluffy yet crisp meringue-like topping, it hit the spot with a little post-dinner sweetness.

For this particular experience, the portions seemed to match the 1976 pricing, which is not necessarily a bad thing as I walked away content versus crammed. Perhaps if we ate like it was 1976, American waists would be more in line with a healthy standard, but I digress. 

While there are a million and one new restaurants in Philadelphia that are far more trendy than La Familiga, this is the spot to go if you are looking for an upscale Italian dining experience.

Writer's note: after initially submitting this a 4 star review, I can't honestly give a reason that it shouldn't be a 5 star review. I don't typically give 5s out for infrequent visits or promotional menus, however there is absolutely no reason a star should be deducted due to my personal Yelp "rules."

Not bad at all with a really great lump crabmeat fried rixe and stir-fried shredded beef chow fun.  The sauce for the chow fun is rich and savor without being greasy in the slightest, which I really liked.  The crispy fried quail was flavorful with well-marinated meat and the lemongrass beef skewers were juicy and savory.  I'm not an expert on Cambodian cuisine authenticity but I am a huge fan of the banh cao here, which is a crepe stuffed with pork and veggies, and dipped into fish sauce.  It's definitely a must-try and the portion is huge!  The Khmer fish amok is another dish to get here: spicy, creamy, and tender pieces of marinated fish in a savory and indulgent coconut broth; it's basically a Cambodian curry and it is soooo delish!  We have yet to dine in but I always end up sopping up the last of the broth with a baguette from Ben City or mixing it with jasmine rice or lunch the next day.  Just try it.  Anyhow, the staff here are sweet and our food, perfectly packed with utensils, is always ready and waiting to be picked up after our shopping trip next door.  Definitely worth visiting next time you're grocery-shopping at Ben City.

This is probably the most affordable place to eat among all the new places that have opened on Freret St. and they have been there longer than most of the others.  They have many tasty options that are all very reasonably priced.  The only slight complaint I have about this place is along with the free chips you get some "queso" that tastes like the velveta cheese you get on Superdome nachos more than any real queso I've had (so they might do better just switching to salsa but it is free so you can't complain too much).  They also were having a half price drink special the last night I ate there so that was a GREAT deal for a Friday night.  

Their tacos are all around $3, depending on the meat selection, and you then get to add additional toppings of your choice.  At my last dinner I selected a chicken taco, shrimp taco, and fish taco (they use flounder for their fish tacos) and I was quite satisfied with the portion size (with the chicken being exceptionally generous on the toppings).  They also offer "bowls" of various combinations of taco ingredients sans tortillas and then a few additional entrees with the most enticing to me being a steak.  This is certainly not the best Mexican type food I've had (and I'm not the biggest fan of this type of food) but I would definitely go here before Superior Grill, Nacho Mama's, Taqueria Corona, Maya's, Baru, Rum House, or Felipe's.  Overall a fantastic value for some good simple food with some great drink specials.

Wow! The best of the Edley's I have had the pleasure of visiting. Their other locations are a bit more tricky with parking and the area they are in  but this one in West Nashville/Sylvan Park is perfect. I took two out of town visitors here for some food and their Tuesday night trivia. It was definitely a good spot to take people who are visiting and requesting to try barbecue. 

I ordered their special of the day which was a rib sandwich with fried pickles and cole slaw. I hope this is the special every single time I return because it was phenomenal. As with their other sandwich specials it comes with a choice of two sides, so I ordered the potato salad and green beans. Both of these sides are very tasty although I was eyeing the cornbread from my friend's plate. The food came out within 15-20 minutes of us ordering which was not too bad of a wait. 

We ate outside on their patio, which is oh so pleasant on a warm evening. We did have to find someone to clean our table off but they took care of that quickly. If you plan to do trivia you can still hear everything very clearly over the speakers even if you are seated outside. Their patio is also very doggo friendly, so we got to pet many pups sitting out there. 

Although we came in 7th place for trivia (boo!) I would rate Edley's #1 for barbecue in Nashville. We had a great time at this location and I will definitely be coming back.

I've been a sucker for Hello Kitty and kitschy Asian items since I was a child. A visit to South Korea to visit relative when I was 8 just added fuel to the fire which explains why this 31 year old woman owns a Hello Kitty bathrobe. Being an adult certainly doesn't mean that you have to be mature at all times, right?

Happy Japan is cute specialty store with new digs in the cozy Berry Hill neighborhood. I never visited their previous location was on Gallatin Road but from sheer neighborhood cred, this new location must be a total upgrade for them. Being nestled next to See Spot Eat and Pied Piper Creamery makes a lot of sense as kiddos are sure to drag their moms in here post snack and anyone who will purchase their pup gourmet baked goods is likely to give this place a while too. (I'm clearly one of those people) I loved the layout of the store which happens to be a little cottage and walked through the 4 rooms that comprise the retail area with ease and curiosity.

In the main area, I enjoyed sifting through the Asian candies, cookies, and other treats. The prices are fair especially because these goods had to be imported. One of the rooms featured Anime items along with a collection of stuffed animals and figures. Another room showcased gear for wanna-be Harajuku girls that included wigs, platform shoes, and dresses. Why do I want a blue wig now? Because. In the 4th room, various trinkets ranging from magnets or books to cooking utensils and paper goods were displayed. 

I enjoyed the store but kept thinking that there would be more? I just didn't feel inspired enough to purchase anything. I'll definitely come back to check on their inventory and for gift items.

THE  place to stay to get a balcony overlooking bourbon street and party all the time. It's all happening below you and right outside your door. If you like to get some sleep, better go somewhere else, it is non stop on bourbon street every weekend.

Shopping at Target!!! I am a TRUE fan of Target..this is a large store.
I usually go to the Super Target in Smyrna LaVerne Area, but this one is closer to my home if I cut through the Woodmont neighborhood. I love to see the large homes on my drive over to the Target and the shopping center.
There is a lot of additional shops located at the Shopping center so when I go to Target I usually stop at other stores also.
This store is large, clean with a friendly staff. The shelves are always fully stocked and the store is clean. The bathrooms are clean. I can always find what I am looking for and they always have plenty of open lanes for checking out.

I love this Target store...!!! do you ?

I absolutely love Jimmy John's. Each sub shop I've been to has always been the same, right down to the motto, "subs so fast you'll freak." It's nothing fancy and what you see is what you get. There's catchy phrases on the wall, bright neon signs, and day old bread for 50 cents. 

I can walk in, order my #3 Tuna on white, with jalapeno chips and know all is right in the world. We had a friendly conversation with the franchise owner who gave us a brief history of Jimmy John's (as if I didn't know-I am from Illinois after all) and me, my sister and my Christian sat down for what would be my first decent lunch in Reno. It's so sad that it had to a fast food place like Jimmy John's but thank goodness it always has been reliable and good to me for the last ten years. 

My sandwich was perfect to say the least. The bread was fluffy and hot, and the meat, lettuce, tomato and mayo had a consistent and even ratio. I personally like to shove jalapeno chips to my sandwiches to add a crunchy texture to my sandwiches and Jimmy John's kettle cooked chips make a perfect addition. I obsess over their sandwiches and if they had any in the Bay Area, I'd probably be their best customer in the history of Jimmy John's.

Rippy's marries 2 long bars, 2 live stages, and Barbecue without any major dysfunction. 

Downtown Nashville is an fantastic place for live music, but surprisingly there aren't just too many barbecue joints to pick from. Jack's has a prominent place on Broadway across the street but I left a bit appointed so I decided to dial up Rippy's a few days later to see if I couldn't find a winning 'Cue. More a concert venue than just a straight up barbecue house, Rippy's is big enough that there are actually multiple sections with separate live bands. The walls must be pretty well insulated, because I couldn't even hear the other band from my side of the restaurant. The crowd is rather wild and loud - if not just bone ass wasted - but the service was still excellent. 

I opted for the 1/2 Chicken Barbecue plate and what came from the kitchen was more than I bargained for as it flaunted the mentioned 1/2 Chicken that is seasoned and then slow smoked. The meat had a great smoke level, which matched perfectly with the evident smoke ring yet remained moist and juicy especially in the dark meat areas. The Curly Fries were standard issue and a bit overly salted but that did little to keep me from nibbling on them every few bites. The Chili on the other hand was flat and contained Beans - a pet peeve of mine. I would skip the Chili altogether on the next go around. 

Naturally the party atmosphere is what most patrons come to Rippy's for but the food isn't a slouch when you weigh in the nearby options of the genre and while Rippy's wasn't the best barbecue I've ever had, but it was certainly passable. I'd go back for the drinks and music any day, although I'd likely order a Burger instead.

This location is extremely slow when it comes to the Drive Thru. I could have walked to Berlin and back by the time my order was ready. They were not that busy and it was later in the evening. You would expect that your drink is made as you pull up to the window, but not with my first experience. The employee had to ask me again what we ordered. Really!? Why did I bother telling you through the speaker/microphone. So not only was our drinks not made, but we had to wait again for them to be made. 

There are better locations in the area. I would avoid this one, espeically if you are in a hurry.

Came here about 12:15pm on a Friday.  It was not very busy. The place has about 10 tables and some counter seating. 4 other tables were occupied. They also have a few outdoor tables. 

The waitress told us to choose a table and brought us menus. There are several salad options, various sandwiches and soups. The soup of the day was broccoli cheddar today. 

My wife chose the southwestern salad and I chose the southern melt. My wife really enjoyed the iced tea!!! The restaurant has a cool feel and is part of the West street market. 

Our food was delivered in a timely fashion and everything tasted delicious. 

One downside is the acoustics. We noticed it was difficult to hear each other but we could hear everyone else's conversations. Next time we will sit outside.

Overall, a great experience. We will be back.

3.5 Stars...here's why:

I spent an entire afternoon strolling up and down Talbot Street, and I was impressed by the artists who were there as well as the variety of mediums that were for sale.  I bought art and also had henna done on my hands, which I thought was pretty cool too.  I had a lovely afternoon at the Talbot Street Art Fair.  However, I do have two critiques:

(01) Prior to coming, I checked their website to see if pets were allowed, but I saw nothing.  I brought my dachshund in tow, but when we arrived, there was a wishy-washy sign that discouraged you from bringing your dog, yet I saw people with their dogs all around.  I was confused: why no definite answer?  Now, my puppy did no harm at the art fair, and I didn't feel as if her presence was a big deal for the fair-goers.  In fact, many people asked to pet her, and one of the artisans even held her while I chose and purchased a piece from him.  Still, I think the organizers should make up their mind about this specific issue in order to prevent confusion.

(02) Nicey Treat was there, which was awesome and refreshing on a warm, sunny day, but why not bring in some more food trucks?  It's not like Indianapolis has a shortage of them!  With an art fair that is so anticipated and popular, I would have loved to see more than Pineapple Delight and popcorn. Save that for the State Fair.  Besides, food is art.  Showcase it with some tasty stuff!

Will I come back next year?  Yes.  Will I bring my Dachshund? Most likely, if the organizers can make up their minds.

I have had this spot bookmarked for a while.  So I am happy to check it off my Santa Barbara bookmark list.  Unfortunately I came here in the evening and was not able to take in the beautiful views but my experience was still amazing.  They were near closing so it was not very busy.  We had the shop to ourselves for most of the visit.   My party of 4 tried 3 Signature Tasting: 2 whites and 3 reds, and 1 White Tasting: 4 whites.  

The owner of the shop was very knowledgeable of his wines and the wine making process.  Before the evening was over well all had a better understanding and appreciation of wine.   If you are interested in joining a wine club you should check out this spot. 

The atmosphere was relaxing and laid back (the wine may have had something to do with this), they provided great customer service and I would love to go back during the day to try more wine and take in the view.

Finally got a chance to go to Craft Street Kitchen and I was happily satisfied with everything.

We first tried the Buffalo Cauliflower. They had a nice kick, that after awhile the heat crept up on me, but I still wanted more.

I ordered a lobster benedict thanks to Stacy's recommendation. It came with nice pieces of lobster meat. I would have liked it deconstructed like she had it in Trinity, but I'll ask for it that way next time.

We also tried their Brussel sprouts with bacon which was excellent. My hubby had the brie burger. He liked it so much that there was no room for him to share. 

We will definitely be back, and check off more menu items and fun craft cocktails!

I can't say for sure why we chose to spend our afternoon at Winners and not Losers when we all know where my friends and I stand. However, with some folks (not me) it's probably difficult to diagnose the full extent of their problems with a cursory glance, so they let us inside anyway.

In any case, Winners might look like your average sports bar, but they did have complimentary bail bonds koozies, picklebacks, buckets of six Bud LIghts for $12, and the sweetest bartenders around. 

And although the food is just your standard fried fare, the cook will gladly give you handful of flour as long assure him that you just want to slap your friend in the face with it.

Mostly I come here because of the movie theater.

Sometimes I come here to shop.

Once in awhile I come here to eat.

Rarely do I combine two of the above activities here at the Summit, but it's pretty dead handy when I do.  My favorite stores are the Apple and Old Navy stores.  I love the little doggie park and the mini putt putt green they have at that end of the mall. Just a nice extra thoughtful touch.

Unlike other people, I am not one of those people who delight in leisurely walking from shop to shop, spending 45 minutes here, 25 minutes there, and dangling multiple shopping bags from my arm, leaving red marks on my skin.  

That is not my idea of fun; therefore the idea of walking from store to store doesn't bother me.  I tend to just go where I need to go, zero in on what I need to buy, and then get the heck out of there.  That's why this kind of open layout is just fine by me.

Contrary to the belief of to the two reviews thus far, Mike's does not offer the best pizza on earth.  While I agree the staff is typically friendly and forced to put up with the drunk mess of late night Main Street, their pizza misses the mark.  Being open late is their saving grace, as is their location directly across from Brew Pub and Mad River.  If you need something to absorb the nights drinking, Mike's will do.  Else wise, I remember you avoid.

Brunch level? 1000 

I came here on a Sunday around noonish with two others to grab brunch. It was a BEAUTIFUL July day and the perfect weather to sit outside and drink mimosas. There was about a ten minute wait that flew by as we enjoyed the scene. If you didn't already figure it out, Molly's has one of the best patios around.

For brunch I ordered their egg sandwich and home fries. It was only like $8-9 and amazing. Seriously, I could eat it every morning. Egg sandwiches are one of my top favorite things to eat for breakfast and they NAILED IT. It had fresh slices of tomato and juicy bacon slices. Pairs well with their mimosa but what doesn't?!

We even go to enjoy some live music during the meal. Not many places have live music during a Sunday brunch! It was a charming touch. 

Can't wait to go back again.

Yes, it's a big box giant, but Party City has everything I need! At least most of the time. I'm not even certain if it's priced well, but the fact that I can count on it to deliver the good is really all that matters. I'm there 1-2 times a month and I'm always greeted by nice employees and when they see me walking around in circles, they're eager to help out and point me in the right direction. I wish there was a Party City on the West side of town, because the drive can get kind of daunting at times. Overall this place covers all my party planning needs from balloons, to helium, to sombreros and face paint and more!

My college chum and I met January 2 for lunch. We had great service. We both drank water.

She got two pancakes with extra syrup ($6). This may sound like a small meal and it did to me, until I saw the size of these pancakes. They were the size of the plate!

I got an omelette ($9.95) with roasted red peppers, caramelized onions, white cheddar and turkey sausage. The omelette comes with four additions. I opted out of toast and hash browns. And got a fruit cup.

More than four omelette additions cost 50 cents each, with plenty of additions available.

And there are premium additions: smoked salmon and lump jumbo crab for $2.50 each.

This was a lovely meal, and we got a chance to catch up, without any pressure to leave.

She liked her pancakes.

My omelette was PERFECT! The roasted red peppers and caramelized onions were such tasty additions. And the turkey sausage was small pieces scattered about -- which gave me a piece of turkey sausage in every bite. Great composition. And the eggs were beautifully done.

My fruit cup was ridiculously fresh: blackberry, raspberry, kiwi, grape, honeydew and pineapple. What a glorious mix of fresh fruits.

I took home half of my omelette and half of my fruit cup, which served well as lunch the next day.

May be the most affordable restaurant Chinese restaurant in the casino. The only thing I don't really get is the seating is really limited at this area. If you have a lot of demand, why not give up some space. I am guessing each gambling table is worth more than a person seat at the somehow fast food bar. 

They have many good reviews. It because their BBQ dish. Some of the BBQ items is from off site and bring it into the restaurant. However they do have good flavor. The BBQ items included roast duck, BBQ pork, crispy pork. This item mixed with rice in duck sauce and make a good simple meal. 

I have order the oxtail noodle. This is actually the most expensive dish. Since it is their prepare meal. I really want to try their actual cooking skill. The meat is separated from the bone. The soup is almost like beef stew soup. This dish is not special enough to worth for the price you paid. I have better. 

This is about 3.5 stars restaurant but not quite there. However, I do give them the first consideration instead of casino food court.

The Polo Club Lounge is a sophisticated and classy English style bar in the Winsdsor Court hotel. It feels very masculine with all of  the leather chairs and couches and dark wood paneled walls, but I felt quite at home here. I could almost see all of the men retiring to this bar after a polo match drinking glasses of scotch on the rocks.

Service here is friendly, not snooty but be sure you're dressed nicely or you'll stick out like a sore thumb. 

This may sound a little weird but the ladies restroom is to die for gorgeous. Lots of fresh flowers, places to sit and wait for your friends (not the toilets...nice little benches lol) and wonderful smelling candles and upscale toiletries.

Might I suggest a Mint Julep? They are fantastic here. And don't forget to check in. The check in offer for the free order of truffle fries is one of the best check in offers EVER.

This is an adorable gift shop at the End of Main Street in Historic St. Charles.  When you think you have gone too far...keep going and you will find Aprils on Main.  From the moment you walk in your eyes get drawn in different directions.  Holiday items, gifts, home decor, accent furniture, picture frames, and even lighting fill the store from wall to wall.  This is the perfect store to walk around before or after lunch on Main Street.

If you have been shopping in St. Charles for years you would have seen Aprils work at the Flower Petaler.  She now has her own business and an updated spin on Artificial Floral Arrangements. If you need a fresh look for your holiday decor head to Aprils on Main today.  Follow them on Facebook to see what is new and on trend.  Aprils on Main also holds monthly Ladies Night Events with specials and cocktails.  Stop by soon!

After reading the reviews and seeing the popularity on Yelp we decided we had to check out Ralph's. The atmosphere is one of those little restaurants with generations of history. The main dining area quickly filled up with regulars at dinner and the staff was terrific. The bar is comfortable for drinks, appetizers or even dinner. 

We had the pleasure of Sean Baker entertaining us on the piano and several regulars taking center stage throughout the evening.  When the pianist asked for request I prompted my husband to ask for his all time favorite Charlie Brown music. Most don't take the request seriously or don't know the songs but Sean did. He played several to the pleasure of my husband and the crowd. Perfect birthday treat for him and icing on the cake. 

The bacon horseradish dip was tasty with the horseradish not overpowering the bacon flavor. Served with a large basket of ripple potato chips and re-heats well for leftovers. My Hot Pot was excellent and I'll be ordering again in the future. One of the dinner specials was a Beef Manhattan with soup and dessert. Again, one of birthday boys favorite being an old fashion meat and potato guy. Plenty of tender beef accompanied by an extra large serving of mashed potatoes. The high light of dinner for me was the delicate and fluffy coconut cream pie. So much so I'm ordering a birthday pie this Friday for my sister in law. Delicious, light pie with a flaky crust perfect after a large meal or by itself.
 
Excellent service, terrific food, fun, warm atmosphere, nice mixture of ages and personalities. Parking on street or in lot behind restaurant.

Café Ole is the latest incarnation for a café at this cool location in Old City.  Fortunately it's a good one.  The atmosphere  in the café is as warm as it has always been.  And the food and drinks are good.  What is special here?  Glad you asked .... it's the Shakshouka.  This is the best Shakshouka, I've had in Philadelphia ... and it is served with fresh bread to scoop up every last drop. 

One note to keep in mind is that the kitchen closes at 3PM (strictly breakfast & lunch) and the whole café closes around 7PM.

Was seated right away but, took alittle bit to get our drink order in.
The food came out very quickly. Very good! Had the baked chicken and dressing mashed potatoes with gravy and added a side of corn. 
Would recommend--

Really cool vibe here but honestly I don't care for the pizza. I have been here a few times and have never been wowed. The crust is too thick and doughy/chewy for my taste. 

I did used to like to come here for an appetizer that was absolutely amazing for any olive lover, it's was an olive cheese bread. But they no longer have it on the menu! So upset they got rid of my favorite thing! No clue why, it was delicious. 

The mellow mushroom soup is pretty good. Last time I came here with a group I had mushroom soup and wings, cause like I said before I don't like the main attraction, the pizza lol. The wings and soup and other various sides are good. They also have a nice beer selection. Service is a hit or miss but in my experience typically it's slow.

I was waiting for a friend to get off work and had some time to kill, and got lured in by the sign out front that mentioned oysters. 

The bartender who was working that night was absolutely great, and it was his conversation that kept me in my seat for drink after drink when I had planned on leaving much sooner. The music was good. They have a nice outdoor courtyard, flat screen TV's. 

But the oysters were some of the worst I had ever had. First of all, they did not arrive on ice. I have seen this before at another bar in the city, but that was a dive, so I wasn't expecting it here. They oysters were NOT cold whatsoever, they were room temperature. And bone dry to top it off. There was absolutely no liquid in the shells. I should have sent them back, should NOT have eaten them, but I did. I was fine, but when I told a local about it he said it sounded like they were not freshly shucked. I don't know what the story is, the venue is good otherwise but I really have to side-eye any place that would serve oysters this way.

Ban Thai. Holy jeebus, I'm pretty sure I've passed this little Thai restaurant more times than I care to count. I've always noticed the sign driving by but stopping for a bite to eat never crossed my mind until now. I guess it's because when you live in the area, you take things for granted. That or you just stay at home to cook. At least that's my train of thought.

A buddy and I decided to check Ban Thai out on a Tuesday evening. We arrived at 6:30pm and the place was pretty empty. There were two other groups of five that came later while we were eating but for the most part, it wasn't too busy. That's probably good because our server, leaning towards the ancient side of things (but super nice), was a tad on the slow side. No biggie though as the slow pace goes with the relaxed vibe and interesting, eclectic décor. The walls are plastered with Thai paintings and man, the menus sure are old.

Speaking of the menus, they had a couple "suggested combinations" but I'm not sure why you'd order that when you can go a la carte style and the price comes out pretty much equal. Combos are supposed to be deals no?!?! They probably should take a page out of Million Thai's playbook.

- Po Taek (#12) ($10.00) - spicy sour mixed seafood soup with tomatoes and mushrooms. The lemongrass was prominent and gave it a nice sourness to the broth. I didn't find it too spicy but there was some heat to it. Couple pieces of shrimp, squid and mussels were mixed in. Great way to start our meal.
- Gaeng kiew waan (#54) ($12.50) - creamy, green coconut curry with fresh basil, red and green peppers, snow peas and for meat, we picked chicken. We were both surprised by how dark the green curry looked like when it came out. It also had an interesting aroma - smelled something along the lines of mild coffee? Maybe we were losing our minds. Or it was the lighting. Definitely blame the lighting. It didn't matter though because the green curry was spot on. Rich and creamy in a subtle way.
- Kao mun (#27) ($4.00) - Thai rice steamed in coconut milk, aka. coconut rice. It says serves 2-3 people, but it's more to 2 people. We probably could have ordered another bowl, as we ran out of rice to finish off the green curry. It was good though, fluffy and the coconut came through loud and clear.
- Padt Thai (#33) ($15.00) - the padt thai is their house specialty (according to the menu). Thin rice noodles fried soft with minced pork, baby shrimp, tofu, chives, egg, bean sprouts and topped with crushed roasted peanuts. We were impressed by how generous the portion was. It's always a struggle finding a place that does this dish justice but they had the perfect balance of sweetness in their sauce.

Ban Thai is a sweet, sort-of-not-really hidden gem on the west end. Nice to see there are a few, emphasis on few, good spot on the West end for some good eats! Another Thai place in town to add to the list. I'll be back to try a few more things now that I know they do the basics well.

Excellent. Great service, location is convenient, and conditions are new. Rooms are perfect.( Large bathrooms alwats a plus!) However, I've stayed at some of the best Resorts and thought it was a bit over-priced. Restaurant downstairs was delicious! Gift shops could be better.

***Not to mention, I forgot $1,000 in the room. I called about 8 hrs later and the room service turned it into security! How often would that happen anywhere else?***

My feelings about my experiences with Daleng are very mixed. I'm willing to chalk that up to the fact that I've only done takeout, while most of the reviews and photos (which heightened my expectations) were based on eat-in experiences. 

The pros: highly flavored, completely delicious on both entrees that I've tried, specifically the Eggplant and Veggie Curry and the Cambodian Stir Fry with Tofu. The sauce on the eggplant and veggie curry is so good that I could just pour that on a plate of brown rice and happily call it a meal. The tofu in the Cambodian Stir Fry is well prepared, there's lots of lemongrass, which I love, and the the vegetables in both are so thoroughly cooked that every bite is a melt-in-your-mouth party of tender vegetables, flavorful sauce and fluffy rice.
The service is friendly and quick, and for eat-in it looks like they have a good drink selection with really good prices. So I definitely want to have an eat-in experience here.

The not-so-pros: In spite of other reviews claiming the contrary here, the portion sizes are not really that generous. I feel like for the price, the portions might have been what you would expect for a lunch portion from a restaurant that was less "takeout-esque" (borrowing Karen X's brilliant wordplay there) than Daleng. They don't really pack the takeout containers, which is understandable because there's A LOT of sauce and it was spilling out even from the 3/4 filled containers. The amount of rice was a little harder to forgive though; the cup-sized cartons were only partially filled to the top, and there were gaps at the bottom of the container (so not even packed in). Again, probably not a problem if you were to do an eat-in meal, but not great for what I'd expect from a takeout carton of rice. When similar sized takeout containers from most places provide enough for two generous meals for me, and from here the containers provide about half of that, I can't help noticing.
 
All that said, I will almost definitely still be doing both takeout and eat-in here. My husband tried the vegetarian banh mi and was underwhelmed, so maybe I'll just stick to their stir fries (and gotta try the spring rolls too). That eggplant and vegetable curry will definitely be a permanent favorite.
Yes it is just an Albertsons, but the check ot people were so conversant, and the fruit was fabulous! Yes it is just a supermarket, but I gotta tell you I loved the produce section!

Oh Whisk... I can't tell you how much I love you. How much you make my taste buds happy. How much my treadmill loves you for all the action it's getting.

Seriously, Whisk is everything I love in a local bakery.

The staff is so sweet. I was stalking out some pumpkin snickerdoodles they posted a photo of on Facebook, and when I called and found out they were gone, I was sad. That's until the owner told me she'd pop some in the oven for me. They were out of this world.

The look of this place is so charming, comforting, colorful, and is such a great addition to Cherokee street. I can see myself spending some time working here with baked goodies and some local coffee (the only thing missing is wifi!)

Swing by when you can, seriously. I haven't had something I didn't like here. Vegans, there are options for you as well.

Thanks for just existing, Whisk!

I was hungry and was released from my meal obligations for the night with the family.  I also had seen this as a new place listed earlier in the day by the Yelp team on FB so, I thought I would splurge and get a meal that wasn't quite on my diet.

I ordered up the Rustler sandwich with no cheese ... and it was delicious. On first blush I think this could easily be one of the best sandwiches served in Reno.  The design is a bit more messy than other places with the bread on top.  But still the stuff they put on the sandwich was an explosion of flavor.

I also got the mac salad because I am a sucker for a new mac salad.  It was pretty good.  As was the cookie that really made the meal a complete splurge.

The quick-serve style is like any other small sandwich shop.  I am not sure the location is the best for what they are doing, but if people like the food as much as I did, they will be packing in the people.

There is no better lunch option on a Friday than the Assumption Greek Orthodox Church Lunch.  Homemade Greek food with love.  Every Friday from 11 am- 2 pm, you can be sure to enjoy true Greek hospitality.  Drive to the very back of the parking lot and enter the white doors where you see a set of small stairs and a wheelchair ramp.  If it is your first time, there are plenty of people to point you in the right direction.

The church does an amazing job of posting their whole month's menu online.  They even have a downloadable copy for offices and groups that order together.  Take Out here is a breeze.  You can call the kitchen and place your pick up order directly or wait in line to see the options.  If you choose to eat at the location there are plenty of round tables filling the entire auditorium space.  

On my last visit, I was thrilled to order Lobster Bisque ($4.00), Spanakopitia ($3.00), Greek Salad ($5.00) and Dolmathes (2 for $3.00).  I had so much left over it made a second lunch.  Over the years, I have probably ordered almost everything.  Every Week they offer a Baked Fish option.  I have gotten the Baked Fish and served it for Dinner before.  Everything is boxed nicely and holds well.  The homemade soups never disappoint.  Once a month or so they sever Lamb Shank, expect longer lines on these days.

You do not have to wait for the once a year Greek Festival for fresh and flavorful Greek food.  Plan a visit to this West County hidden treasure soon.

WV is one of the many locations along my personal Bucks County Wine Tour - I visited because of the high ratings on Yelp! Thanks Yelp!

The wine is everything you'd expect for the region, and then some. They also feature free hors d'oeuvres that compliment the wine, and the venue is very nice as well. The staff is quite lovely and super super friendly - there was a large party off to the right so they CAN accommodate parties if that's your thing.

They also feature smoothies for those that want to indulge in something fun and different, especially on those warm Summer days!

It's a must visit and it'll be a must returned visit, for me!

THIS has been a review by Gaurav

5 Stars for what it is, and 5 Stars for what it's going to be. Does that mean I can give 10?

For the longest time I followed that the owner of South Philly Tap Room was going to open up a cafe that hook up delectable coffee offerings from one of my favorites, Counter Culture (http://mealticket.blogs.citypaper.net/blogs/mu/2009/05/05/first-look-at-brewultimo-coffee/). and even better was the fact that it wasn't only going to offer one of my favorite vices, it was going to offer TWO of them by doubling over as a beer store as soon as it procured a liquor license (http://ultimocoffee.wordpress.com/2009/01/23/meal-ticket-round-two-keeping-tabs-on-brewultimo-coffee/). And while one of those goals is still a work in progress, the coffee shop is very much alive and might just be one of the best in the city.

as soon as I walked up one of the South Philly roads that is less traveled for me and saw my destination, I became enamored by it's outdoor seating and garage door that opened to combine the outside with the in. the incredible decor expanded with church pews and antique window fixtures hanging indoors. I also made note of the many refrigerator units that will one day hold mass quantities of delectable beer.

The iced chai that I initially order made for the perfect relaxed wake up call during a hot day. and the coffee that I ordered afterwards embodied a dark richness to it's body that was fully accentuated by the drip method that they utilize. and the lemon square that I ordered along with it was sheer perfection. 

Overall the staff were friendly and extremely accommodating, and the atmosphere made for the perfect environment to have our book club in. It looks like Ultimo is a place that I'll be visiting for a long while to come!

I'm not really a prophet of Restaurant Week or anything. I can take it or leave it. Mostly leave it, since I feel like I can have a better experience for the same price (sometimes less, sometimes more if we're all being honest here) any other night of the year. That said, I do dig RW for one thing - lunch. Because if you can score a table at one of the few gems on the list that runs like a well-oiled machine, you are all but guaranteed a fantastic meal at a price that can't be beat. Barbuzzo is one of those gems. 

I entered the restaurant at 12:45, my reservation time, and my lunch date and I were taken to our table right away. No waiting! If our server was unhappy to be working this shift, he certainly didn't show it. He took care of us for the duration of the meal and offered helpful suggestions when we asked for his opinion. I started with a crisp glass of white wine which went perfectly with my meal. 

To start, the vegetable board, which had a piece of buttery oven-grilled bread, roasted peppers, brussels lightly scented with truffle, glazed carrots and some broccoli rabe. It wasn't rocket science but it was a healthy and satisfying start to the meal. The sheep's milk ricotta across from me was wiped clean from the plate. Next up for me was a chicken dish, with two thin cutlets topped with parmesan and a little prosciutto. This was served over some braised greens and mashed potatoes with a little bit of gravy around the bottom. It was very nice, not too heavy and packed lots of flavor. My companion had the pizza. Folks, if you haven't had Barbuzzo's pizza, get on it, because it's some of the best in the city. Last but not least, the caramel budino. I somehow managed to restrain myself to only half, which is honestly plenty for me since the flavors are so rich and sweet. 

Surprisingly, this was probably the quietest meal I've ever enjoyed at Barbuzzo. Everyone around us seemed to be seated on time and there were no waits at the door. I guess when a restaurant is used to having a full house on the regular, Restaurant Week is no different from any other day.

So much fun! I came to SB not knowing this fiesta was taking place. I noticed everyone was caring colorful eggs, no not plastic eggs but real egg shells. They were decorated with all sorts of colors and characters. I noticed some people breaking them on each other's heads; the inside has been emptied and replaced with confetti.

I started walking towards the crowd and found all the yummy food being sold at double the regular price! But that didn't stop me from indulging in one of the best tacos I've ever had! So good I will be remaking them at home. Each taco was $4! A drink was $6... yup I limited my self to 3 street tacos. They had kabobs, loaded fries and more than any other food: Mexican food. 

They had bands playing, they had a dance competition, every street was decorated with flags from Spain. It was fun and would definitely recommend.
God why does this place always seem to have like 2 people working the morning rush? It takes an eternity to get in and out of here even when there are only two people in line ahead of you.

Had fingerprints taken for a security clearance here (gateway Shopping Center Location) .
No issues.

Think of all the times you went out to eat and found yourself walking out of the restaurant in an uncomfortable food coma.  That is NOT the case with Nook.  Given the restaurant's concept, this place is as good as it gets for the paleo folks.  The front side of the menu is geared around them.  But what if you're not on Team Paleo?  What if you're vegetarian or vegan?  Good news: you have options too.  Just flip the menu around, and Nook has laid out what you can eat.

I went the vegetarian/dairy-free route and ordered the Shiitake, Lemon, & Basil Cauliflower Wood Oven Pizza from the vegan menu but opted for the paleo crust (it has egg in it).  I really enjoyed the pizza, finding the highlight of the pizza was the paleo crust.  I was in disbelief of how tasty my pizza was, yet there was no food coma looming.  Feeling good, I also shared the Chocolate Avocado Mousse, topped with shredded coconut and pistachios, which turned out being another excellent choice.  Walking out sans food coma, I knew I had found the best option in Indy to eat out without consequence.

(PS: big shout out to the entire staff for their attentiveness from start to finish.)

I can only speak about this establishment with regards to the maki rolls.

A lot of Japanese places walk a fine line with their sushi. They want to preserve the humble discipline of ancient tradition while still appealing to the American sense of gluttony. This is why you see menus with a number of traditional options and then like 4 or 5 wacky maki rolls where tons of stuff are thrown in. Kabuke makes no bones about what they do - They make wacky rolls to appeal to the American who wants it all(in a roll).

Kabuke's special roll menu has like, 50 of these, and they look good. They pack everything from lobster to honey wasabi into their creations. Granted, a lot of these are different by way of one ingredient and some parts of the menu kinda look like this:

Super Duper Roll - Salmon, shrimp tempura, eel sauce, masago, sesame seed bun, glass, copper bullet casing.
Crying Angel Roll - Salmon, shrimp tempura, eel sauce, masago, tuna, glass, copper bullet casing.
(None of these are actually on the menu. Do not take these seriously)

...that being said, the rolls are hefty in size, content, and quality. The spicy Mexican roll is pretty good and the Kabuke roll caught my eye for next time(It had like tuna, asparagus, shrimp tempura, caviar, sweet sauce, salted tuna, and probably other things I am forgetting). I'll be back here soon and will report on more of the wacky rolls.

On a slight negative, the regular salmon maki is a little squishy. The place still rules.

Furthermore, the service is really friendly and prompt.

On the action-movie-parallel-satisfaction-scale, this place is The Terminator.

Fun spot to grab a bite to eat with a small group of friends as the menu has a nice variety of types of food to choose from. I arrived in town late Thanksgiving night and while intrigued and somewhat excited by the multiple options on State Street that were open and serving special Thanksgiving meals I really just wanted to sink my teeth into some standard American fare like a burger or pizza. I'm always hungry for a pizza. The menu has tons of unique burger options, salads, cleaner entree options like fish, tacos, lots of interesting appetizers, tortilla wraps and a big section of pizza options. I loooooove garlic with white sauce pizzas but my man is not such a fan so typically we end up sharing marinara sauce pizzas. Since I was here sans man I went with my gut instinct, ordering the White Out Pizza and was not disappointed! Grilled chicken, mozzarella, garlic, TRUFFLE oil. Yummmmmmm. 

I'm still not much of a drinker anymore so I didn't sample any of the brews but some guys next to us were having a grand old time with the samplers and I saw some cool sounding beers on the menu board that I would definitely want to try if I didn't have to be careful with belly bloat before an event!

Service was average. Seat yourself at any table and hope that a server notices your presence. We sat a good 15 minutes before were even able to make eye contact with someone who worked there to flag them down to take our orders.

The only place I will go to for color ever again! Josie (Josephine) took the red out of my now rich brown hair and it stayed brown for the last four weeks. No icky red oxidation has wormed it's way into my rich brown locks thanks to Josie! Prices are competitive for the neighborhood and the staff is warm and professional. We had a great time. What more could you want ?

So I love local coffee shops. This place is tucked away and almost unnoticeable from the main street, but it is a must for Chai lattes and a quiet place to do some work with wifi. Due to the intimate space, I don't know if I would have louder work product or personal conversations here. The seats and tables are too close together, and there is very little white noise.

As a general principle I try to avoid big box stores because of the damage they do to the local economy of so many small towns across America.  Yet, there are times using them becomes necessary because the local shops are closed, or just don't have the universal inventory of HD. 

Like most men I start to feel intoxicated when facing floor to ceiling tools, hardware, paint, lumber, you name it.  It is amazing what I can convince myself I need when walking up and down the aisles. You mean I don't already have a long handled hammer to extend my reach and leverage?  How can I live any longer without one? Gotta have it!  Right gents?

So, I found myself there yesterday with my son who needed two cans of spray paint for a 6th grade school project and had waited to mention it until after my Newtown Hardware House was closed for the night.  I felt the tug of the tidal wave sensation of all that great stuff.  After 10 minutes evaluating the Rust O Leum , more time picking up some light bulbs, and perusing that long handled blaster (all at good prices), we left the airplane hanger.  

I was so drunk from hardware overload I had to let my son drive home.

Lemon blueberry goat cheese pancake stole the show. A show that went on. Way. Too. Long. 

I get the brunch rush, and a prolonged wait even twice the quote time. It's the weekend. It's brunch at a brunch spot... I truly understand. But once we had butts in seats, it still took near an hour to get food ordered and served. Inexcusable.

The Bloody Mary tasted like lime-squeezed hot sauce and little else. The chicken and biscuit breakfast sandwich was hearty, salty and comforting - proper fried breast, moist and well-seasoned, a "broken egg" that wasn't and cooked hard, and a tender biscuit with savory sausage gravy. I wish I was hungover, but wasn't and enjoyed it nonetheless. 

The wait murdered the whole experience, though. I felt bad for our server who was being burdened by high-maintenance tables. That said, there was only a passing apology and a definitive write-off to our table's needs. Definitely dampened an otherwise four star meal.

A beautiful hidden gem nestled in the heart of Lambertville. My husband was so proud that he "found" this place, and I was happy to oblige in trying something new!  

We actually walked over from the Wine Cellar at Lambertville Station, it is super walkable (~7 mins). Anyways, once we walked in, we immediately knew we found our new favorite restaurant. The smells of the food were intense and super fragrant. The restaurant is a no-frills basic room, yet intimate and charming. Copper tables dotted the space in various configuration of 2's, 4's and even a party of 6.  Antique middle eastern lights hung from the ceiling in various colors, proving just enough light to see, with tea candles flickering on each table for a pinch of romanticism.  You can see into the kitchen vaguely, and get the sense that it's only a couple people back there, doing what they do best. 

The menu is surprisingly large. So many options ranging from Zatter bread & babaghannough to gyros, Koshari, and Egyptian samosas - it was hard to choose! We settled on sharing 3 things, and made a deal on what we'll order the next time we dine (gyros, hummus, and Ouzi, for the record).  

To start we ordered babaghannough, which was sublime. Their menu described it as "eggplant dip will be the best you ever had" and, I gotta say, it was! The "generous dose of garlic" definitely tickled our tastebuds, but we're complete garlic lovers so it was right up our alley. Plus, the pita was served warm, always a good touch!

For our meal, we shared a salad with shrimp and kofta. Honestly the salad was "fine", totally good and shrimp was flavored well, but, it got lost in comparison to the kofta, that I hardly touched it.  

The kofta; omg. First of all, the meat itself was so packed with flavor that my taste buds were practically dancing! It was served with tahini and toumeaa (a garlic sauce); both of which were unlike anything I've tasted before.  They doctored up their tahini - it was bright and flavorful, almost zesty.  The toumeaa was unreal - the words "that's money" from a certain flame-wearing diner-visiting chef popped into my mind. It was like a kick in the pants, for my tastebuds - SO unbelievably garlicky, yet somehow I couldn't get enough.  The dish was served with yummy long grain rice, which I happily used to shovel more toumeaa into my mouth.  Let's just say, it's a good thing we both were eating the same thing - otherwise I would have had some SERIOUS garlic breath issues (I mean, I still had it - but at least we both did!)

The server was super friendly and hospitable, prompt without being pushy, but left us alone just the right amount! I legitimately cannot wait to go back and try more of this menu!!!

::Heads up, no reservations unless you have a party of 6+. You can do call ahead seating! We came around 9pm on Saturday and we're seated immediately, but the place was really full.
:: BYOB! Wahoo!

CHOW284 has totally gutted the Wing Walker Pub, aka Inn Flight and put them to rest, while busy redesigning not only the inside of the restaurant but totally revamping an interesting menu and a concept that will take me time to adjust to. Chow 284 is not affiliated with Inn Flight and this is the owners first baby, according to our server.
 
When you first enter the restaurant, you are greeted by a large and well lit menu on the wall, however it was malfunctioning at the time, so we were handed menus to read and this is how it must be done, which threw both hubby and I off for a sit down restaurant. After reading the menu, you then place your order at the front desk and pay for your meal and beverage, unless your beverage is alcohol, then you must order that, once seated and start a new tab. 

I am not one for changes like this, but according to the girls at the front desk, this concept is being done in Florida quite a bit. Once they get their website up and running, I will enjoy reading the menu on line and deciding, rather than feeling rushed in the vestibule. 

Hubby had a coke and was handed a blue plastic cup and shown where the soda fountain was, which does allow free refills. The hostess handed us a large playing card and asked us to give it to our server, we were also asked to seat ourselves. There is only one dining area, off to the right and they are all booths, which are quite attractive for a very casual restaurant. 

I was most impressed with the bar and lounge area which sits directly front and center and is wide open. It is a huge horseshoe shaped bar with TV screens scattering the walls and the coolest wine bar I have ever seen in my life! Their wine list is awesome and these are from wineries around the world that can only be bought by the case. Each section has a controlled temperature and sealing to ensure freshness. You have to check it out, very sophisticated, I think this impressed me the most!

So, you place your order and pay for it before you choose your own seat, hand said server a playing card, she already knows from the hostess that I will be having a glass of wine and opens a new check and delivers. Then they have a runner, because your order was already turned into the kitchen and as it comes up, it comes out, it does not matter if you ordered a side of mac & cheese to go with your crab cakes, the mac & cheese will come out first if it is ready to run.

I started with a colossal sized bleu cheese wedge and when I saw it I laughed to myself thinking of Fred Flinstone! It was a huge wedge with a large dinner fork shoved right into the top of it and a large knife to break it all down. It was not chintzy on the bleu cheese dressing or crumbles and the bacon was plentiful, alas no tomatoes and skimpy on the red onion, but they quickly brought me a few more slivers of onion... It was served on a chilled plate, very crisp, I would order this again.

The twin crab cakes said absolutely no bread fillers and I asked if they were pure lump crab meat and was told yes. The crab cakes were a bit of a disappointment, mostly shredded crab meat with a bit of lump crab mixed in, but there was no real flavor, no onions or peppers and if there was it missed my two cakes, but the whole grain mustard sauce I could have eaten with a spoon it was so good. My crab cakes came with plain steamed broccoli, which I am not a big fan of, but no substitutions of sides are permitted so I ordered a side of mac & cheese, which was in a creamy velveeta like sauce, spirals enough for two, nothing spectacular.

We are both soup lovers, but there were no soups on the menu, we did inquire and they do plan on having soups in the near future, Chow284 just opened this past Monday. 

Hubby had a French dip which came with a side of gravy instead of au jus and a side of horseradish sauce. Layers of roast beef lined this crunchy and delicious roll and the meat was topped with Gruyere cheese, bonus points there, but he said the meat was dry and a French dip should be served with au jus, not gravy. Ah change again, I need to open my mind up to new concepts. This came with crunchy homemade potato chips. 

The one thing that stood out to me, no two, no three, was our server hanging at the bar with two bartenders all text messaging when we really needed her attention, two= the runner stood outside the kitchen chewing gum worse than I have ever seen a cow chew cud and three, the owner walking around while on his laptop and even sat in the vestibule on it as we were leaving, get an office. It was kind of him to ask us if we wanted a bag for our containers on our way out, since the server never offered them.

This was not meant to be my 700th review and I have so many that I am behind on, but I felt the need to let you know Chow284 is here. I'm hoping my next visit will be much better now that I understand their format in operating. The jambalaya intriqued me enough to want to go back, hopefully it's awesome.

Some eighteen hours after ingesting it, I'm still amazed that the best Indian meal I ever have had was in this small, nondescript hole-in-the-wall tucked away in the middle of an off-the-beaten-path strip mall in Clearwater, Florida. Eager for a change of pace from the chow mein palaces, seafood joints, and steakhouses prevalent in the area, we made the effort to find this place despite a heavy downpour resulting in a lengthy traffic jam. Its modest outward appearance might have deterred us had it not been for the number of people within - if that many were willing to come here in a deluge, it must be good, no? And indeed it was. No, not just good . . . outstandingly superb or superbly outstanding, take your pick, both are fitting descriptions of a dinner that definitely was worth the trek in what ended up being the fourth worst storm in Tampa Bay history. I stress the weather only because on an evening when most people were content to stay home with leftovers, a Lean Cuisine, or delivery from Domino's, a few dozen had braved the elements to come here. Clearly it wasn't for the decor, which heavily suggests this was an Italian trattoria before its current incarnation. What drew them was the food, which is rich, flavorful, plentiful, and inexpensive. We decided to eat family-style, and ordered a number of dishes we shared. Given the choices of mild, medium, or spicy, we fortunately opted for medium, since it provided just enough fire without leaving us thirsting for relief the rest of the night. We started with an appetizer platter which included samosas and vegetable, cheese, and chicken pakoras, four of each, which made dividing them among us a simple task. This was followed by tandoori chicken - a hearty portion of three drumsticks and three large breasts served on a bed of sauteed onions and green peppers - creamy palak paneer, butter chicken in a thick tomato-based sauce, ginger and garlic-infused curried lamb with tomatoes and onions, peshawari naan (stuffed with coconut, almonds, cashews, raisins, and cherries), the house naan (topped with chicken, garlic, and cilantro), and fluffy, grease-free poori. Each dish had its own distinct flavor, and all were served with basmati rice. Friendly and very attentive service was provided by a sweet blue-eyed blonde teenager and a hippie-looking, college-age busboy, unexpected in an ethnic eatery, but not surprising considering its location. The total bill for four, including a couple of beers and two iced teas, tax, and tip, was an amazingly low $99 . . . and we brought home enough leftovers for a second meal. A lunch buffet, served Monday through Friday from 11:30am until 2:30pm and priced at only $7.95, will have us returning next week. Even in far more sophisticated culinary centers like New York City or San Francisco, Laziz would be a five-star gem.

Rare Ethnic Food 52. Ethiopian cuisine 

It is close to 4.5 stars for my experience today. I kind agree some food need to tone up the spicy taste. However the spice and ingredients are there. With that said. Let me get into the experience. 

Mitmita is actually meaning one of the Ethiopian Spice. It can be mixed and make many dish. I like the restaurant reflecting their true calling. The culture of food is use a piece of injera to pick up a bit of entree by hand and eat it. That is how it done to enjoy the different cuisine. 

We have a group there can try different dishes. Injera is a crepe type sheet for pick up the food. The best dish is the Ye-doro Wat. This is a chicken dish with Ethiopian Ber-bere sauce. The sauce has so many ingredients. It is flavorful. We also order the  Kat Wat the chop beef with Ethiopian bbq sauce, Kitfo the lean beef is with the Mitmita sauce, Gored Gored the raw tenderloin beef with amaze sauce. Those are good dishes. 

Afterward we have Ethiopian coffee with ceremony incense to celebrate special occasions. It was a great celebration. On the appetizers, we have the chicken, veggies, and beef sambusa. Very tasty. We have good time there.

Pi, a place where one can get hand-tossed or Chicago-esq pizza in University City's Loop district.  This is a place my aunt had been wanting to try, so she dragged us down there to give it a whirl.  We ordered up a KIRKWOOD and subbed out the red peppers for pepperoni (slight upcharge), a Schlafly's seasonal draft, some wine and their signature drink called "Pi Squared."  The pizza came our pretty quickly for being as thick as it was.  The sauce on top was nice and chunky and had a great flavor, as did the Italian meatballs, but the pizza crust just had too much corn meal for my liking.  So I ate my two slices, and avoided the crust where possible.

The service was fantastic.  Our server was energetic and on the ball, despite having a full dinning room to tend to.  I'd like to return and try their hand tossed pizza.

My childhood is filled with memories of enjoying the annual Philadelphia Flower Show and then walking to Vietnam for some lunch/dinner with my family.  This has happened more times than I can count, and each time its been wonderful.  It may not be the typical family tradition, but it's mine and I love it.
