Even now that I live in CO, any opportunity I have to come back to Vietnam is an exciting day indeed.

I've been to Vietnam more times than I can count and two things are guaranteed, my Mom and I order the Flaming Volcano for two, and the table shares the BBQ Platter.  If this is all you eat and drink at Vietnam you'll be in heaven.

The Flaming Volcano for two includes rum, vodka, gin, brandy, grenadine, Bacardi 151 and fruit juice.  This is a boozy beverage and will leave two people feeling the buzz as they suck down every drop.  And don't let them take the drink too soon, as the ice melts and mixes with the remaining booze and juice you can have a "second drink".  Don't forgot to blow out the flame and drink the rum from the center, it's a warm burn as it makes it's way slowly down your throat.  

The BBQ Platter includes, crispy spring rolls, beef stuffed grape leaves, char-grilled chicken, grilled meat balls, rice vermicelli, lettuce, and rice paper sprinkled with crushed peanuts.  They say this serves two people but I think this easily serves four to five people, especially if you're ordering entrees.  The crispy spring rolls are those addicting spring rolls that you dream about.  If I was on a desert island and could only have three things, I would want these spring rolls to be one of the three items.  In addition to the spring rolls, the grilled meatballs are delicious and I love taking the lettuce or the rice paper and making a wrap with the rice vermicelli, char-grilled chicken, pickled vegetables and topping the whole thing with some peanut sauce.  The BBQ Platter will feed the table and people will fight over the last bites.

I've tried multiple entree items and they have all been good, but nothing has the variety that the BBQ Platter offers.  The BBQ Platter gives you multiple items and a mixture of tastes that a single entree cannot offer.  Take my word for it, order the BBQ Platter!  And if you're feeling a bit crazy, the Flaming Volcano for two is the perfect accompaniment.

The Lobero Theatre is California's oldest continuously operating theatre since being founded by José Lobero in 1873 as an opera house! It has all the things I look for in a theatre and it is no surprise that celebrities come from all over the world to partake in the Santa Barbara Film Festival! 

Offers fabulous shows, CHECK!
Gorgeous design and history (look up inside), CHECK!
Close to plenty of dining/drinking options, CHECK!
Easy nearby parking, CHECK!
Safety protocols for attendees, CHECK!

I recently came to the Lobero Theatre to see one of my favorite comedian drag queens, Bianca Del Rio. The staff kept everyone safe by requiring proof of vaccination, had everyone converse with masks and social distancing on the foyer prior to the show, provided visible signs indoors announcing expectations, and had a bar outside! We had a wonderful time that evening. I would have no hesitation to return for one of their wide-variety of shows or performances.

This has become one of my favorite places in the city.

Since my review over 2 years ago, I have tried much of the food, a lot of the wine and some of the beer. Delachaise is the perfect little bistro when you want to enjoy a night out, but you don't want to get overly fancy.

My favorites on the food menu are the gourmet grilled cheese and the cheese plate. I have tried many cheeses on the cheese plate and I've always been delighted by my choices. The gourmet grilled cheese is to die for. It's so rich that you can pretty much split it with a friend.

I really like the seating area by the window, and it's always a perfect night when I am lucky enough to grab this limited spot. Sitting on the patio is perfect for early evening as the sun begins to set and the night winds down.

There is an extensive wine selection so you are sure to find something that suits your tastes.

I went mid-September with my girlfriend. We both got 4 bones. She got porto fries as her side. I got corn chowder.

I cannot say how much I LOVE that they offer more sides than the standard, oh-so boring barbeque sides.

And there are the pickles!! I got three spears, and they're just so good!!

The ribs were great, chewy, no fall off the bone here. I ate most sans sauce, but I did try the coffee sauce and the mustard sauce.

The coffee sauce was great. The mustard sauce was too totally mustardy.

The corn chowder was creamy good with snappy kernels of corn, and appropriately hot. It had a bit of a kick to it. It was earthy, so I would say cumin.

My girlfriend's porto fries were Portobello mushrooms cut like steak fries, breaded and deep-fried. They were made ON THE SPOT, exactly when she ordered them, and brought to the table.

She shared one with me, and they were fabulous.

A lot of interesting sides were available this day, and I had trouble selecting just one.

I took home half of the corn chowder, two ribs and three pickle spears, which made for another glorious meal.

TO NOTE: There is now a BIG sign over the appropriate entrance door. The sign reads: ENTER. So, I got it right this time.

Evenso, we did witness many folks entering through the exit door and making their way backwards through the cafeteria line to get to the order area. Arghhhh!

I would like to patronize other Sugarfire locations, as I understand the sides are different, depending on the location and the chef's flair.

I am absolutely loving Rebar Coffee. Matt Christianson, the brain behind Union Ale and American Ale, has hit it out of the park with this adorable cafe. 

Rebar serves delicious drip coffee, lattes, and cold brew. They have an assortment of bottled, cold beverages, as well as, local beer and wine. They also offer fresh squeezed orange and tomato juices. 

On a hot day, I usually opt for the cold brew. It is rich, bold and tasty! When I'm looking to warm up, I tend to order an Almond Milk Latte - sooo good! Or an Almond Milk Vanilla Latte, made with a touch of their house made Vanilla Bean Syrup. I am so delighted that they make their syrups in house rather than using the ordinary Torani brand syrups. 

Rebar offers breakfast daily, fresh baked pastries and lunch items including massive, gourmet burgers with fries, pizzas and salads. 

I've had the Sticky Bun multiple times and it is the dessert sweet dreams are made of! Imagine a cinnamon bun but better, doughy on the inside, crispy, perfectly caramelized crust on the outside, topped with candied nuts and a sauce that trickles down the outside ridges of the crust, mmmm good! 

I also highly recommend the Ricotta toast which consists of an extra thick slice of fresh baked bread, topped with a generous slather of hand pulled ricotta cheese and finished off with a layer of jam of your choice (Blueberry Strawberry, Strawberry Rhubarb, Peach or Honey). I had it with Strawberry Rhubarb and it was fantastic! Not too sweet and very filling. It could be a light meal on it's own or order one to share as a little amuse bouche for your table. 

The Avocado Bacon & Egg Sandwich is definitely worth a mention as well. House made Brioche bun, baked to golden perfection, sandwiching a fried egg over medium, several slices of thick, smokey bacon, smashed fresh avocado and topped with diced chives. The sandwich comes with a Chipotle Ketchup that I've heard is wonderful, however, I love a combination of sweet and savory for breakfast so I substitute the ketchup for house made jam, usually Strawberry Rhubarb. It's heavenly! If you've ever had the breakfast sandwich at Renaud's, this is reminiscent of that (only slightly different ingredients), and served with a much better bread in my opinion, because the brioche does not tear up my gums like the bread at Renaud's does. Just try it, it's worth it!

It would not be a complete review without mentioning the ambiance, decor, location and music. Rebar feels like a respite from the hustle and bustle of State Street, even though it's located right on it. Walking into Rebar is like stepping back in time to the Prohibition-Era. Natural wood, metal and steel accents, the greatest jazz humming through unseen speakers and beautiful large windows to people watch. 

There is also a huge, dog friendly outdoor patio with plenty of picnic tables. They'll even bring a water bowl for your pooch(es). I know because I've brought my two loves. ;) 

The staff is warm and friendly. They all seem very well-trained. There is free wifi, password: 214union. 

Parking is easy in their lot adjacent to Rebar, or if necessary, you can park across the street in the Amtrak lot where the first 75 mins are free.

The only note I have of constructive feedback is regarding the bathrooms, which are located next to the patio and across from the kitchen doors. They are often dirty and need regular attention. I suggest having an hourly or bi-hourly schedule for the staff to check the bathrooms and do any clean up necessary. It is very off putting when a bathroom is in disgusting condition at a restaurant because it gives off a vibe of uncleanliness. Something I would not associated with my restaurant if I owned one. Other than that, I'd say Rebar is close to perfect for a little cafe.

While there are billions of good reasons to go to West Philadelphia, Clark Park is probably my favorite reason for it.  It's so peaceful and green. It's the perfect place to relax and read a book, toss around a frisbee, or to just go for a nice walk. I feel that Liberty Lands Park is a little better when it comes to wide open space, but the area around Clark Park has so much more to offer (at least for now since the part of Northern Liberties by Liberty Lands is under a lot of construction).
There's also plenty of events going on inside it. Flea and Farmers's markets galore as everyone else has said. But it also has one of my favorite music fests every summer (even though it ended up not letting all the bands who were scheduled to play this year play!). It's also going to even have a production of Romeo and Juliet going on early next month. That's right, Shakespeare in a wide open park!

When I rate an airport, I think about whether or not I could spend a great deal of time there without snapping. Too many hours in a bad airport and I will cut you. 

So for example, the Tom Bradley International Terminal at LAX - between the champagne, caviar, high end shoppes and lounges, I'd rather be there right now. 

But Detroit, Phoenix, and Vegas - total snap zones.

This airport was great for lots of reasons:
-Decent food options (there are very few airports where I would consider eating raw oysters)
-Easy to get in and out of via subway, cab, uber, whatever
-Multiple sod potty stations for your dog with cute mini fire hydrants 
-Some good shopping, though the political store that was half Trump half anti-Trump, lame
-Good selfie mirror in the bathroom

It was so easy to be here, even if due to last minute planning we were flying Spirit or the first (and probably last) time ever. BTW Spirit, definitely the capital of Snapville.

Good and plentiful pho servings here, with a good large selection of other  Vietnamese items as well.  Son and I had regular pho bowls (which range from $8.00 - $8.50).  They also offer a "super bowl" for $11.  Wife enjoyed a nice serving of steamed pork dumplings, which were good and fresh tasting.  Clean and modern decor.   It was a nice place for a tie-me-over meal after a day of fried food and other food stand servings at the Indy State Fair.

This joint was super popular among my coworkers. I had the lentil salad which I liked but it was sort of hard to eat because the lentils are just sort of shake to the bottom and you don't really eat them in a good mix.

I also had the pasta with chorizo which was excellent and cam in something of an insane portion.

Tango's is a little hole in the wall on Orchard.  I wouldn't have looked twice if it wasn't for the yelp reviews (yay yelpers) and some word of mouth by friends.  And, thank God I did.  This place is not only so totally delicious that you'll find yourself gazing at your empanada whispering, where have you been all my life...but hands down the best service I've received in all of Boise.  We were greeted upon entrance by one of the owners (Monica?  I think) and when we told her that our seven-year-old had never had an empanada--she immediately showed him what one looked like (she actually had a clay/plaster empanada for this very situation) and told him the most popular fillings for children.  This was awesome and completely demystified what had a moment before been "weird food" to my son.  I can't say enough about the service--she was so very sweet to us.  

I ordered their Fugazza empanada, which was filled sautéed onions, mozzarella, and spices.  It was heady with herbs and flavor.  My dining companion ordered the Moleh, which was chicken in sweet sauce (chocolate, peanuts, and various chilies) and was pleased, though said the flavor was a bit unusual and wouldn't be for everyone (I didn't dig it).  My seven-year-old got the Hawaiian, which was the usual pineapple, ham, and mozzarella.  He was delighted.  The prices were incredible.  $2.25 per empanada.  We each had one, which was enough for me, but my dining companion could have eaten two plus dessert. 

We didn't partake in the dessert empanadas as we had already promised the little guy fro-yo.  However, we have every intention of doing so!  And, once we do, I will definitely update.

Justine is a great addition to the 5-star dining scene in NOLA.  This is a much larger restaurant than you'll typically find me, but they've done a stellar job of separating the various dining rooms to make it feel more manageable.  The decor varies in each of the dining rooms as well.  The front area feels like a Parisian sidewalk cafe, perfect for a casual lunch, glass of wine, etc.  The main dining room and bar area is more traditional, while the rear dining room has a classier upscale vibe, with some stunning artwork.  Don't miss the paintings near the restrooms.  They will put a smile on your face. 

I know, that's a lot to swallow before even considering the menu, which is amazing in its own right.  Let me stop here to tell you that whatever you do, do not miss the French onion soup.  If there was ever a bowl of soup worthy of a $15 price tag, this is it. Combine it with some of the best bread and butter you'll find anywhere and a glass of wine from one of the best wine lists in the city, and you've got a starter that will leave a lasting impression.  Pace yourself, because you'll want to experience more mouth-watering creations.

The only thing that matches the food and atmosphere, is the service.  Truly NOLA 5-staresque.  (Yes, that's a word.) 

Kudos to the folks who brought us Le Petite Grocery.  You've set the bar in the Quarter just as you did Uptown, which is no small feat.

I love trader joes - and this one is smack dab in the middle of down-town Media.  (With parking - yay!)

Same stuff as at my beloved Phillybranch - but pomegranate seeds were $4.99 in Media - just $3.99 in Center City.  Odd.

Great frozen meals, too.

LOVE!!!!

There's a reason that Babe's Pizza has been in business for around 30 years.  Their pizza is amazing!  I will never forget the first time that my friends took me here.  I remember driving up and seeing an old, strange looking building with "Babe's" written on the outside of it.  Um, just exactly where are we going?  Once I had a bite of this pizza I was a believer.  The double decker pizza is unlike any other pizza I've ever had.  Imagine a pizza on top of a pizza with gooey, delicious cheese and sauce crammed into most of the crust.  We order ours with extra sauce to make it even better!  You'll be surprised at how few slices it takes to make you really full!  While you're eating your pizza you can watch the model train that circles the entire length of the dining room.  I love supporting local businesses like this.  Babe's make it easy because the owners/workers are SO nice and the pizza is SO good.  If you're coming here on a Friday or Saturday night I would suggest arriving early because this place gets packed on the weekends.

Protip: Babe's has a very small parking lot.  They are located behind an Einstein Bagel.  You are allowed to park in the Einstein parking lot.  Einstein is only open during the day and Babe's is only open at night.  They agreed to share their parking lots.

I wasn't that hungry, so just popped in for a simple cheese slice and a cup of water. Total cost: $2.54.  Total wait from ordering to sitting down?  Less than 5 minutes, during which the slice was thrown into the oven for a crispy crust.

Perfection.

Gotta come back one day when I'm starving to try some of their pasta dishes.

PS: I am a return transplant to the area after having lived out west for the past 20+ years and was so happy when a co worker told me to avoid buying soda when eating out due to some high taxes for sugary drinks. WOW!  Good to know.

Pretty good dinner I had here recently. This place is pretty nice! I went here for a friends birthday dinner and it was really cool looking from the outside. It is right in the middle of Jackson square which is pretty awesome, and they have a ghost table!  

Here they have a pretty cool dining package you can do. For $45 you can order a appetizer, entree, and desert. Myself and a couple others at my table decided to do just this. 

For my appetizer I had the seafood gumbo. This was by far the biggest disappointment for me for the night. The lack of flavor in the gumbo was noticed and it just did not have a lot of taste. The seafood was mostly just shrimps and I did not notice anything else in it.  

For my main course I got the Shrimp and Grits. This for sure was a different take on Shrimp and Grits than what I am used to but it was very good. It came in a large bowl and had about 8 gumbo golf shrimp, and a nice large portion of savory grits. It was a lot of food, and it sat very heavy. I would get it again, but not very late at night and would prob share with someone. 

For desert I got the Bread Pudding. It was very good. It was my friends birthday so they gave her a complimentary King Cake which was a really nice gesture!  

I would for sure go back here and I do highly recommend it!

Suburban hangout, good for shots, and maybe dinner.

PJ Whelihan's - at least on weekends - is full of college types (or folks pretending to be), so hanging here might not be everyone's cup of tea. Still, there's much to like about this sports bar: plenty of seating, flatscreen TVs, and a spacious front area. Did I mention tons of parking?

The Saturday I was here, I was pleasantly surprised to see a DJ spinning. (He wasn't bad.) While there was a good-sized crowd, they must have had the AC on full blast - we were freezing!

Jordan, our helpful server, was fast and friendly.

Celebrating a birthday, we knocked back shots (in classy plastic cups): chocolate cake, dirty girl scout, alien secretion (my favorite), and the time-tested Jolly Rancher. Apparently there's a three-shot maximum? (Not sure if Jordan made that up.)

Their wings were okay, a bit burnt, somewhat pricey for what we got. Additionally, they wouldn't mix wing flavors. (Don't blame them, but I was disappointed.) Try their other bar food, but your mileage may vary.

I was excited when I heard the Taco Bus had made restaurants that served their food. When I finally got a chance to try Taqueria Monterrey I was a little impressed and a little disappointed. 

As far as service goes, it could be better. As Tony mentions, once you order and get your drink you might never see you waiter or waitress again. Not something someone would normally worry about at the Taco Bus since normally you just get your food and eat it yourself. 

They have horchata like the Taco Bus, but it wasn't as good here. I think the jug might have been sitting around because the cinnamon sweet taste was far too strong to really enjoy. The salsa bar had some interesting options, though I preferred their salsa.

I had carne asada tacos, which I always order at the Taco Bus. It was tasty, but I could notice differences in the seasoning/flavoring of the meat and found myself wishing I had gone to the Taco Bus instead.

Taqueria Monterrey isn't bad (and certainly better then some other Mexican options in Tampa), but it isn't really good either.

As a fair-weathered country fan, I even found this tour interesting. I imagine that any huge country fans would be loosing their ish if they went on this!

You get to walk where all the country stars have gone- into the deluxe dressing rooms, up the celebrity back entrance, on the stage and on the little wood circle in the center of it where they all sing. 

The coolest part was the mini mail room. Apparently, fans can send the Grand Ol Opry mail for any of their favorite stars. The Grand Ol Opry saves it and hands it to the stars when they enter. Such a cool tradition! 

The dressing rooms are gorgeous and super fancy. It's cool to see which celebrities choose which dressing room. You also get to take a picture on the stage and there's a great gift shop.

Tony and I went to Publix Super Market to pick up a few groceries. We were in the area and decided to shop here. 
We absolutely love the fact that this is a VERY CLEAN store..and we both agreed that the CHAIN of Publix are always the most clean stores we have grocery shop in.

We noticed all the employees carry a cleaning cloth with them. We noticed that there is always so many employees to help out.  They are so helpful.  The groceries are so well stocked and I love the flow of the stores 

The prices are a little more expensive. A few pennies here and there, and some items about .30 to .50 more but they have a lot of Buy ONE GET ONE FREE items.
I love the Bakery section, The Deli section, well actually all the sections.

The store chain could give lessons to other chains on how to keep their stores this clean and they Rock on Customer Service...
Others like Kroger's ((( which I love by the way)) should learn from them..

Great store..!!!!

One of those special foodie stops when you visit Tuscon, make sure to save a whole lotta dollars and calories in reserve for a visit to Monsoon Chocolate.

We bought a box as a gift, and at $50 for 15 gorgeous signature collection hand painted craft chocolates that is about $3.40 a chocolate.  They can also be bought individually. We grabbed a few bars of chocolate and several bon bons to sample on the spot. They also have packages of dark chocolate covered mango, dark chocolate covered craft marshmallows, and other yummy looking creations in their display case.

Our favorite items include the various jewel tone bon bons that taste as good or perhaps better than they look (which is often not the case for chocolates this beautiful.).  The wall is covered with awards, so you can chose your award winning flavor, including pepper rose, prickly pear carmel, matcha sesame rice milk, and blueberry oat cardamon.  We didn't try their housemade Mexican hot chocolate with crafted marshmallow, but wished we had. The frozen hot chocolate sounds like the perfect hot weather freeze.

Not quite we expected. It's on the road. Lots of road noise. We could hear our neighbors talking, dogs barking, elevator dinging.

All we wanted was some rest, away from elevator and noise. Although we were assigned a room 1 hr earlier than checkin, it did not serve our needs. On the first evening, I informed the desk that we will be leaving the next morning due to the noise. Also, there was a "smell" that lingered all night. Not sure if it was there room spray or something else, but it made me nauseous. 

Bed and pillows were very uncomfortable. And, here I thought we were paying extra for a nicer hotel among 3 in the area. I should have went back to the Clearwater location instead.

Breakfast were wrapped danishes, yogurt, muffins bananas and apples.

Looked like the staff got themselves a pancake breakfast from someone else.

Now we know.... choose Clearwater. 
We left early and headed to Orlando, to a BRAND NEW Laquinta. Quite a difference.

This is really in an old house. The house was built in 1859, and was the first home to be listed on the Chesterfield Historic Register.

You can figure out which room was the family room, the dining room, the sunporch and the kitchen on the first floor. Upstairs are bedrooms and a couple bathrooms that have been repurposed.

One of the bathrooms was full of children's toys, plush animals, pull-toys and the like.

This is folk art, Early American, colonial, Americana -- whatever you want to call it, but you get the idea.

Offerings include scarves, candles (both artificial and real), soaps, quilts, pillows, pottery, linens, placemats, rag rugs and many other soft items.

Some of the real candles had spot-on smells, like oatmeal-raisin cookie, Santa cookie crumbles, lavender, sugar cookie. The soaps smelled fabulous, too: oatmeal, lavender and numerous others.

And they had hogwash soap, which is an all-natural stain-remover. A perfect offering, for being in Hog Hollow.

Lots of furniture.

Earrings and other jewelry that were quite inviting.

Many hand-crafted decorations. Metal works and wood works of pigs, cows and other barnyard animals. Hand-made dolls. American flags everywhere in many varieties and displayed in artwork, on dolls, framed and other permutations.

Many primitive artwork framed originals, some going for upwards of $300.

On the second floor there are three large rooms, including a 10% off sale room. Here, we found Christmas ornaments and decorations (some metal, some cloth), braided rag rugs, lighted branches to create your own wonderland and many other decorative things.

In the kitchen we were generously offered a cappuccino, but we declined, since we'd just had lunch.

The kitchen held beautiful little appetizer forks and spoons; silicon lid covers in many sizes; Wind & Willow soup, dip, salsa, cheeseball and baking mixes; red pepper jelly and green pepper jelly; Texas hot rub; and a colander that works for draining as well as steaming. I was a bit intrigued by that. I believe I was silicon.

A great lot of quality offerings.

Located in a highly desirable spot, but in a very undesirable looking hotel, Bongos was a sharp contrast to it's surrounding, largely run down property. I am sure you've already looked at the pictures and know that you'll get a chance to seat on the beach while enjoying a meal. Although that's absolutely true, I'll write about an element that pictures won't describe.

Fun and friendly staff make the visit worthwhile. You'll get a piece of fish anywhere in St Pete, but finding such great people is hard. The bartender was managing a ridiculous influx of thirsty tourists and doing it in a friendly, efficient manner. All drinks are made from pre-made Walmart shelf mixers, so don't expect anything exquisite. Rum selection is as basic as it gets, Bacardi, Morgan or well. The place has a very typical, average American beach bar feel to it. Of course, that comes included with country music and southern middle class crowd. In other words, people who want to be country, but live in a city like Birmingham, Mobile, Augusta and the like.

Food is fine. Again, standard stuff. The much recommended artichoke dip was pretty good. Seafood selections aren't phenomenal, but there. Lots of fried items as you'd expect at an American beach bar.

The establishment shines of course in one area and that's its location. Right on the beach, it's a perfect spot to watch the sunset and have a beer.

It really IS ALL THAT. Yes, it's small & loud - so if you come on a weekend call in advance and STILL be prepared to wait.

Chef RED did his thing tonight.  As did Steve, our server.
In fact, all the staff were "on point".  The sweet lady who gave us the marvelous bread (infused olive oil with a blob of lemon ricotta in the center) and kept our water glasses full is a doll. The hostesses even helped to clear plates.  Everyone pitched in and ran their asses off!  A great team.  We noticed and we love ya!

One warning - this meal is a diet-breaker.  Nothing we had was "light 'n healthy".  They should have an MD onsite to perform emergency angioplasties.

I had heard of Modo Mio for a long while - but when I tasted the Mozarella en Carroza at the "Taste of Philadelphia" event in July, I knew I had to come here.

Our party of 4 had the 4 course menu and everyone LOVED everything they had.  The house-made pappardelle with brussels sprouts, the bistecca, the skate wing - all of it.

Chef RED even sent out a platter with 6 glorious desserts on it.  Standouts were the flourless chocolate cake, tiramisu (theirs is light and wonderful), pumpkin bread pudding and home-made crusts, cookies, cremes and panna cottas of all sorts.

A near orgasmic experience at Modo Mio tonight.
Only one complaint, at 8:50 PM (We had a 6:45 reservation and were seated closer to 7 PM), they made us leave to seat the next table.  Politely.  Overtly.  But I only had like 2 sips of that wonderful coffee I wanted to enjoy.  Ah well - next time we will come on a weeknight.

WOW!!!!

Can't wait to come back. Can't wait to try Paesano.  (You do own that, right??)

Just the mention of the name Buffalo Billiards takes me back to the early-mid 90s when every summer weekend night ended up with a foray down 2nd Ave.  It typically ended up at Buffalo Billiards or the upstairs Havana Lounge where the cigars smoked and the swing band played.  Ah college!

After moving away for 11 years and getting a little above the age of the usual suspects down on 2nd Ave I could barely believe it when I heard that they were still open.  A friend decided to get togther at BB this weekend and I was pleased to "party like its '95" again!  

Thisplace has changed considerably from the old days but not in a bad way.  Downstairs is now a Dick's Last Resort so gone is the huge room full of pool tables and cute boys.  Upstairs where the Havana Lounge was is now the entirety of Buffalo Billiards.  Don't worry though, it is still a pretty sizeable bar!  The huge round bar still exists and these great big Samsung HDTVs are all around the bar.  (Bonus - they had the one in front of me on the NASCAR race!!)  Tables are also available on the left side of the bar.  In the back is another bar and two rooms with pool tables.  Note that you can reserve one or both of these two rooms for private parties (as I have for my December birthday)!  

They had good 90s rock playing (Soundgarden! Pearl Jam!  Alice in Chains!) which will take you back ,again, in a good way.  The vibe is chill and you can actually hear each other talk.  Drinks were strong - they were not playing around with these.  And all the bartender/bartendress staff I saw were good lookin, so you can have some eye candy with your drink.  Also noticed a dart board in the back too so you can challenge your friends to a duo of bar games (maybe a trio if you play quarters or something?  No?  But it's 1995 man!)

So yeah, I loved the vibe and the whole feel of this place and am glad I have it reserved for my birthday in a few months.  Give it a try if you are downtown and want to get away from crazy tourist traps and Irish-pub-dance-club places!

There's no question that this place is a little sketchy sketch on the outside...and while the interior is no gem either and little to no English is spoken here, and the kitchen is separated with a curtain, and both times I've been our server has been a minor and placing an order here is like picking a number out of a hat, and the most descriptive words on the menu are "three shredded stuff,"  I'm intrigued. This is not your typical Americanized joint. Is it fast? Yes, but that's as American as it gets. Portions are definitely generous and you won't find sweet and sour chicken on this menu...unless I read it wrong. Yelpers in the know of the legit Chinese food directed me CPH. I wouldn't have made it through my first experience without their guidance! 30 shrimp/pork dumplings, 1 pork bun, and 1 order or fried rice later, I got a good taste of MSG free Chinese Cuisine. While China Pasta House literally is a noodle house with most dishes resembling Pho or Udon dishes you can also enjoy Century Eggs, Gruel, rice dishes, Hot Pot and more. The noodle dishes are really soups and portions are huge and spicy here mean spicy, like a level ten spicy. While fellow yelpers broke a sweat over their noodle dishes I peacefully enjoyed my fried rice and Pork Bun. I'd never seen anything like it! So if you love spicy food then this place is for you. You're bound to run into Chinese students and families at this spot. For sure check out the the specials as they feature several soups that are on the regular menu and it's a good way to taste something new and not commit to full-sized entree.  
-If you're not super familiar with Chinese food, it's ok! I'm not either....read the Yelp reviews first!

Great place for a variety of fresh produce.

I got huge, red tomatoes, last Thursday, August 6.

My girlfriend got half a watermelon and tomatoes.

Also available: cucumbers, zucchini, yellow squash, peaches, radishes, cauliflower, plums, celery, cantaloupe, green beans, eggplant, garlic, jalapeno peppers. Much, much more.

I don't know any place where you can get half a seedless watermelon. But they had a half ready for my girlfriend -- all wrapped up -- and it was beautiful. It comes from Sikeston.

The folks are so friendly and personable, as are the patrons.

The address is Delmar, but the open-air market is really behind the shops on Delmar along the huge parking lot that spans east from Cicero's for a couple blocks.

It's adjacent to Midtown Farmers Market.

This location is a bit further from my work than the other Brothers on this service road but they have a better selection of convenience store items but have a puny number of gas pumps.  So it is a great place to get a better selection of coffee along with having fried food items like chicken, fish, crawfish pies, meat pies, french fries and various other items.  It is a terrible place to get gas so I would skip on down to the other location if there is a line here for gas.

I go to Fleming's about once a year.  I know that while it will be expensive, all the food will be good, the service will be friendly, and the atmosphere will be clean and comfortable.

My friend and I sat in the bar - first at the bar for cocktails, and then moving into a bar booth for dinner.  Our server was efficient, although a little slammed with all the tables she had going.  Great deals for happy hour from 5-7 - they offer 5-$6 drinks, and 5-$5 appetizers.  

Taking advantage of the discounts, we shared the pork belly and tenderloin carpaccio to start with.  The pork belly was just okay - the best part of that plate was actually the creamy goat cheese grits that accompanied it - yum!  The sweet onion chutney was just not enough of a contrast with the rest of the plate.

The carpaccio was excellent.   It was a generous portion, sliced extremely thin, with capers and a creole mustard sauce on top,  with cheesy crackers to put it on.  My one wish would have been more 'bite' to the sauce.

For dinner I had the French Onion soup and the small plate of New Bedford Scallops.  This was one of the best French Onion soups I have ever had.  It was baked with both gruyère and parmesan cheeses, with a nice crispness to the bread inside.  The cheese topping was incredible, and the broth was flavorful without being too salty.

I liked the scallops, but didn't love them.  The sauce had flavor, but the scallops didn't really seem to.  I  know, I know, only eat steak in a steakhouse, but I'm a seafood girl!

For dessert  we split the carrot cake.  Since I am a carrot cake connoisseur, I will rate this one 6/10.  Very moist which I love, it did not have even close to enough frosting on it/in it.  I guess that's why they serve it with a side of homemade whip cream - there needs to be some sweetness to contrast the non-sweet flavor of the cake part.  More than just a tiny drizzle of dark rum caramel on the side was needed, too.

Final thought - GET WIFI!  Sheesh - close to the airport, close to many businesses - enter this century and make the upgrade - thanks!

I will preface this review by admitting that we are lucky enough to have a couple five daughters bakery locations in Atlanta, where I actually left. However, I was helping my friend move to Nashville and on our morning walk, we decided to stop by L & L market. When I realized there was a Five Daughters Bakery inside of the market, I told my friend we needed to get a doughnut. I was actually not even in the mood for a doughnut, but I cannot pass by a Five Daughters Bakery without at least considering. We decided to split the pumpkin spice latte seasonal doughnut, and it was really fun to watch my friend enjoy her first five daughters bakery donut. These are just so delicious! The pumpkin spice latte donut was so good! It had a cream cheese filling and they used a bit of coffee to nod to the latte flavoring. I actually only ate about a quarter of the donut, but it really was so delicious!

If ever you've been confused by a review of mine where I gave a popular restaurant with high ratings a low star review... then come to Tito's and see why!!!

So far I've only tried the CHURRASCO SKIRT STEAK PLATE ($14) with yellow rice, but I honestly don't know if I will ever try anything else because it was SOOOO GOOD! Seasoned by angels and cooked with such perfection that I will absolutely crave this for the rest of my life! THIS, my dear Yelp people, is EXACTLY what I mean by "flavorful" seasoning. They have completely ruined skirt steak cooked by anyone else because I can't go back to anything less than this level of satisfaction! Even the Strawberry Banana Smoothie ($6) is excellent!

Tito's is currently located in an empty lot next to the Citgo Gas Station on the corner of North Jones Ave and West Waters Street, but this is also the location of their soon to be brick & mortar restaurant. So if you love New York style Puerto Rican cuisine, rush here as soon as possible and taste heaven on a plate!

2021 / 91

*Mobile Review*

Came here with NYU ADEA faculty and student doctors

Decor: 4/5
-indoor and outdoor seating (mostly outdoor)
-lovely weather but leaves may fall onto your food

Service: 2.5/5
-Service was average.
-Servers had missing or gold teeth
-overhyped, not impressed

Food Presentation: 4/5
Taste: 3/5
-BBQ Shrimp: did they put BP seasoning in this? the shrimp tasted rubbery
-Veal: not what I expected. small portions for the price ($30) and wasn't that great
-Banana Foster: the amount of brandy was too much. I have a sweet tooth so the banana and vanilla ice cream was yummy
-Pecan pie: warm and soft yet not too sweet. This was good

The average rating says it all. Don't expect much from this place. I wouldn't come back.

How often do you find a store inside of a mall that isn't a major chain? I think it might be one of the only ones in Southgate Mall. Sure, there's something to be said for consistency across the malls of Canada (where can't I find a Spring or an Aldo?), but it's such an awesome surprise to find something like this in a mall like that.

The clothes here are gorgeous, with unique details and careful construction. The price is right, too.

Even if I'm not in the market for a new garment, I can usually find a gorgeous new bag or jewelry piece. Dainty necklaces, feather earrings, you know the type. Lots of Matt and Nat stocked in here, too.

Last time I was in, they were having a sale - bonus! Sales clerk was super friendly and explained the price reductions to me. Definitely coming back soon (esp. if there's another sale)!

After a long, long day of traveling (and I mean LONG), it was time for late night sustenance. As per usual, hot dogs were on my mind.

I ordered the Guinness dog and a helping of cheddar bacon ranch fries. My friend ordered the alligator sausage.

I had a bite of the gator, and it was definitely the star of the show. My fries were also awesome, but the Guinness dog had too much of a crazy flavor juxtaposition for me to handle. I left most of it behind.

Bathrooms here are gross, as you may expect. Service was friendly. They also have a full bar, if you're still up for drinking more at your night's end. We were not.

Prices are reasonable, and I'd definitely head back to try a different dog concoction.

Disappointed.  Service was slow and my soup was below average.  We had a large party (9), and it was not too crowded.  Our entrees were brought out at different times, and it felt like 5 minutes passed between when the first and last entrees were served.  Someone in our party asked for lettuce to roll their entree in and the wait staff said "no it doesn't come with that".  I had the noodle soup with seafood (Hu Tieu Tom).   The broth had a nice flavor, but the shrimp were mushy and i couldn't eat them.  I probably would not go back.

Your humble correspondent went here -- don't ask how, sometimes it happens (I've been to Everest Chicago, OK?!) -- and left feeling full and satisfied.

So why only 3 stars?

It just wasn't sublime given all the glitz and hype around the place. You are paying a premium for 'cool' decor that you might see in an Emma Stone movie, but the novelty of that wears off after like 15 minutes. I'm glad they kept the music volume at a level that allows you to talk. +1

Food?! We had pork and chicken dumplings, which were delicious, but the Price-to-Portions ratio (PPR -- metric I invented here) not so hot. Scallops were great, too, but again PPR too high. Even though we blew three dishes, we still felt we hadn't eaten much.

The red snapper was a real bust. Overly done and dry. Not sure if it was an off-night or what, but it just didn't taste good at all. Shoshana refused to touch it, and since I don't like microwaved fish, I had to force it down just to make sure I got full value.

Overall, it's just a 3 due to PPR and hype-reality issues.

Went on a date here not long ago, and although the food was good, the service was excellent, everything (including the date, thank you for asking) was top-notch, I'm not a terribly huge fan.  

It's probably just me -- I'm a vegetarian, more or less, and while they were awesome about making a veggie dish for me (and it was fantastic), I think that this place appeals more to carnivorous dudes than it does to mostly vegetarian chicks. 

Two things that stood out to me, aside from the service and quality of the food, were 1) my wine was served in a juice glass, which kind of took away from the experience and 2) the napkins look like bar rags, which also detracted somewhat from the ambiance.

Meh. I'm not dying to go back, but I wouldn't be opposed if I was with a group and everyone else really wanted to go.

Crema is the cream of  Nashville's crop. Service was extremely pleasant; namely Francesca & Shawn who went above and beyond with niceties. Francesca was such a doll! She was very welcoming and helpful. Shawn made a mean Cortado with almond/coconut milk.

The space is roomier than it appears from the outside. Lots of local goodies: chocolate, t-shirts, tumblers, mini ceramic mugs, whole espresso beans sold by the bag, French Press coffee makers, pastries and of course hand crafted pour over, drip & iced coffee blends from around the globe. 

Seating was prime from the window bar top where you get all the natural sunlight you could hope for, outdoor patio over looking Hermitage Blvd, standing high-tops and bistro tables. There were fresh flowers, water & condiments to set the mood. 

Although I enjoyed the coffee and atmosphere the macaroons were a total fail. Hard, dense, brittle...nothing like I'd expect from such a well reviewed establishment. 

The Training Lab (a room I assume is used for brewing tutorials) is a nice touch. I'd return (just not for the macaroons.)

~Christy

A delicious surprise but not unexpected. I read "Joe's Pizza" took over this place but I was still reticent but today I thought, why not? The delivery man was nice and the pizza came on time. 

I ordered a plain pizza which came hot and thin crusted and a cheeseburger hoagie because I haven't ever seen that on a menu up here in Philadelphia. The pizza was yummy and so was the cheeseburger hoagie. The pizza dough seemed lighter with a thinner crust than from Joe's (we both love thin crust pizza). Frankly we all enjoyed both items and I recommend you try this place because everything came hot, fresh and on time!

We had a nice dinner here late at night. The small plate conch was tasty as was the loaded chip appetizer. The service was pretty good and seemed on time as needed. This place is located near TPA airport. There was plenty of close parking in their large lot. The place was clean and not overly loud. The food portions were large and everything was nice! I would go back here again.

U-FRIGGIN'-MAYZING! I recently tripped it inside M&D with my friend Michelle and her tyke and man was I impressed with all of the wonderful interactive component in this place. It's a children's playground (not great for mommas and papas looking to get a move on) and around every corner there is a little slice of wonderment worth looking into! When had to pick up a little somethin' for Michelle's son who turned 3 last week, I knew exactly where I needed to go. There is a section in the back left corner of the store with insane trucks, front loaders, trackers and fire engines. They have moving parts galore, perfect for keeping the little ones engaged. I had no idea which to get, so I asked the owner what she though (I hate that I can't remember her name) and she pointed to one that was pretty popular. Helpful staff, unique toys and games, a comprehensive play area where you can try before you buy - the place has it all.

Ok I admit it.  I'm a fan of Starbucks!  I have a gold Starbucks card with my name on it.  At my favorite location they make my drink as soon as the Barista sees me pull into the lot.  

So why am I reviewing Old City Coffee?
1. I love the atmosphere.  Way better than that "chain look."
2. The location is great for people watching. (limited vehicle traffic)
3. The food is as good as or better than the chains.
4. The Baristas are knowledgeable.  
5. They roast their own beans in the café.
6. Oh, and the coffee is great!

The coffee here is excellent. My iced coffee had a strong, robust flavor and was definitely made with quality beans. In not a coffee connoisseur by any means, but there is no mistaking this is good coffee.  It was not at all watered down like some places tend to make it. On a rainy thursday afternoon this place is still full of patrons. It seems I am one of the last to know how great the coffee is here! They also offer some pastries and a few lunch options which I will have to stop back in to try. If you are in need of some great coffee while walking on Main St in Manayunk (and want to avoid the cliché Starbucks), this is definitely the place to go.

Out of the places I visited here this was my least favorite spot.

What attracted me here was the music of course.  The singers were amazing and everyone was loving the music.  However, when I walked in there was a typical bar stench smells germy. 

The space itself is huge and food is served.  It is kid friendly..I think bedause there were kids enjoying the music as well.  I ordered a basic vodka pineapple because at a place like this you can't get anything too fancy.   I stayed for a drink and a few songs and then I was on my way.

Hole in the wall joint. Deviled crab is the bomb dot com. One order was as big as my fist. They don't kid around with the crab meat ratio....sooooo much crab!!!

It gets super busy during lunchtime but luckily we only ordered the Deviled crabs which came out really quick. You can use your credit card but they charge you $.95.

Their food sounds better than tastes which was so ordinary but sometimes it's all about the ambiance! The décor is not boring at all with a a good vibe. Our waiter( Zak ) was friendly and full of energy he ROCKS!!! Overall this restaurant left a memorable impression!
Two and had Yelps!

The last time I was in a Texas Roadhouse was in NJ with my family and a friend from Ireland.  This time I was in a Texas Roadhouse in Nevada with the same friend from Ireland.  I wonder if there are any Texas Roadhouses actually IN Texas.

It's lunchtime, it's the weekend, and after a hard morning of shopping for bargains, The Irishman proclaims a need for steak.  This place is just around the corner, so we decide to split a steak and ribs combo.  

First, though, we must conquer the bread rolls.  Oh dear god, why must something that tastes so good be so bad for you?  The rolls were divine, soft, sweet, and with the cinnamon butter slathered on, a fairly deadly combination.  The Caesar salad came out - simple, lots of nice parmesan, chilled.

The combo plate arrived quickly, and we split our order between us.  The ribs were good, but I wish they were a tad bit meatier.  And I'm not a fan of messy barbecue, but this one was certainly worth a few napkins.  The strip steak was done to absolute medium rare perfection, and was so juicy and beautiful that I didn't want to finish it.

I don't rave too often about chain restaurants, but this one has my steak stamp of approval on it.

Here are some facts about Tim Lan, executive chef at Melodia Grill:

1.  His meats are not cooked by a stove or a grill, but by a demon that he tamed as a whelp at 12 years old.

2.  The Melodia chips are not baked on premises.  Instead, Tim wills them into existence every morning before opening.

3.  Cows that know they will become a Melodia Grill burger must be kept away from sharp objects, lest they end their lives early to hurry their fate.

4.  The Sweet Thai Chili Chicken Wrap is a popular export to Thailand.

5.  When asked "Why did you settle in Souderton and not a larger city that might appreciate your innovation?," he will respond in Latin.  All those who have understood his answer are struck deaf.

This is the best restaurant in Souderton.  The rating reflects my feelings regarding this location in relation to other Souderton eateries.

I ordered delivery.

The burger was juicy, crisp on the bite. And the milk bun was soft, chewy, and fresh.

The grilled romaine salad had lots of texture and. unique contrasting flavors. Though the leaves we slightly wilty. Hard to argue with that ordering a salad delivery. Even EMP would have trouble delivery lettuce.

We were celebrating my grandfathers birthday with some pizza and let him choose the place. He chose Pizza Time over in Conshy. They have a Sicilian special (pepperoni, sausage, olives, mushrooms, and green peppers) for under $20! (It was $18.82)

Parking isn't great in the area because there's a bar right next door; I basically had to park on the corner to run in and grab my order. And when you walk in, directly to the left is a steep ramp so be careful! I wasn't expecting it and was caught a bit off guard! 

The people who work there are a bit quirky, but the pizza was good. (And heavy too, the box weighed at least 5 lbs, no exaggeration!) My grandfather has ordered here two other times (same pizza) and has not had any issues! Worth a try if you are nearby!

Why 5 stars? Because the menu is giant and the quality is great.

   ---   ---   ---

I booked this spot a while ago because it had a very strong 4.5 star rating and is close to my house. But recently, I noticed that 4.5 upticked to 5 stars overall, so I knew I had to make it a priority to stop in. We did so today and were very impressed.

We started off with wanting one sushi roll. I couldn't decide which one to go with when our server suggested an off-menu roll called the Roger Roll (named after the owner.) All I really remember from her description was crab with a bunch of other stuff that sounded good, so I was sold. It came out with a bunch of thin, fried... tentacles on top? Not sure how else you'd describe them, but they were delicious and added a nice crunch.

We tried to fatty tuna sashimi next and this was the only unfortunate miss for us. When we visited Tokyo, we loved getting fatty tuna as much as possible, but this was nothing like it. It was warmed and I guess pretty cooked? It didn't really even taste like tuna. I'd avoid this in the future.

Both of our main courses were excellent: pad thai and crispy chicken cashew nut. The pad Thai was a tad sweeter than normal. Our server said she doesn't normally like pad Thai but does like their version - I could understand why. It wasn't wildly different than normal pad Thai, but just a couple ticks tastier than usual. And the crispy chicken cashew nut was also very enjoyable. 

We finished with coconut ice cream and mango with sticky rice for dessert. The mango stick rice was fine, but the coconut ice cream stole the show. Also, our 15 month old acted as if it was the best thing he'd ever had in his young life. 

For the majority of the time, we were the only customers in here, but we did arrive about 2 minutes after they opened on a Sunday afternoon. I hope they have a steady rush of customers because they certainly deserve it!

Made a quick pit stop on our way home back from Atlantic City - we needed to fuel up & grab a bite to eat so we chose Wawa! Plus, my bf had never experienced Wawa food so I thought now would be the best time. This location is full service, meaning they have a gas attendant to fill you up. A lot of gas stations are like this in NJ. The attendant was nice & helpful. After that we went inside to order some food! Wawa has a digital menu you can use to place your order and customize it anyway you like. They have a wonderful selection & serve breakfast and dinner items all day long! Whoo hoo! My boyfriend ended up getting the pizza sub with banana peppers which, no surprise, was amazing!!! He always picks the good stuff! I ordered the chicken quesadilla with mixed veggies which was delicious! We also ordered a strawberry & mango/peach smoothie; they were so freaking delicious. :D The kids behind the counter were very friendly too, and worked well together! All in all, Wawa is the ish. This location was a bit busy for a Sunday but still well managed. 

Favs: Pizza Sub & Peach/Mango smoothie 

Would Change: Not much! Great experience :)

Lettuce Lake Park is one of my favorite natural wildlife parks in the Tampa Bay area. The park is located along Fletcher Avenue, east of USF and just before you hit I-75. Lettuce Lake Park can be found on the northern edge of Tampa, and it protects 240 acres along the Hillsborough River. There's a bend in the river within the boundaries of this park, and that forms a swamp and a small natural lake which is filled with water lettuce vegetation.

Lettuce Lake Park provides a quiet sanctuary for hikers, bicyclists, boaters, and picnickers. There is a $2 per car cash admission into the park which certainly seems very reasonable considering how clean they keep the park and the restrooms. I saw maintenance guys emptying trash cans and mopping the floors in the restrooms while I was there.

There are large public green spaces with playgrounds for the kids, covered picnic shelters with fireplace grills, and wooded picnic tables throughout the park. If you prefer to hike / jog / bicycle then you'll find a trail, complete with a fitness course, which meanders through the park. There's also a 3500 foot elevated wooden boardwalk which winds through the hardwood swamp forest, and eventually brings you to a three-story wooden observation deck overlooking the river and the entire park. You can climb up to the top with the other Touristas Americanus Loudmouthus and try your luck yelling at the turtles and alligators.

More than half of the park's property lies in the natural floodplain of the Hillsborough River, and consists of a hardwood swamp forest (cypress and oak trees) as described above. This unique feature provides a natural storage reservoir for floodwater and it helps to improves our water quality, acting as a natural biological filter to remove excess nutrients from the water. As a result, visitors to Lettuce Lake Park will have the opportunity to observe the pine flatwoods plant communities, and a huge variety of wildlife. You'll no doubt see birds, turtles, and possibly an alligator or two from the safety of the boardwalk.

This past weekend I rented a kayak from the ranger stand at the front gate - $25 for 4 hours - and drove back to the river access area where I was handed a personal flotation jacket, and given a brief safety overview and navigation tour of the waterway. After that I was off, and peacefully paddling along the river, and then just drifting along as I took some photos. I was able to explore the lake area just north of the observation tower, and saw some 3 - 4 foot gators happily swimming along or laying up on the banks. There were turtles galore in the water, and all sorts of fish munching on the water lettuce. Plenty of egrets and herons had already flown south and made the park their winter home.

What a glorious afternoon, and I highly recommend just getting outdoors and enjoying some of the Florida sunshine at one of our awesome natural parks. Hope to see you here!

Mmmmmmm I really don't understand why this is so highly rated. I mean I guess it's an oasis on Bourbon street? 

We were desperate and the only place that was open for food was Mambos. 

Oyster Rockefeller: ok 3/5. Served warm, greasy, looks amazing in photos but really wasn't very substantial not even for an appetizer. Quite expensive considering that. 

Cajun pasta: 3/5... I could make it better at home. 

Bread pudding: 5/5 pretty darn delicious. 

Seasonal cocktail: 3.5/5 while it was delicious it was LOADED WITH SUGAR ickkkk. I just felt like I was getting diabetes drinking it. 

Service was swell. 

This was one of the most expensive meals for what we ordered and it was quite bleh. 

Here's what I recommend: 
- Atchfalaya
- Brennan's for brunch
- Jacques Imos dinner best fried chicken
- Streetcar Cafe for the best Po Boy

I know, the pickings are slim near burbon street, that's one of the many reasons why I avoid burbon street.

They give you large snowball sizes for little money.  They have a selection of ice cream, hot tamales, burgers, hot dogs etc. in addition to just snowballs.  The ordering is very quick but then you often have a very long wait to get your order as many people are ordering for MANY people and get a big box full of snowballs.  Overall its a good snowball at a value price for the larger sizes they offer along with a good flavor selection.

I do not give out five starts lightly. As I thought about this review though, I could not think of any significant reasons to give a lower rating. The hotel reached out to me over a week before our arrival to help us plan our trip. After a quick few emails we had a great trip all handled. They took care of everything.

We opted for the valet, but there is self parking available. From the moment we arrived the entire staff was fantastic. Check in was quick and painless. We always carry out own bags so we chose to do so here. Lesson learned, when we went to leave we used the bell desk. This property is on a hill and large. I recommend utilizing the bell desk staff for your bags.

Our room was large and well appointed. The bed was comfortable. There was a large patio. It had a separate shower and tub, both of which were large and luxurious. There was a nice gas fireplace in the room too. We had it on quite a bit because it was cooler in the evenings.

We arrived late in the evening so we could not really see everything that night. The next morning we took a walk through out the property to check everything out. The buildings are all beautiful. The landscaping team is clearly on top of their game too. The pool area has a great retro feel and has a lot of cabanas.

Each day we took advantage of the hiking trails on the property. They are well maintained and easy for everyone. The scenery is great. It is also easy to take a walk on the beach. The sand is well packed so it was easy even with shoes on.

There are multiple restaurants on site and the bar in the lobby is nice too. There is also a coffee shop. They did have coffee set up in the lobby for free though each morning, so we took advantage of that.

The spa was nice. We did not do any treatments, but we took advantage of the amenities. We both really enjoyed the eucalyptus steam rooms. My skin felt amazing after a few minutes in them. It is also very peaceful. There were hot tubs and saunas as well.

Overall it was a great experience. We may have found our new go to for our trips to Santa Barbara. It is not affordable, but the experience is well worth it.

During Labor Day weekend we went jet skiing at Woody's and decided to stop next door at The Hut Bar and Grill for lunch.

My sister and I ordered the shrimp tacos and my brother-in-law ordered the monster fish sandwich. My brother-in-law's sandwich looked like a huge fish stick and the texture of the fish led us to believe the fish was frozen, not fresh. The shrimp tacos were inedible and may have been the foulest tasting dish I have ever ordered at a restaurant.  I ordered grilled shrimp on my tacos, but there were no grill marks on the shrimp and the shrimp was undercooked.  The soft taco shells smelled really weird... after one bite I could not continue and tried to eat the center of the taco to avoid the shell. My sour cream had yellow liquid in the plastic cup so I skipped using it in fear that the sour cream was spoiled.

It's a shame the food was not better. The music and water view gave the bar a really cool vibe. I really appreciated the misting fans on the deck and all of the waitresses were super friendly. Maybe I would come back here for a beer, but I would skip ordering food here.

If you need a Korean fix, the area of Chesterfield on Olive is the way to go. There are several grocery stores, restaurants, and then this bakery. I honestly don't know how authentic this bakery is, but there is a mix of Korean bakery items, more "Americanized items, and other random Asian desserts. But nonetheless, it's cute and delicious. 

First and foremost, I LOVE the creme puffs from here. They are not as sweet as what you thing a creme puff is in bite sizes. You can get a package of 10 and bring it to the Korean restaurants! They have mocha cakes, lots of sponge cakes in a variety of flavors, and general cakes. And if you want to get someone a gift who loves playing pokemon go, this is where you get your pokemon theme cookies. They also have Hello-Kitty cakes. 

Great place to just stop in and they open late for a bakery until 8pm. There are also a few tables for you to sit and enjoy your desserts too!

I've been on a sushi kick lately. Seriously though, I'm relatively new to sushi and this is the 4th time I've had sushi in the past 4 weeks. That's a lot for me to have one specific cuisine and I've never been happier. 

Wasabi is right off of Wash Ave and has a pretty decent happy hour deal. It's all evening on Monday's and it's buy 1 get 1 free on select rolls and special prices on apps. They're menu had tons of "fun" rolls with a ton of stuff but it seemed lacking in traditional options. If it weren't for the happy hour, it wouldn't be a very good deal financially either. Cafe Mochi and many other sushi bars have better prices. Although, 4 rolls and 1 seaweed salad for $27 is hard to beat. 

Overall, it was good but I won't be back anytime soon. Unless my wallet is cravin' a savin'...

Definitely had more fun at this event than I thought I would! I'm not a beer drinker, so I have never gone until a friend graciously offered me a free ticket. And seriously, everyone in Nashville that I've met in my life was there! 

They have a ton of tents with plenty of beer to pass around. There was also a couple wine cooler type tents as well as a whiskey one if I'm not mistaken. They had some great food options, the stir fry noodle tent was a huge hit with a very long line in front of it for a good portion of the night. You also can't go wrong with Mafioza's pizza either! 

I really enjoyed that they had a live band playing and a grassy area in the middle to bring chairs to lounge. 

My biggest disappointment was that it rained heavily the last 30 minutes or so and they kicked us out of the tents at 10:00 while it was still pouring. That's not very friendly people! 

Otherwise, I had an excellent time!

The second we stepped in here, I said to myself "I like this place!". Black Penny is definitely a local spot, just a bit off Bourbon but far enough away that locals and the people who are done partying by 11PM pop in just to have a drink or two.

The bartender Gio is great and remembered us from the night before. Their beer list is downright impressive. The beer menu alone is nearly 3 pages. There is something for everyone, including your regular beers such as Heinekin and Stella. But if you come here, I encourage you to try a craft beer. It's well-worth it.

Everyone here is so friendly and welcoming. Even if you're "new" to the 'hood, they still make you feel like you belong and will add you to their conversation. The beer prices are also very very good. Definitely a great spot to check out if you want something less crazy and with a more intimate feel.

What a great museum! The architecture is beautiful. Love the sculptures and fountain in front of the museums. Also, the Rocky statue and the famous Rocky stairs!! This is a popular tourist attraction stop. All the hop-on hop-off tour bus stop at this location. 

Definitely a must visit place!

Three stars for ok coffee and friendly service, but it's seriously bordering on two total here. 

I don't eat much, if anything in the AM, so I stopped here to grab a coffee and something light. They have a selection of sandwiches and breakfast offerings, and some grab and go stuff too. I scoped out the selection of protein bars and snacks, which included Clif and Kind bars, and settled on some organic peanut butter sandwich crackers.

I about had a heart attack when I realized these things were nearly $3 a piece. We're talking the same snack size stuff you get ON THE PLANE! $3 for about 10 mini crackers. 

I expect to pay more at the airport but $9 for these two packages and a medium coffee is insane!

My friends and I decided to go camping in Fort De Soto Park on Easter weekend.
We made a reservation on one of their 236 campsites on their website.
I think I made a reservation about a month before the weekend, however almost all the good sites were taken by then.  

The way to the park is absolutely beautiful!  You see the ocean driving on the bridge, and  you see all the nice houses and condos in the area dreaming if you could ever afford something like that oneday in your life.

Every single campsite comes with a grill, a picnic table, faucet and 50amp electricity.
They have nicely maintained bathrooms with showers throughout the sites.  
They have trails all along the shore and there is a place you can rent kayaks and bicycles.  But remember those rentals close at 4:30, so as soon as you check in (the check-in time is 1:00pm) you want to get inquires if you are interested in those activities.  We actually could not do any of the stuff since we stayed only one night and did not get there early enough.  You can fish from the shore.  There are lots of fish called "Panfish".  There are birds just walking around, ducks, and of course racoons!  Actually we got some of our foods eated by squirrles tho.  

The only downside is the price.  We did pay close to $50 dollars: $45 for the campsite including county tax, seasonal tax, waterfront charge etc, $1.5 for the toll boothes for 2 cars,  and $3 for a fire pit.   However you do not have to pay for the $5 parking for park visitors.  Thank God!      

Although the waterfront costs more (prob like $5 or less), you really want to book a waterfront site in Area 3.  Area 3 is no pet and all campers including RVs.  Even if you have tents,not RVs, you still want to book a waterfront in Area 3.  Why?  Because Area 1(only tents) does not really have waterfront sites, even tho they say they do.  Area 1 waterfront sites are far from the shore and they have trails between the shore and campsites.  They also have trees on the shore so you cannot see any water from the campsites.  On area 3 waterfront campsites, you have an immediate access to the water.  Do not worry!   Even tho the sites for RVs, you won't be surrounded by them because there are trees between each campsite.  

P.S.  There are mosquitos somewhat in April.  Even tho I was the only one who got bit by mosquitos, there were at least 5 bites on my legs.  I did spray bug repellent but I was wearing shorts.

Trivia Tuesdays = win

I love Trivia and the Lodge just started doing trivia on Tuesdays.  There were only 4 teams and the top 3 teams got money off their tab.  I guess I shouldn't write too much about it or else it is going to get busier!

The sangria here is pretty good and only $5 during happy hour.  That can get pretty dangerous.

I also got the Seared Tuna Appetizer and it was delicious.  The cucumber salad underneath had a nice crunch and pickled taste.  I also got to try the Apple Cobbler with Ice Cream and it was pretty good.  My fiance got the steak skewer appetizer and loved it.  However, there are only 3 skewers to an order, so to really fill up he ended up ordering two.

The parking is kind of hit or miss.  Sometimes it is valet and there are not too many spots.  Luckily, at 6 p.m. on a Tuesday it is not valet and there was enough parking.  I honestly hate parking on SoHo, because I never know where people actually tow.  You can park all the way down in Hyde Park at the free parking garage and the walk is not terrible, if you want to put your mind at ease.

On a whim Mrs. K and I came to The Pasta House.  Our server was really amazing.  Mrs. K. wanted no onions on the salad and of course I wanted onions.  So Mrs. K. came with no onions and I asked for and received extra onions. 

I ordered spaghetti with meatballs and Mrs. K. ordered their Chicken Flamingo.  My food was just perfect and Mrs. K. was too.  She asked for almost a custom dish no mushrooms, no broccoli, light sauce.  It came just she wanted it.  

The reason for the update is to acknowledge how The Pasta House has become very accommodating in their service and food presentation.

The Arlington is more than just a venue where you can catch a flick.  The theater itself has character and charm, and I'd go out of my way to watch a movie here over a more convenient place with less of the above.

I watched Avatar in 3D at the Arlington and it was a very pleasant experience.  Because the theater is old, it only has one screen and a whole lot of seating, including a balcony, and this set-up gives the place a wide-open opulent feel.  The inside walls are built to mimic a quaint village and the ceiling is painted with stars.  The result, instead of being cheesy, is really just pretty.  The screen isn't the largest and the seats aren't the most comfortable around, but nothing is substandard and the loveliness of the place more than makes up for anything lost in the way of modern convenience.

The lobby and exterior are beautiful as well, with cute hand-painted signs, a courtyard, and a free-standing ticket booth.  If you're strolling through downtown Santa Barbara without the time to stop for a movie, the theater is still worth a peek.  It's a wonderful place, gorgeous and unique, and I'd love to come back and catch another movie under the stars.

I watched Mockingjay here opening weekend.  It wasn't busy at all and the parking was plentiful.  

Popcorn was cold...probably from sitting around due to lack of business.  Blah.

Once getting into the theater, we found seats without any issues.  Ok so the seats...they were the most uncomfortable seats I have ever sat in at a theater.  They were absolutely terrible.  They reclined way too far back which made for rally awkward posture and balancing acts during the movie...especially one that lasted over 2 hours.  I thought maybe it was just the chair I was sitting in...so I tested out 4 more.  Nope...they were all terrible.  The cushioning was non-existent.  Double blah.

The screen and sound system were the usual.  No issues there.  Cleanliness was good.  3 stars.

Monster Meaty Sandwiches!!

Bold sandwiches bigger than your mouth with a giant portion of meats require both hands, ton of napkins and ... I know that sounds clunky but I would say, fork and knife! So yah be prepared with a teenage boy huge appetite!

Dirka Dirka on Jalapeño cheddar bread was what the lady on the cashier recommended to me! 
A pile of griddled, tender and nicely caramelized corned beef and pastrami draped with a thin slice of melty swiss cheese and topped with seasoned Jalapeño coleslaw, fresh pickles and a splash of yellow mustard on a nice crust and chewy inside tasty baguette! Is this the longest sentence ever or what!!

My Kat got the Sicilian on sourdoug while my sister got the Steak and cheese on blue cheese bread!  "It taste good!" .. that's what they said!

Freshness .. is the key here! Large selection of fresh breads, meats, cheeses, condiments and toppings for cold cuts sandwiches and hot options like phillys and meatballs is a big plus! 

Quick and friendly service! They don't skimp on on the portions/quality and charge a fair price!

Full Belly Deli is absolutely on the right track!

Came here on a whim to get away from the city a few weeks ago during the change from spring to summer. As classic as Santa Barbara gets, we happened to show up during the Summer Solstice Celebration, without even realizing it was even a thing.

The obvious cue was how congested the place was when we got there. It wasn't even 11 AM on a Saturday and many streets were closed off, at least the ones around the center of the city where the celebration is held.

Parked in a place that offered free parking for the first 75 minutes, and walked on over to the area for the celebration. Lots of beer present, but as I was driving, I could not partake in that aspect. But I could see the abundance of performers, and the throngs of people finding a way to move along as the performers went ahead in a slightly muggy but otherwise cool weather day.

Finally the celebration ended around early afternoon at least from what I could see. 

As this seems to be an annual event, I can't exactly suggest to Yelpers to check this celebration out next week let alone next month, but I'm sure this event repeats annually. Check Google and Yelp around next summer!

There's nothing better than raging in downtown Reno, drinking some tasty cocktails and brews with buddies and suddenly realizing it's 11PM or later. Why rejoice at the late hour you ask? Because it's the perfect time to for some preventative medicine at Golden Flower! 

Grab a table and get ready to fight off that hangover with a banging bowl of pho, some delicious imperial egg rolls, or one of their cold noodle dishes! On this last visit I'd had enough liquid courage to allow me to order the most daunting dish on the menu, Bun Bo Hue, a spicy noodle soup made with a rich, complex, and meaty broth, packed full of all the best animal tidbits like well-done flank, rare beef, tendon, and oh yes, blood cake! The version here does tendon right! It cooks for hours in the broth until extremely tender, all the while absorbing the rich flavors of the stock. Andrew Zimmern would describe it as meat jelly, and I'd concur. If it eats like that, you know it's good! The blood cake is harder to describe, but it turns out it was way more a textural thing than a flavor. Kind of thought it would be a little different, but eating it is worth the shock value! I'll be back for more of this soon! 

But slide a big bowl of that up right next to a big plate of the chicken wings they have on their late night menu, and that is a match made in heaven! My fiancee, who enjoyed her night just as much as I did ;), only ate a tiny bit of soup that night before we went home. The next morning, Bun Bo Hue #FTW! Hangover be gone for me, and well, lets just say she wasn't as happy!

Took a short weekend trip to SB, I was looking forward to ending the day with a delicious meal.... unfortunately things did not end well. For a restaurant with such good reviews and was recommended by so many, I was extremely underwhelmed. 

The combination of ingredients in their dishes just don't pair well in my opinion. My tastebuds were confused and not happy 

Saddest part of my night- the A5 wagyu was as chewy as a piece of ribeye. They should not advertise this as wagyu, nothin tender about it. 

I'm still upset we wasted our night out at the Lark.

Sweet little tea shop that gives you a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the town square area.

Their teas come from all over the world and are different varieties so you have options.  You can also purchase tea accessories for that caffeine lover in your life.

Bubble tea is probably the most popular thing.  They have the oversized straws that you put in your tea cup that allows you to suck up the globby gooey flavored tea bubbles.  If you have glooby things you should stay away from bubble tea.

The prices are really affordable for the quality.  The staff is very knowledgeable so if you have tea questions don't hesitate to ask.

I get a mean craving for Vietnamese every once in a while, and I immediately thought of Pho Grand when the craving hit last because I always drive by it but never go. One of my favorite things to do on a weekend rainy day is pick up something delicious to go and bring it home while watching all of my shows on DVR... pure heaven. Pho Grand was a great addition to that equation.

I called Pho Grand and placed an order for pick up and the guy on the phone was really nice, and he gave me a wait time of about 15 minutes. I got there about ten minutes later and scored a parking spot right out front, walked in, and my order was already ready! Also, $13 for an appetizer and an entree? I'm definitely okay with that. 

When I got home I found that they packaged the food in a great way to where everything was still hot and nothing was running all over other things... that's a common problem when I get things to go! For an appetizer I got the veggie spring rolls, and wow. I know for sure that I'm going to be craving those again sometime this week. They were so fresh, so full of veggies and rice, and if you're a cilantro lover like me you'll be very happy with these. The sweet and sour sauce was pretty standard but a nice compliment, and the lady who gave me my food made it a point to tell me to use the s&s on both the rolls and my entree. For the main course I had the Ga Xao Xa Ot (stir-friend chicken with hot chiles and lemongrass) and it was just alright to me. It was kind of sweet which I didn't really like, and I wasn't crazy about the taste of the chicken. Luckily, the two huge spring rolls filled me up plenty.

I like this place quite a bit! Next time I'll try and dine in to see what else they have to offer. If you're craving a good spring roll or want Vietnamese with really fast service, Pho Grand is your place.

It's located on the Indiana Statehouse lawn. In its simplicity and brevity, this one packs an emotional wallop. 

It's a rectangular stone monument with a subtle wood grain design and an inscription.
