The powerful inscription is a nineteen word quote from President George W. Bush spoken on that terrible day.

"Terrorist attacks can shake the foundations of our biggest buildings, but they can not touch the foundation of America."

The monument was donated by the Bybee Stone Company and Independent Limestone Company on 7-11-02

Can you say LUNCH omakase??? Second time that I've been to Japonais Bistro and I have to say, it is definitely growing on me. Really down to earth restaurant with delicious food (although be prepared to wait). It's all about quality over quantity, err'day.

Anyways, we went for lunch on a Tuesday and all three of us decided to get the lunch omakase ($20/person). So instead my usual ramblings and excess overwriting, I'll let the pictures do the talking (everything was top notch).

As you can see, there was a variety of items to devour :

- Miso soup to start - not too salty. Perfect way to start our meal off on a cold September day.
- Rice and seaweed salad - I could eat this seaweed salad all day
- Chicken karage - crunchy, perfectly fried and tender/moist in the inside
- Salmon and tuna sashimi - nice edible sizes. Tasted very fresh.
- Oysters - not sure exactly what kind they were but they were slightly on the sweeter side.
- Salmon collar - cooked perfectly and very tender
- Tuna tataki - came with with roasted garlic pieces and red onions
- Seafood ceviche - pieces of octopus, shrimp and fish. Couple of chips to eat the ceviche with. Om nom nom.

Japonais Bistro is a solid, solid spot just west off the downtown core. Definitely a great spot to check out and a classy atmosphere to boot.

Books as far as the eye can see. It just keeps going and going...and then goes some more. This, my friends, is a bibliophiles dream. I spent an hour just taking it all in without a specific list of books I wanted but found some goodies that I couldn't leave without. If you love books and love to browse for books this is the place to be! 

It's very organized and everything is categorized well (especially for a used bookstore) so my OCD was happy, too. If you can think it, they have it.   

They also have games, old vinyl records and toys. I didn't have any interest in those as I was here for the books, but it all looked organized as well. 

Love, love, love the book exchange program and you can bet if I lived in Nashville this is where I would be 90% of the time!

Gather 'round, friends. I'd like to tell you the secret to finding decent Mexican food in Indianapolis. It all starts with finding a restaurant with a name that has nothing to do with anything remotely Mexican. Find a restaurant with a gringo name, and you might find someone in the kitchen making good Mexican food (i.e. Biscuits Cafe, Chris's Ice Cream). 

But let's focus on Biscuits Cafe. Does that sound like a good Mexican place to you? Of course not -- why would it? Mexicans don't eat biscuits. It's just not a thing. However, they make really good Mexican food at Biscuits Cafe, so you should visit to partake of their Mexican food. 

(Although, I've heard they make awesome biscuits and gravy, too, so you should come for that if you feel in the mood. They serve breakfast all day!)

We got the chicken tacos al pastor and fajita platter, and both were really good. To me, the sign of a good Mexican place is whether they have good rice and beans. Rice and beans are the backbone to any Mexican meal, so if they are good, then that sets the tone for the rest of the meal. Fortunately, they have excellent refried beans (covered with yellow cheese, as they should) and Mexican rice. The rice doesn't have peas and carrots in it, by the way. My chicken tacos were served with diced onions and cilantro, and I was given two huge bottles of house-made red and green salsa to use at my discretion. The green salsa was mild, and the red salsa had a chipotle bite to it and was a little more spicy. Both were really good and went well with the tacos. 

The fajitas platter comes out sizzling, so be careful when touching the plate! My husband said his fajitas were really good. 

My kids got pancakes and bacon. (I know, right? I mean, we're at a Mexican restaurant ... but what are you gonna do. Kids, dude.) They loved their pancakes! The pancakes come three to an order, but they are kid-sized and come with your choice of meat (bacon or sausage) and fruit. They even provide you with warm syrup to drizzle over your pancakes. My kids ate most of their meal, which is unusual because they usually leave at least 2/3 of it on their plate! Wasteful kids! (Heaven love them.)

Like most Mexican restaurants, Biscuits Cafe gives you complimentary chips and salsa when you sit down. Both are excellent and addicting, as chips and salsa at a Mexican restaurant should be.

Giovanni's Pizza is a Italian shop on York Road in Jamison, Pa. They do a big pizza business as suggested by the wall of pizza boxes awaiting use in the entrance hall. When I asked one of the guys behind the counter how many pies they do a day, I was told anywhere from 50 to 300! Quite a range, but they were getting ready for the high end when we were there by cutting up the dough and placing them in small aluminum canisters. 

The house itself has two dining rooms and can accommodate quite a crowd. It is clean, and service is prompt and friendly. We ordered a single plain slice to see how they do with their most basic commodity, an eggplant parmesan sandwich and a burger with onions and mushrooms.  Nothing stood out as exceptional, and some things need work. 

The plain pizza is average in size and taste. Mine was a reheat job, well done. They got that right, and the crust was nice and firm with a mild scorch on the undercarriage. There was too much cheese for me, and not enough sauce. Really could not get the flavor of the tomatoes due to cheesy dominance. Pizza requires the right balance on top to make it stand out. This did not do it. The eggplant parm sandwich was in a large torpedo roll, again covered in copious melted mozzarella. The nightshade itself had a heavy breading that absorbed a lot of oil in the frying.  Would have been better if just sautéed in olive oil without the extra breading, but was still okay. The burger was disappointing. A frozen puck, cooked to well done when medium was requested. Dry and tasteless, despite the additional sautéed onions and mushrooms. Even the ketchup couldn't save it. 

This was a late lunch, and we didn't explore the dinner and pasta options, which may be as good as the other reviewers report. Still, I can only write about my experience, which was not quite middle of the road.

2.5 Stars.

Yum!  This place can certainly rival Georgetown Cupcake. So many tempting flavors... If only I was in town just a little bit longer!  And... They are just $3.00 each. Take that, all you DC cupcake boutiques! (That means you, Sprinkles!)

I lucked out by choosing a hotel near the shopping center where this cupcakery is located. Yes, cupcakes are all you're gonna get here, but don't frown; they are delicious! The best thing about the two seasonal ones I chose is that they were super moist. I'm a good daughter, and I shared both my treats with my mom. I did scrape off some of the avalanche of super sweet buttercream frosting from my diabetic mom's portion.

The Charmed cupcake was better than your average pumpkin spiced cupcake with cream cheese frosting, and the Spoiled Rotten was a delicious apple spice cake flavor with apple cider buttercream frosting. It also had a caramel topping and toasted pecans.  Once you try this one, you'll be spoiled from boring, ordinary grocery store cupcakes forever!

Next time I visit Nashville, I'll make sure I make it to the 'Burbs to sample more flavors from IveyCake.

Okay, how did I not know about this spot for the last year or so that we've lived in Tower Grove East! I'm going to come out and say I am no comics, nor superhero, guru... but this place is cool as hell! 

Did you know that, although this spot is primarily a comic book store, you can come here, hang out, and enjoy a beer or canned cocktail while listening to comedy? And not just any beer, too. They have beer from Against the Grain Brewing Company, Modern, Earthbound, UCBC, and Old Bakery- just to name a few. Naturally, the also have Busch- so you know who was obviously right at home. On Saturday nights they'll sometimes have local stand up comedy shows. 

Obviously, the place is full of comics. They have new books, classics, and local work too! If you want to pick up local gifts for the holidays or a friends birthday, this is a great spot- which I wouldn't have guessed! I've got my eye on this cool black and white map of Fox Park. 

I really enjoy this spot and am excited to come back soon.

I had a blast visiting the renowned Jackson Square during my first trip to Nola! This adorable lil' area is extremely close to the original Café Du Monde, along with several fabulous bars and shops nearby, and hosts plenty of artists throughout the week. 

I stopped here and sat on a bench facing the monument of Andrew Jackson, and enjoyed live music that was being played nearby by a band that was sitting in the square in front of the cathedral. It was slightly dirty around some of the benches -- however, this space is actually pretty clean considering the fact that I didn't notice anyone who looked like they were hired to keep the area clean or keep an eye out for litter. 

I'm sure there's so much more history to Jackson Square, but the ghost tour I took where we met here to start didn't mention too much on it, so I have a lot to learn! If you're looking for a lively stop in the French Quarter, for live music, art, or even a tarot card reading, I highly recommend stopping by Jackson Square!

Satisfies my Asian baked good needs, but I think we came at a time when there wasn't a huge selection.

Looking at other people's pictures, I think we just happened to come when they didn't have a lot of variety. We were there at 3 p.m. on a Sunday, which I will admit isn't prime eating time, but since they are open till much later I thought they would stay pretty stocked. 

They were out of egg tarts, which I read was a hot commodity. We ended up getting a matcha mousse, pork bun, cream bun, milk cream bun, and a buttermilk cream bun. I don't eat pork, so I didn't try that, but I tried everything else. 

I liked everything enough, but I've been to bakeries that have more variety and taste better. I felt like a majority of the options was the same bread just different filling. However, after seeing other pics I think they were just out of a lot. 

The matcha mousse had a good matcha flavor. It was more of a cake though. Honestly, I would have liked just the top mousse part and done without the crust! 

I will definitely come back if I'm in the area to see if there are different options!

I went back again on Thursday ! There were some changes to the menu from the last  menu that I saw!  I went with my sister and my niece. We started with the garlic bread , we always order it because we can really taste the garlic! They had steamed clams, I do not remember them on the last menu. The were excellent, not at all rubbery! Very tasty! The soup was a cocanut curry cauliflower, very smooth and tasty! I  could not pinpoint any one of the ingredients , how ever as always in the past found it very enjoyable! My niece had a baked penne with chicken. It looked yummy,and she said that it was very good . My sister had the rib eye ,with mashed potatoes and asparagas.She was very happy with it ,cooked perfectly! I went for the herb crusted tilapia,with artichokes , mushrooms,and roasted potatoes! A combination that I would not have thought to put thgether ! It was wonderful,they complemented each other perfectly! It was fairly busy,and not very noisy for as busy as it was. Service was excellent as we have always found it !  Still one of my favorite restaurants !

You really can't get better scenery than the serenity and beauty inside the Nevada Museum of Art. The white room with large windows has amazing amounts of natural light, and it almost feels like you're seated outside, and the high ceilings let noise carry and dissipate, giving a sense of privacy in a very open space. 

I find Chez Louie to be a great meeting place for all those reasons and more. The food is easy to eat and enjoy. You can be dainty and not feel weird. Ya. I said dainty. So when a wonderful new friend suggested we meet there for lunch I was excited.

I've lunched at Chez Louie twice, and both visits have been enjoyable, but to be honest, I'm waiting for the WOW factor. On the first visit I enjoyed the "Plate Lunch", which is a beautifully presented meal featuring the soup du jour, salad, half a tartine (open faced sandwich), and a small dessert. It was good, and left me satisfied me for lunch, touching on the savory and sweet parts of the palette, but I found the price tag a bit out of reach for me on the regular. On this recent visit, I tried the Jambon Brioche, a hot black forest ham and brie sandwich, served on housemade brioche buns, with apricot jam. I had the frites as my side, served with a delicious tarragon aioli, which was honestly my favorite part of the meal. The sandwich was good, piled up with sliced ham, but the thin slices of brie had been over melted and the bun actually had a little bit of char to it as well. It was tasty, but when compared to other meals I've enjoyed in Reno for $13, it just didn't measure up. 

Maybe you pay for the atmosphere at Chez Louie, which is why I'm tempted to give it the fourth star. Sitting in the atrium and enjoying a glass or wine or beer would be nice any day of the week, but the food has left me wanting more. I've had some really amazing things prepared by Chef Shakka before, so I'm hopeful the menu will continue to evolve overtime, but I'm also prepared for the reality that maybe French bistro faire isn't going to deliver it for me though.

The Getaway is a cool spendy new Key West style tiki bar off Gandy next to IC Sharks just over the bridge in St Petersburg. I don't frequent the Gandy area of St Pete much because it's a bit Redneck with the dog track but when I heard this place opened i had to check it out.  There is usually live music or a DJ. People can dock their boats or pull up their kayaks or paddleboards on the sand. Urban Kai offers paddleboarding rentals here for $35 per hour and kayaks for $25 per hour. There are two bars and plenty of seating with views of the water. The bartender Kristen was very nice and attentive. They have a large selection of tropical cocktails for $9: the Painkiller, Key West Rickey, Getaway Margarita, Skinny Coconut breeze cooler, Mai Tai, Cabbage Key Creeper, Mojito, Hemingway Daiquiri, Sunsetter, Islamorada, Banana Caipirinha, Swizzle, Macdill Grog, Dark N Stormy, Pins Colada, Strawberry Daiquiri, and $11 Zombie. I had the hurricane and Macdill grog and they were pretty good. I have to detract a star as $9 per drink and $6 for wells is a bit pricey. I also have to detract a star for the parking lot. It is terribly sandy and bumpy. The beach isn't large enough for lounging out, just sitting. Will have to come back to try their new food menu.  Thanks! :)

Fido is a cool local spot in Hillsboro Village which was converted from a pet shop to a cafe (hence the name Fido). I'm not sure why my feelings about Fido are lukewarm compared to everyone's rave reviews. Perhaps my feelings are my fault for ordering just a latte and a salad which were just "okay" but nothing that I would feel excited about to get again. 

Their menu does have a lot of options and they have some nice looking specialty coffee drinks. They serve breakfast all day (a bonus for me) and Fido is definitely a hip hang-out spot for both Vanderbilt and Belmont students, locals and tourists. 

Overall, a fine choice for coffee or a meal. I prefer Frothy Monkey over Fido and their vibe and menu is pretty similar.

This review is for CVS, but moreso for the 'Minute Clinic' that saved me yesterday morning.

I felt like dog dirt for two days, and NEEDED help.  Especially since I didn't want to miss any work time, due to many summer hours I'm taking time off.

SUMMER COLDS SUCK !!!!!!!!

Kim Brunnet, NP, cared for me during this visit.  She was kind, pleasant, and we had a nice conversation about Vitamin D, the weather, Florida, and animals.  (She had on an adorable pair of flats w/ Dachshunds on each - one half of the body on one shoe, the other half, on the others - sooo cute!).  

Kim was genuine and patient as well.  

I was dx was a double ear infection and a virus.  Fun times.  She had my meds (with my okay) sent to the CVS pharmacy, literally and DUH, right there.

Sooo convenient!    Within a few hours on the antibiotic, I started to feel a bit better.  Today, even moreso :) 

$8 co-pay w/ my killer health insurance plan and out I went.

I would GO OUT OF MY WAY to go to this location again for this Nurse Practitioner!  

As for the actual store - very nice and organized / clean - great red and white colors - as all CVS's.  

I spied a bagel place in the same cute, little center that may need some looking into!

I don't generally review chain department stores, but there is something special about this Super Target that just takes it over the top.

First, this is a SUPER Target, which means that in addition to all of those wonderful Target values on clothing, housewares, and cleaning supplies, you also have a full-fledged grocery store with some pretty terrific deals on fresh, fruits, veggies, frozen, canned, and packaged food. You won't find a butcher shop or fishmonger, but they do have a lot of pre-packaged meats.

You'll find this Super Target just south of the intersection of W. Hillsborough Avenue and Montague Street, which puts it real close to people who live in Westchase and Town & Country. The store is huge, very clean, and open late -- all great pluses in my opinion. Since this place isn't right around the corner from my Carrollwood condo I'll usually wait till I have a good shopping list, and then combine my trip to Target with  dinner out at one of the many restaurants in the area.

Such a great addition to the food scene and Oro Valley area! And such a fitting name too! Love it. The menu features Banh Mi (aka French influenced Vietnamese sandwiches . There are  six different options ranging from 
 BBQ Pork, Grilled Chicken, Lemongrass Beef, Tofu. All Banh Mi are served with pate, jalapeno, cilantro, mayo, pickled daikon/carrots, cucumber.  You can opt out of pate and mayo to make the tofu vegan. 

We ordered three to try! Not sure when we'll have time to go back! We ordered the lemongrass beef, Grilled BBQ Pork and the Tofu.

Our favorite was the Grilled BBQ pork. The tofu tasted a little runny- not sure if that's the standard way of serving it. THe bread was warm and crispy and quite good. I hear it it sourced from Ghini's Le Baguette bakery...which is awesome! 

I enjoyed the rose milk tea for dessert. It was plenty sweet and extra floral! I have my eye on a few other boba items for my next visit. 

You can order online, here on Yelp or just call it in!


.

Definitely the best Di Bruno's in the city! Prices are high but quality is good. The staff is always super friendly. The guy in the cookie department is well acquainted with me, hehe. Their hot food is always delicious. Can get a little packed so try to avoid at peak hours.

Another Labor Day Weekend = Another Rib Cook-off at the Nugget
It was time to roll out my "PETA" shirt....and practice some stomach stretching!

Here's this year's breakdown of some of the obvious similarities and differences from years past:

Similarities.......
-The competitors.....representing different parts of the country
-PETA (People for the Eating of Tasty Animals) was out in full force!...Huge crowds as usual.
-Bone Daddy's BBQ was a hit again....taking People's Choice this year
-Sauces and rubs for sale.  We definitely stocked up!
-Street vendors (probably more tents this year).  Great variety of items for sale from crafts to ShamWOW!
-Live music on different stages while ribbin out.....and some dancin too!   
-The fresh squeezed lemonade, fire roasted corn, Texas-style tators, humungus beer-battered onion rings, and beer were our choices of staples this time around.  I guess I didn't have enough room for the usual funnel cakes, fried zucchini, and pulled pork fries. 

Differences........
-Reigning champ Joey Chestnut lost to Pat Bertoletti in the Rib Eating Championships.
-Armadillo Willy's became a new competitor this year (didn't place).
-More funny t-shirts for sale that said: "I'm a Master Baster" and "My Rack Is BIG.........In Japan"
-Only tasted ribs from about 14 different companies, instead of our usual over 20 tastings.  Ribbed out early this year!
-I noticed that many of the ribs I tasted were dry this year....weird!?!
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

My favorite competitors this year were Awsom Aussies, Checkered Pig, and Porky n Beans.  I chose them because their ribs stood out with mouthwatering sauce, meat falling-off-the-bone tenderness, noticeable smokerings, and overall taste.  Sadly I didn't have a chance to try this year's winning rib from Desperado's.  Damn lines!!!

Can't wait till next year!  I smell a Labor Day UYE trip brewing up...

The Winspear! What can I say? A fabulous venue for many concerts that I've seen over the years. Michael Buble, Hawksley, the ESO and others. (And MB even touched my hand! That alone is worth 5 stars.)

It's a beautiful hall with a beautiful pipe organ, great drinks and friendly staff and bartenders, clean bathrooms, and there isn't a bad seat in the house. Seriously. Even the lobby is a great open space with huge windows all along the front.

Oh, and it's a great wedding venue, too!

After a long car ride home from North Jersey, the last thing I wanted to do was go back out in search of dinner. We placed an order with Slice, and within 45 minutes dinner arrived. One small signature salad and one large margherita pizza came to around $25, with free delivery. 

The dressing for the salad came in a side cup, which was great because there were no soggy bits. Just fresh arugula, dried cranberries, gorgonzola and pine nuts. The pie, on the other hand, was definitely soggy. Some time in the oven helped significantly, but shouldn't delivery pizza be ready to enjoy when it arrives? 

Nonetheless, I do like Slice and I'll give some of their other pies a try the next time we order.

If you enjoy waiting in line at amusement parks you will love the wait at MacDintons. Wait to pay your cover, wait to get your drink, wait to get into the bathroom... this place is a zoo! The $10 happy hour is a great deal, but by the time I manage to get my bracelet and stand in line at the bar for a drink I am lucky to get 2 drinks. Not to mention the happy hour rum & cokes taste like rubbing alcohol!  My suggestion is to skip the bracelet line and just order a beer. 

MacDintons is a great scene for the poor college student, but I have outgrown this crowd. There are so many better bars in South Tampa for young professionals.

I'm so ashamed of myself for not yet reviewing this location! I LOVE the Brandon location ever since it opened. So when my parents moved away from Brandon and to Town n Country, I was glad to have this South Tampa location also.

Just as I (probably) said in my Brandon location review, Green Island boba is THE BEST and my favorite! I always compare other places to Green Island, and rarely do the others ever win. They just know how to cook the tapioca just right and make the drinks with the correct flavors.

The only thing is that this location does not have frozen yogurt like Brandon. So you don't get to add some fro yo to your smoothie to make it creamier. They also have separate rewards cards, so you can't use the Brandon punch card at the Tampa store and vice versa.

I feel bad for the girl who is all alone on her shift when I come in because I always roll in with friends and family aka almost 10 people. So she gets bombarded with our orders. Poor girl needs help! We always have to wait, so it's nice to have the games to entertain us.

We love Twistee Treat! We have been coming here for years and the ice cream is delicious, the staff is friendly and we always have a wonderful time! Twistee Treat is a FL chain restaurant and you can identify them by the giant ice cream cone that they sell there ice cream out of! 

Twistee treat have shakes, cones, sundae's, and blizzard type ice creams. We normally get milk shakes and cones when we go! I love the cookies and cream milkshake! It's super delicious and always taste good. I hey always put whipped cream on top and a cherry! 

My nephew and niece also get the hand dipped cones and those taste really good on the hot summer days! The strawberry ice cream dipped in cherry is so good! 

We love Twistee Treat a lot! I highly recommend this place and I highly encourage you all to check it out!

Would I let them perform surgery on me ? No. 

Still a way better facility then the old VA hospital !! Well lit and very clean. Most of the folks working are even a bit more personable then they used to be. Still long waits for appointments to get into VA. 

Not a fan of the pharmacy or how long it takes to get appointments but the rest is a substantial improvement!!!

They have a Starbucks coffee inside and small shop inside and a gymnasium as well.

The urgent care is solid and although the wait was long there they solved my problems.

This shuttle service was recommended by both the website for the Sheraton Philadelphia Downtown hotel and the conference I was attending, so naturally I chose it when I got to the ground transporation counter (baggage claim) at PHL. Picked up at Terminal B/C first, and stopped twice more at the other terminals before leaving the airport, total of 6 passengers took awhile for everyone, at least an hour for me. The van itself was questionable - torn/ripped seats, empty chip bag on the seat, three pine-tree air fresheners, huge crack in the windshield, and the shakiest plastic parts (e.g. cupholders below windows) ever when In motion! Also, not sure if this is typical due to the relative location of the airport and the hotels, but the passengers who needed to get to residential addresses were dropped off first, and then the hotels. This made for an interesting drive through parts of Philly I probably would not have ventured to on my trip at all:  narrow streets, evasive driving maneuvers, double parking. A little plastic stool to help get in/out the vehicle topped it all off. Then again, it did only cost $10/person to Center City/University City so you get what you pay for I guess. I paid cash, and the only receipt provided was just a blank business card with a handwritten amount. Just saying, quite misleading and not what I expected especially based on the company website and recommendations. I did not choose to use Lady Liberty on my return trip to the airport, instead caught a cab.

Sur La Table makes me smile.  They have rows upon rows of exquisite Kitchenwares.  This is the place you will find everything you need to host a perfect dinner party.  It is able to sell to the cook and to the party planner alike.  Le Creuset Cookware to Salt Blocks for the grill to pie weights speak to my inner cook.  Table Clothes, tiered serving trays, and holiday table decor speak to my inner party planner.   Barware, roasters, coffee makers, knives, specialty salts, aprons...if you need it Sur La Table has it. 

Sur La Table is a beautiful store with helpful employees.  This is the type of store to come for gift giving.  In Plaza Frontenac you can find it one the second floors near Neiman Marcus. 

I shop their catalog, their website, and their retail store.  They have a customer for life in me.

This was the first time my toddler didn't shriek and cry during a hair cutting session! It was amazing. I'm still in awe. 

The kind woman who cut my kid's hair put on Daniel Tiger's Neighborhood (they let you pick whichever show you want from Netflix, or, if you have an older child, they can also choose to play video games), and my child shut the heck up, sat still and let the woman cut his hair. Hooray for TV! Hooray for kid-centered hair-cutting places that have TVs, too!

This Cookie Cutters has a giant slide to play on while you wait, which was awesome because trying to get young children to wait patiently is ... let's just say it's very difficult. They also have a touch-screen game to play with, and a reading area with a chalkboard table, with lots of chalk and an eraser. There were several kids books available for one's reading pleasure, although I didn't see any kids in the reading area, because hello, there's a giant slide there that needs attention. Physical play almost always beats quiet reading time when you're younger than 5 years old.

We walked out of there with two haircuts for about $27 (not including tip), which is a little steep but worth it for our particular situation. (When you have a baby who will not tolerate haircuts, you will throw money at the situation just to get it taken care of.)

One interesting thing is that they do "mommy and daddy" haircuts here too, so if you're in need of a trim, you can get everyone looking tidy in one shot.

Performance Auto Group, otherwise known as Tampa Window Tinting on Google is the top rated window Tinter on Google with a 4.9 star rating and there is no mystery why. As summer time approaches, it's been so hot I needed to tint my car to protect the interior leather and stay cooler. They quoted me $60 under another shop for ceramic Tint and had an available time slot to install the tint the same day as I called on a Saturday! Ceramic tint is amazing because it provides 92 percent infrared heat reduction versus 50 percent heat reduction with a carbon or metallic Tint. For a 2 door sports coupe the metallic tint is only $120 but can cause degradation of phone, Bluetooth, and GPS signal. For $180 you can go with carbon tint that does not cause degradation of signal and gives 50 percent heat reduction. To step it up even more you can go with the ceramic film for $245 with Ceramic 92 percent heat reduction. The owner has a infrared gun to demonstrate the difference in heat with different tints when you slide it over and the ceramic is cool as a cucumber. So you know I was sold. Performance Auto group has an air-conditioned waiting area with leather couches, car magazines, free Wi-Fi, and a Blu-ray player where you can pick your movie while you wait. Performance Auto group is located off Hillsborough near i275 across from a family dollar, Performance Auto works complete auto repair, and 1 block from Howard ave. Performance Auto group also offers alarms, stereo upgrades, wheels and tires, hid upgrade kits, and led interior lighting upgrades. Installation only took 1 hour and the wait wasn't bad with their nicely equipped waiting room. All their tints come with a lifetime warranty against fading or bubbling. I highly recommend getting Tint with Performance Auto Group! It's definitely made a big difference and kept my car a lot cooler!

I was greeted as soon as I walked in. Drew seated me, gave me a menu and asked what I wanted to drink. I went with coffee and water. I am slow looking at menus and Drew checked back a few times before I made my choice. I had the Pastrami Blue Burger and was offered the cup of soup that I was going to order as my side for a slight up charge. The soup of the day was a potato, corn and ham, it sounded interesting so I tried it. The flavor was good but the texture was a little bit grainy. I ordered the burger medium-rare, it was closer to medium. The pastrami was a little bit bland and the blue cheese overpowered the whole thing.

They did a good job remodeling, the China Star that was here before felt kind of dark and sleazy. This is now light and open with fairly comfortable seating.

I will wait a while before I go back to give the kitchen some time to work out the rough spots. Drew did a great job, he tried very hard to make sure it was a good experience. They have potential, but they need to step it up in the kitchen a little bit.
Great little breakfast stop in Santa Barbara.  Parking can be a challenge.

So after seeing all those commercials in the Miami market, and with VAGUE memories of the one we had in Homestead wayyy back in the days, I had the opportunity to try one during a business trip to Florida's West Coast. 

If I only had eaten the Strawberry Sundae, this would undoubtedly be a 5 star review. Served to the brim in about a 20 oz cup, it was filled pretty close to the trim with a thick sweet vanilla syrup, a substantial balance of strawberry syrup and a cherry on top (literally). Heck, I'd be more than willing to overlook the extra ten cents they charge for the berry. Even the chicken burger is 4, 4.5 star territory. The portion is adequate for the price, and the seasoning has a mild kick to it. They listened to my opting out of mayo, and were generous with the BBQ sauce (very important for me.)

However, I have to take a star and half off for the fries. The portion was small for the price, and the taste too plain almost as if they had  just refried frozen supermarket fries.

4 Stars in total, since they get an extra 0.5 for the cute waitress on roller skates!

All vegetables (not fruit) are 50% off from Jan 1 - March 31 every year!!!
It is a terrific deal and we now buy 95% of our veggies at Linvilla (includes tomatoes which technically are not a veggie).

Love the winter veggie sale!

Also in 2016 apples (many varieties) are 69 cent per lb!  Stock up!!!!!

Every single wonderful review is accurate. Worth the drive from a 100 mile radius... spend a few hours. Beautiful gift shop and outdoor cafe/garden. The self guided tour is a must ... it's included. Don't think of walking through without the wonderful narration. The Frida Kahlo exhibit was an absolute delight and so informative. Do what we did and walk over to Engine No.9 for a dynamite burger and then head towards the Morean Art Center and check out the hand blown glass and catch the exquisite works of Dale Chihuly. Watch the film and marvel in this seemingly impossible art.

Woodfire Grille is known for their Nashville Hot seasoning flavors which you can choose which flavor you want on your entree. The setting has a casual but comfortable ambiance with a bar area separated from a dining area. My friend and I decided to come here spontaneously on a Friday night for dinner and we were seated right away. Little did we know it was "Live Music Friday" and we were about to get an amazing show! We intended to just come here for a bite to eat but ended up staying from around 6:30 until 9 pm to watch the live music. Shoutout to Birdsong & Paula Chavis they were amazing! They got the crowd singing along to tunes like Marvin Gaye's "Let's Stay Together" and other fun tunes, which we really enjoyed.

I ordered the shrimp entree ($11.99) which you can choose grilled or breaded shrimp with two entrees. I got grilled shrimp tossed in the lemon pepper sauce with a side salad and sweet potato fries. My friend got the Nashville Hot Tenders ($9.99) with fries and a side salad as well. We both enjoyed our food but I wish they had given me more shrimp! It really wasn't a very big serving. The drinks were nothing too special. I got the Tennessee Lemonade which was just a spiked lemonade. My friend said her cocktail was okay but neither one of us was crazy about it. 

The only reason I did not rate Woodfire Grille higher was the service. Although our server was nice he brought us our checks without asking if we were finished, then we had to tell him we actually wanted to order some post-dinner drinks and stay to listen to the music. After that, it took forever for our drinks to come out and our server said he was bartending and serving everyone which was crazy! It was definitely not his fault but I hope management reads this and knows to schedule more employees at peak time.

This truly was one of the best dining experiences of my little life so far. The turtle soup is as good as everyone says, the pecan encrusted fish was dreamy, and the souffle was puffy and chewysweetspicy and I could eat it every day. The champagne and wine recommendations were crazy good. 

Most outstanding and noticeable of all is the quality of service at Commander's Palace. Nothing compares. Everyone who wants to work in service should train here. Every single person we walked by who works here in any capacity gave us an incredibly warm welcome like we were dear old friends and beloved regulars. Every person at our table of 10 received personalized recommendations and considerate, focused, attentive care. The way each course is served, with synchronized, balletic precision, is breathtaking but then the moment your plate is placed in front of you, your waiter checks in with you to make sure you have what you need in this distinctly Southern, friendly, unpretentious way that makes the choreographed moment so much sweeter. 

The design of the original dining room took my breath away, and the garden room was lovely too. I'd love to eat at the table in the wine bunker someday, but since the president sat in the garden room I can't imagine who this even-more-exclusive room is reserved for... Beyoncé probably. I can dream.

What a neat place Hotel McCoy is. 

The murals are what stand out immediately. So many colors. Beautiful artistry. Why don't more places do this?! Just don't hire the homewrecker that is now my "wasband's" girlfriend. Please. Two middle fingers up to her all day long.

Then there's the super nice staff members.

Tokens for free adult beverages.

The small pool looked refreshing, but we didn't partake as it was lightning and thundering upon our arrival, then we simply ran out of time.

The room ($101.71 for a double queen room - I called for a better rate) was cozy and clean. Had everything we needed.

Then I ordered our complimentary breakfast the next morning via email. It was at our door within about a half hour. The boast "the world's longest oatmeal bar." Kind of funny, but true. Here's what I ordered:

1 oatmeal with:
Dried blueberries 
Granola
Pecans
Flax seeds
Brown sugar
Cinnamon
Whole milk

1 toasted strawberry poptart & a toasted cherry

2 Juice boxes 

1 tea

The parking lot is bright at night time with well-lit lamps so if someone is snooping near your vehicle you can see them fairly clearly. The spots are numbered so you may park in front of your room conveniently.

Elegant restaurant with good food and service.

Strawberry Manilow $12
French Onion Soup $8 - Good soup.
Fritto Miso $12 - Good mix of tempura vegetables
Ravioli $25 - Rich and savory ravioli.
Seafood Fettuccine $26 - Noodles were a bit too al dente.

.|\---/|
| o_o |
.\_^_/..2021
Cheap tickets for $5.50 matinee. Definitely an older theatre. iIt reminded me of a theater from back in the old days of black and white movies. I could of definitely been a fan of that.

CASH ONLY! 

Ok now that that's out of the way, we came here over Mardi Gras weekend for lunch. The line was out the door! I thought this was just because of the heavy holiday weekend traffic but it looks like it's always like that from the pictures on their Yelp page. We waited in line, half way up it, people at the front of my group start yelling to the rest of us it's cash only. Do we all have enuogh cash? No. Some had no cash at all (me). So, we leave to go to an ATM, come back, start the line over again. My "po boy" is $13. Whatever.

Food: I got the Shrimp Po boy and I will say they loaded up the shrimp, which was good. The bread was nothing special and the lettuce was like the shredded Subway stuff. Why on earth would anyone pay $13 for this? This place is just for tourists I think. I can't imagine why anyone who lived there would frequent this place.  

PS- this might just be me being a total "tourist" but isnt a "po boy" the same thing as a "sandwich" Lol?

This is my favorite restaurant in Dunedin and I've been here a few times over the years.  I was seated at the bar this time and enjoyed talking to the chefs and watching them make my food.  I had a delicious swordfish au poivre and a sumptuous chocolate cake dessert that had strawberries and, surprisingly, also beets.

There is a lot to be said about first impressions, and while I enjoyed my food, I can't look past a few details, hence the 3 star.

Upon walking in, we were not immediately greeted.  We had to sort of stand by the bar and wait for a "How's it going" so that we ask to be seated.  The gentleman stated we could sit where ever we liked, so we opted for the bar.  First thing I noticed was that the bar was dirty and sticky.  Then, we were handed menus that looked as if they'd never been wiped down.  Additionally, my menu had an ant running around on it.

At this point, I was very reluctant to order, but because we had a direct line of sight into the kitchen, I decided to go for it.  The kitchen looked clean and in good order.  

I ordered up an old fashioned to drink, and to eat I got the hummus platter as well as the chicken skewers.  The hummus platter was pretty good.  It's served with 3 types of hummus: black bean, regular and red pepper.  The pita chips are fried, and I found that a little weird, but they weren't bad, so I pressed on.  The chicken skewers had great taste, but they were dryer than the Mohave during the summer.  Had they been juicy, we could potentially be talking about some of the best around.

La Chica ordered duck wings, of which I took a few bites and wow.  Those jokers were tasty.  No gamey after taste either.  I highly recommend those above all else I sampled here.  Maybe bring some wet naps too just in case everything needs a quick wipe down.

I've been to the 12 South location several times and have loved it. So when I heard they had a second location, I had to go. The new location is on Charlotte so it's much calmer than 12 South. I recognized the building right away because it very much resembles the 12 South building. The best thing is they have a big parking lot! You should have no problem finding a spot. 

When walking in, it's about the same setup as the other location. You grab a menu, walk up to the register, and order your food/drinks. You order individual tacos so you can try several different types. They take your name and then you sit wherever you like. I love the interior of this place. Very clean and simple but beautiful. I especially love the patio area. It's heated in the winter and it looks like in the warmer weather they can open the windows. 

Within 5 minutes of sitting down our chips and queso came. My favorite part. Their queso is soooooooooooooo good. I dream about their queso. 2 minutes later, our tacos arrived. I always get the brisket tacos. So juicy and delicious. My boyfriend got the Memphis taco and an enchilada. The enchilada is smothered in a red sauce and cheese. Yum. Everything was so good and it's all at a great price. The staff is always really friendly and the owner has greeted us at both locations. I love love love this place and will for sure be a regular.

What's not to love about Citygarden?

From the Arch, out past the Old Courthouse, and quite a bit into downtown, lies a small oasis of greenery and art in the world of commerce and capitalism.  There are some lovely synchronized fountains which play in patterns, and attract excited children to dare to be splashed in the face.  Old people routinely gather on the periphery and smile as they remember their youth.

There is an oversized Pinnochio reaching for the stars, there are 2 oversized rabbits that remind you of Alice in Wonderland, there is a sideways head of Alexander the Great that is hollowed out for kids to explore but yet on the edge of a flat water "fountain" if it can be called that.

All this, intermingled with greenery and thoughtful landscaping.  

A wonderful place to escape from the city, be it on a workday or on a weekend.

Oh, and the price is right, too.  Free.
Felix's. The strength is by far the oysters. Nice charbroil, comparable to Drago's. Nice fried. Good gumbo and turtle soup.

This station is super convenient to I-10. 

There are few things in life that are guaranteed. I know most people say death and taxes, but I'm talking about needing gas and having to pee. Since I frequently find myself in need of gas and a bathroom when I'm in The East, I often come here. 

Gas 

This Shell branded station has a boatload of pumps. Don't let that make you think getting gas will always be easy, because it won't. Unless you come really early you're likely to find every pump occupied. I've also noticed a trend of folks getting gas and then abandoning their car while they go inside. This means I skip the station when it's full. Waiting for someone to return to their car is an exercise in frustration. 

Bathroom

The bathroom here is awful. I'm not sure if it's lack of cleaning or just so many people using it. But it stinks and is never clean. Making matters worse is the lack of hand towels. All there is to dry your hands is an old hardly working hand dryer. Most of the time I wipe my hands on my pants. 

Staff

There are more workers here than almost any station in the city. They just sell their entire inventory daily as they're always restoring something. It's like an obstacle course to get a water or to pee. 

Should you go?

If you need gas and it's not packed, yes you should. If it's packed or you need to deuce it up, hell no you shouldn't.

I checked out Steam Boys for lunch yesterday, and I thought it was a decent lunch. I do think the menu is really limited: bao, dumplings, and soup. That seems like a lot of options maybe, but for bao, there's vegan and there's pork. And that's it. (They do offer steamed or fried bao.) They have a few lunch specials; I ordered the bao sampler lunch combo, which  is described as "any two steamed bao and any seared bao" for ($12.00). I was brought four bao (1 steamed vegan, 1 steamed pork, and 2 fried pork). The way I read the menu, I thought I was getting three bao, but maybe I read it wrong (or maybe I ordered paid for an extra; not exactly sure what happened). With tax and tip, it came out around $18, wasn't quite the deal I was expecting for a lunch combo, but definitely not a terrible price for lunch in Nashville. Of the bao I tried, the steamed pork bao was easily my favorite. The steamed vegan bao was pretty good - big chunky pieces of vegetables (napa cabbage, shiitake mushrooms) that were pretty flavorful. I definitely preferred the steamed to the fried, but that's just my preference generally (I like the texture of steamed bao better). It was an a-okay lunch: nice, casual eatery with plenty of seating, pretty quick service (you order at the iPad at the counter), and pretty good food. I liked it, and I'll probably come back with vegan friends and family (since I'm always on the hunt for vegan eats for them in Nashville), but I wasn't blown away by the menu or food. But there aren't a lot of places making bao in Nashville (I previously lived in Houston where bao are everywhere, it seemed), so if you're craving them, check out one of Steam Boys' locations (one in Donelson and one in Germantown).

This is the Apple Store. There are many like it around the country, but this one is ours. In it you can find demos of all Apple products, the "genius" bar and some of the best people watching this side of the Mississippi.

Products - If you're interested in becoming an Apple fanboy like me, you can play with all of Apple's latest devices in the store. Here is my one word review for some of teh products I played with:

27" iMac - Badass (bought one)
iPad Air - Badass (have the old pre-air, still badass)
Watch - Dumb
iPhone 6Plus - badass (have one)

"Genius" bar - This is where you go to get your device repaired when something goes wrong. Despite my fanboy status, I will admit that these things can, and do break. Depending on when you make an appointment (do this), your wait time will vary. I've waited as long as 45 minutes past my appointment and other times been seen right away. Appointments will usually remedy the situation and are free if it's under warranty. They are usually so efficient at fixing your device that I am considering paying for Apple care for my next device. My main issue with the "genius" bar is that this is the only place for miles where you can get a warranty repair done. Because of that, the place is often packed which leads me to the next part of my review.

People watching - Oh. My. God. The Apple store attracts people from every nook and corner of society. If you like people watching like I do, just stand around towards the front of the store and enjoy. Here are a few of my favorites and the names I gave them:

Moby - A man who looked remarkably like the singer sat across the packed store staring creepily at me for at least 30 minutes. Making matters worse was his legs spread as wide as humanly possible. Dude, no one wants to see your jort covered crotch.

Full diaper baby - Hey lady, your kid has a diaper that is obviously filled with something. Having him crawl all over the table top is pretty gross.

Gutter punk - Dude, take a bath and stop wearing Capri pants. They clash with the anarchy patch on your jacket. 

The end.

I tried the al pastor and lengua tacos and found them to be flavorful traditional style. They have a green squeeze bottle salsa and a punchy red sauce that is flavorful and quite zippy. This is a dicey place with a small TV.in the corner and pasted up wall posters of various Mexican celebrities and sights. Sombreros. 

There is a large side room with a bar stand and three pool tables. The lady told me Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays that room is open and people pool from 4 p.m. until about 2 a.m. I look forward to returning to try the sopes and torta. The pool room has some fun decor too, mannequins, and a.variety of poster art including funny scenes such as Obama serving a platter of tacos and legendary comedians. I did not see Donald Trump.. Viva Mexico!!!

This location is still just teetering along with inconsistent service and often being very slow to get orders out.  The French Quarter location is much more on top of their game than this location and literally I could drive down and find a parking spot and walk to the Quarter location and get my food faster than I did on my last visit to this location so to say I was forced to wait an inordinate amount of time for my order would be an understatement.

It's been ages since my last visit to Wing Chicx so I figured we'd give it a shot, especially to see how it would hold up against all the new KFC joints that have opened up lately. That and all my go to Korean places were closed Monday.

L and I got there just before the rush and were able to snag a table. I don't know what Wing Chicx's deal is but either their layout is terrible or they need to train their staff better because we were asked to move once we had settled down along with another couple to make room for a larger group. Wouldn't have been an issue but the rest of service was terrible. It's a rarity that I complain about service but woooooooow, dreadful would be putting it nicely. 

There were two waitresses working the front but they were running around like headless chickens. Or maybe they were hiding in the back, I have no idea. Sure, it was busy but it wasn't packed. I have no idea why/how it was so hard to take our order, re-fill our waters (that didn't happen), and to process our payment (had to ask multiple times for the bill). 

- Banchan - pretty standard stuff. They brought out kim chi, bean sprouts, braised potato and pickled daikon. The potato was the tastiest of the four side dishes. Good luck getting any refills.

- Jap chae (#32) ($11.99) - pan stir fried sweet potato noodle with beef and assorted vegetables in their special soy sauce. My bud's never had jap chae before and I've never had Wing Chicx's take on this Korean staple so we ordered it. It was pretty average. I'm not a fan of the cabbage that they throw into the mix. Can't help but compare how much better Korean Grill's version was.

- Original bulgogi beef (1D) ($16.00) - bulgogi beef with mixed vegetables marinated in Wing Chicx bulgogi soy sauce. Again, I wasn't very impressed. It was almost identical to their jap chae dish except that there was more beef and an unnecessary, excessive amount of cabbage. And seriously, what's with using the exact same vegetables? I know times are tough with increased food prices but yikes. At $16.00, our most expensive dish, I wouldn't order it again.

- Chicken drumsticks ($10.99) - they were out of full chickens (we wanted to get half a chicken for $15.00) so we settled with their 6 piece drumstick option. These came out PIPING hot. You've been warned. The skin is hot, crispy and evenly battered while the inside is tender and juicy. Pretty good but you need to get a side of the sweet sauce to jazz up the flavours. We asked for extra sauce but that never came. Easily the best dish of the night and price is on point. I prefer their half chicken option as you get a variety of cuts and it just soaks up the sauce better.

- Seafood pan fried pizza (8-S) ($12.99) - assorted seafood and mixed vegetables battered together and pan fried. It came without the vinegar soy sauce that usually accompanies seafood pancakes, which they didn't bring out until we were two thirds done. Of course, we weren't able to flag them down to tell them this so we gave up and ate it without. Sadly, It NEEDED sauce to save it. The pancake itself was mediocre. Lacked any crispy texture (read: kind of mushy) and the amount of seafood inside was laughable. 

Pretty disappointing. This was one of those times where bad service really can affect your food experience. Food was above average but it's no longer on my list when I'm thinking of going out for Korean food. Too many choices these days to have to settle for mediocrity. If you go, make sure you order the dishes they're known for doing well and you should be okay.

I am  not sure I have the words to describe this experience... Some landmarks are hype of a long gone memory.. This place is a living and breathing icon. This place is a cathedral.... This place is a religion.

My sister had surgery at Summit Surgery Center for a rotator cuff tear. I was her designated driver but also her POA. We were both extremely pleased with the care and skill provided by Dr. Yau--after all, arthroscopic surgery is one of his specialties. We found his entire team to be welcoming, friendly and helpful during this time. 

A shout-out particularly to Cara and Amy at the surgery center front desk, along with her pre-op and recovery nurse Emily S. It was a wonderful experience and often businesses like surgery centers don't receive the acknowledgement it deserves. We came back a few days later after her follow-up visit to give the staff holiday cupcakes. Thank you!

Charming place for cocktails and breakfast. Although they are open till midnight! Woohoo. We had the banana foster French toast which was super delicious and textures melting in your mouth & the breakfast board. Simple and delicious. Save room for wedding cake! Omg! 
#bakerybar

2.5 Stars

Decent Thai food with some good items, and some fails.

Fried tofu to start with was marginal - it was very bland with almost no flavor, and didn't have the silky interior that I love. However, the Larb Gai appetizer, chicken mixed with chili powder, scallions, mint leaves, Thai herbs and lime juice served with sliced cabbage, was outstanding, with a fabulous, fresh flavor.

For my entrée I had the Amazing, which was anything but.  Served cool, with a cloying, sweet brown sauce on top, it was almost inedible.  I sent it back to be warmed up, but that just made it even worse. My boyfriend had their special fried rice which he liked, but they must have gotten their 'heat level' confused, because his ordered medium was extra fiery.

Service was just okay. They had two waiters in the restaurant, and while they were attentive at first, that dropped off as more tables arrived.  It's been ten or so years since I tried this place, and it will probably be that long before I go back.

California girl searching for delicious tacos in the Midwest!  I definitely found it at Bakersfield Mass Ave.  My boyfriend and I were there on a Tuesday evening.  It wasn't too crowded, but the tables were packed.  Luckily, we walked in at the right time and a belly bar table opened up.  

I really liked the ambience.  It's noisy, but not so bad that you have to yell at each other across the table.  It's everything I expect a hip whiskey/tequila drinking institution to be.  Couple that with delicious street style tacos, BAM I'm sold! 

Service was excellent.  Our waitress was very sweet and offered lots of great suggestions.  Between the two of us, we got a couple drinks, Chips and Queso, and a few tacos each.

The Chips and Queso were yummy, but it got a little too heavy towards the end for me.  My boyfriend loved every last bite of it.  The chips were really addicting.

As for the tacos, we got Fish, Hongos, Pollo Rojo, Pork Belly Pastor, and Short Rib.  It's great that they make their corn tortillas in-house.  I loved loved loved the pork belly.  It was flavorful, slightly crispy, and cooked to perfection.  The short rib taco was delicious as well.  Highly recommended!  

I also ordered the sangria which was made with rose and a moscato.  It was refreshing, but a  little too sweet for my taste (should've known with the moscato).  

Other details:

Not a huge restaurant, but they can accommodate larger groups if you plan in advance. 

Clean bathrooms. 

Paid street parking.  Plentiful on a Tuesday evening, but may be a little difficult on weekends.

Located near tons of other shops, restaurants, and boutiques.

Overall, I had a positive experience.

I've used Hufford's Jewelry since I moved to St. Louis in 1979 and my watch battery died.

Since then, I've been back for many other watch batteries.

My husband and I got our wedding bands here.

I've gotten some modest jewelry. And a sterling silver cup engraved with my daughter's name and birthdate when she was born.

Whenever I've gotten jewelry on vacation, i.e., out of the country, I've taken it to Hufford's for an appraisal. 

And a dear aunt gave me a bracelet she told me to get appraised for insurance purposes.

The appraisals are always meticulous, and beautifully and accurately describe the pieces.

Their jewelry displays are incredibly enticing. Service is friendly and knowledgeable.

This was our first time here and I was surprised with the large, eclectic selection of furniture and home decor. They have a great selection of furniture for most homes from current trends through traditional. Every inch of the store has furniture, home accessories and accent pieces to compliment each room from ceiling to floor. 

We were immediately greeted as we entered the store. The saleswoman was friendly and asked if we were looking for anything in particular. We weren't at the time but I love browsing furniture and home decor stores. I love getting decorating ideas and adding a few pieces to update my own space.

Unfortunately when I did have a couple questions the salesteam was busy with others. I could have waited longer but they weren't life or death questions requiring answers that very minute. If I were purchasing I would have made a point to wait.

Prices varied from average prices to overpriced. There was a nice sale going on when we were there. I'm going to be in the market for new sofas soon so I'm going to begin following their sales. The eclectic selection made browsing fun for me and I look forward to returning in the future.

acme oyster house really really reallyyyy is as good as they all say. 
stellar reviews from thousands of yelpers means good stuff. 
i didn't even like oysters before this trip. i'm now an addict. 
damnit.
you will be too. try it. i dare ya.
the po'boys and hush puppies and gumbo aren't too shabby either. 

had the raw and the chargrilled oysters... i actually preferred the raw. 
whatever you do, don't leave NOLA without eating oysters here at least once.
 
yes, there's a line. yes, you're probably on vacation and don't feel like waiting around in line. DO IT ANYWAY. trust.

Pros:
- Pet friendly
- Super comfy bed and pillows
- Free WiFi
- In walking distance to the Galleria
- big flat screens
- indoor pool
- Nice lobby with pool table 

Cons:
- Rooms a tad small
- Doors are heavy as heck, our bathroom door didn't close all the way
- no shuttle service
- weird set up, our bed was next to the bathroom with just a thin wall in between, you can hear it being used
- no breakfast included
- not much space in the parking lot, had to park by the gym.
- bathroom sliding door had broken mirror pieces, was so scared that I might step on it.
- loud AC unit

My friends and I were visiting New Orleans for a service trip and wanted to try out a local brunch place and this came up on Yelp as very positively reviewed. We were staying in Chalmette, so the drive was a bit long but the food was well worth it. There was street parking (free and metered options) nearby, which was convenient. 

When we arrived, the restaurant was already packed, but luckily we were seated within a few minutes. In total, we ordered the pumpkin spice pancakes (one order  definitely serves 2 people), cheese grits, freshly squeezed orange juice and grapefruit juice, and eggs creole, which were all scrumptious, hot, and fresh. 

The service was quick despite the busyness of the restaurant, and the waitstaff was friendly and attentive.

Great place for brunch! Definitely worth a visit if you are (or even if you are not) visiting the Touro neighborhood!

I had a very enjoyable visit to Yogurt Mountain. They had some very fun, tasty and interesting flavors. It certainly helped that I was with Boon, Grace, Fernelly and Rachel who are always entertaining..

Nate was friendly and helpful and I started off with a few samples. Didn't love the pomegranate (not pomegrantey enough) but the cookies and cream, coffee, yellow cake, and birthday cake were all good. The original tart wasn't the best I've had, maybe on the sweet side? but it was fine. The watermelon is SUPER interesting and fun. 

The toppings are also very playful. lots of sweets like gummies, chocolate covered gummies, licorice strands, sour strips as well as fruit. The price seemed quite reasonable for what I got. The place was pretty busy even late and it's nice that it was open late enough for us to enjoy. Seating was comfortable and the decor is nice. Well lit. People were friendly. 

If they had mochi and the blackberries were a lil better looking I would give it five stars. No WiFi also a lil disappointing. And I like fresh mango and kiwi toppings. Makes me believe I am being healthy.. But otherwise it's definitely a super fun place with a lot of variety, taste and fun. Definitely go with Boon, Rachel, Grace, and Fernelly if you can.

One of my favorite local pizzerias has just opened up it's Westchase location, and I couldn't be more excited because they use Grande cheese.  I walked in tonight during their unofficial opening and chatted it up with the owner, Freddy, for a bit.  He advised me the official opening is tomorrow night, so I'll have to place an order to support these guys.  If you've eaten at their Ybor and Hyde Park locations, you know they have a good product. 

When I was walking out, they offered me a free slice.  I brought it home, and tore it up.

Bruno, who was here before, had a good product, but not as good as what these guys offer up.

We really enjoy the Metro Diners. This is my first visit to the Plainfield location which is directly in front of Mejiers on Dan Jones Road.

The hostess was pleasant with a warm greeting and I only had to wait a few minutes since I beat The lunch crowd. The restaurant has ample table and booth seating plus patio seating and first come counter seating. 

Everything on the menu is served all day from open to close. This is a great place for brunch whether you prefer breakfast, lunch or dinner. Friends and family can have a large omelette, creamy shrimp & grits to scrumptious chicken pot pie anytime of the day. And if you fancy a glass of wine, beer or mimosa with your meal then your in luck. I'm also happy to say they serve Coke products here.

Today I ordered the Greek Omelette with feta cheese, black olives, tomatoes, spinach and I added mushrooms. They have always served generous portions of everything we've ordered and the omelette was no exception. It was stuffed with oddells of black olives, mushrooms, creamy feta cheese and fresh spinach. The serving of hash browns were the width of the plate and served with 2 slices of toast. I ended up taking half of my meal home for lunch later.

The service is always excellent from the hostess, the servers and even the bussers.

If you're looking for good comfort food in a pleasant atmosphere with good service then definitely give Metro Diner a try.

A newer WOB location nestled away off of Causeway in Brandon. It's a standalone building that shares the parking lot with LA Fitness. Plenty of parking even on the busiest nights. There is indoor and outdoor seating, bar games (cornhole/Jenga), and live music many nights. Dogs are welcome on the patio!

The staff is friendly and for the most part attentive. This evening, our server brought the wrong beer and recognized it was incorrect. She told us to keep the beers on the house and brought us our initial selections. Small gestures like this will keep me coming back!

Beer selection is usually very good! This location has lower prices than others (namely the South Tampa location). Many beers are $6 for draft. Sample all you'd like. This WOB has a full liquor bar. 

The food is also very good. Have the ginormous pretzel...you won't be disappointed. Tuesday's are $5 burger days (with fries)! I'd skip the bacon pint though...its covered in sweet stuff and not worth it.

First time visiting downtown Dunedin and found it rather charming, with lots of interesting shops, and quite a few Little Free Libraries too.

Our friends recommended this place. It doesn't look like much on the outside, or inside. There is an outdoor dining area with about 6 tables. Some of the servers wear masks, some don't. 

Service is quite good. Portions are huge. I was told that the soups and desserts are home made from scratch, and they do taste fresh. While the introduction on Yelp mentioned Lobster Roll, to my disappointment it's not on their current menu. My friend said their lobster bisque was really good too, though that one was gone from the menu as well.  

While this doesn't look like a place for great fish and chips, without any crab shack or pub vibe, they were amazingly good. For starters they use New England cod, and the batter was light and crunchy. The fries are really delicious too. Portions are very generous.

I've been to this Mona's several times, once I finally figured out it was there. (Not sure why, but the door/signage is inconspicuous; I literally had no idea this place existed for years and years.) It's always quiet, never crowded, and therefore a convenient place to go for a quick bite. 

The hummus is good, the lentil soup is pretty awesome, and they've got a miniature version of the huge store that's part of the original location on Banks Street. You can buy stuff like a pint of jordan almonds (which I can eat in a matter of days, they're awesome) and random European items like Kinder eggs (which I believe are from Germany).  

Located in the middle of the Frenchmen Street hubbub, it's easy to walk by Mona's without even realizing it's there. Once you walk in, though, it's surprisingly large and makes you feel like you've been transported to, I don't know, somewhere other than Frenchmen Street. Which could be a good or a bad thing depending on your mood, I guess.

Love love love the water ice and gelati here. The staff is usually friendly and are quick to get the lines down. It's a plus that they have a pretzel factory in the same strip mall so you can have pretzels too

If you are more interested in portion sizes and getting the most food for your money, then this is your joint. If you want food that tastes good and has flavor, don't bother coming here. 

I ordered the Philly steak and cheese omelette and the meat was literally the same flavor and consistency as the eggs. I had to add salt, pepper and tobacco sauce to eat it. The hash browns also didn't have good potato flavor, it tasted almost watered down. 

The biscuit was doughy and heavy. I regret eating the calories. 

The wait staff was unfriendly too, seemed like they were too good to serve me breakfast, or take my money. Even when it came time to pay, they helped the customer ahead of me, and then just walked off when it was my turn. There was no "hold on, I'll be right back". I just stood there for ages looking at everyone's back. When someone finally took my payment, she asked me if I needed a receipt, I said no, and then she just walked away as I was writing in the tip. I wasn't sure if the transaction was done. Most ppl say, "thanks for coming, or have a nice day". After standing there for a few more seconds and realizing she was done with me, I left. 

I don't want to say they were racist, but, I was definitely the only non-white patron there, and everyone else was getting chatted up. 

Anyway, I won't be returning. Even if it only cost me $11.

First, absolutely nobody calls this place the "Improv Comedy Center." 

Why is Tampa Improv listed this way here on Yelp? It makes it tougher for people who want to go here and see reviews to find the right page. (Perhaps the ownership or management of Tampa Improv can reach out to Yelp and tell them to change it)

I have been coming here since the venue originally opened as part of Centro Ybor's redevelopment plan to change the way people in Tampa thought about Ybor City.

That plan obviously didn't work and with the exception of Tampa Improv, the movie theater and Tampa Bay Brewing Company, virtually every other business originally opened as part of Centro Ybor predictably failed. Much like the damn trolley that nobody rides either. That stupid thing should disappear so the city of Tampa can open up more lanes for people in actual cars to drive between Ybor and Amalie Arena. 

It is a credit to Tampa Improv that they have survived the failed Centro Ybor concept.

Personally, I have always been able to count on Tampa Improv for a consistent experience and affordable night out with friends. My interactions with management and employees in the box office have also been nothing but positive.

My most recent visit with a group was to see Al Romas on Wednesday, June 14th. Al never disappoints and all of us laughed openly from his performance. Yes, I've seen him a few times over the years and truly appreciate how Al interacts with the crowd. He also doesn't simply use profanity as a punch line to try and get a laugh...which is such a crutch these days for comics when they don't really have a joke to tell.

Al had to work even harder on this particular night because the so-called "comedian" that opened for him completely mailed it in and did not want to perform. This opening act  basically admitted his lack of interest as he took the stage to fill 20+ minutes and verbally condemned the smaller Wednesday crowd.

So, I guess it is our fault that we showed up and the rest of Tampa did not? Dude, if you don't want to perform, do us a favor and don't take the gig or the paycheck. I'm sure you can find someplace else in Ybor to get more high than you already are and let the rest of us get our money's worth from comedians who give a damn about doing a quality show.

Customer service at Tampa Improv is good. Sure, there are minimums per person, but that's part of attending any comedy club I've ever visited and the drink prices aren't anything that ridiculous. I pay roughly $5 for a bottle of domestic beer and that's in line with what most bars charge around the Tampa Bay Area when it isn't happy hour or a posted special. Parking in the garage two blocks south is only $1 per hour and it is an easy walk as long as you don't step on the roosters or the hobos along the way.

Funny to me how people here on Yelp complain that the tables are too close to one another at Tampa Improv. These are some of the same hypocrites who wax poetic about the atmosphere at Bern's where the floorplan in the dining room is about as spacious as riding a Subway train after leaving a World Series game at Yankee Stadium.

Why? I mean I can now say I've gotten an actually philly cheesesteak and it's just sadly disappointing. With wiz or without whatever it's really just kind of sad. Particularly for when it's almost 10 bucks and parking is a bitch. I ended up going somewhere else to eat another cheesesteak (not Pat's) in the same night, just to get the taste out of my mouth basically.

A wonderful place to visit for all ages. It is a volunteer ran facility that serves as a retirement sanctuary for big wild cats and some smaller felines as well. Do not be deceived, this is not a petting farm. You cannot take photos close up with the animals nor can you touch them. These are large untrained cats that are here to rest and spend their golden years. It is a beautiful place for them to call home as many of them were abused and mistreated in their prime. The staff here is fantastic. There are different tours you can choose from, some more hands on than others.

We began our Day Tour promptly after we sat through a safety and informational video. Each guest was given a headset unit that plays each cat's story as we see them on the tour. Our guide was very knowledgeable as well.We were able to see several different lynxes, cougars, bobcats, tigers, lions and servals. Many of them were kept in circuses or bred for hybrid pet collectors. Some were declawed and had no way to go back into the wild. It was very sad to hear their stories. Fortunately, now at BCR, they are able to relax and be at one with nature. Each area for each cat is rather large. There is a fence around them to keep them separate as big cats are solo animals and do not play well with other unfamiliar big cats, however, there is plenty of space in each fenced area for them to run, jump and lounge around. In addition to that, they have special 'vacation' areas that they rotate the cats around every couple weeks so they can get a change of environment. 

You end the tour back at their gift shop where you can purchase something as a form of donation to BCR. All proceeds do go back to the animals. Great place to learn and give back to the animals.

The spinners at the counter are wobbly, and there is a photo of the marriage of JKF and Jackie O. on the wall, but Kitty's Luncheonette is as real as it gets for traditional breakfasts and lunches in this part of Philadelphia. They don't know from brunch, and they close before happy hour; so don't bookmark it for your weekend morning meal, nor try to stop in after work.  This is a 7 to 3:30 corner grill that had a few dozen thick scrapple slices frying to a dark brown while I drank their Ellis Coffee and awaited my first taste of their french toast.  

The house has about a dozen tables in two rooms and eight spinning stools along the counter that overlooks the chef workspace.  It was about half full of neighborhood personalities who seemed to know each other as they were greeted by name.  The server, a lovely young woman who is Kitty's niece, took care of me, and filled me in on the history of the institution, open since 1952! 

Yes. It looks its age, with family photos on the walls, and original floors, walls and stools.  Either you get the deeply rubbed in culture here, or you don't. With its gritty charm and surprisingly good food, it is easy to develop a crush on Kitty, and want to visit her often. She is as authentic as the day is long.  My three slices of thick egged toast were very good.  A little sweet from the vanilla and sugar in the mix, and a little crispy on the edges where the hot steel melted that sugar and left its hardened residue.  They know how to do FT here. $5.50 was a happy price. The java was strong and a little rough (bitter), but nothing to complain about. Again, her Joe is straight up Bunn-O-Matic.  No expresso options with Kitty. 

Kitty's is very close to I-95, and an easy on/off if you want to stop before reaching Center City from the north. Not sure she could handle becoming a hit on the breakfast bookmark circuit, especially on weekends, so if you want to check her out, come on a weekday morning when the regular crowd is thinner.  

But, if you like hard stop traditional breakfast without any frills, give this old girl a go.

I've been trying to grow my curls out for YEARS so just hate having to go to a salon, but I knew I needed my ends trimmed and I love DevaCurl products so I did a bit of research and found Barbara's. I went for the first time in March of 2013 and was given a Devacut by Peggy. I felt like she took maybe just a little bit more off than I wanted but overall she was great and I was happy.

My second visit was a NIGHTMARE. I went back in October of 2013 and Maggie took those scissors and just completely butchered my curls. I was in tears when I left there that day. I actually ended up going back a few weeks later and Peggy tried to fix it but even she admitted that Maggie had cut off WAY too much and there was really no fix but to wait for it to grow out. 

I ended up going to a Devachan salon in NY in March of 2014 begging for them to help me. They did what they could but it's really just going to take time. 

I was basically Maggie's experiment. If I ever went back to this salon, I would go back to Peggy. Peggy is the only reason why I am giving this salon a 2 star and not 1.

A wise person once said about this place, "Absolutely breathtaking.  It felt as though we were transported to Scotland. The landscaping and architecture are well preserved. The town surrounding the museum is quaint with boutique style shops and a strong New England air. The museum itself is tucked away amidst other well preserved historical landmarks."

I guess this is true, but I just came here for a Philly Beerfest event and got drunk as hell.

I have nada to add to the review of the castle.

I'm very sorry.

I've been to Kokopelli's twice now for the all-you-can-eat sushi, once during this past weekend and the first time after a snowboarding trip two winters ago. The funny thing is that the sushi chef during my recent visit was the exact same chef during my very first visit! Definitely great service from this chef. I can't recall my first visit very well but I remember being more than satisfied. During my more recent visit, the wait for dinner was about 45 minutes which was pretty long. I think they wait until the people currently sitting at the sushi bar all clear out before they seat the next set of AYCE folks in which they serve for a set of folks for one hour, wait until they clear out and then fill up the seats again so it's kinda like waves of people at the sushi bar. However despite the wait, the rolls here are pretty darn tasty and you just want to try them all! This time around, I tried:
