Ceviche Roll: Surprisingly good! I thought this roll cold have been a hot mess of raw fish with lemon and cilantro but it was just really good. It tastes just like ceviche with rice which doesn't really sound that good but all of the fish and citrus flavor work well as a roll. 

Mountain Roll: The crab topping is just too sweet for me. Otherwise, this would have been a great roll.  

Dragon Roll: A very hearty roll if you will. The combination of crystal shrimp and unagi make this roll almost meat-like as opposed to seafood like. I really liked that quality of this roll. 

Ring Roll: A yummy roll especially with the basil sauce. 

Kokopelli Hand Roll: Reminds me of honey walnut prawns minus the walnuts, wrapped in seaweed. It may be good to others but too creamy and heavy for me. 

Seaweed Salad: The salad isn't too oily and comes in a big ol' serving. 

Baked Mussels: Do yourself a favor and order this first thing since they take 15 minutes to be made. The mussels are excellent! The chef can make em spicy by adding a jalepeno slice and sriracha on top of each mussel which gives them a hot kick.  

Dessert: Green tea ice cream and Mango sorbet were the options during dinner. I went with the Mango sorbet, which the chef gives plenty of. It was a bit on the sweet side, but what the heck, it comes with the meal. 

The waitresses do a good job of coming around to clear your plates and re-fill your beverages. Overall a great dining option, especially if you're craving sushi in Reno!

One of my go-to lunch spots.  I always get either a baba ganoush sandwich with carrots, zucchini, and white beans or the lamb sandwich with baba ganoush, carrots, and zucchini.  Their baba ganoush tastes like bacon.  Seriously.  Don't ask me how or why just enjoy its delicious smokiness coating the perfect fluffy semolina roll as it cradles all of the other delectable fillings you've selected.  $6.99 for a solid lunch that won't leave you hungry or weighed down, you just can't beat it.

I love this store. I usually come here to buy the giant sized sage for my house to smoke out ghosts and ghouls. Yes, I can go get sage anywhere, but I love to support my local businesses. Everyone should do this as much as possible. Besides that , I love browsing  in this store, and sometimes I get caught up and buy other things too. On my recent visit I bought a little monkey pipe . It had an eye on it so I knew I had to have it . Anything with an eye on it , I snatch up. Could be the Greek in me:-) I love it . It so small, cute, and gets the job done well. On my way out,  I was browsing the chronic pops, and the guy who runs the place, that let me add, is always very helpful & nice when I come in, told me to take a couple and let him know what I think . That was very nice of him. Thank you! I'll be back when in need of more Sage. Got to keep those ghosts at Bay.

I get my car's oil changed every three months or so, so when the little wrench popped up, I knew I had to make a call and get an appointment.   I called on Thursday afternoon, about 4:30.  When the service department answered, I asked about Saturday times. Unless I was leaving my car with them, they didn't have anything available until 3pm. I was fine with that. 

When I arrived at 3pm, I was told that they'd get my car in as soon as possible. I'm fine with waiting a bit, I'm a patient soul.   While waiting, they played a movie on the DVR, but it's nearly impossible to watch a movie in their waiting room with all the ambient noise. The volume is either too much, or not enough, there is no happy medium. 

It was almost exactly 1 hour to the dot, and my car was finished. She runs beautifully now. Thank you, Courtesy Palm Harbor Honda for doing an excellent job on a tire rotation and oil change. You always do good work.

My wife and came here about 12:30pm on a Friday for lunch. She loves Mexican food and we have been to the location in Stead on several occasions. We have always enjoyed it. 

It was not too busy and we were told to have a seat where we liked. We chose a booth along the wall. The booth on my side of the table felt like the cushion was gone in the middle and my chin was on the table. I just moved a bit toward the wall, but my wife commented to me not to lean against the wall. I looked and it appeared to not have been cleaned in a while. There were all sorts of different colors and specks on it. I wish I took a picture but I did not.  The remainder of the restaurant looked clean but the booths along the side of the restaurant should be ripped out and replaced. 

The server brought us menus and took our drink orders. We were familiar with the menu since we have been to their other location. I chose the enchiladas lunch special and my wife likes their chimichangas so she ordered that. 

Our food arrived in a timely manner and looked yummy and the server was attentive. We enjoyed our meals and appreciated the fast service since we had to get back to work. 

Overall a good experience but next time we will definitely not sit in the booth.

Long line for this deli during lunch time. You place your order in line for the sandwich. Make sure to order the potato latkes before you get to the front because it takes 10 minutes to fry. 

I ordered the pastrami hot deli sandwich with rueben special and potato latkes. Latkes are fluffy and a good balance for all the pastrami in the sandwich. I felt like there was too much pastrami in the sandwich. Half the amount would have been enough because it tasted like only pastrami cause the other ingredients were drowned out. 

I sort of wish I had tried the corn beef because I heard so many other people trying it and getting blown away by it. The pastrami was good, but just pailed in comparison after seeing other people's reactions.

Pay at the front and grab a seat anywhere.

Beware of "the gauntlet": the bridge that is covered in bird poo.
You'll probably be tempted to stop to visit the cute fox along this dangerous route, but that's just when it will happen.  White bombs from the sky will land on your unsuspecting shoulders.  

Then when you make a bee line for the bathroom you'll find there are no paper towels.  Check another bathroom - strike two.  That's okay.  That's what men's bathrooms are for.  Just send your friend in to check in there for you...  Oh, wait.  You came here by yourself?  Who's genius idea was that?  

I came here not expecting much and I came away with small touches of avian excrement all over my clothing.  Enjoy it, I did not.

Years ago, before the birth of many microbreweries, Saint Somewhere used to be in a warehouse. They would pour you some beer after you paid for a tour, as they couldn't sell beer and most certainly did not have a taproom.  

Three weeks ago, Saint Somewhere finally moved to their new location, inside a historic home right in downtown Tarpon Springs.  It's a lovely blue building, with a small front courtyard and a two rooms for enjoying your beer.  Unlike most breweries, and befitting their historic building status, they keep the interior homely and reminiscent of an earlier age, with fading photos (apparently some are of their ancestors.)  Upstairs will be guest rooms, as a new form of B&B - Beer and Bed.  Isn't it how things were hundreds of years ago?  

When we visited today, their beers are still fermenting after the move and won't be available for another week or two. They therefore offer several Belgian ales on tap, as well as some of their own brews, plus cider, non-alcoholic tonic water etc. in bottles and cans.  When fully operational, there will be 10 drafts.

It's great to grab a beer and sit inside by the big window for people watching.  Or sit outside by in their little yard.  Right next door is KC Cue, a great bbq place for grabbing some award winning ribs or pulled pork.  

They don't do flights, so the beers come in a full pour at around $6-8. They are nice enough to let you sample their beers, in the cutest miniature beer glasses though.

Pizzeria L'Angolo has a great patio space. Unfortunately, as it opened around COVID, I never had a chance to try it out. Therefore, this review is purely based on my takeout experiences.

If you couldn't figure from the name, they offer a wide selection of pizzas.  Like most places, you can order a few standard menu options or create your own.  Unlike most places, I think a few of their standard menu items are a bit different (in a good way).

My go to is the Capricciosa: Mozzarella, Prosciutto Cotto, Artichokes, Mushrooms, and Kalamata Olives. They don't go cheap on the toppings. The sauce is solid and the crust not too thick not too thin.  

Beyond Pizza, they have an extensive menu, however, I have stuck with pizza my visits to this point.  Staff interactions have been minimal, but friendly.  Honestly, I am excited to check out their patio and enjoy more of their pizza.

Two Words: Klassic Kyle

This burger was juicy and perfectly cooked. I even ate all the fries and I usually don't order fries.  

Next time, I will have to write on the chalboard

Come check this place out!

I didn't get to eat here on my last trip so I made it a point to make it this time around. The restaurant itself is beautifully decorated. You walk through the kitchen into a room full of bright colors. There's a bar upfront and some outdoor seats to the side of the main dining area. It gets absolutely packed and they don't take reservations for parties under 5, so be prepared.

My favorite dish may have been the fried eggplant appetizer with an oyster cream sauce and mushrooms. I'm a sucker for any cream sauce but this was amazing. Perfectly cooked eggplant smothered in a rich seafood based sauce, amazing. 

My friend ordered the eggplant perogue with shrimp, oysters, and fish in a cream sauce. She loved it but the sauce had some kind of cheese in it and I'm just not a fan of seafood and cheese.

I ordered the Godzilla, a seasonal special of fried softshell crab over fried green tomatoes with remoulade and a side of slaw. I'm not usually a fan of softshell crab (I know, I know) but this was the best I've ever had. The fried green tomatoes were on the soggy side, that may have been due to the remoulade or the crab sitting on top of them, I'm not sure but I left them alone in favor of their amazing slaw! Our entrees came with two sides and a salad. Unknown to us the salad also comes with a fried oyster. Why don't all salads come this way? 

Service was beyond fantastic, our waiter was extremely patient while we struggled to make our choices. Their Fi Na Ye and watermelon margarita drinks are delicious. Their creme brulee is also a winner. Check them out!

I've come here a couple times for happy hours when traveling for work. 

They're very flexible about seating. The service is always friendly. Make sure to tell them up front if you want to split checks. 

They have an extensive selection of beers and a couple ciders on tap. 

I've eaten dinner here before and the food was pretty good, but this time we just got an appetizer. We got the reuben nachos which had soft pretzels instead of chips. We all enjoyed them. 

Overall, it's a great place to grab a drink after work.

I wanted to love this little bakery by the river in middle of New Hope, but unfortunately the items I tried here were disappointing. On the plus side, service was very friendly - everyone I interacted with was genuinely nice, and they were offering some samples outside the bakery. The location by the river is also lovely, and there is a nice outside seating area. They also accept credit cards now.

I tried the mango mousse and the clafoutis, which were $5.50 each. The mousse was ok, very light and not too sweet, but the sponge beneath was more like a grainy wet cookie. The custard portion of the clafoutis was ok - very eggy and barely sweet - but I didn't like the tough crust underneath or the very bright and artificial cherries. I hope these two are exceptions and that the rest of the large selection is better, but I don't think I'll be stopping by again the next time I'm in the area.

There are two things that keep me coming back to The Southern: the atmosphere and the killer food. 

Yes, I've had some mixed experiences with service (especially at brunch) but once I get my plate of goodness, the annoyance melts away. I can't stop coming here for their consistently amazing food. I haven't had a meal here that wasn't excellent, and since it's opened, I've brought family and friends here over and over again with great success.

I finally tried their oysters a couple months ago (they offer variety of kinds) and I was blown away. My only experience with raw oysters was not a pretty one, but at the Southern, they do them right. For any of you new to raw oyster eating, I like mine on saltine crackers with a squeeze of lemon and hot sauce. Perfect. I've heard from multiple people they are the best oysters they've ever had. 

I've also had the pleasure of enjoying some stand out dishes; the shrimp and grits is incredible and the steaks are up there too.

Can they improve some of their servers? Yes, and it should be addressed, but I've had some good experiences with them as well. And have never had the same issues with my dinner waiters. 

Go to the Southern. It's worth it!

I've been here for a wedding and a few other events.  Its an interesting Victorian house and there are some rather eclectic decorations inside along with the sort of spooky "Doll House Museum."  The outside courtyard is a nice space for an event and makes a good wedding spot.   This is definitely a uniquely New Orleans location to host any type of event.

Atomic Cowboy is one of the coolest bars in The Grove by far. It has a massive outdoor patio, great food, and a ton of character. 

I came here for a ISC planned by Sarah S. It was such a great choice. The weather was perfect so we had the privilege of sitting outside. I went ahead and ordered their Red Sangria. It was pretty good but not really worth it. I should have just ordered something with whiskey in it. Whiskey and Tacos synergies pretty well on the palette. The Sangria was more like a "meh" overpriced cocktail than sangria. Who cares, let's get to the noms. 

Now, as I age like fine wine from the south of France I crave the presence of tacos in my diet. No joke. Young Aaron B used to say, "Tacos, meh?" A wiser Aaron B emerged through the flames of the Yelperverse and now craves what the hip youth might call, "bitchin' tacos." 

I went ahead and ordered 1 Fried Tilapia, 1 Chorizo, and 1 Breakfast Taco (egg+bacon+Cheese). I saw they had street corn so, of course, I had to order it. It all came out in a timely manner along with about 7-8 other orders. Granted, we were like the only ones there on an early Wednesday evening. Any who, the tacos were great. They aren't the best tacos around but they are pretty damn good. The Fried Tilapia was pretty spot on. Not as good as Milagro or Mission taco but I could go still go ham on a bucket of them. The Breakfast Taco was also legit. I loooove breakfast tacos. The least favorite of my 3 was the chorizo but it was still good! They were all cooked perfectly, came out warm, and were the perfect size. 

The street corn deserves its' own paragraph break. It was sooooo good. If you are a corn fanatic I highly recommend trying it. I don't even know how to describe it besides amazing. It comes out on a stick, roasted, with a sweet-ish-red seasoning, cheese crumbles, sour cream (?), and idk what else but just get it. It is the knees of the bees. 
 
I highly recommend checking out Atomic Cowboy. It's a great place to grab a drink and some grub. I hear they have an awesome brunch. Can't wait to come back and try it out!

This is one of those times where I'm like, "I could have sworn I wrote a review for this place", but honestly, I loved it so much that I'd write it over and over again if needed. I mean, who doesn't love ranch dressing? And, well, if you don't think is not the place for you.

I found myself in St. Louis and had been looking all over for random places to try. A friend of mine came up with this suggestion at the advice of a friend. I said, "how could this be bad with ranch in the title?" 

The biggest issue with dining here really was finding street parking. Well, also, the place is packed, but you can make it work like we did by sitting at the bar. Believe me, they can fit a lot of plates on that bar because we went to town on some food.

Also, I'd like to add- if you don't like French fries you're going to 1) be missing out 2) I guess order onion rings because how do you not get French fries with ranch dressing?

Okay, so the main attraction in my opinion, and I have to be in the majority here is the ranch this country flight. For $13 you get a mountain of fries and 13, yes 13 different type of ranch of your choosing. They have like 30 total so believe me, it's difficult. Not a glutton like us? Well you can do the ranch this country flight for $5 which has your choice of 5 ranch flavors.

Some of the flavors include: Twisted Ranch (original), Asian Zing, Avocado, Carter's Smoke (Smoke Paprika), Buttermilk Basil, Greek, Jack the Ripper (Pepper Jack), It Takes 2 to "Mango", Pesto, Red Billy Goat (Red Peppers & Goat Cheese), Roasted Garlic, Southwest, Ruffalo (Roasted Garlic & Buffalo), and Smoke Tomato Basil just to list off some of the choices.  The flight comes on essentially a lazy Susan that spins around delightful ranch dressing. The amount of fries is almost absurd. But the fries and every ranch dressing were delicious.

Being me, I got even more fries with my patty melt style burger which was cooked exactly how I wanted it to be, but again, you almost don't come here to eat anything other than ranch, but please do because the food was quality even if it is under the shadow of that ranch dressing which we were told was made in house.

The service was great. The staff behind the bar were super friendly and chatted with us a lot while we ate. It was a great experience. Something I didn't know I needed in my life and a place I have to get back to. It's one of those places you'd travel there just to go to, well, at least if you love ranch dressing as much as I do. And the prices are so unbelievably cheap too. It's definitely a win.

I've walked past Paul a few times, and while I've been intrigued, I've never been certain of what they had to offer. Then of course, I consulted Yelp and low and behold, Paul had a mere 2 reviews. So I decided I wanted to blaze a new trail (i.e. try spot that doesn't host 50+ reviews); they only recently opened after all. When the gays decided it was high time for a classy, self-affirming team dinner, I quickly offered up Paul. They were understandably confused since they thought I was bringing new bait (named Paul) to dinner...

The interior is bright, airy, and *gasp* not cramped (as many BYOs are known to be). Sure, it's small, but they're not forcing communal dining to accommodate more guests. The menu is inventive but accessible; I'm used to going to fancy restaurants where I'm asking the server for a translation- this isn't the case here. Halibut, chicken breast, scallops, oysters, duck...they make it sound much better, but they cover the basics and offer something for any omnivore. 

I had the pancetta wrapped halibut. I recently started eating fish, so my palate is still in development, but this dish left me considering dropping red meat altogether. Perfectly flavored and generously portioned! I was expecting a thin filet, but what arrived was at least 10oz! I highly recommend ordering it, or at least convincing someone at your table to order it so you can steal a bite.

After your meal, you'll want to open another bottle, chat up Effie and your server, and close the place down. You'll instantly feel at home. As for the name, the BYOB is named after Effie's late father, Paul. It goes without saying, but he'd be pretty proud.

It was time for a work birthday party and we discussing cake. One of my co-workers, said how about trying, "The Cakery". I immediately light up and said, YES! YES! I grabbed my smartphone, and showed them reviews and pictures on Yelp to sell them on the idea of ordering the cake from, The Cakery. 

My enthusiasm sold them and we ordered the birthday cake. The honoree is a big candy lover, so we selected one topped in a variety of sweet treats. The cake was a two tiered chocolate separated by a vanilla butter creme. The top was close to a Tiffany Blue dripping down the sides. Beautiful presentation. 

Our birthday boy loved his cake and my co-workers who had never experienced, The Cakery were totally impressed. They loved the rich flavor and how moist the cake was. This was a total win. 

Perhaps we'll celebrate the next birthday with cupcakes from, The Cup. I already started singing the praises of their cupcake store. 

Would I go again? Yes, I always love a good cake. 

When: October 7, 2017
Why: Birthday Celebration

Solid 4 stars for the delicious tiramisu alone!

It was the best thing I ate at Reading Terminal Market! It was also the first thing we DEVOURED because we were so hungry....but it was tasty!
The staff was friendly enough and we were able to find somewhere in the general area to set up and eat.
I would absolutely come back for baked goods and sweets from Termini Bros!

Ike's has an open, spacious and somewhat modern feel. It is comfortable and cosy, with several couches and lounge chairs and even bamboo plants. North facing on Speedway, you get a gorgeous view of the Catalinas, albeit interrupted by Speedway traffic. Still, the tall windows here are wonderful.  

The menus is pretty straightforward. The cafe sells breakfast all day, which is pretty awesome! Try the veggie scramble. Meateater or not, this is an awesome meal and a good deal. The Super BLT is meh. I was disappointed to find way too much turkey and not enough turkey bacon. But the hummus plate also is a good treat, and they also sell granola and oatmeal. 

I have been spending time here studying, and have found that the password-protected free WIFI can be spotty. The staff is working to fix it and, really, it was much improved this time. And I love a place that actually uses its air conditioner during the summer months. Nothing like a bead of sweat running down your back when you're focusing on your theory. 

But feminists and women's studies majors be forewarned -- Ike's has a very strong firewall. So, if you are studying anything related to sexuality and fluid sexual identities, you may not be able to access the sites and resources you need. 

I tried a couple of times and was barred access, receiving -- instead -- an intimidating black and red full-screen banner indicating that I was barred from viewing such things. As if pointing a big, red finger saying, "You! Yes, you! No, you are not allowed to read 'The structure of sexual orientation and its relation to masculinity, femininity, and gender diagnosticity: Different for Men and Women' on these premises! Take that somewhere else."
great ambiance but acoustics could be better.  too much echo.  food was nice, tasty fritters.

Wing Stop's catch phrase is, "The Wing Experts". I don't think so.
They were not "bad", I've just had better. In fact I've had better from a pizza joint or a pub and I was hoping for better. 
The fries, were limp and tasted as if they were prepared in old oil. Another big disappointment, after reading Shelly D's glowing review. 

My co-workers get carry-out frequently from here, so I'll re-visit too in hopes of a better experience. Perhaps they were just having an off night.

Very yummy place.  Everything they do, they do with top notch ingredients. 
 I ate there 4 times during a week long visit....It's  'mother ship establishment' Cochon, right around the corner is also really worth a try...but get reservations well ahead.

I can not believe it, no one has written a review for this great co-op boutique. I was here for a Halloween party before their opening and just now got back to actually shop. I am now remorseful for not returning sooner. 

There are about 40+ vendors offering all sorts of goodies. Ranging from clothing for women and men, to hand made soaps, posters, candies, candles and so much more. One vendor offers some very creative and tasteful stationary. I'm a sucker for note cards and thank you cards. 

Next time you are downtown, make it a point to stop by and shop this "Collective" boutique. Chances are you will find something to your liking. I did. I love my new poster/map that shows all the neighborhoods in Saint Louis. Now I know where all the Yelp Dukedoms are located. Also, the Milk Chocolate Triple Dipped Malt Balls from, Oh Lolli Lolli melted in my mouth. Yes I am dieting, but I can still have a treat and these malt balls were truly a treat.

Being such a nice and genuinely awesome guy, I'm starting this review by looking out for you. How so? Well, if you were planning to, for example, go to Xu Hue on a Wednesday, you would be in for major disappointment (like a certain someone that tried to go during supper time). Yep, they are only open from 11am to 4pm so you've been warned!

The following week, I went to Xu Hue on a Tuesday evening for dinner with three friends and this time, they were open for business. The place is your typical Asian restaurant - hard seats, white walls, TV (U.S. Open on - win!) and random Asian decorations. I'm pretty sure if the seats are hard and uncomfortable, you know the food will be good. Just a tip I've picked up over the years.

A good Viet buddy of mine recommended Xu Hue as they are known for having several local/regional dishes that are hard to find in other Edmonton Vietnamese restaurants. So, with that, we decided to order a couple appetizers to share:
 - Green onion cakes ($4.50 for two) - these were surprisingly delicious. Add some of their chili hot sauce to it (which was also awesome - definitely had some good heat to it). We devoured these like they were going out of style.
 - Banh xeo ($6.95) - apparently these pan fried Vietnamese crepes are super hard to find in town. Comes with a side of lettuce and fresh basil. It was very crunchy and the inside consisted of bean sprouts, shrimp and sliced pork. Also came with a fish sauce to dip with. I was expecting the banh xeo to be delicious but we all concluded it was very average. Not bland but just very ordinary.
 - 2x Bun bo hue (spicy) ($9.95) - two friends ordered this and it looked/smelled delicious. They both were big fans.
 - Five colour vermicelli ($10.95) - spring rolls, pork, shrimp, beef and chicken.
 - Fish sauce noodle soup (spicy) ($9.95 large) - I ordered this dish. The broth was on the sweeter side compared to other pho places. As well, the broth tasted much more subtle, almost cleaner if that makes sense. I overheard the owner saying that there is no MSG in it, which I like. I also really liked the noodles - they were different from the normal rice noodles you get. Yum.

Solid pho place in Chinatown with a lot of interesting/different dishes on their menu. To quote Tom Haverford, "Treat yo' self".

The library was a steady source of reading, audio, and video entertainment when I lived in Greenwood.  The staff are very helpful and I have gotten to know several on a first name basis.  Even after moving to Mooresville, I maintained my membership even though I now have to pay an annual fee.

In addition to the stock of materials on hand in the local branch, they can transfer materials from any of the JCPL branches at no additional cost.

I also use the digital download Hoopla to borrow electronic media without leaving my home.  

Finally, I can reserve upcoming new releases so that I don't miss any of the entertainment that is of interest.

Review #63

Stopped here for gas yesterday, and wanted to add a quick tip making note of the fact that you can NOT pay at the pump with a credit card. It's a pain in the behind, on occasion, specifically when you've only got a credit card. 

Otherwise, this place is your run-of-the-mill gas station in a possibly iffy neighborhood, the kind with bulletproof glass between you and the person taking your money. 

I've been here a couple times, for no reason other than it happened to be convenient to wherever I was when I decided that my gas light had been on for long enough, and I was forced to give in and refuel. Though I did have to go inside, I didn't bother to look around much, so didn't notice anything worth sharing with regard to their selection of candy/cold drinks/miscellaneous gas station crap, but I didn't notice the aroma of fried food, so it's not one of the gas stations where you can get fried chicken and that kind of stuff.

And yes, I realize this is an elaborate gas station review. And no, I don't think I'm silly for writing it.

When you go in to watch the Wildcats play UCLA and you get a seat (for six) right away, I'd say that's a pretty decent start to the night. Yep, they have the bible of beers and more at this joint and quite frankly, that's way too many options than I personally care for, but that's no reason to knock off a star or two. The more beer the the merrier, right!?  We also had pretty good and attentive service. Was our server a beer connoisseur? No, but she tried and was quite nice. Plus, they have a giant beer book at each table so you can brush up on key words and definitions. We ordered some bites to keep us sober. I had pretty basic expectations of the food...and basic it was. Nothing spectacular, just your typical bar fare (hummus, pretzel, tater tots), served warm and in a timely fashion. I was under the impression that this was a great place to watch a game. I wouldn't say it was great, but there were plenty of TVs, albeit in odd locations. But best of all they played the sound! I'd almost give fourth star for that...but really, this place, while it has an insane beer list, doesn't have much of a draw for me. It feels cold and corporate inside. One staff member mentioned they may start hosting free beer classes as they do their Phoenix store, and I highly encouraged him to pass the word onto management, that they should! I think it might be a good way to engage with our local beer loving community.

Wow an American casino that is completely smoke free!  Way to take the lead.  What a relief.  To enter a casino and leave without having to wash all of your clothes or hang them outside your balcony to air out.  No more guilty essence of sour tobacco when sneaking into bed.  

The dining options and amount of craps tables open could really improve.   The smoke free aspect makes me a huge fan.

Don't come here for the food, but the atmosphere is fun at night and the margaritas are decent.

We got a pitcher of Margarita on the rocks and it was good.  I have no complaints.  I also got the chicken quesadilla and it was fine.  It wasn't amazing, but you really cannot mess up a quesadilla.  I was also starving when we got there, so that definitely helped.  I can't see myself going back here for the food.  My friend got a Mexican pizza and it was absolutely covered in Jalapenos.  They really overdid it!

The atmosphere of this place is fun.  It is in a great location in central Ybor and it is a lot of fun to sit at the bar looking outwards and people watch.  They also had a live band the night I went.  

I can see myself coming here just to chill with friends and drink, but I probably wouldn't spend money on food here again.

While many of the great original businesses of channelside plaza have failed and closed, splitsville and hooters remains open since day one and still bring a good crowd of people.  We came for a company outing to splitsville in the once legendary hot spot, channelside plaza, in downtown tampa, on the water, now a much less popping area, but not quite a ghost town. Back in splitsville's hay day they had a dance floor in the back, live dj playing some great music, and the place was always the place to be on the weekend and you needed bowling reservations at least a week in advance. Now it's more of a low key, kid friendly, chill spot with pg rated music, to gather and bowl in an upscale atmosphere with a group of friends. Splitsville wasn't packed like it used to be, but it wasn't empty either. I'd say 4 out of 12 bowling lanes were open. The good thing is that you have a good chance of walking in without reservations and getting a bowling lane, although I'd definitely recommend reservations for large parties or just to be sure. If Id compare Splitsville to their experience 10 years ago, id give it 3 stars but if i compare Splitsville to other bowling alleys in Tampa, id have to say Splitsville is the most modern and upscale bowling alley in the entire tampa bay area with the best food too. 

We had a large variety of surprisingly good sushi, chicken tenders, pepperoni pizza, and veggie pizza. Service was good and it was a decent atmosphere although not as lively as it had been in the years in the past. Now that Thai Thani moved out due to demolitions, splitsville is the last remaining place to get sushi. If you live downtown by channelside, I'd definitely recommend their sushi! Our food came out in under 20minutes but it was no rush since we were busy bowling. Probably the biggest negative about going anywhere in channelside is paying for parking. I was surprised to see that the bucs teams, lightning teams, Dave attel, and even Rihanna have visited and all signed bowling pins on display under glass. They've had quite a few famous people roll through! The pictures are classic 1950s post world war 2 mad men style and very nastalgic. Will add more about the sushi we got later!

The most amazing Caribbean food I've ever tasted hands down. Brought me back to my trip to the Caribbean and was home style all homemade foods. 
Came here after my sister found this place on Yelp. Thanks yelp! 

Walked up to the store front and it looked like a small take out joint- walked inside and was welcomed by a smiling face and a warm welcome. The menu had so many tasty Caribbean choices on it- I didn't know what I wanted to get. 

I ended up getting a jerk chicken platter/ the kind and welcoming cashier gave us a tip about the jerk chicken and said to get mild if you're not used to spice. So got the mild jerk chicken with rice, and sweet potatoes. 

My sister got some other chicken with Mac n cheese and green beans. While my mom got a Cajun shrimp salad. I also got a side of mango chutney so it could sweeten up the spice. 

There is some seating in the restaurant but not very many. We pushed some tables together and sat and watched the Hobbit movie that was playing on the large tv. 
The food was done quickly and we all dug in. No one talked for about 25 mins- all I heard was ooo and yum and wow this is good... as well as some heavy breathing and panting for the fact that the mild still bad some spice to it. My mouth was on fire but I was loving it! The food was amazing and mouth watering! My mouth and lips seriously got numb but I didn't care I kept on tearing it up! 

The mango chutney helped the spice a lot and the rice also did. I tried my sisters Mac n cheese and it was the cheesy and most delightful meal within itself. The portions here are hefty but do not break your pocket! 

I ended up having leftovers which I later devoured two days later and it tasted just as good. I ordered two sandwiches to go- 2 jerk chicken sandwiches with Mac n cheese for my brother and he was raving about how amazing it was and for the price. 
The cashier told us that they have special bread on Saturday's so it looks like ok going back tomorrow to get my fill. 

I highly recommend this Caribbean place! If you want some tasty food that's made on sure from scratch with a little spice- this place is for you!

We stopped at Ace hardware, so I decided to run in and give it a shot while the hubby did his shopping.
I was expecting a regular donut shop showcase filled with 
Donuts, but there wasn't.... they explained how the ordering worked, and they had a small example of the donuts. I asked if they were the size of the examples and they said yes!... uhhhh.. no regular donuts?.. there was a worker frying the mini donuts near the cashier,  that was it.
Oh well.. a cute idea, probably for kids,.. but I could just get a can of biscuit dough and fry them myself and top with cinnamon sugar for pennies..

Cure is about a 1/2 mile from my house so I drive by all the time.  And the crowds of glitterati (or what attempts to pass for it in NOLA) made me think Cure wasn't my sort of establishment.  Well, it turns out I was wrong.  I know shocking.

I went on a weekday after work for a benefit for a New Orleans charter school.  The after work crowd was friendly and a good mix of ages.  I had a glass of their fall sangria (because I got a free glass) and it was really tasty and delicious.  My friends sampled a variety of cocktails and deemed them all well made.  Well, except for the unusual presentation of the Old Fashioned which should have been labeled a New Fashioned.  What no muddling?

And I LOVE the building and that it is no smoking indoors.

The feel of this BRU Burger is a little more upscale than the other two around town.  There is plenty of outdoor seating as well as plenty of room in the dining room, the bar area, and what appeared to be a private dining room.

The service was really attentive and friendly, even holding the door for us to enter!  

My wife seemed to enjoy her Buttermilk Cobb salad which was rather large, even though she ordered the smaller version.  Lots of tasty ingredients cut down to decent sizes so that she didn't need make additional cuts.

I have been hearing about the Black Bean Burger for awhile now, so I decided to give it a try and upgraded my side to Onion Rings.  The Burger had a nice flavor, somewhat less spicy than I expected from reading the ingredient list.  The "burger" was full sized and moist...maybe a little too moist since chunks of patty dropped out of the bun when I lifted it.  Fortunately, there was a fork handy to pick up the fallen parts.  The onion rings were lightly breaded and the onion inside was very sweet.  The house made ketchup paired well and is highly recommended.

We also decided to share the Peach White Chocolate Bread Pudding with pecans and whipped cream.  Very delicious and just the right size for sharing after a full meal.

Review #385

The good:  the servers were very helpful and friendly, and I was able to get a seat at the almost empty sushi bar at 6 pm on a busy night before the holidays.

And those are essentially the positives of this restaurant. For my dinner, I ordered a ginger salad, tuna tataki, and a soft shell crab roll. The $5 salad came out first and consisted of lettuce with two tomatoes in a ginger dressing. Hmm, not impressed.

Meanwhile, I could see the young, clearly new sushi chef struggling to make my tuna tataki.  But I don't blame him for it being so terrible, I blame the head chef, who could CLEARLY see the young man had no idea what he was doing, come over, change something, walk away for 2 minutes (to aimlessly wander the empty restaurant) then wander back and change something else.  When the final product was served, it was terrible. Not only was it NOT tuna tataki, but it had huge pieces of sea salt on it, making it inedible. Fortunately, when I returned it, it was taken off my bill.  

I did like the flavor of my soft shell crab roll, but my personal preference is not to eat huge rolls cut into just five pieces; I like when the roll pieces are bite-sized, and there are more of them. I found myself taking out the soft shell crab and eating it separately, then squishing the rest of the roll together to eat it.

It was not an enjoyable meal, and I doubt I will return.

No purses are allowed unless clutch size.

Yes, ladies. Fair warning. You will have to walk all the way back to your car to drop off your bag. In our situation, we had to call our ride back since we were dropped off. It was a pain in the ass and a bit off-putting to say the least. And, does anyone know the reasoning of this policy? Apparently, (as I've been told) this is a rather newer update?

I refuse to wear a fanny pack and don't really think that a clutch make sense for my daily ins and outs so I guess we are supposed to put our keys, wallets, and lady things, where? 

Besides this major inconvenience, the stadium is well-kept and I love the box seating too. 
Although, I wish that they had some healthier and veg-friendly options offered in their concession stands like many other venues do. A veggie-dog or burger goes a long way folks. 

Until then, I'll guzzle beer and chew on french fries while I reach for my credit card stuffed into my bra (where else would I store it) so that I can pay for this.

Someone asked me where a dealer can be found. I pretended not to understand. They repeated: Dealer - where? I ran away. Next thing you know I'm writing a Yelp review of a welcome center.

Not a fan of highway rest stops. This is why. Gas is more expensive than most places in Delaware. Service here is appalling, some of the servers (cough cough Starbucks) are very rude indeed. Not that I even like Starbucks. Choices are awful (Burger King - yay... not), and the prices of all the places in here are higher than they should be. For example you can pay more for a Starbucks here than at a regular non-highway Starbucks.

Wifi didn't work properly, my lemonade tasted watered down, and the only reason it doesn't get one star is that it's safe to sleep in the parking lot (I would know), and it's kept very clean (like her motor).

You know that the mall has fallen when you see Burlington Coat Factory as an anchor store.

This used to be the go-to mall in the whole Indianapolis metro area.  It had everything you could possibly want and while it was crowded, you could find your way to shop, even on Friday or Saturday night.

Now, it doesn't seem there is much of a reason to keep the doors open.  West 38th Street is craptacular and you have to be more aware of your surroundings.  It's not unusual, though.  Malls all over the U.S.A. are declining, partly due to online shopping.  Anchor stores are going away, due to consolidation.

If a mall isn't owned by General Growth, Simon, or Westfield, it's not likely getting enough money to thrive and they're likely to focus on areas where people have money, and it's not this neighborhood.  People will head to Greenwood Park Mall or Keystone or even Castleton Square and you can't blame them.

I think the photos speak loudly. Never have I ever had Biryani with peas. This isn't even considered chicken fried rice, it's just flavorless rice with dry chicken and peas. 

The chicken vindaloo wasn't actually vindaloo, not sure what paste they used but they didn't cook the potatoes all the way through. Which is sad, because we were the only people there and our order took 40 mins to come our. 

The naan was a non issue. Didn't even try it. It was cold and I'm 99% sure this is the same stuff they sell in the frozen section at Wegmans. 

It's hilarious that this place is called "Indian Restaurant", it's anything but a Indian restaurant.

Slowest Waffle House I've been to and I've been to waffle houses all over the country. They are nice just incredibly slow. It wasn't very busy, especially for a Waffle House. They also don't have gluten free waffles here like many others do. Overall I was disappointed and incredibly tired after waiting an hour for my to go bowl, not getting dinner until after 1am when I had planned to be asleep before then. I had an important morning and waited because they kept saying 10 more minutes. Again very kind people, but I would eat somewhere else if you don't have time to kill.

La Colombe has a lot of great things going on for it: the complimentary "draught" sparkling water (with a sign that says "everyone on earth should have access to free clean water"; it then goes on to explain how they're committed to drilling wells in Africa to help with that), the use of Califia Farms almond milk, and the employees who - while they may come off "no nonsense" - are friendly enough despite the high volume they're doing and always seem two steps ahead of their customers (i.e. before we were done paying, our drinks were already waiting for us - so was the person's behind us who had given his order to the guy at the register who was cashing us out at the same time; talk about a multitasking champion).

What I wasn't a fan of, though, was:
a) The coffee: my iced coffee tasted pretty watered down, and I didn't end up finishing it because (sorry!) I just didn't think it was that good.
b) The vibe: this place was INSANELY busy, and as result, way too loud and chaotic for me. That sort of intense energy and volume - people buzzing in and out and all around - just isn't for me.

There's a lot of really great coffee shops in Philly.; shop around to find the best one for you. For me, that's not La Colombe.

I have seen the light and it comes in the form of spicy pork tacos from Tortas Guicho Dominguez. Dear friend, let me tell you, this wasn't just any ole' slab of pig - we're talking meat that tasted and looked like it rolled straight out of a hog roast. The convenient/not-so-healthy news is that this taco simply filled with diced onions and cilantro, rolled into a soft wheat-like tortilla is only a few doorsteps from my new dwelling. ayayaya. 

Other updates:
-if you ask for a water, try the "in a cup/on ice" method because if not, you'll end up with a bottle of water (a little piece of my tree-hugging heart will die each time I think of this). 

-chips and salsa are not complimentary --- the guacamole is fresh and tasty. A large order with chips will run you $6.

Wow!

Traveling for business in the area, I could not keep my eyes off the beautiful sculptures on Raymond James Campus when I drove by.  So, after business was done, I walked the garden for a closer look. . .

Stunning and spirit filled.  

This is such an impressive collection-- most of which capture the Native American spirit. I walked from one sculpture to the next with my mouth wide open, in disbelief that such amazing pieces are here.  

Absolutely breathtaking.

Information from the website:
More than 90% of the collection is owned by Tom James, Executive Chairman of Raymond James Financial, and his wife, Mary James. Mr. James has selected almost every piece of artwork himself. While some of the artists in the collection are now deceased, he believes buying works from living artists helps to sustain them in their profession. The collection is on display at the firm's corporate headquarters in St. Petersburg, Florida.

http://www.raymondjames.com/careers/raymond_james_and_the_arts.htm

This hotel is conveniently located in downtown Philadelphia by 13th Street station, which made commuting and exploring so much simpler. When you checked in, the front desk gives you two room cards/keys to be used for your room, elevators, gym, etc. In order to use the elevator to go onto any floor, you have to use your room card/key with exception of the 1st floor (lobby). 

I had to stay here for a week on a business trip. The service was really nice and friendly and my room was nicely sized, modern, cute, comfortable, and clean. It also came with a microwave and a mini fridge. They have happy hours on the 2nd floor in the evening from Monday to Wednesday. The food and drinks from happy hour can be brought to your room if desired. The gym is located in the basement and it even has a laundry room for those who want to to self-service laundry. The stay also came with daily complementary breakfast on the 2nd floor and the food was pretty fresh and legit. Overall, I had a good experience here and would recommend.

& continues to grow on me each time I visit!
& seems to constantly be adding new design elements, beers on tap & fun to this neighborhood cocktail lounge!
&'s cocktails never disappoint...the last visit I had the Water & Life, & the Lime & the Coconut
& who knew aquavit, an old school anise flavored liquer, could be so delicious? 
& if you don't like something on the menu, just ask & let the pros mix something up for ya!
& oh ya, the crowd is cool, lively, somewhat hipster chic, & friendly too!
& they've got great music and events. 

& well, what are you waiting for?

This spot gets 4 stars instead of 5..for the fact they didn't have any french onion soup ready at 11:30 am for me to dive into. I asked what else they had that was diary free, and chicken noodle was the only option she gave me. It was fine, but not what I wanted. I'm all about the Napa Almond Chicken Salad sando to go with the soup, you pick 2 option. And if after a nice spin class and you feel it's OK to eat the rich, fudge brownie, go for it. You won't be disappointed.

This is just a beautiful park that overlooks the Tampa Bay. I've been here many times and it is a beautiful place to watch the sunset, walk on the beach, have a barbeque, play on the playground, or just have a fun day in the sun or sunset. 

My favorite part of the park is the Disc Golf course. It's pretty challenging and definitely one of the nicer and more beautiful courses I've played. Really enjoy the layout of the baskets and appreciate the level of skill required for each shot.

Wow, went there for the first time a couple weeks ago, the service is very friendly, the prices are fabulous, the portions are ginormous and the bakery is super cheap and yummy!

If you give your Spanish a shot, they appear to appreciate it.

The empanadas are really good and if you like it hot, don't forget the salsa, it ROCKS!!!

The milanesa steak was so huge, so wonderful, so "oh I'm going to have leftovers!" good.....will definitely be back.  It's just not a part of town we're in often, but we'll make the trip!

The bakery has lots to choose from and you can buy a loaf of bread for $1!

The food is really really good.  We will definitely be back!

Not incredibly happy with his last visit.  One nail was cut too short and so my poor baby's cuticle was cut and he was nursing it for a bit :(   They're also a bit pricey but that's ok since this place is very clean, friendly and I know my baby is safe with them since he is quite delicate.  My other issue is that they don't quite give him the cut that I like... It's not perfect, but right now, it's the best that I know of....

We came here early on a Saturday night after the place we really wanted to try was inexplicably closed. Somehow we walked in just in time to score the next to last booth. The smells were pretty enticing right from our entrance, and from all directions we saw patrons really enjoying their food.

There were a few apps that sounded interesting, in the spirit of diplomacy I agreed to sharing the ricotta fritters. They were really good too, a blend of a few different cheeses with perhaps just a bit of risotto to help bind them, the garlic aioli was perfect too. But next time the meatballs will be my choice( more on that soon)

We each decided to choose our own pies of the smaller size, hoping that the other would be open to sharing a slice. Trish selected a special of the evening, white Brussels sprout with pancetta. She asked for it to be cooked less crispy than she noticed other tables pies were. It was a solid white too, lots of meat but lacking in the sprout department. I think another sharper cheese other than mozz may have pleased me more. She really enjoyed it, and the thin crust too. This crust has a slightly sourdough taste, the bottom holds up well to toppings, at the same time the outer crust, though it may look burnt, still has a nice chew to it.

This was evident in my Carni, pepperoni, sausage and meatballs. I asked them to cook as they normally would, and I was alright with the slight burn marks. The red sauce was flavorful, and the toppings were great. In the future I would probably skip the pepperoni, not because it wasn't good, but due to its small shape, all the pieces curled up off the pie and became too crispy. I was tempted to point this out to our waitress but after a few bites I decided the rest of the pie was too good to send back. The sausage was very good, and this is an item I use to gauge many places. Better yet was the meatball, super tender and parmy. I'm usually not thrilled with meatballs on my pie, this was probably the best I've had on one.

The decor was darkish, with a lot of hardwoods used as wall coverings. But a very casual and welcoming vibe. Our waitress was very good, patient with us noobs, and receptive to our special requests. I think on a future visit I would prefer trying a large pie, it was only a few$ more than our personal size, and appeared to be much bigger and a little thicker. My only minor complaint was the cost of the meal, I think $13 or so for these tiny pizzas is steep, another place I can think of has this size with unlimited( though lesser quality) toppings for less than $10. There seems to be a few other good shops nearby, so we will most likely try them before returning here. Rounding up to 4 thanks to killer meatball Yelps

On my recent trip to Philly, I loved Frieda so much I came here three times. That is something I never do ever, as I usually try to experience as many spots in a city as humanly possible while traveling. But I was so smitten with Frieda that I genuinely looked forward to returning.

MISSION: Frieda is an intergenerational restaurant, community center, art gallery, bakery, and coffee shop. Its primary identity may be a restaurant, but they often flip the space for workshops, readings, and other cool classes. They sell amazing local goods by local makers, and I love their statement about their artists, bakers and employees: "And while you're here, know that any money you spend at FRIEDA helps us create fair-wage jobs for people of all generations - many of them retired, but still needing to work to make ends meet - as well as support our Outreach Community Program."

FOOD + DRINK: Reasonably priced and crave-worthy. The salmon avocado toast was beautifully presented, had delicious flavor and was very generous. As for bakery, my Mom and I both agreed their croissant was the best we've ever had. Thick but still flaky and melt-in-your-mouth chocolate. The London Fog and other coffee drinks we had were always well-made and satisfying.

SERVICE + VIBE: Nahir is amazing. I actually hugged him on my final visit! We had so many great chats about Frieda's programs, the menu, and just Philly in general. He went above and beyond. The vibe here is very white and minimal, but open and airy. You get a great feeling just sitting there and existing.

I wish this spot was in Cleveland because I'm obsessed with its multi-faceted approach to community and its inclusiveness. I can't recommend it enough! It is such a pleasant surprise that you can feel good about supporting.
Good, worth trying.  For fast food, it is much better than the typical chain restaurants.  The gyros are really good, the wings were good too.

Needed a Poboy!! M

Had this place bookmarked prior to our arrival in NOLA. It was a must stop! 

We stopped in for lunch and super happy that we did! 

My boyfriend had the Big Easy Po Boy, which consisted of roast beef, ham and gravy. I had a bite and it was delicious!! 

I had the Who Dat Po boy which was fried shrimp covered in seafood bisque. It was amazing!!! If I was still hungry I would have ordered the bisque as well. It had such a yummy flavor. Also it wasn't that spicy, but had a great kick. 

Service was very friendly!

When it comes to Carr Wines, two words come to mind, Cabernet Franc! It's delicious. Rich, full-bodied, slightly spicy with a hint of tannins...yum! If you like big, bold reds or Rhone varietals, you'll probably enjoy Carr's Cabernet Franc. 

The tasting room is expansive, with a few high top tables, a large bar and lounge type seating. It's the perfect venue for private events. I've been to several private events here and the space works seamlessly with catering and is large enough for dancing too.

It's also a great place to listen to live music. I like the acoustics. Check Carr's website for a full list of upcoming line ups.

This place has no menu because they serve just one thing: pho ga (chicken). Well, they will also serve you pho bo (beef), but why in the world would you order that if the name of the place is Cafe PHO GA Thanh Thanh?

In the DMV, there are no places that specialize in pho ga, so there was definitely a novelty factor in my experience. Usually, when you order pho ga, you receive a piping bowl with slices of either white meat or dark meat. Here, you can have that AND a plate of sliced chicken (used to make that broth) on the side. I was advised to order a bowl of plain pho (no meat) and a plate of chicken on the side. For two people, small pho bowls and half a chicken are plenty. Pho was actually developed in Northern Vietnam and this place definitely served their food Hanoi-style. The sauce for the chicken was a mixture of lime juice, lime leaves, salt, pepper, and thinly sliced habanero peppers. In the South (where my family is from), it is dipped into nuoc mam gung (ginger fish sauce). After trying the Hanoi-style dip, I still have a nuoc mam gung bias. I suggest everyone try the Hanoi-style dip and judge for themselves because it might be your cup of tea. The broth of the pho is light and flavorful. The chicken platter includes offal, such as creamy liver and heart. 

Service was decent. The establishment is on the small side and in a predominantly Vietnamese zone, but not what is considered Little Vietnam (Bella Vista). Cash only.

3.5 stars, but will round up for novelty factor.

This was a five star experience for me all around.

First of all, I'm shocked it was so hard to find menu pictures. I tried their website, I tried Yelp, I tried Google and came up with nada. I'm not as persistent as I was before kids when I had all the time in the world, but I would have thought there'd be one Yelper who took a picture. I posted menu pictures, albeit not the best quality because of people's heads blocking some parts, but I tried to get the most I could. Zoom in and most of the menu is legible between all four pictures. You're welcome.

I've been dairy free for four (?) months when my nursing baby was diagnosed with a possible dairy intolerance. All I could think of was I never got the chance to get Shake Shack's cheese fries. (It wasn't open that long before the baby was diagnosed and I'd been waiting for the lines to die down.) Once I got cleared (well I strong armed the doctor into allowing me, but the results are the same) to eat dairy again, I knew I had to come to Shake Shack. 

Parking: super easy. There are a ton of outdoor lots and indoor garages. It will be interesting to see the parking situation when everything opens since a lot is still under construction, but on a Monday at 11 a.m. there were a bazillion spots open.

Ordering: The iPad system is really efficient. As long as the people in front of you aren't super slow (which luckily the people in front of us were not), it makes ordering a breeze and pretty foolproof that your order will be correct. There isn't that much customization that can be done (for instance if you randomly want a rare burger, which why would you at a fast food chain, but I digress, you can't get that. You can customize it to be well done though. I wanted it without the bun and with a lettuce wrap and that was an option). I won't be able to order extra cheese on my fries, but I'll live. Overall I like this system. You enter your phone number and they text when your order is ready.

Seating: There's outdoor and indoor seating. Since it's pandemic time, I really appreciate the abundance of outdoor seating. We were here at 11 a.m. on a Monday so not exactly prime time, so I was happy that we pretty much got our pick of tables. Some have large umbrellas that is helpful in the sun.

Food: I got the Black Truffle Burger and cheese fries. All I can say is amazing. The crispy shallots really made the burger. Also, I chose lettuce instead of a bun and the lettuce was massive. It made holding the burger a breeze. The fries didn't let me down either. More places need to embrace cheese sauce. 

I'm lucky this place is 25 minutes from me or else I'd gain 20 pounds. I prefer this place to a lot of restaurants in Tampa. Quick, delicious and (relatively) cheap. I'll definitely be back.

Went for the free coupon and when I get there I was surprised how slim the line was although it's hard to compete with red beans and rice on a Monday in New Orleans. Well the service this day was abominable. They literally threw what I ordered in a bowl in such a way that half of what they threw landed on the assembly line bar and not in my bowl. It was as if none of the employees had been trained in how to make orders. What caused me fury the most was their was a line nearing the door and I had to wait 15 minutes for the cashier to come back to her station to pay, at that point I just walked out leaving my order on the line. This place is too far a drive for me to get this bad a service thus at that point the free coupon meant nothing because I will probably never come here again.

This review is cheating a little because I didn't actually visit the restaurant, but my co-workers ordered lunch for the company one day and decided on Ale Emporium. They got the two best items off the menu, fries and wings.

The Hermanaki wings were SO GOOD. I can't even describe the flavor except to say, I want more. It's cool to know that the flavor was named after the chef who invented them (I believe) and it would be interesting to try the other ones. Best of all, the chicken can be boneless! Oh and make sure to get ranch and bleu cheese dipping sauce!

I imagine this would be perfect party or game day food as well. I'd totally throw a party just to cater fries and wings from Ale Emporium. And to have beer with them. Sounds like a plan!

What better way to end an eventful day that led into the evening, but with an amazing meal at Del Frisco's. As we walk in (Jason K. and I) it might have been a little past 10 pm the first thing you take notice is the decor.  Del Frisco's has 3 floors from the basement to the main floor, leading to the second floor with every floor having a tranquil state. This by far is telling you to just come in ,relax and enjoy .  
 
A former bank converted into a steak house with still a few items left behind to remind you of its past. If you should go to the basement you'll see the vault, this GIANT vault door leading you into another room. This  is where they would host private parties, with  the cases and cases of wine to be admired as you enjoy the atmosphere.  
 
The bar is another great view, with flat screens along with ample seating lining around this place of homage to the libation gods. Then you take notice to the tower of wine bottles leading up to the ceiling . There is more, Del Frisco's also has a fantastic assortment of liquors and drafts to follow. Del Frisco's basically covered the aficionado in you. I feel the libation gods would highly approve of this marvel.   
 
                                   *The feast that was had* 
 
Appetizers- 
 
Steak Tartar~ This came with toasted bread so we could spread the Tartar over it. A nice subtle taste to it, somewhat pasty. Now would I go with again? I would try something else in my opinion. 
 
Fried Oysters~ (2x) This is something we had to order again being it stole the show in the appetizer realm. This came with 2 dipping sauces, I believe one was their homemade tarter and a mild cocktail sauce. Nice sized pieces of oysters that covered the plate.      
 
Main Course with sides- 
 
Del Frisco's Double Eagle Steak ~   A carnivores paradise down to the bone. This was 22 ounces of deliciousness with a peppered crust rubbed into it. Cooked to a medium rare with every cut that just melted in your mouth with every bite. Made me say "Oh my Lord, I'm in heaven"  chew some more and then unleash a moan of satisfaction. I could not finish this masterpiece, this work of art, Michelangelo himself would have been jealous.  This was my lunch for the following day , still held that amazing taste.   
 
King Crab Gnocchi along with the Lobster Mac and Cheese was shared for our sides. Yelpers .. my fellow carnivores,  these heavenly side dishes were the perfect compliment to our steaks.  It was doing a double hit, entering a state of bliss, a euphoria one might say , making your taste buds go into a frenzy. This tag team duo of cheesy goodness that had chunks of crab and lobster mixed in there. This was like I've died and gone to food heaven, a food induced coma.  A MUST order , do it you'll thank me.  
 
Dessert- (shared) 
6 Layer Lemon Cake ~ Like we needed more food , but this was something I have heard about , we just had to do it. Picture 6 layers of heaven with a lemon filling separating each layer. A soft sponge type of  cake, covered in a lemon icing that would make anyone sing with a choir.  Simply put , this was Orgasmic !  
 
The service was on point, our waitress Sasha was with us for every step of the way , making sure everything was to our standards. The general manager was there, a great guy by the name of Carmen that I met, which Jason already knew talked with us. Joking around making sure we were as comfortable as could be. A friendly staff I feel makes your meal even more enjoyable. Even with my "eh" on the Steak Tartar , this is simply a 5 star rating across the board, even if it is a chain establishment.

This is a review of the walking path that spans the entire bridge.

To be honest, reviewing the actual drive across the bridge never crossed my mind. I primarily use this bridge as a running/biking trail. You may find it weird that a path next to traffic is one of my favorite exercise destinations in Tampa Bay, but I challenge you to try it and not feel transported away from the hustle and bustle of everyday life.

A few facts that put into perspective the beauty of this walkway. It is 3,500 feet and cost more than $27 million. Let that sink in for a second - that's a lot of doughnuts. Heck, that's a lot of Bern's dinners! Do I look at the walkway and think, yes that was the best use of $27 million? Well no, because of, you know, poverty, homelessness, etc., but you can't turn back the clock, so you might as well soak in the extravagance of this bridge now that it exists.

You are able to run the entire bridge from Clearwater to Tampa. I believe it is about 11 miles total, but don't quote me on that. I do know that if you start from the middle of the bridge, right where there's a huge...bridge (seriously, there is a part of the path where the walkway separates from the driving lanes to create a bridge. It's a bridge within a bridge.), it is three miles to run to the Tampa side. Therefore, you get a nice six mile run if you run to Tampa and back (I always have to return to where I started so I can get my car) including the excruciating incline that is the bridge within a bridge. Other than that bridge within a bridge, the pathway is flat.

The palm trees that line this walk really contributes to the beauty of it. With the foliage, the beautiful water, and Tampa in the background, you can get some pretty Instagram worthy shots. It also breaks up your run if you stop every so often to take a picture to make non Floridians jealous. #yesitswinter #runninginshorts.

Parking along the walkway is super easy. There are tons of parking spots and I've never had a problem finding one. It's very clearly marked where you can pull off the main highway to park. I'm always coming from the Clearwater side so I park right before the bridge within the bridge. I'm a masochist and enjoy beginning and ending my run with a steep incline (although at my speed I guess you can call it "running").

The beauty of this walkway is not lost on the residents of Tampa Bay. There are always people out walking, running, fishing, generally enjoying nature. If you judge Tampa solely on this path, we would seem like a very fit city. 

I've actually forced someone from out of town to run with me on this bridge so they could experience the allure of Tampa Bay. Yes, I had to loan her workout clothes and shoes, but it had to be done. That's how much I love this trail.

If you're looking for a great new walking trail, forgo the parks and normal sidewalks and come to the Courtney Campbell Bridge.

This place is cool. Is "cool" still a cool word?

I have yet to make any brews or vinos of my own (on my bucket list), but when I do, I know just where I'm going to take my business. Great Fermentations has such a friendly staff and what appears to be all of the ins and outs of becoming your own Brewmaster. 

I'm particularly interested in the cleverly boxed cheese kit they sell - - officially added to my to do list. Hot date: wine AND cheesemaking. 

Bill led my sister and I back to GF's new classroom space in which they have been offering budget-friendly classes ranging from cidermaking to again, cheesemaking;) The best part about the classes is the casual approach in which they take: you decide the amount you want to make - rather than the  more common xyz123-style classes. 

Now, it's time for me to stop brewing (har har) and make a purchase.

A song that I love so dearly begins: "Things we lost to the flames..." 

Rincon Market has shown a notable improvement since the fire of 2013. We thought the market would not rebound. It stayed closed forever and ever and ever. 

The footprint is pretty much the same, though the grocery section appears to take up a bit more real estate. Here, you will find a hot deli (with an amazing asparagus soup, which appears to be on rotation), a delicatessen and an amazing salad bar. 

In fact, my favorite thing to do while vising the market is to hit up the salad bar. Biggest salad bar I have experienced in life -- I am sure. You have the choice of dozens of toppings for your salad. Hard-boiled eggs, chicken, different cheeses, tofu, several different types of olives, onions, corn, dolmas, couscous, peppers, marinaded tomatoes, croutons, and a bunch of different cold salads -- and so much more. All yummy and fresh. 

They also have a wonderful selection of fish and meats, including ribeye, tenderloin, porterhouse, salmon, ahi tuna, sea bass, halibut and salmon roe (ikura). Very good ikura, in fact, imported from Japan. 

If you are looking for lunch on the run -- or if you have time to sit in, or out on the patio -- they do sell (often on rotation) lasagna, chimis, meatloaf, chicken Parmesan, roasted potatoes, sandwiches, mac n' cheese, steamed vegetables and a whole range of other hot dishes. Plus the desserts! People go nuts over the cookies, pies, cakes, pastries and other sweet eats. 

They serve breakfast, and also have a kid's menu -- so family friendly, yes. 

The only ding -- prices can be a bit steep, and no WIFI. 

FYI: For those of you looking for catered services, Rincon will cater all kinds of events, including weddings. And they even have a meeting space for groups and organizations.

[946]

6/25/2019

This Olive Garden is located on busy Baltimore Pike.

Plenty of parking available.

The staff is very friendly and the restaurant is clean.

I love the breadsticks and minestrone soup.

The soda was flat so I switched to water.

The food came out while we were in the middle of our soup.  We had to take it (who sends food back).  We felt a bit rushed because of this.

I had the grilled chicken on pasta $14.  It was just ok as the one piece of chicken was really small.   I should have just ordered the soup and breadsticks

Hubby had chicken parm which he enjoyed.

Kid had the chicken tender kids meal.  He had a few small chicken pieces.  He doesn't like pasta so that was a waste as we could not substitute it for more chicken or grapes.   He was still hungry after his kids meal.

Hubby had potato soup which he loved.

We spend about $50 and felt like a waste :( 

Probably won't come back.

If you want to get a unique experience and start your day of New Orleans partying off right (i.e drinks and a base so strong it could withstand a hurricane of, well, hurricanes) start here on a Saturday morning.  Manhattan omelet is ridiculous, but load up on sides like bacon, and well, bacon.  

What makes this place great though? the servers. only in NoLa

Made a quick end of school semester hurrah, hey it fit the bill for a quickie, but I wouldn't make party plans here.  

2 pool tables. VERY limited food selection, hello only pizza.  Limited beer selection, inclusive of bottled, hello this is Louisiana huh, ehhhh ok. What happened to smoke-free??? (coughs).  Technical difficulty with opening & closing a tab... hmmm ok.  New to the rodeo I see. 

Nice bar staff.  Ample parking. Nice flat screen tv for viewing.

We played darts.  Two rounds of pool.  Fed the juke box, or is there a more tech-savvy name for it nowadays? And stood around & caterwauled. ... and yeah that was it.  I guess you say what more is there to do at a bar/daiquiri shop, but it just seemed a dismal place.  Not much happening. BORING!!!!!! 

Stop in if you like, but for me there's too much drinking & eating going on to park it here.  I'll pass & keep passing & keep passing...  you get it.

For the discerning person who knows there's a world of NOLA T-shirt sayings better than "I got Bourbon on Sh*t Faced Street," and the cool thing is that even if some of the sayings/slogans and images seem too obscure for a souvenir, there's plenty of more familiar-to-the-masses T-shirts that are creative and funny. 

These shirts are made really well and aren't your typical Hanes Beefy T, y'know? Ladies shirts are a soft, thin cotton- even V-neck and beater varieties, and can I get an AMEN for no cap sleeves that would make even Lara Flynn Boyle look like she has fat arms?!

My favorites: 
It's Not Beautiful being Easy  
West Bank Pho Ever 
Come Hell or Bywater (love the shotgun house image on that one!)

Meeeeeeh.  WORST SERVICE EVER.

I stayed at the Sonesta hotel, which is attached to this Elephant & Castle outpost.  I'm familiar with the chain.  I've never been super impressed.  However, when you've been traveling all day and desperately need food and it's on the late side of the evening and you're from Chicago and not really in the mood to get lost in Philly hunting for a restaurant, this was what it was going to be.

Our server couldn't have been lamer.  He took at least 20 minutes to bring me a Sprite and a Coors Light when there were maybe 10 other people in the restaurant.  He was talking about how he's leaving soon to be a ski bum or some shit and I was like, 'Bro.  You may be quitting your job soon but I need a drink now.  Hop to it."

Food?  Eh.

I'm not into it.

I don't travel to sit around in hotels - all I want is a safe place that is reasonably clean, has warm running water, and seems safe - for those purposes Sun Suites of Metairie fit the bill.  At a mere $46 a night I had a TV (the remote didn't work,) two beds, a coffee maker, a refrigerator, a microwave, and even a stove.  Parking was free and well lit, checkin/checkout were simple and without any charges - honestly, for the price it was a helluva a deal.  They even had free Wi-Fi!

Admittedly I did see a couple of small roaches during my visit - both in the kitchen and near the table...my mother would've freaked out, but honestly I didn't mind...unless you have allergies they are harmless.  One star off for the roaches, a lack of a gym, and the crappy soap.

Yeah - I have pretty low hotel expectations - how else do you afford to eat like I do on vacations?  :-)

Lots of items from local artists, from ceramics, jewelry, hang bags, cards, and lots more things. Really wanted to buy a very nice mug for $20. Love the color of the glaze. There were a bunch of wind chimes too. Very cool!

Royal Orchid is a very large restaurant with multiple seating areas and an open bar area in a Ramada Hotel in Westshore. They serve up some first rate Indian cuisine and also have other Asian and continental dishes in an extensive menu to meet all tastes. They are introducing a lunch buffet for 2015. They also have an extended happy hour and lunch specials.

The multiple seating areas at Royal Orchid can accommodate a very large gathering but the setup maintains intimacy and comfort and isn't overwhelming at all. The main space is a large open area with a bar area and dining space with high tables and comfy booths. There is also a patio area, more secluded side dining area and banquet rooms.

Royal Orchid serves various Asian dishes and offers a lunch buffet. The Tom Yam Goong, Thai shrimp coconut lemongrass soup, was tasty. The lamb korma was excellent with a rich subtle taste. The mango lassi was rich and delicious. The naan was excellent. They will spice to the heat desired and the food tends to have some zip.

Dishes are served in hammered silver bowls and rice (white, brown, jasmine) that are conducive yo family style and group dining. Have as much or as little of any one dish as you like! They also split a soup no problem so two of us could share it. Serving various dishes over a rice felt traditional and everything tasted very good. 

We met the chef who has more than two decades of experience internationally. Our server Kristina was super and sweet. It's a classy tasteful feeling space but also relaxed. There are even nooks with pool and Foosball for gamers.

Look forward to returning. Hope people find this great space with some very tasty dishes.

Sterling Pig is yet another creation by the same guy who brought Media Diego's (OK), Belle Epoque (Can be great can also be so-so) and Picasso (Not good - and shares the SAME KITCHEN as Belle).

Decor is Rustic at SPB and my husband enjoyed a specialty IPA.  ($6).
The food is way, way over priced especially for the meh quality.  My Flank Steak salad had a small portion of delicious sliced steak over a bed of boring mixed greens with 3 (no kidding, 3) tiny cubes of diced tomato.  I asked for more tomatoes and they were brought.  No cucumbers were  available.  For $16 that is kinda steep.

DH also had flank steak - his was also a small portion (too small in his opinion) served with grilled zucchini, red and yellow peppers.  $22.  (Whoa.)

Our kid had the pulled pork sandwich ($14) sans coleslaw.  It was very smoky and kinda dry.  She added BBQ sauce to it.  Brioche bun was tasty.  

The fries that came with the sandwich could be a memoir all their own.  They literally glistened with grease and were so oil-soaked it was almost comical.  They were presented in a cute "mini fry-basket" lined with paper that el kiddo said "was (clearly) not doing it's job".
No way for $6 I would have ordered a separate side of these oil-slick fries.

Unless I am dragged here by fellow Media-ites, I am in absolutely no hurry to return to SPB.

Stick to the beer and you'll be fine.

I tried to give it 4 stars but my heart wouldn't let me. Yes they need a fridge in the room. It's hot here most of the time!! But the benefits outweigh the negatives.

If you want to be on Bourbon but away from a  reasonable amount of noise then get a courtyard balcony or facing Toulouse balcony. I recommend the Toulouse balcony. It can get a little noisy. Check my pics/video but you can people watch and you can go to sleep. Well after 2am... That's me! Clean clean room. Awesome shower. Room is small which is why I recommend balcony room.  But the beds are heavenly Sheraton beds
