Everyone from the front desk to the valet staff are helpful and friendly. Even when you are drunk. I know I asked some stupid questions lol. But the benefit of opening that front door and you are literally right on bourbon street is worth every penny and I know how much I love my Hampton inn on carondolet. Restaurant/bar downstairs. Cool pool with bed like chairs that changes colors at night. This is what you want. Come join me

Jackalope played host to a fun outing over the holidays. 

We were the first customers as soon as they opened. It seems like this area is up and coming with lots of trendy businesses. I think due to the time of the year we were in Nashville, this resulted in a ghost town like scenario. Nonetheless, I wouldn't sleep on this local brewery!

One of the cleanest breweries I've seen if you ask me. Spotless and extremely well decorated. You really get a sense of the theme and vibe they're going for. The bright colors and meticulous decor made me feel like I was on the set of a Wes Anderson movie. 

With a slight chill in the air, we played cornhole for most of our visit. As customers trickled in, the patio seemed like the cool kids club. Beer-wise, I kept it simple with their Hazy IPA. Tasty enough to order two!

I won't be a frequent customer since I'm based in Colorado, but had to share my good experience with the rest of the world!

Great spot to cop a squat and grab a cup of Joe (soy, almond & coconut milk alternatives available). You can even snag a seat on their plush faux leather sofa to take a load off. They have chess board table tops, a small line of groceries, pet treats, food, knick knacks & more. 

Lighters, umbrellas, bubble gum, muffins, hot tea...YOU NAME IT!

Service is splendid. Conveniently located on Washington Ave for business owners, loft renter's and party goer's. 

~Christy was here.

I spent three days eating breakfast and lunch at the Reading Terminal Market because of a convention across the street. I think this is by far, the best food item I've eaten in the Market. 

The Pot Roast Beef, Egg and Cheese breakfast sandwich was so good!! The roast beef was super tender and practically melted in my mouth. And don't even get me started on the egg - it had so many folds! I don't think i've ever eaten a breakfast sandwich with that much egg in it before. 

The people behind the stand were super nice and food came out quickly in a clear and consistent order. Everyone gets a number and therefore there's no awkward "is that my sandwich or your sandwich?". 

I knew I would be eating a late lunch (had to coordinate lunch with colleagues) and this sandwich kept me very full from ~8:30AM all the way to 2PM.

Excellent! The service and setting were wonderful. However, just to add to the experience it would have been nice to have light Brazilian music playing in background, and maybe a server walking around offering cigars out of a box (just as they do with tea). $50 per person gets you the salad buffet and the meats; there were around 11 types of meat.

With the Pho 75 in Chinatown closing and the bulk of the Ramen Boy reviews scaring me I found myself in serious need of finding a quick and easy noodle fix when I didn't feel like climbing aboard the Pho Train (http://www.yelp.com/biz/pho-xe-lua-viet-thai-philadelphia#hrid:TqIDfYjlnBN7MbrDfxqbEA/src:self). Fortunately I remembered Rachel's and Steven's reviews and was able to savor a bowl of the comforting pleasure that hand drawn noodles delivered.

if my pho addiction had taught me anything its that the perfect asian soups have to be filled with a revitalizing broth, a plentiful and oftentimes odd assortment of additional ingredients, and a helping of some of the best noodles that you've ever had; all while coming at a fairly inexpensive pricetag. And for just $6 the seafood soup with shrimp, scallops, clams, and fish balls had Nan Zhou delivering on all cylinders. But the main thing I wasn't expecting was the fact that the tantalizing consistency and interesting back story of the hand drawn noodle recipe may have me giving pho and ramen a stink eyed comparison for the forseeable future.

Be sure to bring cash to get your fill, but not a whole lot unless your table feels the need to split random delicacies like marinated duck, beef tendons, and spicy pig ears. And be sure to keep your vegetarian friends at a distance.

Had lunch here last month (August) while visiting Philly. We were on our way to the Franklin Institute and decided to grab a quick lunch since we had skipped breakfast.

While visually nice inside the music, as mentioned by others reviewing this establishment, did leave a lot to be desired. Especially at lunch time. 

I really enjoyed the salsa they provided with the chips while we waited for the entree to arrive. One thing I've noticed about Mexican restaurants up north is they only give you salsa with your chips, no white sauce like they do further down south.

Both of us had meal that consisted of 3 beef taco's for lunch. It was ok, but I've had better. There was something about the way the way the ground beef was prepared that I didn't like. Maybe it was the spices. However it filled the spot. 

All in all, not a bad experience but it wasn't great either. Next time I'm in town I'll be trying another Mexican restaurant.

My new obsession. The Crêpe Place is a newish brick & mortar for The Crêpe Cart located in the French Market. A simple name, but I'm just going to refer to it henceforth as Vegan Crêpe Paradise.

Although crêpes lend themselves well to eating in transit, unless I'm in a rush, I prefer to sit down and eat. This airy cafe with plenty of seating is all kinds of perfection for me. I had a lunch meeting here the other day (though to be fair, I was so into my hummus crêpe, it was hard to concentrate on anything but!) 

The folks behind this operation are so dang nice, too! I believe the owner was training a new crêpe maker, and both were super helpful and enthusiastic about their product. I am not used to having an entire menu of vegan options, so I was pleasantly overwhelmed. I mean... sweet *and* savory crêpes for vegans (and GF, though this is not me)? SWOON. For my first food of the day, I always go with savory and the hummus crêpe was calling my name. 

But first, the perfect latte. Although I'm used to paying more along the lines of .50 for almond milk and here it's a $2 up charge, it's worth it (not sure what brand they use but it's very creamy and steams well). 

My crêpe was lovingly prepared and bursting with goodness: creamy hummus, greens (basil and spinach, I believe), tomatoes. Honestly, I cannot get it out of my head and I need to go back immediately. I was encouraged to try the pesto crêpe next time and I'm counting down the days. 

This is also a great dessert place. Besides the aforementioned sweet crêpes (I've never had a sweet crêpe in my life, but memories of walking past crêperies in Europe are vivid. Especially because I knew them damn crêpes would never be vegan!), there's also vegan donuts.

I adore this place so hard.

Close to my place of employment, I've stopped in quite a bit for gas and a few snacks to get me through the day. The only downfall is, they're quited limited in SNACKS & DRINKS. 

I can recall just going in for a quick COCA-COLA & there were none. To be fair, currently, May 2017, they're in the middle of reconstruction and maybe, just maybe, this is the reason for limited supplies prior to this, ehhhhh idk. 

Getting gas was always easy, turn in, pull up to the pump, pay, pump your gas and go... On the corner of Tulane & Jeff Davis Parkway, this is easily accessible. So, hopefully, the construction is finished soon; we shall see what the future holds.

The restaurant is located on the corner of Chateau and Mississippi and there is plenty of free street parking nearby.  I came for dinner on a Tuesday night and there wasn't a wait for a table.  I hear it gets really packed on the weekends.  The décor is upscale with an old time feel.  The back bar area is only opened on Wednesday - Sunday.  Our waitress wasn't the friendliest, but she got the job done.  

The menu is limited, but the offering they have is done well.  I started off with the $5 fried chick peas, but they weren't that good.  They were crunchy and slightly spiced, but I kept waiting for more flavor to kick in.  The $7 KALE SALAD was great!  The soft boiled egg was a fantastic touch.  I went with the $18 special chicken and it was delicious.  The meat was tender and flavorful.  

For dessert, I got the $5 ICE CREAM SANDWICH and it was magnificent.  It came wrapped like a giant piece of candy.  The cookie was soft and perfectly sweet and went really well with the ice cream.

Delectables is one of this Tucson businesses that's been around like Forever, and we mustn't forget about this oldie but goodie (like I have). They've been on my "must visit" list for quite some time, and admittedly, I can be a creature of habit, even in this job. I stick to the same lunch spots when I'm on the go, mostly out of convenience and obviously familiarity. Anyhow, I chose Delectables to pick up a salad as I was on the go as usual. An order of the spinach salad with walnuts, apples, olives, and feta, subbed the chicken for grilled salmon was quite tasty and generous. The salmon was a bit over cooked and tough for my liking, but I at least it's wild salmon. I'll take over fatty farm raised salmon any day. The hostess was a pleasure and pick up was easy peasy. Their new updated bar looks super welcoming and cozy...and I did I mention their check-in offer is 50% off a bottle of wine? Dang! Aside from that, their menu is super vegetarian and health conscious friendly. It has been for many years. It's been a while since I've had the cheese plate, but that's nice too. Looking forward to a cozy happy hour or dinner in the very near future.

This place is COOL and this place is FREE. 

Do you really need to know any more?

As it turns out, I hadn't been to WINO in a VERY long time, possibly for almost a year. Some things haven't changed since the last time I was there - specifically, it's just as fabulous as ever. They have added some new Enomatic machines (they're in the back now, too!) One of which contained the tastiest bottle of Sauvignon Blanc I've had in recent memory. 

My new favorite thing (though I wouldn't advise you to actually do this unless you're looking to invest a substantial chunk of change in the local economy) is running a tab on my pink WINO card (as opposed to putting a set amount of money on it). When you put your "tab" card in the Enomatic machines, it says VIP rather than the dollar amount left on the card. Badass. And dangerous. I heart you, WINO.

I have worn glasses or contact lenses since I was 10 years old. So I have had my share of eye examinations and I am here to tell you the best is Koetting Associates. 

You will get the most extensive and thorough eye examination you have ever experienced. As you are being examined, you'll wonder why your previous doctor never did each of the test that KA completes on your eyes. Before you enter the examination room for your vision, you are taken to a separate room for approximately 8 different test.  These extra test, is what puts them ahead of the class. Being over 40 now and having monovision, I appreciate the extra time they take making sure my distance and closeup vision are both good. 

The entire staff from Dr. Castellano to the receptionist are professional and personable. Thanks to their professionalism, I can see clearly now.

I stopped in right before closing one evening as I was passing by with friends, when I was in New Hope. The first thing I noticed was the amazing smell of leather as I enter the shop. 
I was greeted by a friendly woman and the owner Fred. My friend was looking to buy a hat. He found a beautiful handmade Irish cap. He was going to purchase this exact brand of hat elsewhere for more money and was happy to purchase it for less.. The owner was very kind explaining and showing me around his store. Fred has an extensive knife collection, and his custom hats and jackets are amazing. Fred's wife makes beautiful one of a kind hand made jewelry. I even noticed he sells custom cowboy boots, wallets belts, and accessories. 
This is a small store, and quantity is limited, but if you want something custom or special then this is your place. Fred does some repairs right on the premises. 
If your looking for authentic good quality leather items like handbags, custom hats, and jackets, boots and jewelry, and artisan style knives then you should definitely check out Fred Eisen Leather and Art Knives.

In das Macy´s in Philadelphia sind wir nur durch einen Zufall reingegangen, da wir nach einer ausgiebigen Besichtigungstour bei drückender Nachmittagshitze ein wenig Abkühlung brauchten. Das Gebäude in der Market Street wirkt von außen wirklich beeindruckend und auch von innen wird man nicht enttäuscht.

Im Eingangsbereich fühlt es sich noch fast wie ein ganz normales Kaufhaus an. Aber auch hier fallen schon die tollen Stuckdecken, die mächtigen Säulen auf und man hat eher das Gefühl in einem Florentiner Palast zu sein. Das Gebäude ist das ehemalige Wanamakers Kaufhaus, das von Macy´s in 1995 übernommen wurde und ist wirklich ein architektonisches Meisterwerk..

Wenn man dann weiter in das Innere des Kaufhauses vordringt stößt man auf den Grand Court, der seinen Namen aufgrund der Größe zu Recht trägt. Einfach nur überwältigend und wir haben erstmal die Köpfe nach oben kreisen lassen. Irgendwie eine Mischung aus Opernhaus und Kirche, denn an einer Wand ist die riesige Wanamakers Pfeifenorgel angebracht. 

Der Grand Court soll auch über eine einzigartige Akustik verfügen. Jährlich findet hier die Macys Weihnachts Light Show statt, ein einzigartiges Licht- und Tonspektakel. Untermalt wird das ganze mit einer festlichen Beleuchtung des Grand Court und einem festlich geschmückten Weihnachtsbaum.

In der Mitte des Grand Court befindet sich dann auch noch der riesige Wanamaker Eagle. Die Bronzestatue soll 2.500 Pfund wiegen und wurde wie die Orgel 1904 von der St. Louis Weltausstellung erworben. Der Adler ist natürlich ein sehr begehrtes Fotoobjekt und fast jeder Tourist lässt sich mit ihm ablichten.

Eingekauft haben wir nichts, da wir nur Blicke für die einzigartige Architektur hatten. Ein wirklich sehenswertes Gebäude.

Awhile ago, me and a friend were going to see a 76er's game and we wanted to get a bite to eat before the game. My friend said let's meet at Barrel's for dinner and he text me the address.
I used to work in South Philly long ago and often had lunch from Johnny Barrel's, my friend said it was all in the family.
Barrel's is different than I expected. Well for one thing, it's a house, so I proceeded not knowing what to expect. It was a cold early night, but it was warm inside, the decor was, well homey and we sat down to order some food. Our server brought us menus and I wanted to order something I haven't tried yet. 
I ordered the fried gnocchi appetizer and I chose the Chicken Roma as my entree. 
The gnocchi was good, a little crispy on the outside and goory on the inside. My Chicken Roma was excellent, chicken breast sauteed in wine and butter with a lemony taste, with tomatoes and mozzarella cheese and some linguine on the side. My friend was happy with his food, he ordered the chicken cutlet sandwich,(been there done that).  Prices were reasonable, service was good, and we left Barrel's full and satisfied.

Yiro Yiro, how many ways to say and spell that delicious pita sandwich with grilled meat, various sauces, tantalizing dips and veggies? Over the years I've had many different concoctions of this sandwich and Yiro Yiro's version was pretty darn good.
I DoorDashed them yesterday and delivery was extremely quick and I appreciated the care and the use of quality packaging they use. You would be surprised seeing how some spot use cheap containers for their food.
I ordered the beef/lamb combo with a rice pilaf, fresh salad of diced tomatoes, cucumbers, eggplant and spices, and a wonderful spicy feta dip. I finished the meal with a scrumptious baklava.
The meal came with triangular shaped grilled pita bread. The portions were abundant.  I grabbed a slice of the pita bread and crammed as much of the meat the bread could handle and smeared the spicy feta cheese dip over it. What a heavenly bite! The beef and lamb was tender and that spicy feta was the truth. The rice pilaf was fluffy and not dried out and I didn't know the name of the salad, but it was so fresh and crisp, a perfect accompanying item for the meal.
The baklava was magnificent, two large pieces encrusted with honey and pistachios with a thin layer of vanilla icing across the top of the philo dough. It was a sweet ending to a good meal. 
I would have awarded Yiro Yiro 5 stars if I would have received whole pieces of the grilled pita bread so I could make a whole gyro, the small pieces of pita ran out quickly. Next time I will ask for that in advance.
Delicious!!!

I'm from California, I am just so excited to see a Dunkin' Donuts near my hotel.  Stayed in Nashville for four days, went to Dunkin' Donuts 4 times.  Each time I got a small iced latte, it's been consistent and have been very happy.

Props to my aunt-in-law (second aunt? aunt once removed?) for guiding our group to Pho Grand for some delicious -- cheap! -- lunch. We'd just departed a Catholic wedding and walked a couple of blocks in super-summer-St-Louis heat (not fun). There was a bit of a wait to get us seated, but I have to say given our unannounced party of 15, that we were given tables right next to each other in a fairy fast fashion (even if the host did seem abundantly irritated with our arrival and clustering in front of the non-existent lobby.

I was beyond grateful that they left a pitcher of water at the table for us to rehydrate with. We had two servers taking care of us -- both of whom were exceptionally (I thought) attentive to the needs of two vegetarians in our party... taking care to make recommendations, bring substitute dipping sauces and make sure no fish sauce was included in anything they ordered. 

I opted for a bun dish, vermicelli with pork egg roll. The helping was not as large as I'm accustomed to back home, but it was plenty for one for lunch. The nuoc cham was nothing short of magic; what do they do to make there's such a perfect balance of flavor? I doused it over my dish and added plenty of hot sauce, dipped my chopsticks through the crisp cucumber, carrot shavings down into the warm noodles. Oh yeah. 

Decor is more dressed up then your typical family-owned Asian restaurant. Even the bathrooms were nice! Great food and great service. Pretty large amount of menu options, but would have appreciated more lemongrass items and chicken options. Would have loved to try some pho, but it was prohibitively hot outside to tackle that!

So yes I was here, January 11th, last week and once I did my thing walking around seeing the Liberty Bell Center and all.  I walked through the chinatown area and made it here to the Terminal Market.  I had not been to Philly for a while so it was nice to finally check this place out.  I did like walking around seeing all these nice food options here.  I got here initially early but was not ready to eat too heavy.  It was my mistake, was not sure when DiNic's or the Reading Terminal Market would close in general but I missed my chance to eat the famous Roast Pork sandwich that I saw on Man Vs Food!!!!

I did eat at the Ice cream place, I was told to check that out and it was worth it (so good).
-Philly I will be back, I need to eat that Roast Pork sandwich.  So now I have something to look forward to in a future visit.

P.S. the Bathrooms looked pretty sad here.  I used it of course because I just had to go but this reminded me of some kind of grade school mishap in the bathroom, where some little kid left shit everywhere on the floor included, well every where except in the toilet.  There was plenty of space to walk around the problem areas and just get to the sink to wash your hands or whatever.
Good homey Thai food.  They'll boost or reduce the heat to order (good when you're dining with dietarily challenged).  I LOVE the red curry.

Wow!

Someone had posted on Nextdoor app in my neighborhood..of course I had to try.

They are in S.Reno 10-2 ..South Meadows and Veterans at the end of the road..

Two miles from the house and so delicious.

Bigger and full of meat!

Three carne asada and three carnitas.. red and green hot sauce..

Sauces were kickin spicy, but good..

All for $12!

You know where I'll be during lunch..

[1032]
11/2019

This place was always on my bucket list so I was happy check it out when company came to visit.  

We parked in the visitor center garage 

We visited on a Saturday night in November.  It was cold out but we were able to warm up by the FirePit.  

There was a tent that looked like it served s'mores and hot chocolate but you can see the crazy long line so we did not go inside. 

The kids rode a train, carousel and played mini golf. The golf course was good as each hole was a different landmark in Philly.  

The place looks cool with the zillion holiday lights.   There was a music/light show each half hour that was pretty cool.  

Definitely a cute place to take the kids.    We stayed 2 hours in the 30 degree cold but definitely could have stayed more. 

I'll definitely be back

ALLSPICE IN THE QUESO? Okay, so I'm a creative guy, but c'mon where are the chilis, garlic & cumin?  It's the first queso I've had that tastes oddly like pumpkin pie.

TOMATO-DILLA: I picked-out a plateful of diced tomatoes that terrazoed my steak quesadilla (see pic).  The rest of the entrée was darn tasty but the pico de gallo needs a TexMex 101 class.

SALTY, SALTY, SALTY margarita mix. I've never put a straw in a daiquiri and it cloyed so wincingly.  It's disappointing because the space is awesome, the servers attentive, pricing competitive, however the food is way off.

BETTER NEARBY LATINO: La Casita, Casa Guerrero, Juan's Flying Burrito, Felipe's, Oso's, Purple Cactus, a bag of Fritos with microwaved Wolf Brand...

A decent outlet mall with a couple of big anchors like Scheel's (a sporting goods and outdoors store) and an IMAX theater, as well as a number of smaller outlets lining a pleasant interior walkway with benches and fountains. There's parking galore, and if you're a fan of specific stores here, then it's worth a longer visit. Otherwise, it's a nice, quick stroll in the warmer months.

*******Restaurant week Review***** I was surprised to find out that I could indulge in restaurant week in my old home town of Cherry Hill! I love this town, it's people, and especially the restaurants. 
I've been to the capital grille in Philadelphia, but never the one in CH! They opened it shortly before I moved from this area. 
Esthetically everything was perfect and very comfortable. I didn't like being sat in the bar area once we said we were there for restaurant week, but I had a meeting soon after my lunch so I didn't want to make waves. My lunch date didn't seem to mind. The bartender who was serving everyone in the area did an exceptional job and she should be commended. 
We both ordered the salmon for an entree an appetizer and desert. I loved the flourless chocolate cake and I enjoyed my meal overall.

My friends really, really wanted to do this tour on our last trip to New Orleans, so as the accommodating host I am, I signed us up. Now, little bit of a disclaimer... some of my girlfriends are really into the whole Twilight/Vampire Diaries thing. I am not. But I'm not opposed to vampire lore. I've read my fair share of Ann Rice books and seen plenty of old vamp horror flicks.

The tour I pictured was something completely different. Intimate and entertaining with just a little bit of kitsch. It was none of this. First of all, at the meeting place I was expected there to be maybe 10-15 people waiting. There were so many people (75-100?) that I was confused. Who were all these people? Were we all going on the same tour? They broke us into "smaller" groups and away we went. Our "small" group had maybe 20-25 people and seemed to keep picking up more as the tour went on. You couldn't hear anything the "host" was saying unless you were on his heels constantly. The stories were kind of boring and dragged on. 

Most of us ended up bailing half way through. I hate to say it but this was kind of a waste of money.

Was visiting with my boyfriend for the weekend like I always do and decided to get some delivery since we can no longer go out to eat anywhere. We ended up choosing this spot because it had pretty decent reviews on Yelp and we never tried it before, so we were trying some place different. 

We ended up ordering a bun, cheese wonton, crab dumplings, to share and he got the beef stick with shrimp fried rice, and I ordered the sesame chicken which came with white rice. 

As far as the apps, the beef stick were the highlight of them, the flavors that the beef was seasoned with was so tasty. The bun, cheese wonton and crab dumplings werent anything spectacular and I wouldnt order those again. 

As for the sesame chicken with white rice, it was so good too. The chicken pieces were huge and the glaze on top was very flavorful. 

I would eat here again and try some other things but maybe eat in once the virus is over with. Maybe it would taste different.

I was anxious about air travel with my family - that included two children under the age of three. Faced with the reality of bags, baby carriers, car seats, strollers, and the 17,000 lbs of other "stuff" you need while traveling with children, I really had no idea how the hell we were going to get to Florida without strapping our luggage to our backs like a bunch of pack mules. While we still (likely) looked like a rag tag bunch, Visiting Baby was absolutely clutch to deliver many of our baby and young child necessities to our week-long beach rental so we didn't have to cart them along! 

I'll just come out and say it - the website is dated. The ordering process was clunky and it was hard to figure out what we ordered for the week while reading through a very long confirmation email that was all in paragraph form. That being said, they totally came through with an on-time order delivery and pickup and provided great items for our week. We rented the following:

-Double stroller: Baby trend side by side double stroller that definitely had some wear, but it worked very well for us. 
-High chair: Very clean and a necessity for our one year old.
-Toy box: This was the shining star of our order. Allison (Visiting Baby owner) requested info about what our two girls like, their ages and whatnot. Our toy box was custom "curated" and chock full of books, toys and even dress up items that kept our girls highly entertained. 
-Music table: Again, very clean, and a hit for our little one. 
-Play mat: 25 foam squares for a more comfortable play space on top of the tile floor. 
-Pack n play: In great shape and provided a comfy mattress and fitted sheets. 
-Bed rails: Self-explanatory, clean and functional.

Overall, this service is a godsend for families traveling with young kiddos, and with a handful of technological improvements like an updated ordering system, text options for delivery/time frame, Visiting Baby would be 5 stars in no time.

French Quarter Haunted Ghost Tour

Great tour with Clint! We had a better "haunted" experience this time with our tour guide, Clint (in reference to our first experience last year). We used our City Pass and booked an evening of the French Quarter Haunted Ghost Tour. We stopped by famous places like Lalaurie Mansion, Lafitte's Blacksmith Shop and the Omni Royal as Clint proceeded to tell us stories behind each landmark and, you know, ghostly sites and stuff where ghastly spirits have been documented. I found the stories fascinating.

Lafitte's Blacksmith Shop is actually a bar and it has a long haunted history. We were given a chance to go inside and check it out for a chance encounter with Jean Lafitte. Legend has it that he simply stands in the dark corners, staring at people until he is noticed, at which time his ghost disappears into the shadows. Not sure if his ghost would show up with all that people inside but supposedly he is always seen on the first floor, most of the time near the fireplace that's inside. Well, that was just one of his stories... there's many more where it came from. 

This non-theatrical, non-costumed tour guide shared events rooted in NOLA history and feature historically accurate storytelling. Clint was a great storyteller, no sugar coating anything. The tour was about two hours long. It is a walking tour so wear comfy shoes and probably bring a bottle of water to hydrate yourself. Normal Entry Price - Adult: $25.00  

Review #1500 updated

The last time I ate at the old Farmer Boy predates my existence on Yelp, and it looks like I've been on here since 2007. You can infer my opinion of the diner from that. But just in case: I distinctly remember my dining companion having a large hair in his butter, which he pointed out, and the returning dish simply had the hair picked out and the pat of butter flipped upside down. So...if that's what was needed to keep menu costs cheap, I don't mind paying a couple dollars more. But that's the old Farmer Boy.

The new Farmer Boy is all cleaned up, and bright and tidy! It was a Monday lunchtime and all tables were filled, with a few seats open at the counter. We had a meatloaf sandwich and the chicken and waffles, and were very pleased with both.

The chicken is fried to order, it'll take 12-15 minutes. Its coating is zippy, as is the chile-spiked syrup. It's $11 for a Brussels style Belgian waffle and two large fried wings. An additional order of the chicken is $4. 

The other lunch fare is in the $10-12 range, on par with most restaurants. On my visit, the other patrons had the full range of young and older people, and I ran into family friends from the San Roque area. Everyone was friendly, the food was hot and good. I'm a fan. 

The old Farmer Boy will forever be associated with Mary Birdie, and that woman really scared me. May she rest in peace, along with the old restaurant.

I've hit up Village Whiskey twice in the past couple of months and it's still a great spot for a bite. Both visits were on Sundays, and we've been lucky to get seated right away both times even though the restaurant is small and seating is tight. 

On the first visit, three of us shared a bunch of plates: pickled cherry tomatoes, village burger, bbq pork sammy, and duck fat fries with Sly Fox cheddar sauce. Everything was delicious! I was also happy to see a couple solid non-alcoholic options as well; the lavender fields was a hit! 

Last Sunday, I tried the veggie burger and my sister had the bbq pork sammy. Again, we ordered the fries with cheddar sauce. I do think the cheddar sauce could have a bit more flavor, but the fries themselves are really great regardless.  

Honestly, Village Whiskey is a spot I didn't think about much because I always just assumed it would be too crowded. Now that I've found the sweet spot, it's becoming part of my weekend rotation!

When I first started working in the suburbs, I felt fear.  I feared the commute on the fabled I-76.  I feared the loss of my individuality, as plenty of movies/paintings/songs lament over the disintegration of self that results from daily work.  I feared that this was the next step in life, which would bring me one step closer to its bitter, bitter end.

But most of all, I feared lunch.  I want to look forward to lunch every day by making it really awesome(on days where I don't pack my own food).  My coworkers had enthusiastically recommended a small independent sandwich shop called Wawa where I could get lots of different things for lunch.  Wow!  They have soups AND sandwiches AND cigarettes!(I don't smoke but maybe I will start now).  My prospects looked bleak and, like many in a state of desperation, I turned to Yelp...and Yelp delivered.

I walked into Nadia Thai at lunchtime and the place was impressively packed.  This is a good sign.  I had the lunch special($8.95 for two starters and an entree) - spring roll, coconut soup, and chicken red curry.

The soup and the curry were freaking delicious(the spring roll was OK).  The service was prompt and friendly.

Remember that fear that I talked about in the opening of this review?  It melted like the faces of those guys in Raiders of the Lost Ark.  I had found a solution to my problem, and it came in the form of Thai food in Lansdale.  I will be returning to this establishment frequently.

5 stars for currently being my favorite lunch in Montgomery County.

On the action-movie-parallel-satisfaction-scale, this place is the final fight at the end of Star Wars: Revenge of the Sith BUT all of the terrible plot points and asinine dialogue and hate from everything about all of the prequels has been deleted from my brain, Eternal Sunshine style.

BIBOU (Part 1 of a 2-part review; click link below at bottom to read Part 2):

What, PhillyBestBYOB, no reviews of Bibou???  And you call yourself an expert on Philly BYOBs?

Although I enjoyed this amazing restaurant a total of 5 times in 2012 and 3 time so far in 2013, I went to the "Bibou at Blackfish" dinner last Monday and we are planning a Southern Rhone wine dinner for next week, for some reason I have kept putting this review off.  Perhaps I don't feel that I can really do Bibou the justice it deserves, or maybe I'm having trouble picking the ultimate of ultimate dining experiences, from among so many great meals, about which to write a truly epic ode to French bistros that will finally win me Yelp's ROTD?

Or maybe I'm just procrastinating?

Anyway, I'm going to pick a dinner from last year to write about, since I took photos of all the dishes and have pretty good tasting notes (although appologies to Bibou if I get some of the ingredients wrong...I love Pierre's sexy French accent, but I don't always catch everything).

Since this is an ode, some accompanying music seems appropriate (you know this has to be a great restaurant if someone takes the trouble to write a rap song about it, explicit lyrics and all!):

"She said she wanted foie gra,
And some escargot.
I said I didn't care for that,
Was tired of the snow.
She ordered three appetizers,
And wanted one to go.
I told her she was crazy.
What she doin', I don't know."

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fCneE4uC514

Sunday, 21 October 2012 (see photos):

10 of us, 9 guys and 1 gal (Ladies, this is why you should go to our wine dinners, the guys usually outnumber the gals, so you will be totally fawned over!) met for a Champagne and Rhone wine dinner at Bibou.  An early seating at 6PM, since these dinners usually last ~4 1/2 hours, and good luck trying to get parking around Bibou at 8:30PM on a Sunday night.

In tiny Bibou, a 10-top takes up ~1/3 the room, and given how long these diners last, we are obviously being treated very well by owners Chef Pierre and Charlotte Calmels, since they could probably turn the space a couple of time (although we always order a 7-course tasting menu, so hopefully this all works out financially for them).

As usual, Chef Pierre created a tasting largely composed of dishes that were on the menu that night, but he often throws in a dish or two just for us, or fulfills a special request (like the amazing 3-fish pate from the old days at Le Bec Fin, which would be too much work to serve to everyone).  That night we enjoyed:

1st course: Pheasant consommé, poured over bites of pheasant -- I'm not usually a consommé fan, preferring richer soups, but there is no question that this was an elegant start to the meal.

2nd course: Venison saddle-cherizo-pistashio-foie gras terrine, with date compote, mustard greens -- Always order whatever pate or terrine is on the menu at Bibou and you will not regret it

3rd course: Scallop, butternut squash, pomegrante, milk-lemon-infused verbena, purple potato puree and potato chip -- A visually striking dish (look at the photo!), with a large perfectly seared scallop that was melt in your mouth

4th course: Foie gras ravioli, Pergourdine sauce (usually a veal sauce made with a sweet wine like Monbazzilac), black truffles -- In my mind, one of Pierre's signature dishes, the combination of foie, pasta, truffle is killer

5th course: Beef tripe, baked in a white wine sauce of tomato, onion, garlic, chicken stock, bread crumbs -- I had this amazing dish for the first time a couple of weeks before, so we specifically requested it...it takes 6-7 hours to prepare this...nice with our Rhones, but really dying for an Italian Sangiovese (sorry Charlotte!)

6th course: Venison meat pie, white chanterelles, blood-current-red wine sauce, mustard greens -- A first-time dish for me, Pierre selected this to match our wines (and everyone in the restaurant benefited), this was everyone's DOTN (Dish of the Night)...don't let the blood sauce scare you, a must order dish if you see it on the menu

Regarding the above dish, I overheard the following comment: "Stupid good!" (Craig LaBan couldn't describe it better).

Click link below for Part 2 of this review...

My boyfriend and I went to check this club out when we came on a road trip to Reno for my 22nd birthday. We were wanted to go to a club out here but not knowing which club was "better" than the rest, we sort of just picked this out of random and based on the reviews. We were staying at The Atlantis hotel so BuBinga wasn't walking distance. We drove there and we parked in the El Dorado parking lot (since this is where the club was located). The parking lot was packed and we didn't find parking until the 5th floor. When we found parking, we walked into El Dorado and tried to find BuBinga Lounge. It was a bit tricky to find but looking around and following the crowd of young college kids, we knew we were going the right way. 

The wasn't much of a line, since we got there after the club open. The cover charge for the both of us was $10 each. So $20 in total. (much better considering most clubs back in CA were $20 each to get in). We got in and it was loud (as any club is) , packed with people (like any club, with drunks and non drunks). The main dance floor was really small and the VIP area was a decent size but not packed at all. The bar area was CRAZY PACKED (like any club) but literally my bf and I stood at the bar for what seemed like forever! All to order only two little tiny drinks, which was a total of $13, once Cosmo and one Rum and Coke, which were both watered down, but eh whatever. 

Once we got our drinks out of the way, we enjoyed some dancing on a really sticky dance floor, which had drinks spilled all over it. People weren't too crazy, mostly young crazy college kids, some older couples and some singles lingering around. The DJ was awesome, played a little bit of everything, which is always a plus. The club was open until 4am and by 2:30am almost 3am it was starting to die down, so that is when my bf and I decided to leave. We arrived there at 11:30pm and didn't leave till 3am. I felt like it was a decent time to spend at a club.

Had a good time and I will definitely be back! :D

Found it on Yelp. Ate here mid morning on a Sunday. The parking lot was packed and I was afraid we'd have to wait. But inside was deceivingly large. Looked like a lot of regulars. 
I ordered a custom egg sandwich and they were happy to build it to my specifications: medium fried egg, cheese, bacon, and lettuce. Mayo on the side. She asked if I wanted Home fries and I said "yes!"! I was so glad I did. They were delicious. I had to add salt but otherwise perfect. There were so many crunchy parts.
The sandwich was equally delicious although served weird. It was served open-face with one egg on each slice of toast. 
I also got juice half grapefruit and half orange.
Service was outstanding. Bathroom was clean. 
Putting this in my permanent rotation.

Capital Tacos is a popular Tex-Mex taco shop located up in Land O' Lakes on US 41 extended. The restaurant sits in a corner of the Wisteria strip mall alongside the 2-lane road.

This is one of those spots where you need to get there well before 12 Noon, else you'll be standing in a long line and waiting for a table. There are a few booths inside the restaurant, and a couple of tables out on the covered patio. Otherwise you stand and wait; or you can phone your order in ahead of time and pick it up to go.

The place is very popular with locals, and also people willing to drive from all over the Tampa Bay area to try their Tex-Mex food. Lunch is about 20 different menu combos that can be served as tacos, burritos, salads, or bowls. You pick your ingredients from the menu, and then tell them how you'd like it prepared.

For my lunch I wanted a burrito, and I selected the 'Texas Flood' which was beef brisket, Monterey Jack & cheddar cheeses, caramelized onions, avocado, pickled jalapenos, cilantro, and chipotle BBQ sauce. This "poodle-sized" burrito was smothered with salsa and more cheese, and then baked in the oven till ready. My Yelp check-in earned me a free bucket of homemade chips with their salsa.

I thought that the food was very good, but unfortunately with the limited seating options there were folks hanging over my table and willing me to eat faster. The next time that I'm there I'll go in the mid-afternoon or else pick it up as a carryout order.

Capital Tacos is one of many locally-owned and homemade Mexican / Tex-Mex restaurants in our area, and a very solid choice if you find yourself up in Pasco County. They've just opened a second location in the Wesley Chapel area on SR 56, just east of I-75.

I really enjoyed this place! 

Like many other reviews have mentioned, this place has amazing service! Our waitress was great, she offered suggestions and was very personable. 

I ordered a hurricane and it was good - but very strong! For food I tried the catfish po boy with fries. Classic and delicious, just the way it should be! 

The best part - you get a % off your bill with your Yelp check in!

Give them a try! You won't regret it.

Very cute little coffee shop with very reasonable prices. Ordered a cortado (espresso with milk) and it was delicious. Not too weak, I like my coffee strong. They have a little bakery also. Many flavored coffees to choose from. Very eclectic/hipster decor. There is no parking lot so you have to find street parking.

I got to try a new donut! Well, a donut that was new to me. It was a yeast donut with a cream filling, peanut butter glaze and chocolate sprinkles. The cream tasted just like the pudding you can buy pre-made at the grocery - to me, it has this underlying flavor of plastic. So, I wasn't crazy about that....but the peanut butter glaze was the perfect flavor to help cover that up!

I was seduced again by the charming wares of Two Elle today. This time the lure was their adorable new "Nashville" dog tee-shirts that had my little Chico's name all over it! A tiny bright red ringer-tee for my little furry sidekick was totally worth the $25 price-tag. 

New budget-friendly collections now call Two Elle home that will appeal to the boys and girls. I fell in love with a "bunny" scarf ($25), bunny cardigan ($65) and a mini-lace skirt ($50) that I MUST treat myself to. You can still find popular brands such as Steven Alan, Bulit By Wendy, WESC, Tarina Tarantino, and John Varvatos in the mix too.

If you haven't stopped by in awhile, you may want to pop your head in!

P.S. I am still crushin' on the extensive Converse collection. My charcoal John Varvatos sneaks are still some of my all time faves.

Being that this casino was right across the street from the hotel we were staying at of course we had to drop in and gamble a bit.

Won $200 on some slots, took the money and ran. Gave us some good drinking cash for Bourbon Street.

Gotta love me some Harrah's!

Feels good to be a baller!

Flannel was everything I needed and more during my recent trip to Philadelphia; furthermore, they were so good that I ended up going thrre times during my week-long stay. I very rarely eat at the same restaurant more than once while on vacation so this should attest to how good the food was for me to have gone back two more times after my initial visit. 

Baby let's get into it about their baked mac & cheese! I ordered it thinking it was going to taste cute or whatever (like most mac & cheese at sit-down restaurants), but BABY, the chef was not playing around. He stuck his whole foot up in that macaroni because it was seriously the best macaroni and cheese I've ever had at a sit-down restaurant. I ordered it to split with my friend but told him he couldn't have any more after my first bite. It literally tasted like it came out of my grandma's kitchen, and I can't stop thinking about it as I'm typing this review. 

Now, Flannel deserves 5 stars from their baked macaroni & cheese alone, but I can also attest that everything else they make here is phenomenal as well.  The Nashville Hot Chicken Sandwich, the Chicken and Waffles, the ribs, the pancakes, and the "Flannel Benny" were all amazing as well, and my friends and I left here full and happy on each visit.

All in all, Flannel is South Philly's best-kept secret, and probably my favorite restaurant I've been to on Passyunk. More people need to know about this place, and I will be returning on my next visit to Philly.

This is one of the 1st sushi restaurants I have been to where the entire menu is filled with pictures so you know what the menu items actually look like. It's brilliant. I came for a friends birthday dinner and they made us feel very welcome and were attentive to our large party. Seems like a popular date spot as many tables were filled with 2 people dressed up (and they have dim lighting in the restaurant as well...romantic atmosphere for sure). The prices were a little high, but they had a variety of creative rolls that really caught my eye. They also had several Japanese dishes as well. All the food we had was great and came out in a timely manner. Go during lunch because I have heard Origami has excellent lunch specials and try some of their sushi!

Restaurant on the fancier side, located within walking distance to all the popular honky tonks in Nashville. I came here with a big group of friends for our fancy dinner of the trip and for a group of 8, we got seated in a private room which was great! The service was very friendly and attentive. The restaurant was nice and clean.

My friends and I started off with bread with duo butter tasting. It didn't come free which was unfortunate but we were desperate for carbs after a day of drinking. It came with 4 rolls and a strawberry butter and truffle butter, special for that day. Good and fresh tasting. 

As for the main entrée, I got the seared duck breast which was filling. The duck was cooked very nicely. Okra was tasty. I liked the feta filo clutch because it was a good balance against the sweet pomegranate walnut sauce. We also shared a side of cauliflower which was very delicious. The truffle in the pea pesto was very truffly. The salted almonds were a nice addition, adding a good crunch to the dish.

Overall, a great group dinner!

Acme was recommended by so many friends for my New Orleans trip, so I made it a must-try. 

We came on my birthday (Friday night) in December and the wait actually wasn't too bad at 7PM. We waited maybe 20 minutes and got seated promptly. The inside is casual (no fancy) but I have no cares for ambiance if the food is on point. 

We ordered (from favorite to least favorite):

1. Raw oysters (5/5 stars): WOW. Have I ever tasted such plump, fresh, delicious oysters in my life? I think not. This was most definitely the best fresh tasting oysters I've had the luxury of trying. Amazing. (Raw here is better than Felix's)

2. Softshell crab (5/5 stars): !!! Holy crap. First time eating crab this way - fried but the meat is so soft, so good. The outer layer of fried crust is just perfect - flavorful but not too thick.

3. Chargrilled oysters (4/5 stars): Yum! The chargrilled oysters were flavored with butter, sea salt, cheese, lemon and who knows what else. I really enjoyed dipping the French bread in the sauce - perfect pairing. Still, I always prefer raw oysters to chargrilled because I like the original taste without being masked by so many other condiments. 

4. Boo fries (3/5 stars): Fries with roast beef gravy and cheese. Good side to have, but not the best fries in the world. I guess Acme can't be the best at everything haha.

5. Jambalaya (2/5 stars): Nooooo. The rice was rather bland and dry. Not much going on here. Jambalaya is MUCH better at Felix's. 

OVERALL
LOVED IT. For the price it's totally worth coming here, everyone ate to their heart's content and each person only came out to about $25 including tip. If I ever make another NOLA trip this is a must go-back-to :)

My fiancee' had bought my ring here and they helped him design what he wanted for me. They are awesome no matter how much you spend. At first I was set on a Tacori at another Clayton business, but when I went here there were so many custom made rings to choose from. He picked a few ideas that I liked and had them create them into one. Needless to say anywhere I have went I have got complements on my ring. It's definately one of a kind.

Redheaded Stranger is no longer a stranger to me and I am glad about that. The staff, the food, the ambiance and the concept are all great. I think over time it has the potential to be 5 stars but there are a couple of things I think could get it there.

My friend and I came for a late lunch but there was a line out the door. This is quickly becoming a popular spot! We waited in line for about 30 minutes before we were able to order at the front. The restaurant has a retro/Southwest kind of feel with cactus plants lined up along the window and the mod tables and chairs. They have an outdoor spacious patio that they had decked out with misters which in this August heat was a great idea (although umbrellas would be an even better one). They have a long bar area with seating and then an open kitchen and a place where you can see them making the flour tortillas, fresh. When we got up to order we were informed it would be a 40 minute wait for our food. Since we had already spent 30 minutes in line we were already invested so we stuck it out and waited although we were super hangry by the time the food actually came. Just a note that you will need to patient about the wait if you come here! 

My friend and I both got 2 tacos each since the size looked pretty substantial. The barbacoa taco had a lot of meat in it (yay) as well as black beans, red peppers and a hot sauce. This was super tasty. I also got a vegetarian taco which had poblano peppers, hot sauce and whipped feta. This was also really good so I was happy with these. My friend had ordered queso which was advertised as coming with tortillas. I had made a comment that this was interesting that it didn't say tortilla chips and she had responded that she was sure it was a fried tortilla like a tostada. It was not. The queso came with 2 flour tortillas. Although the queso is a smaller portion, 2 tortillas is not enough to eat with the queso. Conceptually I get it that maybe they want to show off their fresh, housemade tortillas but the practicality factor is just not there. They should reconsider this and serve with housemade tortilla chips!  

Personally I am a fan but for a pretty small menu it seemed like a really long wait. I understand that this is not a fast food joint but the things we ordered should have already pretty much been prepped and ready to go so I think they could be a bit more efficient there. Otherwise, all great!

Stopped in for lunch today with some coworkers.  We sat near the window open to the street and it was very pleasant.

We were presented with a fairly impressive menu but the problem is with the execution.  I had a cheessteak hoagie that was cool instead of hot and had a strange aftertaste.  This is not the first time I have had below average food here.

GiGis is in the heart of Old City.  You have literelly dozens of choices for lunch.  Go elsewhere.

Our reason for being at Jub Jub's was simple.  My wife wanted to go to a performance here so we went.  One of her friends was a performer in a "rock opera" type of performance.  So most of our experience is with the performance space.  This show was set up in an non-traditional way so I can't put a lot of effort into reviewing the space for performance.  I can only say that it seems like it would be a killer space for a band to play at.

The bar was a bit cluttered but things moved quickly and the prices seemed to be from affordable to normal Reno prices.  I think they had some basic drinks available at the bar in the performance space and then a more extensive bar in the regular area across the hall.

We only had waters so can't really say much about the drinks other than they looked really good.  Not just a bunch of ice and a splash of alcohol.

The sound in the place was great!  The only issues I heard were more from the sound guy than from the actual space itself.

Parking sucks.   It's just a small amount then you have to find something on the surrounding streets.  Which is no biggie but can complicate things a bit if you are coming on a rainy or wet night.

Good sized Men's bathroom.  Many bars have gross tiny restrooms this one was just basic and fine.

The worst part of the evening was the smoke.  As far as I can tell no food is served, so smoking is pretty much freely done in the bar and about the building.  The performance space didn't seem to have any smokers though.  Not sure if this was an edict from the performers or if this is normal for all performance spaces.  Either way, I will probably not go back to Jub Jub's because of the smoking issue.   Even though the smokers stayed quarantined, their  smoke still permeated the whole space.

I know it's not a popular view to take, but I just don't get smokers in general.  When person "A" smokes every person (B-Z) around person "A" experiences their activity as a participant.  It's like if I went into a restaurant with a bad case of loud stinky farts.  Blammo every few seconds.  Oh I need to fart outside?  Ok I'll do that....mind if I stand RIGHT AT THE DOOR take a break and blast a few juicy ones right where everyone is coming in?  You have a problem with that?

Anyway I digress and apologize to all my smoking friends.  Just frustrates me when I have to go home smelling like smoke and with a headache just because I want to see a cool show.

So, you are NO In-N-Out. Why are you so busy? Nevertheless, this wait was much less than the one in NYC or Boston. It is a good thin burger and the special sauce is actually better than In N Out's (Shhhh). However, the fries were soggy and a huge disappointment (even with the malt vinegar at my table). And I couldn't bring myself to have a 800 calorie shake, but I heard this is the thing to do here. Damn it, why do you post your calories?

So, I'm definitely a fan, but bring me some In-N-Out on the East Coast!

If you are going for the quintessential Santa Barbara seafood experience, you should check this place out. It is located right at the very end of the Santa Barbara pier. There are maybe, four?, small tables on the outside deck which face the ocean. Super cute and quaint. With that said, prepare for a long wait if you are coming during peak hours.

I shared the following items:

-Santa Barbara shrimp cocktail: seven jumbo, chilled shrimp served with cocktail sauce and lemons for drizzling. They were pretty substantial in size and the shrimp themselves had a slight hint of sweetness. $12.95 for the seven shrimp.

-a half dozen oysters on the half shell: they go for market price (in my case, $18 for 6) and we weren't offered a variety of oysters. I think they serve whatever is available for the day.

Okay, and against my better judgement, I opted to try their popular Rock Crab special which I believe, comes with a side of soup (good, creamy clam chowder in my case) and a small salad for a reasonable price tag of $21(ish) dollars. Oh, the crab is also topped with onion rings. Mind you, my experience with eating crab doesn't go beyond dungeness crab which usually breaks into lumps of sweet, crab meat. The texture of the rock crab is nothing like that. The meat is slightly grainy and doesn't easily form into lumps, so I found myself with little strips/pieces of crab meat. The exoskeleton of the rock crab is also incredibly hard, so I really had to work for that crab meat. This was a less than desirable crab eating experience. 

It is what it is. I am usually not a fan of American seafood fare, so I thought for what it was, it was good.

Don Day is easily one of my favourite Korean places in the city. I've been here a handful of times now since my original post (see here) and have yet to experience a bad meal. This is a quintessential hole in the wall, industrial restaurant that seems to be scattered all over Edmonton.

The moment you step through DD's doors, you're greeted with a heavenly aroma. K-pop videos play non-stop on the TV's and Korean posters plaster the wall as decor. The server/owner is super friendly and genuine. It's like your eating at your Korean friend's parents place. Wish I knew some Koreans here...:(

The menu is pretty straightforward but the dishes are categorized somewhat randomly. First page has appetizers, meats and their specialty hot pots. Flip the menu over and you're left with bi bim bap, meat and a couple other dishes. I have no idea why their jap chae is so expensive ($19.99)! Ridiculous.

At least they have some pictures of their popular dishes if you need a bit of guidance. Get a hot pot for sure - a small you can easily share between two to four people.

Trip #1
- Banchan - there's only two side dishes that you get - kim chee and a rotating dish. This one here is miyeok, a seaplant salad. Any seaweed/seaplant is good in my books. Texturally pleasant.
- Pork bone soup (#18) ($32.99 medium) - you can't really go wrong with the pork bone soup. Hearty, tender meat, flavourful and spicy. There's chunks of potato and think you also get a side or two of rice to go with this. The meat seemed endless. I wasn't kidding when I said a small would be good enough! The medium was hugeeeee.
- Bulgogi (#43) ($13.50) - marinated beef stew with vegetables and clear noodles. I like how they throw in noodles so it's not just bulgogi. For good measure, there's even a variety of vegetables like mushrooms, onion, carrot, green onion and cabbage.
- Beef teriyaki noodle (#10) ($11.50) - only available during lunch. These noodles were thicker, similar to udon or Shanghai style noodles. They came out sizzling hot on a black skillet. If you want something less Koreanish, this is worth a try.
- Hot stone chicken bi bim bap (#39) ($13.50) - mixed vegetables with rice served in a hot stone pot. Rice had a crunchy bite. I'm not sure why they fry their egg here over the traditional runny yolk. Unsurprisingly, the dolsot bi bim bap was run of the mill. Still on the search to find a solid one in town.

Trip #2
- Seafood pancake (#7) ($15.99) - for some reason, I've never tried DD's seafood pancake until now. Super crispy but just the right amount of thickness/density. This one is almost on par with Korean Grill's.
- Spicy seafood soup (#16) ($34.99) - I've had their spicy seafood soup too many times to count now. Spicy, decent variety of seafood, slippery glass noodles, zucchini, arugula and a couple other things thrown into the mix.

This place is a gem. I'll be here again and again and again.

Something has changed....namely the quality of service and food! Took waaaayyyyy too long for the small order to arrive.  My hot chocolate, which I use to rave over because of its beautiful presentation and huge homemade marshmallow floating atop.  Now served in a "go cup" turned me off.  When I explained to the manager that I was dining in and preferred a ceramic mug he shot back "We don't normally do that on the weekends due to business.'  

I was so confused and slightly pissed at the same time.  The drink was simply not the same, the experience was ruined and the food was subpar.  I had concluded on this day....it would be my last patronizing Crepes.

I came here looking for some wall art for an upcoming house "redecorating" and while the selection was good, I just couldn't get past a few things.

First of all, this Kirkland's was really cluttered. There were so many things for sale that there are actually things on the floor because there is no space for them anywhere else. There was limited organization which made navigation difficult.  Also, I came here ready to spend some time really looking for things, but their AC was broken and the place was sweltering hot. On a 90 degree day you really have to get someone out ASAP to fix the air situation. It was stifling and when I started to sweat in the store, I was forced to call it a day. I felt bad for the poor girl working in her long pants because she looked miserable. 

I'll return, but maybe in the cooler months.
Def one of the best places to study for sure. Great quiet seating areas with private rooms. When you want to lounge there's a nice fireplace area to sit down in large comfy chairs and sip.

A really great place to check out in Philadelphia. Imaging stained glass and other shiny things being smashed and then amalgamated into art for you to check out. That's the best way I can describe Philadelphia Gardens.

Everywhere you look things look stunning and beautiful. The artist here I believe struggled from mental illness, and one of his ways of expressing himself was through his art. Each piece tells a story. A great place to snap some pictures, but also explore and enjoy what's in front of you.

On the way home from our Treasure Island vacation , we stopped in the Frog for a bite to eat before our 4 hour ride home. Are we glad we did. Packed house when we arrived around 11am., but we got a table right away. Great service and great food. I ordered the Monte Cristo Omelette, 
Ham, turkey and Swiss cheese. My wife ordered the vegetable omelet, spinach, mushroom and cheddar. Huuuge portions. My omelet was filled with shaved turkey and ham, not just a slice or two, or chopped as usual with other breakfast places. Also my potatoes were cooked perfectly. Our server gave us their homemade strawberry jam, which was so good , we bought a jar to take home. We were so full, we barely ate dinner that night. Do yourself a favor if your in the area , stop in, you will not be disappointed, and try the jam.

Good coffee, cozy spot. It's sort of what you want out of a coffee shop on a brisk fall afternoon. You might need to sit at the slightly too small bar for a while though until a proper chair frees up.

Stopped in on my way to Winter Wine Fest in Skippack, otherwise I would seldom have a reason to be in Hatboro, although it is a cool place.

The man, himself, holds the fort @ Denny's Dogs.  It is a tiny shop in an old strip on Jacksonville Road.  Parking is limited and difficult to negotiate.  However, the Dogs are worth the effort.  You can get them as you like them, and fix 'em up with the extra relishes, peppers and table rockets full of mustard and ketchup.  They are all beef, and the rolls have good body and size to fit and hold the extra sauerkraut piled high on top.  When I was finished with my squirts and slices, I could still close the bun and bite into the creation without leakage.  That is a major plus, as there are no tables in the shop now, and I was relegated to eating in my car on this cold Saturday afternoon.  No fuss. No muss. 

The only downsides are the aforementioned parking, lack of seating, and the use of styro packaging.  To save the planet, I would have been happier with a thick paper rollup, and paper towels rather than the thin napkins that require a handful to be effective. 

Still, this is a frankfurter lovers' haven.  If you lust for one sometimes, a place like Denny's can be your port of entry to the Sea of Tranquility. 

Go ahead.  You know you want one.

Well, this was quite the experience.

After a failed first attempt to even find this place, I made another run at it on a Tuesday at 2:30pm.

Even though it was not exactly peak time for breakfast or lunch, this place was more chaotic than that area outside the will call window just before a Lightning game.

All that tells me is how popular Brocato's really is and I found it somewhat entertaining trying to navigate around all the other customers inside...first to order and then while waiting to pick up my food.

I do feel bad for the people who eat at the tables inside, because they always have random strangers hovering around or over them. If you like a little personal space while enjoying a meal, forget it.

How about how Brocato's uses the "Honor System" in allowing you to simply grab a bag of chips and a drink on your own away from the counter with every sandwich purchase? They clearly trust their customers and it certainly didn't look like anyone was abusing that trust...even though there's absolutely no way any employee could keep track of that with all the bodies running around in there.

After bumping into a few random others while waiting for a large Cuban sandwich (I specified mustard only, which is how an authentic Cuban is actually made), my name and number was called and I was on my way home.

Honestly, I only ordered the large because it was just $1 more than the medium and this was the largest Cuban sandwich I have ever had in front of me. Not only was it long, but it was incredibly thick with an immense amount of meat. (Besides, you avoid an additonal 99 cent charge on your order if you pay with cash)

This sounds dirty, but I cannot remember the last time I actually hurt my mouth by trying to open my jaws wide enough for a first bite of something.

I've now spent the last 24 hours eating about 1/5 of this sandwich at a time and I still will have more than enough for lunch tomorrow...so Brocato's certainly offers more than your money's worth.

Just be prepared for whatever term you would use as a synonym for "chaos" when making your visit, especially if your dining in. (The outside patio seemed very calm, but perhaps it is as hectic as the inside at peak times)

Awesome Indonesian food located in a mini Vietnamese square.
My Indonesian husband and in-laws attest the food to be authentic. They always leave with take out orders so they can savor the goodness later in the week. It's always the highlight of any trip to Philadelphia. 
The best thing about this restaurant is the spice level. Man oh man, the spice level here is amazing. None of that babied down BS. Their sambal is legit HOT. 

Recs: 
(+++) Soto Betawi: beef, beef tripe, potato and tomato cooked in coconut broth. Tastes similar to laksa. Comes with a plate of rice and a small side of pickles and hot peppers. This is my favorite dish as I am a soupy kind of gal. 

(+++) Original nasi padang. This is the quintessential Indo dish known all around. Comes with  curry chicken, beef rendang, potato patties, spicy shrimp, curry collard green, and green chili. This is the optimal entree if you want to try a little bit of everything.  

(+++) Nasi Pecel Lele: fried cat fish with sides of fried tofu, fried tempeh, anchovy, and sambal. Comes with rice. Ideal for fish lovers. The catfish is decently sized. Easily shareable between 2 people.

Reasonably priced, homey, authentic food experience!

Found out about this place using Yelp. It's very near where I used to work when I lived here. It is a small restaurant in a run down strip center on Causeway Blvd. I ordered the most expensive item which was the crawfish étouffée with a side of red beans. Out came a large plate of étouffée which was excellent. Red beans were excellent too. I am only giving 4 stars because this was my first time here but this could be a 5 star place. I will try their gumbo next time. Also their fried chicken looked really good too. My prediction is that this restaurant will quickly outgrow this location and move to a larger place. This is an up and coming restaurant. Good things are ahead for it.

This shop has some gorgeous jewelry. It makes me wish I had money to burn on diamond fleur de lis pendants.

This is a small shop, but it packs a lot in. Beautiful diamonds glisten in the lights and you imagine yourself being draped in luxury while attending some fancy event at someplace interesting. They have a good deal of New Orleans themed jewelry- gators and fleur de lis in every fashion, but they also have a nice selection of vintage jewelry and charms. I loved the selection of antique charms for charm bracelets, and they had so many that I'm tempted to start my own charm collection.

The owner of the shop was very nice and offered to take anything out of a case, so that we might have a closer look. For the average shopper, many of the items here will be out of price range, but they have a few items that you might like for a special occasion.

Fantastic dining/drinking experience. Lovely view. Attentive staff (we sat at the bar). We started with the fish spread. It's no Ted Peter's, but quit good in its own class. I also had the fish tacos (3), grilled. Very good. Finished outside with a fantastic view of a gorgeous sunset. What a great place to enjoy St. Pete Beach.

PS. Located in the Don Cesar Hotel.

This bar was a short two block walk from Bourbon Street. It offered friendly service, a small patio area, stiff drinks, and great drink prices.

Chris (our bartender), was the type of person who immediately seemed like an old friend. He was laid back and attentive.

The bar had the charm of a dive bar with a lot of history, including old pictures, currency from various countries, and a certificate on the wall showing a Chart Room bumper sticker onboard a space shuttle.

This bar also has regulars who have been there every day for decades. Cool! They offered a few gambling machines, an old style juke box and a roller grill. Excellent!

Maybe I'm being a bit generous due to the fact that we were able to get a late-lunch table for two, next to a corner window overlooking the square on Lundi Gras.  That should have told me everything I needed to know, but it was chilly and we were hungry, so willing to take a chance on Muriel's.

The $17 two-course lunch special, with $4 wine/select cocktails, sounds like a great deal, doesn't it?  Well, it would be if the food was up to par, but sadly, it isn't.  The seafood gumbo lacked flavor and... seafood.  The shrimp creole was bland.  My date enjoyed her tomato basil soup and pork chop, but here again, nothing special, and certainly not up to NOLA standards.  Too many outstanding restaurants, to put up with mediocrity in this town.

Bestie was craving their spicy shrimp soup with noodles. I was craving roti Canai and beef Rendang. Bestie also ordered steamed vegetable dumplings. 

The roti was on point! Both of us wanted a bowl of the curried dipping sauce as our main meal! 

I'm no longer craving beef Rendang and bestie is no longer craving the soup.

Bestie came in from VA to have brunch with yours truly and brunch with a bottle of sparkling wine we had! 

Service - terrific! Devon and staff were lovely! Water glasses stayed full and Devon ( yes that was his name ) was honest and nice! The service is always great and "Devon" ( our server )upholds the tradition!

Food - fantastic!
Bestie ordered an enormous turkey club and subbed the asparagus instead of  fries. She raved about her meal and was delighted to take the other half to go. 

I'd eggs Benedict and subbed asparagus instead of potatoes and bestie was right the asparagus was fantastic! I also asked for the hollandaise on the side. All special requests were honored. 

The half price sparkling wine was lovely and we were able to land perfect outside seating on a warm February afternoon - which was brunch perfection!
A good liquor store in Melrose right next to the Kroger on 8th Avenue South. Good selection, helpful employees...what more do you need from a liquor store?!

In the unexpected location of a strip mall in Boise's north end you will find this gem, a crown jewel really, pastry café.  From sparkling and warm ambiance to the same in welcoming service to the absolutely remarkable pastries, "c'est magnifique!"

Baking, they say, is about precision and chemistry.  I say pastries this remarkable also involve artistry, a bit of magic and passion for the process and outcome.  You can feel the love in the surroundings here and taste it in every bite.

Were I a Boise resident I'd manage my calorie and financial budgets to be a frequent customer at Janjou.   As a visitor to Boise, this is on my "do not miss it" list.  It recharges body and soul to go to Janjou.  Highly recommended.  We wish this was in our neighborhood. 

THE VIBE:  Urban cool and "ahhhh...some" warm all at the same time.  White walls, dark wood floors, chic white tables and chairs with chrome bases and legs, sparkling windows looking to let in lots of light, sparkling pastry cases displaying lots of artisan bakery delights. Gift bags with brown and orange tissue paper peeking out add a punch of color.  Just right café music mix set at the just right level to support conversation.  People coming and going seemed all ages and walks of life; truly a neighborhood "all people are welcome" place.

THE SEATING:  Seats for roughly a dozen people at six two-top tables  and maybe half a dozen more at high counters with stools at the front windows. On nice weather days there is additional seating at café tables and chairs on the front walkway outside. 

THE BACKSTORY:  Patissiere and Janjou owner Moshit Mizrachi-Gabbitas moved to Boise from Israel in 2007.  She graduated from the prestigious baking school Estella kitat Oman in Israel and completed worked at Patisseries there.  In 2008 she open Janjou Pâtisserie which she named after her mother.

THE DRILL:  Choose some delights, you won't be able to stop at just one, from the case displays of pastries or quiche.  There are also little cylinders filled with cookies or chocolates which make perfect take away for yourself or as gifts.  Espresso beverages are available too.  Order at the counter, they'll deliver to your table, bus your own.

THE DELIGHTS: I kid you not when I say in learning the Patissiere was introducing the Breton pastry kougin amann to the line up beginning yesterday morning, that my husband and I made it pilgrimage to the bakery (we live in Bend Oregon six hours away) to try some.  These orbs of tender dough folded with butter and sugar are hard to find in American bakeries and these were excellent!  Worth the trip or those alone, but we also enjoyed framboise choux (puff pastry filled with raspberry cream and topped with fresh raspberries) and a bostok (think brioche toast meets frangipane) to take away.

We thought prices were very fair too.  Is I recall our choices were @$5 - $6 each.  We have our eye on quiche ($6.95) on our next stop in.  Not to mention I have a doctor to whom I owe being well enough to travel to Janjou.  I think a gift bag of cookies from Janjou will be a nice thank you. 

The coffee service was also perfect.  Americanos we ordered (12 oz $3.20) were hot and bold.

THIS N THAT

1) LOCATION & NEIGHBORS:  Look for the Marketplace strip mall.  Mazzah Mediterranean is a neighbor.  So is Airbrush nail salon. 

 2) PARKING:  Ample parking in the mall lot, there's a location advantage!

 3) ACCESSIBILITY:  Accessible parking in the lot and curb ramp onto walkway.  Level in to the patisserie and throughout.  Saw a mom with a stroller inside and that means room for wheelchairs too.  Loo is accessible down a hallway.

4) FUN:  In the hallway at the back of the cafe you'll find a window that looks into the bright kitchen where the pastries are made and you can watch the Patissiere and her team creating the pastries.

My kid and all her friends LOVE it here.
Especially the Burrito California with steak or shrimp (extra charge).

Although the neighborhood here is straight hood, this is the most pleasant post office to deal with in my opinion.  The line is never too long, and the lady who usually works here when I stop in is lovely.  She actually lent me tape to tape up a box instead of making me buy it.  For all my postage needs, I suit up in my Kevlar and go to Willard street.

Beach Fire is 3.5 stars for me but I'm giving 4 stars because I visit often when in Clearwater. I like the North end of Clearwater because it's less busy and chaotic. Beach Fire is within walking distance of the motel we frequent and they are open for breakfast, lunch and late night. 

The breakfast has lots of options. Crepes, pancakes, biscuits and gravy etc.  I've bad better biscuits and gravy but not bad. 

Sometimes there is live music at music in the weekends and it's never too packed where you can't get a seat at the bar. 

Overall a good option for a drink away from the hustle and bustle of the pier.

Annnnd here we go again! *Full* redemption for Earthsavers, as I returned to an appointment with Nelly and it was a 5-star waxing. You can't get more thorough than this. I mean... waxing, plus tweezers for those stubborn hairs. In and out in 20 minutes. Friendly service. Nothing awkward or brutal (ie, like last time). While I can't call the session fun or relaxing (impossible, let's face it), I do plan to return for regular appointments. I just won't ever stray from Nelly again, though.

I'm usually pretty good about checking Yelp prior to stepping into a new business. Fortunately, I failed to search this spot before snagging some baked goods, and thank goodness! Sometimes you just gotta make your own opinion, even when the overall consensus is "pass."

I don't know if they've recently implemented new recipes or what, but I love what the Lucky Cupcake Co. has going up in Peddler's Village!

My mom and I were visiting to celebrate her birthday at the Blueberry and Bluegrass Festival over the weekend. We're both insane about sweets (I blame her, genetics and stuff), so obviously we couldn't resist the stand Lucky Cupcake had in front of their shop. She purchased a lemon blueberry scone and blueberry parfait, and I selected a blueberry cheesecake muffin and blueberry crumb cake.

We found a nearby covered table and quickly inhaled our respective sweets before moving along through the shops.

On our way out, we had to make a pit-stop at the shop. This time around, we walked inside, waited in a semi-short line, and each purchased baked goods in bulk.

I chose:
- Chocolate chip cookie dough cupcake: A-Okay.
- Blueberry cake pop: DELICIOUS.
- Blueberry bar: Buttery, watch your bag for grease marks. So good.
- Blueberry pie: Perfect mini size. I admittedly ate this for breakfast the next day. Shhh.
- Blueberry macaron: Filling tasted like blueberry pie. Pretty good.

I love blueberries (if you couldn't already tell) and thought it was awesome to find a one-stop shop for top-quality sweets created with my preferred fruit. I'd absolutely return the next time I visit Peddler's Village.

What the hell happened to this place? We have been Season Pass members for 8 years now and I think this may be our last. Staff is constantly overwhelmed and uncaring.
