The waterpark is disgusting (see my pic). They offer so many groupons lately that it is crowded all the time. They removed the free play areas (which yes needed an overhaul) and replaced them with more rides where the lines move so slow and you bake in the sun.  There are rules posted by the rides but nobody enforces them (people were wearing dripping wet swimsuits on rides). 

If you can figure out an off peak time (non existent) to go this is an amazing place, just please skip the waterpark. 

Btw as soon as I saw the 3/4 year old girl pull down her pants and take a crap in the pool I told a lifeguard. He seemed to have no clue what to do as children were splashing around the turd. The pool remained open for at least 15 min. before another guard came by and they cleared everyone out. And an hour later it was open again.

I've been hearing mixed reviews about this spot but I wanted a grunchy/granola type sandwich after a trying day and thought they would probably have one. And the Veggie King was exactly what I wanted. The veggies were fresh, the bread was hearty and I was a happy camper. Since I was getting take out, I decided to also get the Broken Noodle Salad (lunch & dinner in one trip) and was also really pleased with it. 

The staff who assisted me were pleasant and efficient so no complaints.

I'll have to find an evening to actually dine in and sample the cocktails. Because now that I'm typing, I want that salad again.

Why 5 stars? Because it's a food truck that serves grilled cheese.

   ---   ---   ---

Sometimes my intro has to be creative, but this is a foot truck that serves grilled cheese. Do I really need to dive any deeper to explain why I believe it to be 5-stars?

I have felt that Tampa was an under-utilized market for gourmet grilled cheese, but this is my second review of a grilled cheese eatery this week, which says that our little corner of the world is becoming a better place.

This review is not dissimilar from my recent entry of Tom + Chee. I ordered a grilled cheese with chicken in it (The Full Monty) and the fiance ordered the grilled cheese lined with mac-n-cheese (The Mac Daddy.) They were interachangably delicious, and both made me never want eat another meal for the rest of my life. 

Seriously, if I ate nothing but grilled cheese every day, I could make that work, right? Would I see my retirement age?

I was shocked to see how many people were scrambling to get into this joint, but I also knew it was a good sign. I took one of the high tops and ordered a chicken parm with pasta + house salad. 

When the chicken parm and pasta arrived, I immediately thought: this is going to be a regret. The cheese wasn't melted and the pasta looked like something you would find at a cheap chain restaurant. However ... this was the first time I have seen chicken parm and pasta that looked like that and it was very good. I was pleasantly surprised. The salad kicked butt too.

On top of that, the atmosphere is top-notch. It's clean and has a lot of energy without being noisy. And everyone is in a good mood. The service was also superb (as well as observant). 

It all starts at the top, so good job by management. 

Highly recommended!

it's an airport. it definitely needs a nice new update and places to eat. they should take a visit to JFK and see what I am talking about. the jet blue terminal there is like going to a nice mall. basically once you get inside after security there is nothing to eat really. and why must every time I go I need that hand swab thing? I had buttons on my pants? COME ON! I am this 5'3' little girl with a purple bag do I look like a threat? lol. it's just like they are just bored. JFK doesn't give me a second look. then again in Ny most girls wear juicy pants so it's not a shock to see them. I'm starting to dread going through security here because every time I get pulled aside for no reason. and no I'm ethnic or anything either lol. I'm this little white girl.

also when you land they opened up the rest of the airport but of course they expect you to just figure everything out on your own. everyone on our flight was like um where do we go for baggage? maybe instead of spending so much on security they should think of redoing the airport and fixing it up. no offense but besides JFK, LAX and other big airports I think they can relax on the security.

I know it's Walmart.... but it's been super helpful on my move. I've been here several times already to pick up random things I needed for my apartment while I wait for my movers to arrive. I did some bare minimum research before going but they had the cheapest air mattresses I could find so I mainly went to for that but also ended up picking up some cheap pillows THAT I ACTUALLY LIKE (I find it so hard to find pillows). 

I've always left with more than originally planned but all of it has been true necessities and for a low price. I know you get what you pay for, but for the short term everything I've been able to buy at Walmart for an affordable price has been truly helpful. 

Not my favorite place to shop for groceries but I also don't think it's the worst option to pick up a few things if you're already there (like I have done a few times). I also gotta say their rotisserie chicken is DELICIOUS!!

Never had any problems with any of the cashiers or other employees that I have worked with. Everyone has been helpful and friendly, and overall I find this location clean and nice. I would recommend and have a feeling I will be back here again before the week is over...

Yay for a separate listing for the Library book sale! This is a great spot to find recent hardback best sellers as well as children's books and vintage items. It was the actual carriage house when Latter Library was a private home. Recent renovations have made it a great spot to browse.

It is run by the Friends of the Library and your cash helps fund the Public Library so win win! It is only open 2 days a week for 4 hours each day, Wednesdays and Saturdays from 10-2. Usually they put a sign out on St Charles when they are open.

What a great little cafe! 

Tucked away in a strip mall on SR54, you'll find this little gem of a place nestled next to Beall's. It's got a unique flavour all it's own, that's lent from Greek roots and a chef with good taste. 

Today I visited with my mom, so that we could go spend the Beall's cash I earned during Black Friday.  The service was awesome and quick. The food was delicious. I ordered a western Omelette and mom ordered a strawberry banana crepe. Both came out just as we asked and both were simply decadent. 

I'll find time to come back in the near future.

I've visited Boca twice and both experiences weren't great.  
The decor is wonderful, the space is adorned with wood panels on the roof and modern furniture.

Food:
The tomato & coconut soup was flavorless & made me regret ordering the starter. The roasted potatoes were bland & required heavy black pepper & salt. The french toast was thick and lacked taste. 
The mimosa did not disappoint, it was the perfect combination of citrus and champagne.

My first visit was with a large group:
I was seated on the patio and the service was horrendous. It was a hot Sunday afternoon and the servers were almost non existent. Drinks took 30 minutes per refill and water glasses on the table were constantly empty. 

My second visit was with my partner:
The service was better but the food was cold when it arrived at my table.

Overall both experiences weren't positive. Glad I checked out Boca but I won't be returning.

After visiting our eldest grandson and his new apartment on the west side, we decided to take him to lunch.  Mexican food was agreed upon by all of us and w decided to give La Hacienda a try.  It can be a little difficult to find since it stuck in an inner corner of a large building.  We ended up driving all the way around just to find it.  

Although the parking lot needed some cleaning and pot holes filled, Once we pulled up to the restaurant, we found the interior to be clean and lively.  we were given our choice of booth or table and we chose a section where the music was not too loud.

All three of us ordered something from the lunch menu which was fairly large serving for the price.  Our food came with chips and salsa.  The salsa was very thin with just a hint of heat to it.  The chips were light and crisp...good  enough to munch on even without salsa.  Our entrees came with beans and rice as well, so a full meal. Service was pretty good and the wait time on the kitchen was acceptable.  My wife decided to add a frozen strawberry margarita and thought it needed more mix (not enough berry flavor.)  The waiter brought us our bill and I paid at the front counter.  Overall, a pleasant meal and experience.

#Review 3966

Civil Alchemy is rad af. This place stands out as one of the best places in Saint Louis to buy, honestly, just about anything. 

It's a modern general store, it truly has a pretty vast collection of supplies from fresh flowers, home goods, and clothing to camping supplies, and anything you would need for a cocktail party. Not only do they have it, but their products beam with such obvious quality and it sets them apart from just any ole' shop. 

The family that runs this place is committed to display the vibrancy of Saint Louis and all that it has to offer. They are some creative folks. Just look at the store, it's such a beautiful and comfortable space. 

If that weren't enough, they have a flower bar, where you can put together a bouquet of fresh flowers. They make awesome gifts for your person, friend, or hell, even for yourself. They also have cleaning products, many of which are made with natural and safe products. 

Lastly, they make a gin called Truly Floral Blue. Right now you can buy it here or at the Frisco Barroom down the street, but soon it will be all over Saint Louis. Get your hands on it. It's fantastic. 

Check them out, especially at one of their events. This place is an awesome addition to Saint Louis. It really shines.

If Willy Wonka and Martha Stewart had a child, SUCRE would be it! 
This place is RIDICULOUS!

I love all kinds of sweets and that's just what they have...ALL KINDS. 
But, anyone can have all kinds. They have all kinds of INCREDIBLE sweets. 
I can't take it. 

I am a huge dessert snob and all I have for SUCRE is compliments. 
OK, perhaps I have one complaint: they need additional seating given we had to duke it out for a table. 

We strolled right in and were instantly overwhelmed by the tantalizing choices. 
How are we to choose when it all looks so great? 

Choose we did and we ordered the white chocolate bread pudding, the salted caramel cupcake, petit red velvet  and the turtle. The bread pudding came with a peanut butter crunch gelato. You have your gelato choice. That's all. We did not even get to have their chocolates or macaroons.  Not enough space. We also got cappuccinos because we could and because we are not in France where they will snub you for it. Booyah! 

I know I don't need to say it given my 5 star rating but everything was M-A-R-V-E-L-O-U-S! AND  I don't think I have ever used the word "marvelous" in a review before. 

I wish I had one nearby so that I could taste more of their items. 
This is truly a great place and you locals are very fortunate to have them!

The long wait for this store open in Westshore was well worth it. 
I've already forgotten that I used to look for deals on golf gear at the Sports Authority across the street. 
This particular Dick's Sporting Goods has an enormous space devoted to golf and clearly separates Under Armour from Nike, Puma from Adidas, etc. 
Honestly, it seems like many popular sports have plenty of space in this two level monster of a sporting goods store.
Also, due to mall rules, any sidewalk or tent sales are set up inside the store which allows you to stay out of the heat when shopping for bargain merchandise. 
If you have any questions or trouble finding something, ask for a manager named Rich. Seems like he is always there and very willing to assist customers in any way possible.

Picture this.... it's a beautiful day outside,  the temperature being just right. You head up the stairs and are brought to a tiny balcony with a table set for two. Below are the busy streets where a jazz band breaks out into song. You order two cocktails and cheers to a romantic night.

Food served is typical New Orleans cuisine brought by an attentive server. Appetizers of blue crab claws and stuffed mushrooms are both standouts. You finish the night off with some homemade bread pudding before heading back to your hotel.

This review is one of the times that I wish Yelp had 1/2 stars. My experience was truly a A-OK+ visit. I'm sure after another visit or two I could easily be a fan. The food we had was great, what held the score back was the service. The service was just a little slow. 

How we ended up at Molly's was a surprise to us both. We were driving around wanting some place new and being in Soulard - there was hardly a place we hadn't tried, so Molly's is where we ended up. 

We ordered multiple appetizers to create a meal for two. As you will see, we went with a seafood theme. We started out with Tuna Summer Roll and Crab Cake. The Tuna Summer Roll was better then some I have experienced at a Sushi bar. The Crab Cake was moist and flavorful, not like one you'd get in Maryland, but good. 

We also tried their BBQ Shrimp & Green Fried Tomatoes, as you can see it doesn't photograph well and the taste was similar. This dish did not impress us, Broadway Oyster Bar does something similar so much better.

The last two items I'll mention were the best by far. Molly offers, Alligator Rangoon, something I have never heard of before. I have eaten Alligator and love Crab Rangoon - so why not give it a try. It was very unique and I look forward to having it again. We also tried Baked Macaroni & Cheese which was the bomb. This m&c could be a favorite of mine easily. 

Look forward to revisiting and see if I can't bump them up to a 4.

It's a smaller sized Thai restaurant (about 6ish tables). Better call if party size more than 4 people.

They are also open on Sunday and they were busy. There is one server person doing it seems everything and the 2 chefs cooking in the back.

Got the panang curry with extra shrimp (total of 8 tail on shrimps). It had green beans and some slivers of green bell peppers, but no other veggies like carrots or onions. Curry sauce very fragrant with basil and lemongrass flavors.

About $5 for Thai tea.

Was not asked about what heat level we wanted for curry but  Mr Bland ate the curry we received slowly and drank his water. In fact, every table asked for a refill of water.

Also got the green papaya salad that came with about 4 shrimps, too!

Do a Yelp check-in!

Got the oven going up, on a Wednesday - 
Got cookies baking fresh and I'm choosy.

Happy, Happy - Joy, Joy!! I became familiar with Hot Box Cookie while at law school in Columbia, MO and I must say I am thrilled they are now in the area. The Lou has never seen fresh cookie like this.

Cookie Types: Oatmeal and Raisin, Chocolate Chip, Chocolate Chip & Oatmeal combo, Peanut Butter, Monster, M&M's, Red Velvet and many more.  

Peep the scenario: 

All of the above noted cookie dough's are available to you.  You get to choose one, two, hell pick oodles of them. Then your cookies are baked fresh!!! Not made fresh that day but in your face! Nothing says lovin like a warm fresh cookie.  Then, if you thought it couldn't get better, wait, wait, wait, hold - IT ... it does!!! They deliver (but this review doesn't speak to that), have icing sandwiches (2 cookie w/ icing in the middle), ice cream sandwiches and huge cookie cakes.  They also have cookies on display that are made fresh daily for fast service.  Are you in a sugar coma yet?? For milk options they have skim, 2 percent and chocolate (no soy, almond or rice milk yet) and I think Pepsi products are coming. 

When I went, my wait was only five minutes for fresh cookies so it wasn't bad at all.  The cookies aren't huge but are a very generous size.  I went with: 2 snicker doodle cookies, 2 classic chocolate chip, 2 peanut butter chocolate chip and 2 oatmeal chocolate.  So fresh and so good.  The box was actually hot and the cookies were packaged with care and foil inside to retain the heat.

Another standout for this business is that they are open late - waaaay late (most evenings until midnight and on the weekend until 2am).  So on those nights when you're out kicking it late and your sweet tooth is on ten (that means on high) this place is ready.  That will really work in this area being so urban (in midtown), close to University, medical centers and the Cortex Innovation Community (a.k.a The District - techies like sweets too). 

If you live in the area (or have lived in any trendy metro area) - you know how cool it is to walk to a bar after dinning at a cool place; you've just had good eats and a nice buzz from whatever you just drank then add in a cool breeze and cookies.  It's those nights you don't forget - those nights that feel like you're in a cool music video or a sassy Sex N the City episode (for guys, let's say How to Make it in America or Entourage).  Have one of those nights or just an awesome day/afternoon and stop by Hot Box Cookies - you'll leave with a big ole smile - I did.

Thanks to the incredible UYE that happened here I just had to book Avero for a good occasion in the future. And that finally came when I took my dad out to an early Father's Day dinner since we were in for an awesome wedding weekend. And overall Avero managed to deliver a lot of solid positives.

Since last visit Avero added a lot of new booths, drapes, and dividers that succeeded in providing a few more intimate sitting areas to the expansive main dining hall. Add in a solid happy hour, a few chef tasting menu options, a well rounded beer and cocktail menu, and accommodating service; and they definitely have a few extra bonuses to make the visit worthwhile.

The big emphasis on Avero's menu is wood fired pizzas, handmade pasta, and locally sourced ingredients; and the trifecta definitely managed to shine throughout. While I was disappointed to see the foie gras and proscuitto wrapped asparagus that the elite event crew feasted upon off the menu, I did enjoy savoring their delicious calamari again, even if the sauce was a touch more spicier than I remembered. Since I missed out on trying the bulk of their pizzas last time a pie was in order. And the special Spring Pizza that was topped with proscuitto, asparagus, smoked mozzarella, and farmers egg delivered big time. Since I also had to sample their pasta offerings and was craving seafood I decided to go with the fettuccine frutti di mare which delivered the best of both worlds. With gulf shrimp, pei mussels, buttery scallops, and fettuccine that was hand crafted to perfection swimming in marinara sauce, it managed to deliver a perfect bite after bite by the fork full.

With offerings like that and a menu that features all kind of impressive appetizers, bistro inspired Italian fare, pizzas, and pasta, Avero has plenty of things to make it worth the visit.

Baology first had me at bao! But when it added in tantalizing subject matter like Taiwanese fried chicken and all those dumplings it quickly became my kind of science!

At its core Baology is modern Taiwanese food with a splash of other Asian influences served simple. Depending on what time you come, the tablet POS system up front will showcase a menu for breakfast, lunch or dinner, And depending on when you come in you might find noodle dishes, bento box style bian dangs, incredible ruen bing wraps, or a good sized helping of 3 cup chicken. But for whatever occasion you come in, you might want to wash your food down with their cold brewed hibiscus and ginger tea.

For my first visit I was craving those baos, and ordered in a trio. Making the mistake of thinking it wasn't enough food I also ordered some shrimp & pork dumplings which were a sweet and savory explosion! With 5 baos on the menu it was tricky to choose at first, but I enjoyed the following:

King oyster mushroom bao - the vegetarian bao on the menu and its incredible with its pickled mustard greens, crispy garlic, and hoisin sauce that blends impressively with the mushroom king.

Roasted Berkshire pork belly bao - the fatty and tender pork belly gets accentuated by togarashi aioli, pickled daikon radish, cilantro, and crushed peanut powder!

Taiwanese fried chicken bao - the perfect preview to their fried chicken reigns supreme with lemon aioli and Thai basil!

After enjoying the bao I had to try more of that fried chicken, and it proved to be crispy saucy perfection with just a bit of spice. With two good visits under my belt its enough to have me craving more!

This darling, charming restaurant looks like someone's extended dining room. It's cozy, comfortable and inviting with attentive and helpful service. But it is not sizable -- seems like it could only comfortable seat about 30 or so people. 

Interesting: The hostess/server will reserve tables in advance and without request for the anticipated larger groups.

On the menu are items the restaurant boasts are made in house and from scratch. 

Among other options, you have the choice of sour rye soup, beet soup, chicken and pork cutlets, veal schnitzel, potato pancakes, kielbasa and Reuben sandwiches, vegetable salads (with apples, carrots, eggs and potatoes), broiled salmon and desserts like cheesecake, kolaczki and crepes. Polish Cottage also cares the obligatory, all-famous pierogies with several different options for fillings. 

We were first-timers, so we opted for the dinner for two which, at $34, came with two stuffed cabbage orders, two sausages, a beef stew, two buns and eight pierogies. You get two choices for the pierogies, so we asked that our dumplings be stuffed with potatoes and cheese, and also beef. For dinner, the serving size was able. A great amount of food for the both of us. 

It was my first time eating pierogies and I found them to be just OK. They were served with sour cream (interestingly served in a to-go container instead of a more sustainable option), which did not enhance the flavor. Of the two, I like the one stuffed with potatoes and cheese the best. 

What I loved, loved, loved, however, were two dishes: the stuffed cabbage and the stew. 

The cabbage roll is full of pork and rice, then smothered with a tomato sauce. It was quite delicious! Not rich, but certainly not flat in flavor. I loved that, despite the filling and topping, you could still distinctively taste the cabbage. And the cabbage held its form pretty well, indicating that the dish was made fresh. 

The stew -- I need that recipe! It contains cabbage, beef and I don't know what else. Luscious, deep flavor! I was stuffed, yet found myself wanting another cup of stew. 

On the drink menu, you will find Bulgarian and Romanian Cabernet Sauvignon, Sauvignon Blanc and Chardonnay. There is also a Serbian Riesling and a Tsantali Blanc from Greece. There's also a dessert wine from Croatia. All reasonably priced at less than $6 per glass. There is also a selection of Polish, Slovak and Russian beers. 

All in all, a wonderful experience! And having held the Polish Cottage in my bookmarks for years and years. Don't wait that long to give them a try.

We stopped in looking for a bite to eat. We weren't familiar with the chain, but thought we'd give them a chance. They were wearing masks (if improperly most of the time) but it took a few minutes for the cashier to turn around and notice my beau and I. 

We placed our order: The double Angus with onion rings, and A chicken sandwich with onion rings, when the food came out, it was delivered to the table with a smile, we were asked if we needed anything, which I did, ranch for dipping, and we began to eat. 

The food was good, it was nicely seasoned and tasty. The chicken, which is often the one that people get wrong was nice, juicy. I even forgot that there was avocado on it.  The beau liked his burger, said it tasted fresh.  The onion rings were nothing to write home about.

Had a nice evening here - but had to beg for veggies instead of chips (trying to watch carbs) for the $7 pico 'n chips.  They eventually oblidges with delicious cucumber, celery and carrot sticks.  PERFECT!

I wish you'd offer veggies on the menu as a sub for chips - I'd be willing to pay $2 - $3 extra for it.

But man, that pico (avocado chunks in pico de gallo) is terrific.

Great service.

I miss the days when my sister used to work here... this place is so up her alley and the staff is so happy and kind here.  Fresh organic fruits and veggies, bins filled with nuts and legumes, all your vegan and vegetarian needs, green toiletries and gifts, booze!  What more could you possibly ask for (question mark).

I saw 2 kinds of coconut water and was on a mission to buy as many as I could, they checked the stock room for me and they didn't have any cases so they special ordered me 2 kinds.  I'm so stoked!  They'll be in soon, just have to make sure my little sister has enough money to pay for these guys since she has to drive them up to me up north.  Thanks Miks!!!

Why 4 stars? Because it's a nice option for Greek in Carrollwood.

   ---   ---   ---

I've driven past Santorini quite a few times, but hadn't stopped in until recently. To be honest, the shopping center is a bit run down and I wasn't sure what to expect. But they definitely had some pretty stellar reviews, so I knew that I eventually had to hit them up. 

There was quite the level of add activity happening in the parking lot when we visited. There were people just sitting the parking lot in chairs that you'd normally see at a tailgate. Only there was no game happening - it was just a Saturday night in a strip center. We couldn't really figure out what was happening there.

But we headed inside and ordered our food. The good news is that my gyro was delicious, but the bad news is that it strongly smelled like cleaning supplies in here while we were waiting for it to be cooked. You can actually place pick-up orders here through Yelp, so that is definitely what I'll be doing next time. 

And the loaded fries were not so loaded - more like fries with some feta cheese sprinkled on top. I added some vinegar to them when I got home to spruce them up a bit. They were still tasty, but maybe the name should change to "feta fries."

I'll be back next time I'm craving Greek food, especially now that Simple Greek has closed (RIP.)

I absolutely LOVE Santa Barbara Autowerks, Inc. and can see myself being a loyal customer for years and years to come. 

With the help of my fellow Yelpers, I first called upon SBAW to do an inspection of a used BMW that I was considering purchasing. They did a thorough evaluation, provided honest feedback and helped coordinate pick up and drop off of the vehicle. I ended up purchasing a great car, for a great deal! 

Fast forward a few months later, I call SBAW in frenzy, as I attempted to rush to a yoga class on my lunch break and couldn't get my keys out of the ignition. After troubleshooting the issue for several minutes myself, I called SBAW, and a very patient, Hector answered the phone and started by asking me kindly if the "car is in park?" Why no! It wasn't! A minor detail I neglected to attend to in my haste! As I proclaimed to Hector what an idiot I am and thanked him profusely, he never made me feel stupid and was quite validating. Thank you Hector! 

I've had a couple of other routine services since then and am incredibly satisfied with the work these gentlemen have done. Hector and Aaron are gems to work with and they deserve all the accolades bestowed upon them. They're 5-star reputation is well earned! 

If you're looking for a mechanic that you can trust, look no further and call Santa Barbara Autowerks! 

(Don't forget to check-in on Yelp while you're there and take advantage of their 10% discount, which can go a long way when you're getting a major service. :D)

So I have logged more flights into and out of RNO than any other 5 people that I know. I started making monthly flights in 1981, on a number of airlines that no longer exist. That lasted for over 10 yrs. Since then I still have flown in a few times a year. I know this airport like the back of my hand for better or worse.

However I love it here. This may be the nicest airport that I can remember going to. It is always clean. The lines are nothing like any other place that I have flown to. Reno is the biggest little city for a reason. 

This airport has always had very nice folks working at it across the board, regardless of their being airport staff, an onsite vendor, or working for one of the airlines. I am not sure what has caused this disposition, but I absolutely love it. Flying in or out of here just is pleasant to me. 

After they built the new parking structures a number of years ago, it got much better here. Pick up and drop off by locals was much more easily done and allows you to enjoy a quick bite to eat or a place to relax while waiting for your flight without having to immediately go to the gate.

Also like McCarran in Vegas, you can gamble while awaiting your flight. Sadly they don't bring you any free drinks, and it's rare to see someone hit a jackpot, but it is great when someone does. They have all of the typical vendors here with a coffee joint, bar, newsstand, and some type of ever changing grub spot on each concourse.

As this is the primary destination for people flying in to go skiing/snowboarding in Lake Tahoe, they airline personnel are used to dealing with all kinds of specialty sized equipment. This also includes backpacking equipment of those going into the high country during the spring, summer, and fall.  Having that advantage is huge IMHO and makes life better for the outdoorsy types. 

Overall I have nothing bad to say about this place. Regardless of the season, this place is to me the epitome of how an airport should operate.

My girlfriend and I, who both love Thai food, decided to check this place out for dinner on a Thursday night. After having read some pretty solid reviews, I couldn't help but be surprised when we left disappointed and unsatisfied with our experience. The food was underwhelming and the service was really... bizarre for a lack of better words. :(

We were both really overwhelmed when we first started browsing through the menu. They have SO many options, it was nearly impossible to make a decision. After much pondering we each decided to get the Tom Yum soup (I got chicken, she got shrimp) and the Satay Sampler to share. 

Let me start with the soup - I knew after just the first couple spoonfuls that I wasn't a fan. We both normally love Tom Yum soup which is why that was the easiest decision for us to make. I felt like the soup was extremely oily with really no flavor. In prior experiences, I've always thought Tom Yum has a little kick to it but this one did not at all. I also felt like there were way too many mushrooms. Such a disappointment. :(

The Satay Sampler we ordered came with 2 chicken, 2 beef, and 2 shrimp satays with a small bowl of pickled vegetables (carrots and cucumbers) and peanut sauce. While there was nothing specifically wrong with the satay, there was certainly nothing to rave about either. The meat was cooked well, but with no taste at all. The peanut sauce was just your average peanut sauce. Nothing special about that. 

For our entrees, my friend and I both ordered the Green Curry with chicken. Their spice level ranges from 1-7 (I've never seem higher than 5 before?!) so  I got the 5. WHAT A MISTAKE. It was WAY too spicy for me! I don't blame this on the restaurant at all, it was just a poor decision on my part. I'd like to think I can handle spicy food pretty well, but I definitely should have gone with a 4 or maybe even a 3 at Tamarind. My friend can definitely handle very spicy food, but she also felt like a 5 here was a bit much. Just something to keep in mind when making your decision. 

Spice aside, the entree was about average. Although it was flavorful and had a decent amount of chicken, the vegetables weren't anything special. Didn't taste quite fresh. 

As far as service goes, I was content with the pace at which our food was brought out. What I found rather strange was that we would have to ask them to remove our plates between dishes. When we were done our appetizers, out empty plates were left at the table while they tried to make room for our entrees. We actually had to request and suggest that they take away our empty, dirty plates to make room. This happened between our soup and appetizer and again between our appetizer and entree. It wasn't very eye appealing to have empty, dirty dishes on our table between orders, not to mention we had practically no room on the table!

Overall, Tamarind didn't really impress me. Let my search for the best Thai restaurant in Philly continue...

Just went back to try the food since the new management took over, and it was excellent.  Grouper sammich was way better than the one offer by the previous owners.  The filet was a nice size and pleasantly thick.  I love me some grouper sammiches, but I think the story to write about here was the burger my chica got.  Damn if that thing was flame grilled to tasty perfection.  It's just hard to find a freaking burger grilled over an open flame these days after the fall of BGR.  Honestly, I cannot see going back to Jack Willie's and ordering anything but this burger!
Great customer service! Thanks to the young lady who helped me set up my new Fitbit Versa. Great experience, and great service too!

We had lunch here before a campus tour since Jared's sister is considering UofA for college... It was my first time on campus - I was really impressed!

There were 4 of us and we sat outside... I wish I would've done my Yelp research as I would've known to order pizza.  Instead, I had a veggie burger smothered.  It was just ok.  Service was not great... although it was a basketball game day so I know I can't be too harsh!  However, when I ordered the artichoke app "to start" and it didn't arrive until well after we all finished our meals, that was a little disappointing!

I would say don't go for the food... the sandwiches and burgers were nothing special in my eyes.  Cool scene and love that they put 2 big wide screen TVs outside for those that want to watch the game...

I would go back, but after I check out all of the other cute college bars and restaurants on campus.

Urban Brew and BBQ is a small barbecue joint in downtown St. Pete. The first thing I noticed about Urban Brew's barbeque is that they leave the sauce on the side of their slow cooked smoked meats so that diners can choose their favorite style of BBQ. The BBQ sauces come in a variety of sweet, spicy, smoky, and tangy flavors.

Besides Urban's amazing juicy, tender and flavorful slow cooked smoked meats they offer a variety of classic and gourmet side dishes.  Good lord, these side dishes are so good!!! The Urban Mac N' Cheese and the Pork Belly are out of this world good! The macaroni dish is cooked in a miniature skillet. Genius! A nice selection of craft beers are also available and the selection changes regularly. 

The atmosphere at Urban Brew is very cool and features Augusta Blocks from the streets of St. Pete, tiled penny floors in the bathrooms, a huge mural of Central Avenue and photos of downtown St. Pete from the late 1800's to 1920's. I really appreciate these little details because it adds so much character to the restaurant.

I held back one star because I felt like our meal was a tad expensive for "beer and BBQ". I know... I'm a cheap ass. I need to get used to paying $6+ for a beer. Also I would love to see the outdoor beer garden spruced up. Some umbrellas and a few potted plants would make the area so much more inviting.

Got here 5 minutes before they opened on a Monday and there were already people sitting around, waiting for the line to open up. As soon as it hit 10:30am, there was a line all the way to the door.

Got two plates of the Meat + 3 Veggies. The bread / corn bread towards the register comes with every meal for free! Got the fried chicken and the roast beef, both so good and simple. For the sides, i enoyed the mac & cheese and the creamed corn. The green beans were way, way, wayyy too salty. For dessert, I got the chocolate chess pie. I thought it was good, but I've had way better in LA.

Tip: get here a few minutes before they open and just stand in line. There were people sitting down at tables before the line opened and they ended up 20+ people behind me.

This is a lovely spot to hit for brunch while in NOLA- the Jazz band could play more consistently, we were a large group and everyone came to that individual conclusion that the band was hardly playing the entire time we were there. 
The food is amazing and the chefs are friendly. The staff is welcoming and will help in any way they can. 
Definitely recommend to have the eggs benny and to try them every which way possible. The turtle soup was also fantastic! 
It's a great way to get your group gears up for a full day on the town, the location can't be beat!

I loved my experience at Savannah's Candy Kitchen. As soon as I walked in I was greeted by the friendliest employee ever. He was making fresh pralines and offering up free samples. After my first taste I was hooked and had to purchase a couple. I thought that New Orleans had the best pralines but Savannah's Candy Kitchen proved otherwise. I will be back before the end of my trip so that I can bring some home. 

In addition to fresh made pralines they also sell loads Old Fashioned Candy, ice cream and a huge variety of chocolates. The women checking me out was just as friendly as the gentleman working in the front of the store.

A bit chilly, they definitely keep Starbucks well air-conditioned in this little spot close to 15th & Locust.

Service was prompt and efficient with the barista and the cashier relatively friendly.

Bathrooms were clean.

There were a couple nicer seats, but the seating in here leaves something to be desired with the little wooden tables & chairs; free AT&T wifi.

During the initial coronavirus shutdown here in Nashville, I found myself cooking a lot more and often wanting fresh herbs for my dishes. 

Sure, I obtained some from a variety of grocery delivery services, but they weren't usually the best...in fact, almost never. Not to mention, they're expensive.

Enter Gardens of Babylon. 
They were still allowed to function curbside only, and eventually added an online ordering section to their website.

I found it fairly easy to place and pay for my orders online. Once an order was ready (usually in 24 hours), I was asked to pick it up within a specified block of time consisting of a few days. 
This was (mostly) helpful considering my limited availability and their limited hours of operation at that time.

I ordered rosemary, basil, parsley, cilantro, herb & veggie plant food, organic potting soil, and even pots and saucers!

On each trip, I would pull up to the front of their nursery and open the back of my vehicle for them to place my order inside. All very socially distanced, all wearing masks; very easy and very safe.

Unfortunately, the product availability wasn't always accurate on their site. I ordered some pots and saucers, then later received a call from the staff advising they did not have the exact items in stock as indicated. So I agreed to accept a substitution. A staff member had to call me again to advise I would have to pay more for the substitution. I reluctantly accepted the charge. I think it would have been best if they had just credited the difference considering it was only a few dollars more.

I think they now permit folks to peruse their garden center since it's outdoors. (Although I'd recommend to call them first to be sure.) 

Based on my curbside experiences, I feel fairly confident they are operating safely regardless of restrictions or no restrictions.

Silver in the City is an adorable shop full of fun gift type items. I'd equate it to an Urban Outfitters minus the clothes but with a huge addition of a jewelry section. As far as the gifts go, you'll find everything that's 'in' right now from mustache items galore, bacon items abound and tiny outfits for squirrels. They have a bunch of special Indiana items, quirky cards, fun books, strange cat items and many drinking accessories. 

This is a fantastic shop to find a unique gift for someone, plus they have a pretty space with items on sale. This kind of shop is dangerous for me because I love awkward little cute items.I narrowly escaped with my wallet intact.

Machelle H. describes City Park quite nicely, so please do read her review.  

From own personal experiences, City Park really is pretty neato.  I've been to two Voodoo Fests here - it's a great space for a music festival - tons of room to accommodate an impressive line-up of bands without there being music clash.  

I've also tagged along during a photoshoot here and I've observed others conducting their own photoshoots.  It's not the most stunning park, but it's a pretty great backdrop for some natural lighting modeling promo photos or graduation photos - there's even a few arched bridges should you desire to incorporate those.  I've never ventured into the botanical gardens, but I can imagine it's a lovely place to capture some floral macro shots.  

Of course there's the museum and sculpture garden as well should you deserve to be get your culture on.  Something free and fun for the kids are the duck ponds.  If you're seeking for some fitness - well maintained running and biking paths are available.  

I think it's a nice place to hang out with some friends and dogs or have a picnic - weather permitting.  It's not typically very crowded, unless there's a special event - it seems "calmer" than Audubon Park most of the times.

The oven-roasted gulf fish "fisherman's style" at Cochon is one of the dreamiest dishes that I've had all year.

I know Cochon is known more for their stellar "meatier"dishes - but trust me on this one - get the fish. 

The portion is massive and the fish is so tender, fresh, and moist. My dish was seasoned with so much love - that I never wanted the meal to end.

Cochon is particularly nice - early on in the evening when big occasions are manifesting in the rest of the city. Around dusk - there is rarely a wait and the service is always friendly and helpful.

Trust.

Peg Leg Porker is the brainchild of the famous pitmaster Carey Bringle. Look at all this trophies and you can tell he knows how to compete. 

Parking is such a pain in this area. Over crowded with cars trying to park. Meters are around $2 per hour. 

Huge BBQ joint, 2 stories. Typical order up window. Self seating. Huge indoor and outdoor eating areas. No phone orders.

Full Rack Platter - $22.95 - Ok smoke flavor. Meat had good bite and fell off the bone. Seasoning was visible but had no taste. I had to drown the meat in their bbq sauce. Spicy was good. Mac and green beans were good sides with this platter. 

BBQ Sandwich - $6 - Had to try their pulled pork since they are a pig spot. Nothing special, typical pulled pork you can find all over.

Was super excited to try an award winning place and was sadly let down. Always remember, competition bbq is completely different from restaurant bbq.

I would say this taco place would be about 3.5 stars to me.  I've had my share of tacos and this place really didn't wow me when I was hoping they would since it was pretty famous in Santa Barbara.  We got #16, which was the best one, but also one of the most expensive ones.  The meat for the taco wasn't marinated that well or marinated at all.  The service can take pretty long for tacos.  After you order and find a table, expect to wait at least 15-20 minutes for your tacos.  We also got the pozole special, which was really good! Love the broth!

There are so many better restaurants to be had in the city. I guess the novelty of eating on a boat is cool or whatever, but you know what's even cooler? Good food. And I hate to say it but this place is overpriced and underwhelming. 
I seriously dislike any place that makes you pay for bread, like they did here. And if I'm paying for it it shouldn't be basic bitch bread, like it was. Warm that jawn up or something. We also split a very overpriced sushi roll which was ok but I've had way better sushi way cheaper. 
For our mains I got the swordfish which was really dry and flavorless. Would not recommend. It tasted like I ordered swordfish at a diner, not at a high priced seafood restaurant. Fiancé got a NY strip I believe which he said was ok but nothing blew him away. Dessert was pretty good...I forgot what it was called but we got some kind of chocolate pudding in a jar with other chocolate things on top. 
The worst part of the experience was where we were seated, which apparently was directly underneath the dance floor upstairs. It felt and sounded like it was going to cave in on us and was not conducive to a nice night out. This was definitely a one and down experience for us.

On lunch break from the embroidery class at Craft Alliance, this was the most convenient lunch spot -- just across the parking lot.

The place was hoppin', but we got our orders in quickly, and the food came out (carryout) In reasonable time.

This is not the cleanest St. Louis Bread Company -- or Panera -- I've patronized. At the iced tea station, the lemon wedge jar was nearly empty, and what was in there surely was doin' a botulism dance.

The area where you get napkins and such was so gritty from coffee drinkers spilling their sugar and creamer stuff, I wiped the counter down myself.

Aren't staff appointed to attend to these obvious clean-up areas?

My girlfriend and I both got the Steak and Bleu Cheese Salad, which included a hunk of sourdough bread.

The salad was wonderful, and a huge portion. There was plenty of protein and dressing.

It was just kinda pricey for lunch.

And since I was doing a carryout and going back to the embroidery class at Craft Alliance, I had to ditch the leftovers. THAT'S what made it pricey.

It could have lasted two meals.

Good pizza in Edmonton sure is a hard thing to find. The only place that pops into my mind is Tony's Pizza Palace (sorry not sorry Famosa, Lovepizza, insert any other crappy chain restaurant). Well, my Italian bud L was craving pizza so he suggested we try out Ragazzi Bistro Italiano. Originally beginning as Pizza Boys, they changed their name to the Italian equivalent of boys and the rest is history. Family run and off the beaten track, it sounded like we would be in good hands for our Wednesday evening dinner.

You'll find Ragazzi east of the main strip of Whyte. I've never spotted their storefront myself even though I've driven by many times. Their restaurant blends in with the rest of their tiny strip mall compatriots. I think what deterred me from going sooner was that their website has no menu prices up. Seriously, hate that. 

The inside is interesting.  You see the bar and kitchen the moment you walk in. We were pleasantly greeted by both our waitress and one of the chefs who was busy making a pizza but stopped to say hello. Nice touch. A stone arch splits the restaurant into half (original in the front, old in the back with a few more comfy booths). The place already had a few occupied tables when we arrived around 6:15pm but the front half was completely full by the time we left.

The menu is split into appetizers, pizza, pasta and grill. Wanted to try their famous Soprano bread but seeing as there were only two of us, we opted to go big with two 16" inch pizzas instead. Maybe next time as several tables ordered it!

17 pizzas to choose from. Way too many choices and sadly, I asked the waitress after our meal and they don't let you do half flavours. Bummer. Three sizes to choose from (12", 14" and 16") and price ranges from $15-$30. Prices are on the higher spectrum but this is pretty much on par with Tony's. 

Not sure about their pastas - saw a large group of old grannies order a couple different dishes and they looked pretty ordinary. Sometimes you have to stick with what a restaurant does best and here, it's their thin crust pizza.

- Davide's inferno ($25.00 for 16") - marinated tomatoes, Italian sausage, casalingo salami, mixed blend of cheese and spices. FYI - this one has a four spice level rating. FOUR spice. No big deal right? Well, that's what we thought because normally these things aren't accurate. Well, you've been warned - we both took our first bites and were greeted with a delicious wave of hot chili flakes and spices. Oh and these pizzas come out straight from the oven - maybe wait a minute or two before you start devouring them. I may have slightly burned the top of my mouth - totally worth it. Flavours were great with the variety of meats, sweet tomatoes and spice level. Get it.

- Pizza con spinaci ($25.00 for 16") - spinach, black olives, a blend of Parmesan, mozzarella and feta cheese. Our only complaint was that the centre turned out a bit soggy. The rest was good as you could taste each ingredient on it's own accord. First time for me having spinach on a pizza - I think I like arugula more so as spinach doesn't have much flavour while arugula has that slight punch of anise. L liked how they used a subtle, neutral tomato sauce to keep things classic. 

- Caffe latte ($3.75) - a typical after dinner drink my bud always gets. Smelled great. Add tons of sugar, mix and enjoy. Think of at like a dessert drink.

Simple, homemade and unpretentious fare. Stick with the pizzas and you can't go wrong. Maybe there is hope for pizza in town after all...

When John mentioned that Jennifer from Top Chef used to work here, I got super excited. Google showed me that it wasn't the contestant I'd been thinking of, but I was still curious enough to want to try the place. The wait was close to 45 minutes as estimated, and we eventually got a small table by the window. For lack of supply our table wasn't equipped with the same set of hot sauces as the neighboring tables. Margarita flavors of the day were strawberry or mango, and a pitcher of the latter pleasantly sloshed us by the end of dinner.

I was sad to see that their menu online hadn't been updated with the recent changes. While I understand that it's a pain to keep stock for a vegetarian ingredient that isn't present in any other dishes, I'd been really looking forward to the cactus and sweet potato burrito. Which reminds me, I haven't seen a neighborhood so vegetarian-friendly in a long time. John was gung-ho about what appetizers we were going to get, so I let him take charge of those while I picked out our entrees. Given the amount of food we were about to indulge in, we opted to pass on the endless chips and salsa. As strongly as his roommate recommended the barbecue, I was pretty realistic about our consumption of food and chalked the pork belly off for a later visit.

I've never seen fried pickle chips cut so thick (a hefty quarter-inch), and the texture was right on the border between cuke and pickle. The spicy chili mayo it came with was an okay pairing, nothing special. Of everything on our table it was the least spectacular, and as a result it was the only thing we left unfinished.

The single order of veggie wings with ranch sauce arrived at the same time as the other app. Celery and carrot sticks were acceptably fresh, though the celery was the lower quality of the two. The seitan was sliced thin and fried to crisps before tossed in buffalo wing sauce. An interesting plate that I was content to eat, but definitely takes an open-minded palate to appreciate. Not sure that I'd get this again, but I'd be tempted to make this at home if I went herbivore.

Since the shrimp and chorizo burritos each came as a pair, we traded our spares to share the entree experience. The radish slices were nice to have, but I was unimpressed by the jicama cabbage slaw. I think my main criticism is that the tortillas tasted straight out of the package. I would've enjoyed each bite more had an attempt been made to lightly grill the wrappers. The chorizo was my favorite of the two; instead of pineapple, it's now served with roasted red potatoes that give it a fantastic rustic flavor. The wedge lime lightened the heaviness of the burrito, and I could totally picture this as an amazing breakfast burrito if scrambled egg were included. The shrimp burrito tasted of very fresh ingredients, but citrus wasn't present enough to make the seafood really pop. Sadly, this made the room-temperature tortilla overwhelm the light flavor of the shrimp.

Service was friendly enough to come by to top off our glasses for us despite the packed crowd and the pitcher being right there for our own dispensation. Two bathrooms behind the ATM/cigarette machines, surprisingly clean and tagged with random graffiti that actually fits right in with the feel of the place. The art on the windows made me smile, and the hubbub was too noisy for me to make out the TVs by the bar. I'd be interested in coming back at least one more time for food, and I'd definitely come back for boozing.

Go Glendora!  My hometown!  

Please get past the exterior - OMG - I'd probably never have gone here if it weren't for the great Yelp reviews, plus - again, it's in my hometown.

The interior design is just gorgeous - a lot of beautiful statues and with rich, earth tone colors.

The hostess/server was very sweet.

Although the restaurant only had two other customers at the 1 p.m. time we were there, it took a while to be served.  This is a good thing - everything was being freshly prepared in the kitchen!

My lentil soup was very good, but was NOT like the traditional version that I was expecting, and, it was . . . GREEN!   I thought my sister and I had each other's orders.  Nope.

The next time, yes, definite next time, I go, I'm getting the most EXCELLENT dish that my sister ordered. Vegetable dumplings in a cashew sauce.  It was sooooo good!  (I dipped some of my Naan in).

Speaking of which, the Naan was good but I wish they had offered one with spinach and cheese (my favorite, at the now closed :(, Inde Blue).  

I'm not sure if Dinner Bell has desserts.  We were too engrossed in conversation.  I probably would've passed anyway, as I'm having a big Sunday pasta dinner later. 

Give this hidden gem a try!

Having gone from trying a slice to ordering a whole pie, I must say I could hardly have hoped for better. The specials list here rotates daily, and I ended up with a close to perfect (albeit very salty) pizza, topped with something sweet and flavorful called a "peppadew" and a lot of arugula, which created a wonderfully balanced flavor and made me feel better about ordering garlic knots instead of a salad. The garlic knots were pretty rad.

It took close to forty minutes to get my pizza on a midweek evening. It was worth it, but I would caution anyone that this place is busy and takes time. I would also check the special of the day, as it rotates and there's always a vegan pie; which as much as I like their regular pizza I may try some day.

i want to go back and eat everything on the menu. 
and on the specials menu, too.

sunday funday in philly started with the intent to brunch at the cambridge. but they didn't have room for a party of 8 and we were getting hangry so the long wait was a no-no. so crepe is nextdoor and is delish, but was just about closed (yes, it was a late brunch... don't judge me) so that was out too. a few steps later, we were in front of miles table and everything sounded so effing delectable. 

and it was. 

we got a few dishes to go (boozy late brunch picnic in the park? yes please!) and i fell in love. the creme brule french toast looked spectacular- topped with fresh strawberries and a thick layer of creme brulee custard. devoured. the miles burger was huge, cooked right, and the boys loved them. 
as for me, i went with the falafel burger, topped with avocado. it was perfect. i want to eat it again. next time, though, i'll ask them not to mash the avocado. anddd the bun was a bit too big for me, so i went without half of it. the topless falafel burger was sooooooo many yums. 

seriously, do it. and take me back with you!

Deserves every five star rating.

This place is incredibly thorough. They email you a list of instructions before your appointment. I never thought to use sugar to exfoliate, but it worked wonders! I followed every single instruction to a tee and I left with a beautiful tan. 

I did a custom spray tan and the woman who did it was amazing. I've never felt so comfortable standing naked getting sprayed with cold air. She kept up a cheerful chatter during most of the session. She was definitely a pro.

I did this for a boudoir photoshoot and the photographer even asked me where I got the tan done. She said it looked amazing! I was trying to even out my terrible tan lines and they did a fantastic job. The photographer said she didn't even notice my tan lines!

They do a very good job at making your bronze and not orange at all. I highly recommend this place!

I appreciate the historic nature of this bar, and the crowds here aren't terribly douchey like they can be elsewhere, but for me this was a fairly typical dive bar experience. As other reviews have mentioned, the whole place has a very dark, dank, dungeony vibe, especially at the piano area in the back. At the bar in the front, there are slushie machines going on and on, and all the drinks I tried were OK. Overall, worth a stop if you're already on Bourbon.

I recently needed two tires replaced on my car and the first place I decided to go to get them was firestone.  They are always extremely helpful and friendly.  Not only were my tires replaced with ease, but they gave me a warranty on them, in case I get a flat or have a blowout and need a tire replacement.  They make the stressful situation of needing new tires a lot less stressful with their knowledge and the ease of which everything is handled.  Highly recommended and I would definitely return for future help.

This is one of the strangest theaters I've ever been to, strangely tucked away and hard to find, with a parking lot that's strangely dark and empty.  That said, it's a pretty cool place, with one screen and a tiny concession booth and decor that's evocative of an old mission without being particularly self-conscious.

I saw a Monday night showing of "Broken Embraces" and my boyfriend and I were the youngest people in the theater by about thirty years.  Maybe the seniors were enticed by the disgusting graphic sex between Penelope Cruz and a shriveled septuagenarian - otherwise, I guess this place just attracts an older crowd, at least on Mondays.

I kept hearing, "You have to go to East Nashville." "East Nashville is where it's at." "East Nashville is the Brooklyn of Nashville." Stop it. There is not Brooklyn of Nashville. Or any Brooklyn of any other place for that matter. Mickey's does provide a Brooklyn feel though, amongst a very non Brooklyn area. 

After passing several douchey seeming bars, all that you have to, in the middle of what feels like mini malls converted into bars, we landed at Micky's. I dig the place. It had a good vibe, an awesome back patio, cheap liquor, and a top notch selection of beer. 

It was definitely a fun crowd, that knew how to not be intrusive in other people's business, but if warranted you could strike up a conversation with someone at a neighboring table. The plan was to stay there only for a bit, but we actually ended up staying several hours. It was so much fun we almost forgot about our anti-Semitic uber drive home. 

East Nashville may not be Brooklyn, but Mickey's reminded me of home.

So yesterday I literally ate my way through Concourse B at the airport. I went to let's just say over three restaurants and also two bars today while trying to kill 3hrs. I also had Blue Bell ice cream and one of those nasty infamous weiners found in the French Quarter (you know the name). I only took two bites of the hot dog and I was done. Couldn't take no more!

The Praline Connection has a menu similar to the one on Frenchmen. Very typical cajun food. I tried the file gumbo. The gumbo was almost unedible. Not sure how they make their file gumbo. The only thing I recognized was the sausage. I will pass on the gumbo next time.

Burger Heaven! You basically build your burger with almost anything you want. 100% All natural Akaushi Kobe Beef burger - YUM! It was delicious and flavorful to the max, SO much better than 5 guys. Also, fresh baked buns brushed with butter - yep - and if it couldn't get any better? Hand cut French fries! AND they had rootbeer =)

HUGE shout-out to my boyfriend for using the Yelp app while we were on the road and finding this gem I like to refer to as meat heaven. Not to mention the staff were super friendly, it was so clean in there and there were TONS of TVs, seemed they were going for a sports "bar" feel.  Wish we had one in Orlando!

My husband and I both have numerous watches, some for work and play and others for dress, we also have a very bad habit of when the battery wears out, we set the watches aside and just start wearing another one, until we get to the point where we are left without a watch! 

Talk about procrastination, which ends up costing us dearly! Right now I have three watches that need batteries replaced and I refuse to wear my gold and diamond watch for everyday use, tacky plus knowing me, it would end up in the dead watch pile.

Hubby is down to wearing his Rolex with two Seiko's stopped in time. One of hubby's watches simply needs a pin, but when he has a battery replaced he insists on having it sent off to be sealed, because his watch never leaves his wrist, including showers and dish washing, I for one can't wait to take my watch off when I get home, so I really could care less if the watch is resealed or not.

The last time hubby took one watch to Time after Time and not only did he wait for weeks to have it resealed but it cost him $50.00 plus tax! We have never paid such an exuberant price for having one watch battery replaced and the watch resealed. I'm sure their profit was a grand one, but they lost the chance to service us again!

This place reminds me why I get so freakin' excited over good food. I almost cried over my scallops, and the lamb was beautifully prepared...don't forget to save room for some ice cream! Fresh and delicious!

First time I had frog legs and I won't forget it! Delicious...what was I waiting for? Throw in a perfectly shaken ice cold dirty martini, absinthe, mussels and salty/crisp fries, shrimp and tender/creamy grits, and house-made tongue-tingling ginger and mint sorbets...then please wheel me to the nearest bed. The wine options are amazing and varied. The service was friendly, attentive, knowledgeable and with a sense of humor in spite of an extremely busy, crowded restaurant. A top ten meal of all time, for sure.

Hands down the the most talented and professional hygienist I have ever had! 

Angie was energetic, friendly and outgoing! She spent significant amounts of time on fully explaining the health reasons and steps behind everything she did inside my mouth, teaching me some hygiene skills, suggesting tools for better oral health and providing instructions on the use of them. She made me feel so relaxed and comfortable!

My experience with Angie was as good as it gets! She did absolutely a fabulous job! I highly recommend her!

They had me right off the bat: as soon as I walked in I was offered spiced tea or champagne. *This* is how you make a good impression. Properly besotted with my beverage of choice, there was no way I was leaving without making a purchase. Business owners take note: a small investment yielded a ten-fold (at least) return. If I was offered drinks each time I entered a boutique, I would spend a lot more money. Not only am I relaxed at that point, it's rather rude to not spend money after being given a gift. We *are* in the south. Manners matter.

So, I'd never heard of Color before. Score one for Yelp. This stretch of road in Green Hills is, typically, my cut through to get to the mall so I don't have to wait for the bottleneck on Hillsboro. I never thought to look left and notice that there were/are businesses as I race past at breakneck speed.* Color is one of those fantastic holiday-ready catch-alls: home goods, gifts, jewelry... you name it (in those categories) and Color has it. The store isn't huge but for its size and in those categories, there's a nice selection from which to choose/shop. The aesthetic is feminine and southern so if you're buying for a southern lady, you've got it made in the shade. I saw runners, glasses, pillows, mirrors, and tableware that would have all been big hits. As it was, I found a unique statement bracelet and a charming wreath that were, both, big hits on Christmas morning.

The demographic may be specific but if you're buying for someone in that demo, you're home free. You're sure to find *something* that she'd enjoy. Plus, you live in Nashville. Odds are there is a southern woman in your life. Shop for her home/wrist/neck/fingers/ears here. Guaranteed she'll like whatever you find. And, lastly: kudos to Color for being the consummate hosts and offering refreshments just for walking through the door. That made a big impression on me and that service carried forward as I shopped. As a man who eschews shopping unless it's avoidable, Color made something painful enjoyable and earned a return customer for its efforts.

*Just kidding. I always go the speed limit.

Gioia's deli is an institution in St Louis.  So much so that after about a hundred years (not joking) they decided to expand.  Pretty cool that they did!

The food is the same as the original place although the atmosphere is different.  I love having them out in the county as a lunch alternative.

OMG! One of the best meal I had during my last trip to NOLA. I LOVE LOVE shellfish. When I lived at home my dad would buy a pound of fresh shrimp home for me to eat. For the 6 of us we ordered 20 lbs of crawfish! The crawfish was so fresh and delicious. I am drooling while writing this review. They used a light seasoning which I really much appreciated. No bibs and one unisex bathroom. Seating out back too. Not in the touristy area which is nice.

Had a great time here on a Saturday night. We sat outside, as I had my Yorkie with me, whom they welcomed to be with us at an outdoor table. They even brought him a water bowl. We didn't have to wait long for a table and the service was extremely friendly. The hostess, our waiter, and other staff members were all very courteous and went out of their way to ensure we were happy. Someone brought around warm, fresh garlic rolls. Our waiter was very personable and made good recommendations from the menu. The hostess also came around towards the end of the night to toast with us, as they have a ritual of playing Italian music and clinking glasses every Saturday night - a very cute touch!

Their pasta dishes are family-style, which I don't see much anymore and I love it! The half portion is more than enough for 2 people to share, and the full portion feeds 4-6 people. We had delicious appetizers consisting of spinach dip, stuffed mushrooms, and capris salad. We shared a family-style pasta with brie, which was unique and tasty.

Prices are very reasonable, service is excellent, and food is yummy, too! Can't go wrong if you're looking for a low-key Italian place in a great location in SB.

Oh, how I wanted so much to hate the new Whole Foods. I mean I already hated the awful things the construction did to the neighborhood. Only having been open a few weeks, I'm really hating the new traffic and congestion its already adding. 

HOWEVER, the store is really bright and beautiful. It's a suburban size supermarket smack in the city. I should probably hold off on this review until I go back a few more times, but I feel like I haven't shut up about it in real life so I may as well go ahead and blab about it in Yelp life. 

So I knew they were getting a beer bar, but I had no idea they were getting a bottle shop too. The selection was pretty decent and the prices were fair market value in PA. Goose Island Juliet at $24...I'm coming back for you dear...

I've yet to try any of the little restaurant areas, but how could being able to get Dizengoff's in the heart of Fairmount be a bad thing? 

The salad bar was on steroids in comparison to their former location. Although, they didn't have hardboiled egg on a Sunday morning; that's a fail. 

Same with the soup bar. There were far more fresh soups than were previously offered.

In general, all the hot food and made-to-order foods looked bigger, brighter and are hopefully better. 

And this is my whole view from just the first section of the store. I'm sure I'll write an update once the dust settles. And yes, there was dust flying around the area for months...I suffered through it. For now, I'm smitten with the bright, shiny and new.

Vegan isn't my go-to but Royal Tavern had very good reviews, I found a great parking spot, loved the bar back board and they have beer. This was my 3rd vegan 'cheesesteak' and probably my favorite. I would have liked it more but my roll was cut on a weird angle and it made it hard to eat. Very flavorful and more importantly not overdone trying to hide blandness of ingredients attempt at flavorful. Nice chat with guy next to me that just moved to Swarthmore helped easy the pain of a $23 (pre tip, one beer) lunch bill.

I have a few guilty pleasures that I really don't like sharing with anyone.

I would say guilty pleasure #1 is watching America's Funniest Videos.  

I don't get it.  

I can't stop laughing at little kids farting, dudes getting hit with balls in the, well, balls, and old ladies falling on their faces while trying to catch the bouquets at weddings.

It's so bad that I have all my recordings hidden in a folder on my TiVo.

And yet I keep the porn out in the open.  

Whatever.

Next guilty pleasure is consuming massive amounts of girlie drinks when I can.  

Holdrens makes a stellar pomegranate martini.  After downing two of those, I switched to the grapefruit martini.

Deliciously wussy if you ask me.

I am surprised that Holdren's has such low ratings.  Definately a good place to eat.

I got the top sirloin with the rosemary bluecheese dressing.  

Service was great and so was the atmosphere.

Whiffle.

We came during an off-peak time and the park rangers were so kind to my then 5 year old who brought her easel and pencils - they let her sit and sketch - which I bet is unusual.

There was practically no line on the random weekday morning when we visited.

If you can stand the wait on a Sunday for brunch on a sun shiny day without wanting to dabble in cannibalism (eating off someone's limb out of sheer hanger), then Boathouse is a nice retreat from the more populated area of SB. 

To help curb your insatiable appetite while waiting for a table, get yourself a Bloody Mary (the one with the fatty meets crispy bacon strip and shrimp). It's the perfect way to tide you over for an hour and if you can snag a seat at either side of the bar, then you'll be in heaven.

When you finally do get a seat and order, be prepared for the food to come out quick. The kitchen does a phenomenal job of firing out the dishes. The Huevos Hope Ranch was a stellar dish (two fried eggs, crispy tortilla, black beans, avocado, sour cream, queso fresco & Boathouse breakfast potatoes). It was a good lookin' one, too. I also ordered the French toast as an amuse bouche, but would prob skip this next time as there wasn't anything spectacular about it.

If you opt to sit outside and the sun is a blazin' and you volunteer yourself for the shadeless seat because you think the brisk SB ocean breeze will cool you down, you will very much regret that decision about 15-30 minutes in. I was definitely feeling the heat half way through my meal and there was nothing the Blood Orange Margarita could do about it...unless I chose to pour it on my body instead of in my mouth, but that didn't seem like the classy Sunday brunch thing to do.

Ok so I am a fan of Lumbrada ! 

I'm a fan of their warm chips and that homemade salsa they make! (It's not that Ortega nonsense)

I'm a fan of their badass tacos , their Al Pastor is on point if you were wondering which one to get. Their Carnita is also good, but the Patron here is their Al Pastor. 

I'm a fan of that San Jose burrito that will handcuff your taste buds faster than a kid hitting a piñata! That melted cheese laying over top while there is a fiesta waiting for you to bite into it! A sloppy deliciousness of authentic cuisine just waiting for you to moan. 
Ok, I might've been the only one to have moaned, but you're going to have that same reaction I experienced. 

I'm a fan of that impressive bar they have, and I'm pretty sure the libations gods would agree with me. 

So yes I'm a fan of Lumbrada! Stop reading and just get in here.

Every time I hit New Orleans I'm usually with a group that wants to hit Commander's Palace, so I've been here too many times to count, and though I've found the meals delightful, not really to me of traditional Cajun or New Orleans such as old standbys located in the French Quarter such Arnaud's, Antoine's, Two Sisters or Galatoir's; then with the others seemingly having a less pretentiously overdone flair and easier going ambiance about them. Also, with Commander's location out in the Garden District it doesn't, to me at least, have that Big Easy feeling about it.

I know, my review is permeated with nothing but subjectivity, but that is the way I feel about. As for food, no doubt about it, innovative as well as top quality, top notch all the way, but I could do without all the seemingly unnecessary fanciness of the place; too much akin to the swank of upper East Side New York than the understated elegance of style I think of as more traditional to New Orleans.

Will I be back? Of course I will, since although not my favorite, darn fine in every respect.

We enjoyed our meal here, starting with free bacon jalapeno fritters! Crunchy, not greasy, and delicious with the slightly spicy sauce. The lady behind the counter let us take our time making our selections and asked if we were local since they have a frequent diner card of some kind. The brightly colored building was well-air-conditioned (whew!) and 100% spotless.

My only complaint was the lack of salt on the homemade waffle chips as I think potatoes without NaCl is somehow wrong. Plus, chips taste a heck of a lot better with it! On the plus side, the chips were super crispy which is a good thing! It was easily solved with some salt and pepper from the shakers.

I enjoyed my Cuban sandwich which was flavorful, unique, crunchy and tasty. It was worth the visit to find this well-off-the-beaten path known-only-to-locals-and-yelpers spot! My wife's bowl-based-meal was based on black beans which were also under-seasoned so she was less happy with her meal.

Two of my friends lost a life dear to them, so I decided to send them a plant in memory of their beloved.

I researched florists in their area, and noted Scentaments has primarily good reviews. But I ultimately chose them because of their large variety of plants offered.

HeartLeaf Philodendrons are one of my favorite house plants, and I was elated to find Scentaments offers them! So I chose one for my friends since it is easy to care for with a little insight, and can last many years without much fuss.

A few hours after I placed the order, I received a text from my friends thanking me for the plant I sent. I was very impressed on how quickly it was delivered!

Unfortunately, I later learned they had received a Peace Lily instead of a HeartLeaf Philodendron. While the Peace Lily is the same price, and it looks absolutely beautiful from the picture I was shown, it is still NOT what I ordered for them. In fact, there was another florist I had been eying and their prices are lower, but they do not sell HeartLeaf Philodendrons. If I had known Scentaments was going to send whatever, I would've used the other florist and saved myself about $7.

Look, I have nothing against Peace Lilies -- in fact, I really like them a lot. But what if one of my friends is allergic to them? Or what if one of them had expressed to me long ago that they don't like Peace Lilies? 

My point is this...when you order something like a dish garden, it's a crap-shoot, right? You're not sure what you're going to get. But when you order something specific that not every florist in town has - like a HeartLeaf Philodendron - that's what you expect. At least, that's what I expect.

Scentaments isn't the first to do this, and sadly I know they won't be the last. It's just really disappointing in the forever gamble of Middle Tennessee florists. 

Maybe next time I'll buy my plant from a local nursery and have Uber deliver it for me. It will cost about the same in the end.

Without a doubt, this place is the most crowded and cramped location I've been to yet (Although they are apparently moving to a bigger location across the shopping center this spring). The aisles are narrow enough that if two people happen to walk down the same aisle, someone needs to squeeze by.

One thing this location does excel at is their jewelry selection; their oppertunity lies with their pricing. Rings at the register run $5, necklaces run $5 and up (which I'm sure is what most of them cost new in the store)

They don't have a lot of selection when it comes to shoes, although they do have them organized and grouped by size.

I love how this strip of a park has developed over the years. It's now a lush green space with a fountain where you often find children playing and dogs frolicing. 

Since many of the people who live in the area do not have a ton of yardspace, many make this their defacto front yard which is fun to observe and not crash (unless invited of course). 

Love that the trees are lush and beautiful right now despite the cold winter...or maybe because of it. Now I just wish some neighbor with a green thumb would plant some flower beds to enhance the beauty.

If you're in the mood for some good Cuban Food you may want to try this place out. During my visits pre-Covid19, I really enjoyed eating here. Friendly staff, and they are opened right now during these troubling times. You can place your order, pay online and they will bring it out to you.
Big cheesesteak for under $10.  No mushrooms.  Good cheesesteaks come from the grill but great cheesesteaks come from the heart.  This Cheesesteak need more heart.
Stopped in yesterday to grab an Italian, which is one of the better Italian subs around and my girl got the limited edition King's Hawaiian Pork & Slaw sammich!  OMG LOL

Came here with the boyfriend and his friends for a double date night.

Nikki and I tried the Pink Punk Cosmo, which is a very interesting cocktail that requires the bartender to pour the liquor concoction into a cosmo glass filled with cotton candy. Pretty darn awesome if you ask me!

Then we had our typical 3 for $12.99 dinners (with green bean fries, various entrees, and cheesecake) while his friends had fried shrimp and mashed potatoes.
