Luckily for us, his friend had a 20% off coupon for the table so it was a great deal cheaper than what it would have been (those drinks really add up!)

All in all, it was pretty good service and pretty good food, I'd stop by again if I was in the area.

I miss the Gap of days gone by. I use to be a true Gap addict.  Now, I just do not shop there as often as I use too. Many moons ago, Gap switched their house credit card over to a Gap Visa where you earn gift rewards for shopping in the store. The card has a good percentage rate, so I held on to it for large purchases. I recently got a rewards certificate to go Gap shopping. 

My recent shopping experience was some what disappointing. I found nothing in the clearance/sale section, so I moved on to the short sleeve sport shirts. I could always use a colorful Madras Plaid shirt for attending a summer cookout or Yelp Event. I found a couple that I liked and was ready to go until I tried them on. 

I've been dieting and have lost 30 lbs., but when I went to try a large on, it was too small. What? Even when I was fatter, I did not wear an extra-large. Size is a mental game, even if I liked the shirt, there is no way was I going to buy an extra-large.  So, I was back to browsing the store. 

My eyes immediately were drawn to the back corner where they had colorful socks and boxers/briefs displayed. I've been thinning out and redoing my sock inventory, so this was a win. I have to wear an uniform to work, so I love accessorizing with colorful socks. 

The service today was bare bones, I did not see a sales associate until I was at the cash wrap ready to check out. Again, I remember the days when they would be assisting, suggesting and working to build that sale. 

* Side note - I found a shirt at Tommy Bahamas and I got to buy a MEDIUM. Why can't the fashion industry use the same sizing standards and guidelines?

As a lover of pizza, I've wanted to try Clarksville for quite some time. It was Halloween night and we wrapped up trick or treating right across the street and decided to dine in. Clarksville is on the small side, but its a chill place. I wasn't expecting the pizzas to be in the $17 price point, or that it would take 45 minutes to receive food. For a 45 minute wait, the pizza was ok compared to all the pizza spots in West Philly. 

Clarksville is going for a lowkey gourmet pizza spot, but is lacking some finishing touches. The crust is good, but I didn't care for the actual texture. My daughter's pepperoni pizza was great, but I didn't care for the veggie pizza my wife ordered. It was loaded with too much of one veggie and not much variety. 

The manager gave us a donut hole inspired dessert dish with a caramel dip with coconut shavings and i was fantastic. I would def go again to ry a non-pizza dish on a less busy day.

We frequent the West Chester area and have been here a number of times and have also taken advantage of their take out.  I can't believe I haven't reviewed it yet.  
We were in town to see a show on St. Patrick's day and decided we wanted to come here with a party of 8.  They do have call ahead seating for parties larger than 5 so after the show let out I called us in and they told me an hour an a half.  We were already set to come so I put our name on the list.   We showed up maybe 15-20 minutes later and got our buzzer and I informed the host that we'd be flexible if there would be 2 tables next to each other that we didn't all need to sit at one table if it meant getting sat sooner.  He said he'd see what he could do. Within minutes he came to us with a table ready.  All together too!  Apparently there was a large party also waiting but they found happiness in the bar and said we could have their table!  YAHOO!  
For such a large party too our server was great.  We did one check but she was willing to split if needed and that was nice to know.  We ordered drinks and apps and our meals and everything came out in a timely manner.  I'm always amazed at the size of this menu.  It has literally everything you can think of from Italian to regular American dishes and everything I've tried has been tasty.  They pride themselves on making things from scratch and hardly using processed ingredients which for a large menu I'd think would be hard to do and execute well.  They somehow seem to be able to do it.  I got chicken parm on this visit and it was wonderful and plentiful!  They have really yummy bread too and I ordered some crinkle fries because I saw them being enjoyed at another table and I wanted to enjoy them too.  I know it doesn't go but they are shareable and they were so worth it!  On this visit we also got dessert.  I tried the canollis and they were fab!  Ron's is a must stop when in the area.  You really can't go wrong.

During my last visit to this GameStop, the store has grown to double the size, buying out whatever space was next to it. The selection was still pretty standard, no GameStop really seems to be superior over another. They all have the same newly released titles and most old used games look like garbage. I'm not really a fan of GameStop anymore these days and rather shop at Play N Trade

Very nice dog store with a very sweet owner. They have premium dog foods and treats, and the usual fun toys and all that you can imagine for your pet. Glad they have this nice store on Davis Island, home to a Tampa Dog beach and Dog park. All is good in Mocha's world.

This cafe is located inside the Dali museum.  You don't have to buy the ticket to eat at this cafe.  The place is very small and has limited seating so you do not wanna go when it is crowded.  

Their menu does not offer much variety however everything was great and not too expensive at all.  We got two kinds of muffins...both were good and I loved their Panini sandwich.  Definitely recommended to take a break from the museum viewing.

Friendly and fast servers, high quality food served in the perfect portion for the right price! Everything is so wonderful here I wish they would stay open later but they'd probably run out of all their ingredients before dinner time haha. The French toast is two thick pieces of bread dipped in custard, toasted on a pan, and complimented with berry compote. I highly suggest getting the 100% maple syrup for an additional 1.25 cause it's WORTH IT. It comes in a tiny resealable bottle if you have any leftover syrup to take home. 

Belgian waffle is indeed airy and fluffy as it's titled on the menu! Ask for it with the trifecta and it'll hit the spot. Don't be afraid to ask your eggs done how you like because they will cook it exactly as you want! They have a whole wheat toast topped with hierloom tomatoes, burrata, and sprouts. Super hearty, like everything else on their menu. Definitely pair your meal with the detox juice or day glow.

Their dumplings are dough-a-liciously yummy but their sushi is just okay.  The rolls are pretty small.  Very nice decor and I'm going to try their sushi buffet (Monday's) and will be back to update my review.

Love me some beer! Their refrigerated bottles! Their draft lists!  

Yeah, I was pretty much in beer heaven. 

An Evil Genius sampling event brought us in, the Goose Island Flights of Juliet, Madame Rose, Bourbon County Stout and Bourbon County Barleywine kept me hanging out at their full bar. If I wanted to anti-social, I could have spent a long time checking out that fridge. 

I'm not normally in this area, but I will certainly pay the visit next time I am.

An underwhelming experience given the five-star prices.  S&W tries to deliver the atmosphere you'd expect from a high end steak place.  The selection of premium cuts is impressive and they certainly know how to cook a steak.  Unfortunately, that seems to be the extent of S&W.  The sides aren't anything worth writing home about and the service is only in line with the prices.  We were given a private room for our group of about 10, so kudos for that I guess...

Clang, clang, clang went the trolley!  Oh wait, that was in St. Louis.  Here on the St. Charles Ave streetcar line, it's more like "Screech, screech, screech"as the car navigates turns or a sort of buzzer-like "EEEHHHH" when someone signals for a stop.  And the second car I was on had a peculiar whirring noise which made me think I was sitting on top an alien power source.

Noise issues aside (and who am I to judge, as anyone who's heard my stomach after I've had Tibetan food will tell you), this isn't a bad mode of transport.

If you're a tourist, it's a great deal for $1.25 a ride or $3 for a day pass.  Going through the Garden District and by the Zoo and Loyola, you get to see many beautiful buildings and homes.  The leisurely pace will calm you and help you jump out of the rat race, if only for a moment.

Overall, the times I rode it (admittedly prior to a Saints game) it was very crowded, although people were friendly, even as they stuck their asses in your face.  As others have said, sometimes you have to wait for a few to go by until you can squeeze on one.

I'd advise you to take a ride on this streetcar.

I stop in this restaurant from time to time.... If you like Puerto Rican food, this is one of the best places in the area... I mainly just go into the takeout side.... They have plenty of your favorite dishes to choose from.. roast pork, stew chicken and beef, tripe, chicarrones, ribs, epanadillas, stew goat, puplo salad.. the selections are great..They also serve fresh fruit drinks, and have decent desserts.... I stopped in today with my son, had a meal and he left with coconut cake... 
The appearance looks more like a corner store, you'll see people from all walks of life coming through to buy meals, and parking there is a challenge.. But the food is well worth it..
Friendly service and they do serve drinks in the restaurant... I'll go as far as calling this place a local gem since you can't find any Puerto Rican food outside of the Camden/Philly city limits....

If you are one of my Yelp friends you can see that everytime I go to Lakeside Mall I always park at Macy's.  And most likely in the same spot because I'm getting old and a creature of habit so I park in the same spot every single time no matter what store I need to go to.  It works for me, don't judge!

Anywho, the parking is plentiful which is great because this is the busiest mall in the greater NOLA area in my opinion.  Plus I get to walk through my favorite part of the department store, the purses and shoes!  Now I'm not really a department store shopping kind of gal.  If I know what I"m looking for then I refuse to pay retain unless there is a sale and will hunt something down at TJ Maxx, Marshall's, Stein Mart etc.  But if I get a gift card at Macy's then I will be more than happy to use it!  In fact for Christmas I received two gift cards here and treated myself to a rose gold Fossil watch with a large face.  The sales lady was kind enough take out the links so it fit my tiny wrist.  I have a penchant for huge watches which can be annoying bc I have such a small wrist. They have great customer service as well!  When I had to return something for store credit I had one sales lady who walked me from her spot all the way upstairs to where I needed to be.  I told her manager how awesome she was!

Another bonus is that over the Christmas holiday when stores were open ridiculously late, I found that Macy's was open later than any store in the mall which was awesome because this is where I park!  I have this fear of being trapped in the mall store and having to exit the store and circumvent the entire mall to get to my car walking aimlessly with my poor sense of direction in the dark! hehe...fortunately this never happens since I park at Macy's at the same spot and they're open late!

Ok, enough about Macy's.  Btw, I have been to the original Macy's in NYC and it is pretty mind boggling.  I consider myself quite versed in malls and stores and have been to the Mall of America in Minnesota and even the Mall in Asia (largest mall in asia) but trust me when I say the Macy's in NYC is in a class of it's own!  Makes me wish that Marshall Field's still existed in Chicago. *sigh*

Happy shopping!

I came here because I recently moved into the neighborhood  and remembered that it used to be a good value meal for the price. I  think that it has changed ownership several times since the last time that I ate here!   If what you are looking for is a classy atmosphere do not go here as it is pretty basic as far as furnishings go.                                                              The staff was quick to great me when I came in , and quick to take my order when I was ready! Excellent and friendly customer service!                 I ordered the super nachos to eat there and a large burrito to go.  The nachos were very good, the asked if I wanted everything on them. I did . They came on an oval plate , arranged to cover the plate. The ingredents were fairly evenly spread over the entire plate.The chips and all of the other ingredients seemed to be pretty fresh! I wish that the meat was just a little bit spicer! They were better than many more costly super nachos that I have had elsewhere!  ( Note to self, eat the center first , as it gets a bit soggy if you eat it last! )                                                                                  Now for the Burrito.  Large is HUGE ! I ate off of it three times! They asked if I wanted beans,rice,onion,etc. on it and I did. I like the way they make the burrito , because the ingredents are mixed and not in clumps , so that you get a little bit of everything in every bite!                                                  Great food Speedy Burrito!! :) I will be back ! :)  I was glad that it looked like you stayed pretty steady with customer turn over while I was there!
Great Food the heck with atmosphere! :)

This location of Petco has done a fantastic job of curbside pick-up outside the store.  You can place orders online and you call when you arrive for curbside pickup.  The online ordering system checks with current stock availably in real time and is very helpful.  Thank You Petco for adapting to these trying times for your customers.  You have moved up in customer service and support in my eyes!  You are now my first choice for Pet Food.

I was in Philly recently for one of a cousin's wedding. I was already traveling extensively before arriving in Philly and carrying a suit with me would have been a huge pain. Renting was the way to go and these guys were fantastic.

It was super easy to set up everything with them from out of state and pricing was fair. Just send them your measurements and they'll take care of you. It was super easy to work with them once there too. The suit worked out great and they let you leave it at your hotel (if in the area) for them to pick up. This was very convenient since I left on a Sunday when they were closed.

If ever needed again and in the area, I would definitely use these guys over mens warehouse any day.

Stopped in tonight because I was craving Italian. Mind you, this is a new place and we weren't sure what they had so...

Backdraughts is a definite highlight to Main Street, Tarpon Springs. Their Wood Fired pizza oven makes the place cozy, the big bar is a nice asset as the tv is tucked back behind the topper and not an eye sore to all the other patrons.   The tables are spacious and there's nice tables outside for those who want to dine Alfresco - you know, for the few days a year when the mosquitoes aren't out to carry you away and the temps are bareable. 

The service was Ok. A tad slow, but with only a few people inside it really wasn't bad. 

The food... OMG.  We started with the house cut waffle fries with parmesan & garlic seasoning, they were THE BOMB! Lots of good seasoning and very crispy.  As for the pizza, we tried the White Hibiscus pizza. WOW. This is how I want a white pizza served. It was HEAPED with spinach, the fresh ricotta in literal scoops, a lovely Basalmic drizzle .. all of it was luscious and absolutely decadent. 

We will be back.

If you like Absinthe, you'll love this place. Many choices. Fun place on the bourbon street. 

Tried Nouvelle Orleans, strong licorice/star anise and mint flavor. Pretty good.

This is a beautiful old hotel that preserves some of the history of early days of St. Pete. It was built in the days before air conditioning when folks only came down in the winter from the north.  The renovation make it a great place to stay year round now. A stunning location on the bayfront, and you can walk to all of downtown St. Petersburg. It is pricey, but worth it if you are splurging.

I've stopped at this Goodwill a couple times, most recently last Saturday and was pleased with what I found.  It's a small store located in a busy part of town and I am thankful they have their own parking lot.  Some furniture, a room full of clothes and a some displays of housewares, glassware, home electronics and decorative items.  It's worth stopping in to see if you find something you like, if nothing else for the convenience.

The cashier that helped me on Saturday was friendly and went out of their way to be helpful.

The associates here were friendly. The game was fun. The down side: It is outdoors so play as the weather permits. I think there were two courses, but I was just aimlessly following my friends so I wasn't paying attention to the options available. We chose the Louisiana Course; it was a pretty easy course to me with nothing too advance. I think the price was around $8. 

So visit the Sculpture Garden in the area as well. It has very creative and unique artwork. A very serene place to wind down from the excitement of putt putt. Lol.
Spacious, clean, good coffee selection, good customer service, nice menu, good selection of foods and other items.

As someone who relates closely to Ann, I couldn't be more proud of her, zesting up our streets.

Do I sometimes wish that Ann would sneak in a little hand-jive or soldier boy? Yeah (how amazing would that be?!). But do I love watching people imitating her hip swaying? Double yes.

In my book, any modern art is positive art, especially art that people are posting about and promoting our city with. Let's get more of it, shall we?

This is an alright pizza shop, but nothing special. I much prefer homey, inviting atmospheres, not cashiers who make me feel like I did something terribly, horribly wrong by handing them a credit card.

Considering that I often don't carry cash and would have to pay an extra $2 to withdrawal from their on site ATM, I don't anticipate a visit any time in the near future.

This is a great place for the cheap or unemployed -- I (along with all of my coworkers) was laid off last year so cheap was key for me during my weekends out.  Not only are the drinks cheap at CBGB, but they definitely don't cheap out on the amount of alcohol that they give you.  My friends and I always joke that they give you 98% booze and a splash of cranberry juice (or whatever you fancy).  

The decor is interesting, and I love all of the ants spray painted everywhere.  And if you don't like using the facilities with another lady staring back at you on the other toilet seat (facing your toilet), I advise you employ one of your friends as door guardian while you're in there.  Have fun at CB's!!!

This is a lovely photo gallery located right in the heart of Jackson Square.

The work of Louis Sahuc is featured throughout the gallery, Louis has been a photographer since 1972, and here you can buy originals and prints of his work in all sizes. His lovely art varies from pictures of New Orleans during a hard rainstorm, to St. Louis Cathedral in the fog and the people of New Orleans.

What I like about Louis Sahuc's work is that it isn't typical New Orleans photography. Yes, there are pictures of the architecture of the city, but his work seems to contain more heart than some of the other work I've seen. I feel like his pictures are meant not only to appeal to tourists, but to find homes with locals as well.

If you are in the area, be sure to stop in and check it out.

I heart EVERYTHING about this Starbucks. From the location (perfect for lookey-lous) to the friendly staff to the quick drink processing - to the busyness to the hustle & bustle of it all. 

They handle the load with finesse, grace & class. Due to the location of this Starbucks, I'm surprised it's not a 24-hr store, or is it??? I'm sure in NYC there's a 24-hr starbucks or even Cali. Anywho, I digress; but yeah back to this location...

My hope is that once you make it here to this location, that you're not dismayed by the parking situation. It can be a bit overwhelming, but the treats that await you inside promise not to disappoint. 

#WindowseatsaretheBEST

If you're in from out of town, and you can find your way to Central West End, this is a good place for dinner or to finish your evening, maybe after a casual dinner at Llywelyn's or a nice dinner at Bar Italia.  If you're in luck, there will be some live music as there was for me a couple of years ago when I ducked in here during a business trip after dinner out.  Dark in the bar, but white tablecloths in the dining room.  Great steaks I've heard, but I've only been here for drinks and to finish my night.

There are good and bad to this hotel, I am going to give you the run down of this place.

PROS:
Infused water at the front desk.
You can touch the comforter, because this is the first hotel that I have been in that they actually use duvet covers and so these actually get washed. 5 STARS FOR THAT ALONE!!!! There are no mystery involved on how long has the comforter not been washed.
Close to everything and away from the craziness.
Right across the street from John Besh's Luke restaurant.
On a street that doesn't smell.
Big sink area, so you can put out your toiletries without any issues.
Rooftop pool
Offers a nice gym area and it's not lame.

CONS:
Infused water dispenser is super slow.
They don't offer umbrellas here for their guests.
They aren't consistent with replenishing the toiletries or towels.

I would stay here again, since other hotels I have seen has really small sink area or no sink area at all.

Will update review after I pick up the car.
Drove mby and saw this in my corporate parking lot.

Expensive ($17 for exterior, $14 for interior only, $27 for both) compared to my drive through place.

We shall see.

Very courteous guys running the show.

This is a pretty awesome idea but for those of you familiar with the Santa Monica Area you will get me when I say it reminds me of that little place with the rice balls with ahi tuna and curries stuffed in them. It's sushi roll burritos though with the stuff you usually get in a sushi roll.  I got the spicy yellowtail and it was so good and spicy but I think eating just half of it made me sleepy but I also had the miso soup.  It literally is a burrito in replacement with rice.  It was so good though and a variety of fish options as well as chicken.  I'm wondering if you can order it without the rice and just the sushi paper- that would be ideal.   It appears that you can make it however you want it, I went with  the spicy yellowtail option they had.  

Parking is easy and it's away from the crowded part of State Street in fact it's way up there.  The bowls look good in here too, I would probably do an Ahi Tuna bowl next time.

Ahh sweet review #700, it's only fitting that I review the spiritual heart of my city for this auspicious occasion.

St. Louis Cathedral is one of the most photographed buildings in New Orleans (along with the Bourbon Street sign) which is sort of perfect as it shows the dichotomy of our city.  We know how to have a party and yet we know the importance of spirituality (and repentance).  Whenever I'm in the area, I stop in for a moment or two and offer a prayer to my two very Roman Catholic grandmothers and light candles in their honor.  My Granny was convinced that a candle at the cathedral carried more weight than a candle from another church.

The church is a beautiful example of early architecture and it definitely deserves a tour and a donation!  But remember it is still a functioning church, so if you are visiting be respectful of those who are there to pray.  Check out the gift shop while you're there.

Great coffee shop in the East End. Loved the decor and the feel of the place. Had a really nice leather couch and great art on the walls. Staff was super friendly and my chai on the rocks was just the refreshing caffeine boost I needed on a hot day. It looked like they had a great food menu, too. Would definitely recommend if you need a comfortable place to get some work done.

I'm not a vegan, but this food looked really good, so we decided to stop by while we were at the food hall. 

We got a DFC bowl. It was pretty good for being vegan, but I was hoping not to have to add that qualifier. The chicken was my favorite part. I wasn't super impressed by the mac & cheese and mashed potatoes. 

If you're not a vegan, it's not bad but I wouldn't say it's a must try.

I didn't feel that this place lived up to the hype.  The food was good but not amazing.  We shared the pork belly buns (um, like ribs chopped and stuffed into plain bao) and peruvian ceviche (this was the highlight of the meal - perfectly fresh, creamy, and accented with sweet potato) for the appetizer course.  I got the parihuela, which I suppose is the Latin version of bouilliabaise (w/saffron,, of course).  It was decent but a tad on the bland side.  I sampled the smoked sirloin, which was better, with a delicious miso butter.  It was also generously sized.  The lychee sangria added a nice touch to the meal.  Overall, a decent experience but nothing spectacular.

This is Tampa own nice sandwich store. This is the area they generate a lot crowd during the lunch hour. It is pack most of the time. The sandwich is famous in this area. 

We have the Cuban Sandwich with hot press. We order all inclusive sandwich fully loaded. The sandwich is very thick nice cheese. The ham is very juicy. The mojo pork just a few slice in the center. The pork need to be more mojo marinated with better strong taste. Overall, this is a big sandwich for a hungry person.

We're not from Tucson and unfortunately we didn't realize that Feast changes their menu monthly or we would've definitely stopped in for dinner! The main reason for why we didn't was because it is a smaller menu - makes sense now.

Instead, we had seen some amazing photos of bread pudding so we thought we'd get that after dining elsewhere. The host was very gracious in letting us know upon our arrival that they did not have bread pudding at this time but handed us a their current dessert menu to browse.

It was late, almost close to closing time so we thought we'd just get the Dark Chocolate Truffle Cookies to go. They asked us a couple of times if we were sure and offered to set up a table for us, but we declined. I'll say that the cookies were absolutely delicious & if they're anything like the rest of the food, we would've really enjoyed our meals!

I'm going to keep this on my list so we can try it out in the future when we return!

I liked this place a lot and I don't even like Korean food. Expensive AF tho. 

Visited on 8-14-18 at 5:30PM. This place is kinda hidden behind the new Verizon store on Brandon Blvd between Lakeview and Kings. It looks like they're trying really hard to make it look nice but just dont have much of a budget. They've painted the interior black but have cheaply re-upholstered brown chairs, twinkle lights, Ikea fixtures... cheaply done but they're trying. 

 Service from Randy was friendly, efficient, and knowledgable. $55.70 got us one bottle of beer, one sushi roll, and two entrees. My husband wanted to get the AYCE bbq but everybody at the table has to do it (boo!).

The banchan here is off the hook yummy. We were brought fish cakes, kimchi, cucumbers, radish, bean sprouts, and spinach. I could have happily ordered another of each one because they were fresh and tasty. 

We started out with the $6.95 yaki mandoo which was advertised as fried vegetable dumplings. The dumplings were very large and perfectly fried. The filling looked like cabbage, carrots, and some sort of meat. I'm not a strict vegetarian so it didn't bother me but if you are, beware of the sneaky meat. 

I had the $14.95 japchae noodles. It was sweet potato starch noodles (clear glass noodles) stir fried with veggies. It had small bits of meat, onions, carrots, bok choy, spinach, and sesame seeds. The dish was an enormous portion and served piping hot. All the ingredients tasted light and fresh. The noodles were slightly sweet and cooked perfectly. I enjoyed it a lot and had enough leftovers for two more meals. 

Not a bad meal but for the price I wouldn't go back.

WOW. Absolutely amazing freakin brunch, I don't even know where to begin. The place is covered in Dr. Bob's artwork, service was laid back and extremely friendly- Robert was our waiter and he was great. He even gave us some extra shrimp to go with our fried green tomatoes because we had more people than we did shrimp- and they were big, fresh suckers. This place does decadence right.

For a table of five we ordered one of every lunch appetizer and double praline bacon. I have no words for how amazing the bacon is. Sweet and salty and perfect. Put a strip in your bloody mary. Boudin balls and fried green tomatoes were both winners. I tried fried chicken livers for the first time and while they haven't won me over yet, the pepper jelly they came with was great. The only real miss were the fried oysters with blue cheese; the oysters themselves were perfect but I don't think the cheese went well with them.

The fried catfish was so tender that is practically fell apart before even making it to your mouth. I ordered a special consisting of fried eggplant topped with poached eggs that was delicious. But the star of the show was the french toast burrito. I NEED this in NY, it's just not fair. They take a tortilla, dip it in the french toast egg wash, cover with cinnamon, fry it up, and stuff it with eggs, sausage, and that life changing praline bacon. Cover the enormous thing with maple syrup and powdered sugar. I'm not religious but I felt blessed just to have tasted it.

June 18, 2011 Saturday - lunch 1 PM
2 adults, 1 teenager, 1 child

Atmosphere - 4 stars
Food - 5 stars
Service - 4 stars

Total - 4 stars

Atmosphere - Small crowded seating area, a table for 4 was two pushed together 2 person tables.

Food
Appetizer - none.  

Main Course - I went with a small burger (2.5 oz. patty) with cheese with a side of fat fries.  Burger would be comparable to In-N-Out burgers, but no animal style here.  But loved the sweet relish on the burger, never tried that before.  Next time I think I will go with egg on it.  I am craving that as I am writing this.

Dessert - none ordered.

Service - One of the other burgers was ordered without tomatoes.   I verified the receipt that matched, but it still came with two large ones

Not worth my time for slow service, high prices and lame rolls

Packed at lunch so we took a high top in the "bar" area. They were quick to take the order and deliver but forgot about us after that. Sat with a table full of empty plates for over 8 minutes before flagging someone down for the check.

Rolls were fat with rice and poorly rolled. Not much fish especially in the Unagi roll. We did like the spicy kick in the 911 roll. The menu is packed with non sushi so that's a plus but it's obvious to our orders they don't pay much attention to anything in the raw. The $23 sashimi salad was not worth it. Small fish cuts and overpowered with dressing. No thank you.

The four of us were not impressed with much about Itsuki and with the other options in the SB area, I will not be coming bak here for lunch any time soon. At least, not for sushi.

Our last visit, Oct 13, was below a one star. The experience was so horrible in the first five minutes that we had to walk out of there. Service wasn't there. Bathroom was nasty. Just a bad vibe all around. This ~was~ one of my favorite places. I'm going to give a three star for previous experience...

It took me years to finally find a spot I felt comfortable in. I loved the gumbo and the boils. We loved it so much one trip that we came twice in the same day. 

Maybe we had a bad day our last visit or maybe all my favorites are just not favorites anymore. You know it's so hard to pick and choose from the billion restaurants in the area. I'm really sad that I might just have to take this one off my list.

It has been a while since I have been in Best Buy and Best Buy seems to be selling everything now.

We came here because we were looking for an X Box headset thing, but I ended up getting distracted by all of the other amazing tech goodies in this place. Big fancy hi def tvs, fit bits, hi tech refrigerators- it's all here. I know I must sound like a total newb, but I am so ignorant when it comes to the latest technology. The most technologically advanced thing I own is an iPod and a flat screen tv, so seeing 3D viewers for smart phones is pretty cool. And did you know you can get a watch that you can link to your phone to answer calls? Whoooooa. I don't need to be that connected to my phone, but Best Buy has it if you're looking for it.

Some of the prices for some things are a little high, so wait for a sale if you are trying to pinch pennies. We found what we were looking for and the staff was friendly when we were checking out.

I've flown in and out of Tampa four times in the last year - each time has been as pleasant as one could hope for.

- Rental Car drop off both times I had a rental car was easy - not a long walk to the terminal.

- Check in a the United Counter has always been fairly quick - I've never experienced a long line.

- Lots of shopping/food options in the Main Terminal.

- Free Wifi throughout the Airport!

- Short ride to Terminal E.

- Never a long line to get through Security.

- Limited but yummy food options in Terminal E.

The one thing they could do better is provide more electrical outlets to plug into - they are at a premium - folks are jockeying for position to find a place to plug in. This is in stark contrast to the Main Terminal - which has tons of places to plug in.

Why is there always a bum begging for money and homeless folks living in their truck who hit me up for a hand out in the parking?

A Walmart is a Walmart.  I think they somehow clone the same characters and implant them at every Walmart.

9/21/2018:  I. REALLY. WANTED. TO. BUY. SOMETHING . . . ANYTHING. AT. GAP. OUTLET . . . No matter how the store manager and the retail associates made the rack and shelving displays presentable, marketable, the clothing sold here was like TIRED 2017, 2016, 2015, and eons of old, overstock, unsold inventory.  Meh~I kept perusing upon racks, shelving, and displays recognizing inventory I saw being sold even at believe it or not, ROSS!

WOT~NO WAY!  YES, WAY, WAY, WAY OLD:  Long time forgotten, unsold clothing from West, North, South, and East Gap Outlet's retail stores OLD INVENTORY were being sold, liquidated at this location; however,  sadly and shockingly, the price points didn't trickle down to truly saving customers' buying power purchasing liquidated, unsold, old inventory, i.e., LOW stockturn equals poor, sales inventory performance!

Truly an egregious disappointment visiting this Gap Outlet:  I shall not return.

I'm not big on the Golden Arches Supper Club these days.  In fact, I am only willing to have an occasional McBreakfast.  I'm pretty well over the rest of their menu.

That said, I stop here from time to time while on the way to work to get an Egg McMuffin.  The sandwich was good but what prompted me to write this review is the overall cleanliness of this store.  There weren't that many customers in the place even though the drive thru line was almost around the building.  Those employees who were not directly involved in the drive thru operation or cooking were out cleaning tables, picking up trays, etc.  You just don't see that enough in fast food and/or quick service restaurants these days...

Mmmmm... Irish Coffee and Rum Raisin... I would be willing to sacrifice all reasonable eating habits for these two flavors. They have so many other awesome flavors to try, but it's so hard for me to peel away from these ones every time I come here. 

I don't know if it's just me, though, but Bassetts ice cream seems a bit watery. Most ice cream has no chance to melt before I devour it, but this ice cream always liquefies before I can finish it, even as I stand in the frigid air of the Reading Terminal Market.

D'Angelo's Bakery was a perfect breakfast spot on the last morning of our mini-break in Santa Barbara. Good food, great service, delicious coffee, and plenty of gorgeous baked goods to take home with us as presents for friends and treats for later on. I had the brioche french toast with poached egg which is definitely some of the best french toast I've ever had. My husband had the Eggs Rose which was highly recommended by other Yelpers and did not disappoint. Major props for the mini pretzel baguettes they sold inside-- I fell in love!
Note: the extra star on this review is for the young woman working behind the counter in the bakery on Mondays. She was the nicest person ever. She really blew me away with her cheerfulness and sweet attitude.

I live right down the street, yet haven't been in in a long time. 

During covid they offered to go orders. But now are open for inside and patio dining. A beautiful sunny May day, we chose the patio. It has only three tables. Service was quick with waters and menus. Food seemed to take only 10 minutes. We ordered three sandwiches- a burger, a turkey sandwich and a veggie sandwich. Each came with a choice of a side. My turkey on a toasted croissant was delicious. Fresh and great flavors. The onion rings were huge. 

Inside, when fully running again, offers table and bar seating. The bar has slots. Easy large parking lot out front, as the grill is in an older strip mall. 

Great diner style food. They serve breakfast through dinner at affordable prices.

Do you want to relax and have a good time with friends? If so, this is the place to visit for Happy Hour or a week-end afternoon. UCBC has created a huge beer hall in The Grove neighborhood, that will having you escaping daily stress and finding your "groove" again. 

A couple of friends meet here to support a friend who just lost a beloved dog. UCBC is a dog friendly establishment and Elke had been numerous times, so we thought it was an appropriate place to celebrate her life. Also, we had her K-9 sister Ms. Bunny with us. 

We enjoyed four rounds of different beers, we had a rule that you could not repeat a beer. After all, when you are at a brewery, so you should experience as many  different beers as you can. We also enjoyed a variety of snacks/appetizers from their kitchen. Items we enjoyed; Pommes Frites, Deviled Eggs, Currywurst and Pork Rinds. After beer and savory treats, we treated ourselves to their sweets; Liege Waffles and Berliners. I'd recommend all of the treats, except the Pork Rinds. We all found them to be bland. 
 
I give a thumb ups to all the beers I tried; On The Wings of Armageddon, Winged Nut (personal favorite), Fantasyland and Geiles. I would have posted pictures, but all beers look alike when photographed. 

As a reminder, this is a dog friendly brewery and a great place to bring your K-9 to enjoy a beer. 

When: July 1, 2015
Why: Gathering of friends

You guys know what to expect at Panera. This one is clean, has all the things I need and in the right places and provides an acceptable quick meal when necessary. 

When I ordered my bagel the other day, I asked for it to be toasted. The girl at the counter even said, "you wanted it toasted, right?" So that was two confirmations that I wanted that bagel toasted. Guess what wasn't toasted? 

The moral of this story is, don't go asking for anything above and beyond the status quo at this Panera, and you should be satisfied.

We stopped here while we were in Pennsville for lunch, and this is a good option for some quick ice cream off the Turnpike.

In general, I like to support local businesses, and so when we passed the Pennsville Custard Stand, we definitely wanted to try it out. They had a lot of different flavors and types, so it was a bit overwhelming at first.  We opted for their freshly-made ice cream, and were not disappointed. The coconut was my favorite.

Overall, Pennsville Custard Stand is a quick and easy stop if you're driving from DC to New York. I would recommend it, especially if you have to get gas, which is literally a quarter of a mile down the road.

[Preface] 
Anyone who has been watching the whole Yelp photos conversation will appreciate the fact that I made the decision to go to Santa Fe this evening because it was the first business I found in the mobile app that didn't have a photo uploaded. John L will appreciate the fact that I uploaded two dark, blurry, almost useless photos. 

[Background]
Over the course of the last several years, the building that now exists as Santa Fe was a succession of different restaurants -- it was [insert name I'm forgetting], then Nonna Mia's (I think), then Santa Fe. My memory fails me with regard to the details (clearly), but the point is there were a bunch of different businesses in this location, and Santa Fe was the only one that stuck since I've been paying attention. 

[Rumors/Hearsay]
In any event, the first feedback I heard from other people who'd been to Santa Fe was entirely negative. (I won't repeat some of the more colorful statements, entertaining as they may have been; suffice it to say that the food was allegedly not good.) Therefore, I fully expected to see another restaurant take its place rather quickly, and was puzzled when this did not happen. Eventually, I came up with the theory that they *must* have kickass margaritas, because if the food is as bad as I'd heard it was, then people keep going back because they have an awesome time, love the margaritas, and drink so many they either don't care or can't remember whether or not the food was any good. 

[Personal Experience]
Well, I finally had a chance to experience Santa Fe firsthand, and here is what I have to report: 

-It's a bustling place, and can get kind of loud if you sit inside, because people clearly come here and have fun (again, I suspect it's the margaritas). 

-In all the times I've been to this building in its various incarnations, I've never seen it so crowded and noisy (in a good way). 

-There's an amazing, huge, gorgeous outdoor seating area with ceiling fans, tiki torches and (tonight, at least) live music. There was a wait to get a table outside. 

-The food is pretty standard Mexican fare. I had nachos, which were pretty much indistinguishable from nachos I've had elsewhere. Everyone I was with enjoyed their food, so whatever people were complaining about years ago is no longer valid (if, of course, it ever was).

-The service was very friendly and helpful, but a tad slow. (They were busy, though, and everybody was running around doing stuff. It's understandable.)

-We were greeted by a woman who, I suspect, is one of the owners. When we left, the man who I assume is her husband bid us farewell with a sincere thank you and enthusiastic handshake. It's a nice touch.

-They probably have excellent margaritas, but I can't say for sure because I (unfortunately) didn't have one. 

[Conclusion]
Overall, it's a great place, and the only reason I'm giving three stars instead of four is because I need to go back and confirm they do indeed have incredible margaritas, at which point I'll update my review accordingly. 

[Next Steps]
I'm going back soon for a pitcher (or two) of Margaritas.

[Recommendation]
My advice: Go. Soon. Before it gets too cold to enjoy eating and drinking outside. 

[Post-Script]
This place totally should've been included in the "Yelping Alfresco" edition of the New Orleans Weekly Yelp. It shall appear in round two, should there ever be a round two.

I am never in the area of where Sunshine Thrift Stores was located. I just happened to be this past Sunday.  The place is pretty organized for a thrift store. They have their bins of specific stuff all in the same area. You go through the clothes and some are really good prices, some are really pricey. You just have to know which ones to pick, and what price you want to spend. I notice they have orange and yellow tags on that day that are 1/2 off. That's an added price saver there. I would definitely be back if I am in the area.

Your holding a winning ticket from the Sportsbook next door.  Your about to cash in and you don't have a care in the world about your eating plan and you got a plenty of Peppermil comp dollars and your ready to stuff your faces with no regrets!  

This NY Style "sports deli" has got you covered with plenty of big portions and big meatballs.  I hadn't eaten a meatball sandwich in a hot minute so we ordered......

The Wiseguy Meatball Sandwich with your choice of bread all baked in-house.  No GF options were available in case you request that.  I highly recommend asking for extra in house made marinara sauce for this sandwich.  It needs it!  The jalapeño cheese roll is an OK choice but when you stack it up with those big meatballs the regular white roll holds up much better!  We tried both rolls.  

The cheesytastic pepperoni baguette pizza has that delicious marinara sauce.  It's the sauce.  Definitely not a traditional NY Style pie but you'll be full for at least a couple hours.  

Save room in your gut for later!  Plenty of sweets as well like their "personal size" pecan or banana cream pies.  They both sell out quick so you can request the friendly staff to set aside something for you to buy when your ready to bail. 

A 4 star deli for your belly for anyone looking to drown their sorrows or savor their victories!  Do it now and ask for forgiveness later.  Warning be aware of those hangry salty customers on the weekend.

Its dark and doesn't seem safe. There are lots of homeless people and hustlers.  And its confusing with limited signs  :( But its the closest station to Rittenhouse square and in Center City.  Overall, I'm glad its there, but it could definitely improve a lot.

WORST HAPPY HOUR our club has been to. First the $3 house margarita has little taste and even less kick. Secondly the place smells like a cigarette smoker's old sock. My one friend from Texas sat for 5 minutes looking at other people's plates and then decided to try...

nothing.

Definitely check this winery out if in the area. They offer wine tastings every half hour I believe daily. We tried key lime, blackberry, and few others. Since it was Valentine's Day weekend they had mixed up a few concoctions that were delicious.

Our wine tasting guide was super nice and friendly. They do ship wines if you spend over $125 to most states. We didn't buy enough so we plan to throw it in our luggage. 

You can get to go drinks or sit around and enjoy some in their lounge area. They have small bites and slushees too.

Cooter's is a stop on the family tour of NOLA.  Why?  Because it's the location where my parents got engaged.  Of course, it wasn't Cooter Brown's in 1959/60.  But it was a "pub style restaurant" or maybe my Mom just doesn't want to admit she got engaged in a bar.

I miss the shabby haphazard Cooter's of the 80s. But it's reincarnation as a sports bar has its merits.  Another bar that kept me fed post-K.  And for that alone they get 4 stars.

Honestly the best Italian restaurant in Tampa bay!!!
Gotta try their homemaid raviolis...it's a killer.  
Great service and great food.   
The only thing is it's pricy....One appetizer and two ravioli dishes came out $75 with tip.

Westbound and down across western Indiana on Interstate 74 (I-74) west this afternoon - I'd missed breakfast due to some unforeseen delays - and now it was past lunch time - I knew I'd be pulling into some small, forsaken burg for lunch at some point.

Then I saw it - the Interstate signs that depict which food joints are at the next exit - all of the usual fast food suspects were listed - but also - White Castle!! I knew that I must visit the Castle! I exited I-74 into a small town named "Brownsburg."

It was just after 3:00 pm when I walked in - a couple of other folks were in line in front of me. I ordered one double bacon cheeseburger, one double jalapeno burger, and one fish w/ cheese and an order of Onion chips, and a caffeine-free Diet Coke.

When I got my food, I was a little disappointed, the sandwiches - all three of them were lukewarm - like they had been sitting out. I was expecting something hotter and fresher tasting. The Onion chips were fresh and hot - and nice and crisp. The Coke was icy and refreshing.

Somewhat disappointing given that I don't get to experience White Castle that often - when I do - I want it to be a phenomenal fast food experience!

Have been to Lola twice in the past week and I'm officially a fan! The first time I came here, it was just for drinks. They have an extensive cocktail menu, plus some pretty tasty Pinot Noir for less than $10 a glass. Done! 

Came back yesterday for a weekday brunch with a gal pal and we enjoyed a gluttonous meal of mimosas, crepes, pommes frites and cheesecake. We were both moaning and groaning with satisfaction throughout the meal. Seriously, how could anyone NOT like that on a Thursday before noon?

Come here for lunch or a late night snack and you won't be disappointed! Can't wait to go back soon!

My very first experience at La Locanda del Ghiottone was on a first date, almost a year ago.  The guy I went out with had dined there several times and the owner and staff welcomed him with open arms.  In fact, they showed us to the "engagement table," where they claimed many first dates occurred in which the couple later got engaged.  Mmm-hmm.  Probably one of the more awkward moments of the date...

Luckily, the food (and wine that I was now guzzling at warp-speed) made up for any weirdness.  My date asked if I liked mushrooms, and when I said no, he insisted on ordering the mushroom appetizer anyway and promised I would like it.  Ooohkay.  

I had to hand it to the guy, the "crepe con funghi" was good.  Points.  He also recommended the homemade gnocchi, which I believe is a special and made from cheese instead of potatoes.  Of course, being the stubborn girl that I am, I went for the ravioli instead.  Which were good, but not as good as the gnocchi, which I stole from my dining companion's plate at every opportunity.    

The tiramisu that was given to us "on the house" was to-die.  

There was a love connection made that night, only it wasn't with my date.  But I will be forever grateful to him for introducing me to this charming little Italian BYO.  Swoon.

Man. It's been a LONG time since I have been to PM! So when my friend and I needed a stop for our Friday night Restaurant Week adventure, we decided to enjoy the 3 course meal for $20.13 offered here!

We were able to grab a table a little after 6pm and ordered the white and red sangria. YUM. Very tasty and a healthy portion for sure! Great start. We decided to have the shrimp spring rolls and moo shu quesadilla to start and wow, they did not disappoint! I loved the sauces on the side and we knew we were off to a solid start! 

For entrees we decided on the green curry with chicken and the salmon teriyaki with veggies. I ordered my green curry spicy, and it was even though the heat kinda floated to the bottom of the bowl. I have to admit I didn't love the broth, it seemed a bit watered down (maybe from all the restaurant week orders?) and I was let down. The salmon was good, and I definitely grabbed more than one bite from my friend's plate.

For dessert I ordered the tempura brownie bite with caramel and my friend the coconut sticky rice with mango. Both were good but not great.  Probably wouldn't order it off the menu again. 

I always say that your appetizers shouldn't outshine the main course. I feel it should be a delicious and amazing build up to the grand finale that is your main dish. In this case, I was wishing I could have done a re-do of the appetizers.  

What brought it down to 3 stars is that they rushed us out the door. I HATE when I'm still working on a course and the next one is brought out to me. Give me a minute or two please! And they weren't completely slammed or anything when we were here. 

Overall, not bad. I'd like to come back and have a refresher on the sushi!

When in the Santa Barbara area, take a detour off the 154 onto Stagecoach Rd to find this unexpected, somewhat hole-in-the-wall, in the middle-of-nowhere, roadside bar and food joint.   Rickety looking old wooden buildings, ivy taking over in spots, large logs for seating outside, some picnic type tables, and benches too; tables and stools inside.  Dusty during summer, damp in the winter.

We had first passed by during a wine tour.  After the tour, we immediately made our way back to indulge in this experience.  The bar/tavern is adjacent to the restaurant.  We had just had lunch on the wine tour; our time was spent at the tavern.  The smell from the bbq wofted throughout. Live music outside and a line at the bar(s) inside.  Cold beer, happy people, all walks of life.  People all about with people leaving and arriving at a steady pace.  This is a place to return when in the area again. 

It's not hard to find, just awkward.  Expect windy roads and a grand curve and at the apex is Cold Spring Tavern.  Parking sucks, let's be honest.  If arriving by car, you'll need to find off pavement parking along the road; no sidewalk; precarious walking up the road with traffic both directions.  On motorcycle, no problem, pull right in, usually.  

As soon as I find my pics, I'll post.

My husband and I were in Reno last weekend celebrating our wedding anniversary and we originally planned on booking massages at our hotel spa -- that is, until we saw the prices.  So we looked around for alternatives and came up with Healing Wizdom.  For the same price as a half hour massage at our hotel spa, we got a full hour here.  Plus 5% off for booking together  :)

It was a little hard to find, but the GPS got us there and after a bit of poking around, we found it inside the little "mall".

The receptionist is very friendly and the place is a little on the hippie side but still cozy and inviting.  We didn't have to wait around before being brought in to our treatment rooms.  My masseuse was Matt and he did a terrific job.  He was very courteous, attentive, and thorough.  Probably one of the best massages I've ever gotten, actually.  He also integrated some hot stones into the routine which I've never had before -- it was a very nice touch.  

The treatment rooms are relaxing, although not very soundproof -- I could hear people in the front office talking the whole time.  But it wasn't really bothersome.

After the massage, we were given some really good herbal tea that tasted like apples & cinnamon.  After a weekend of breathing smoky casino air, it was pretty soothing on my poor throat.

The only thing I found the place lacking was a shower facility -- after a massage, the last thing you want to do is put your clothes back on when you're all greasy!  Ha ha I know, I know....first world problems, right?  So yeah.  They still get 5 stars.  Next time we're in Reno, we will definitely make another appointment.

I would go here every week if I could. I have considered getting a yearly pass multiple times but just don't think I have enough time to get there as much as I want to! The atmosphere is so casual and fun and it is the perfect stress reliever. The music is energetic and there are always a lot of people (at all different talent levels) climbing. 

The people here are just really cool. You will meet some really unique people if you come here often enough. There are also always crazy talented people that are fun to watch when you get tired of climbing yourself. 

This is a great place to bring friends, a date, a date, or people new to town!

Allow me to add to the pile of praise for this lovely establishment. As soon as I heard that a fancy grilled cheese restaurant was opening in New Orleans, I was immediately on board. As soon as I got as taste of the deliciousness that is The Big Cheezy, I knew that this would have to be my 1100th review.

It took me forever to get here and when I finally did it was on a Thursday at about 7. I was thrilled that there was no one else here, so we were able to order quickly with zero wait. I had looked over the menu before I came, so I knew exactly what I wanted. The Flying Dutchman was in my future. With ingredients like gouda, turkey and bacon, it seemed like a no brainer. My dining companion wasn't so sure, but after a few minutes he decided to get the Crazy Old Goat, which was packed with goat cheese, monterey jack, bacon, grilled peppers and red pepper jelly. That sounded pretty amazing as well. We also got some waffle fries to munch on the side.

Because we are smart, we decided that we would split our sandwiches so we both got to taste both. We sat down and we didn't have to wait long at all because there was literally no one else in the place. As soon as the sandwiches came out I was SO excited. Gooey cheese was oozing our of the sides of both of these sandwiches. I could tell that the bread had been buttered (the only way to do it) and the sandwiches looked simple but delicious.

First I bit into my Flying Dutchman. There was so much cheese on this thing and it was melted perfectly. The cheese mixed with the turkey and the bacon to create and amazing and delectable experience. After I finished my half, I couldn't wait to switch. The Crazy Old Goat was so different! I loved how the cheese and the bacon made for a savory experience, the peppers added a little kick and the red pepper jelly added a bit of spicy sweetness. There was a lot happening on this thing and I loved every bit of it.

Both sandwiches that I tried were incredible and I can't wait to go back and try some more of The Big Cheezy menu. I would definitely suggest going later in the day, if you are like me and have no time for a line.

The previous reviewer, Julie, is absolutely correct.  This is your basic everyday Starbucks and that's not a bad thing.  It's clean and neat and has generally competent baristas.  It is a small one so it has a tiny variety of travel mugs and other retail stuff.  There are also very few tables.  This is a three star kind of place for me.

We finally got an influx of bubble tea houses in this city and Highway is one of the priciest in the area.  Fortunately, the price also made up for the high quality.  I ordered sea salt oolong tea with mango bubbles.  They have about a dozen different bubbles, jellies, puddings to choose from.  The flavored popping bubbles encased fruit juice and weren't like the usual chewy tapioca balls.  The sea salt tea is their specialty and I have not seen it else where.  The tea is topped with fresh whipped cream that is slightly salty to contrast to the lightly sweetened tea and garnished with a dash of matcha.  I will go lighter on the cream next time.  There is no cloyingly sweet syrup saturated with bright colors here, which is why their menu seems limited.

Modesto is out of place in the mainly Italian influenced "Hill Neighborhood," but this rustic jeans to semi-dressy hangout has a fresh seasonal selection of spanish inspired tapas and killer mojitos!  

It is one of my favorite tapas restaurants in St. Louis.  And ordering tapas style is a great dining experience!

If you're by yourself or with one person, I highly recommend eating at the bar.  The barstaff have been there a long time.  They give the best service and if you've been there a few times, they usually remember what you drink.

They have unbelievable food deals in the bar during happy hour, all night on Tuesdays and late night on Wednesdays.  These deals are not usually available in the restaurant.

As with most tapas restaurants it is recommended that you order one or two things at a time so you get a feel for what you're ordering.  It will come out hot and fast.  So, no worries about waiting for food at Modesto!

Short Story: 4 star milkshakes with a 2 star atmosphere. Not worth the wait. 

Long story: Rolling in the Cookie Dough Shake was fantastic. Was it worth $15? No. I enjoyed it. Here's what threw me: if you're a premium priced milkshake bar, you'd think there would a great vibe and service. This was the saddest ice cream shop I've ever been to. 30% of the tables weren't bussed for the 30 minutes we were there.

All the king cake! Looking for beaucop king cakes and don't want to drive all over town to pick up various types and flavors? Then KCH is your new bestie.

I stopped an hour before closing but they still had a great selection. Cakes from 6 or 7 different bakeries with a great selection of flavors. I went for a HiDo one but they had a special berry flavor from Cannatas that was this week only which turned my head.

There's a cooler for cakes that need to be refrigerated.

Staff is friendly and helpful. I was worried because I heard it was on the driveway of the Mortuary but it's well covered by a portico. Cash or credit card. And it's funny that all the scary mortuary statues are decorated for carnival.

My wife and I strolled into this house-turned-business on the south side of Old Town Zionsville.  There is a large porch that you climb a few steps to from the free street parking out front.  Once inside, you see the room where they have cookie doughs for visitors to buy.  To the right is a prep room where the guy who waited on us was busy but stopped what he was doing to help us.  A third room around the corner contained a counter with baked cookies that was what we were looking for.  

I really liked that they had bite sized samples of several cookie types available.  My wife selected a thick and softer chocolate chip cookie.  I picked a peanut butter cookie and a combo raisin/cranberry cookie that were also very good.

The young man who worked there was friendly and helpful and I appreciate that he was able to attend to us promptly without making us feel rushed.

I think if my wife and I liked eating cookie dough, this place might even get a higher rating, but since we only like our cookies fully baked, we will settle on a 4-star rating with only the limit on the number of options keeping it from being a 5-star.

Review #2641

I've heard some good things from a few co-workers about Co Do Hu so  I finally went with a friend for lunch on a Wednesday. Place was pretty busy but we were seated right away.

We each knew what we wanted and ordered:

- Pho ga ($10) - comes with your usual bean sprout/basil side dish. My bowl had a massive amount of noodles in it (not that I'm complaining). Broth was tasty but a bit on the salty side.  Good broth but not the best in Edmonton.
- Won ton soup ($10) - My friend had this and she liked it. Came with a bunch of won tons and some mystery type meats. The kicker was she didn't know how hot those chili side bowls are and she put in 4-5 scoops! Oh man, rookie mistake. She managed to eat it though (trooper!) and took the rest for leftovers for another day.

Anyways, place is your typical Vietnamese restaurant. Fast service, good prices and good food. Will definitely be back to try more things as it is close to my work. Beats everything else in the area.

It has been over 20 years since I have been to Santa Barbara but when I had a week with Pismo Beach as my home base, it was the perfect chance to go for a day trip.  Unfortunately that day happened to be during a heat wave limiting how much time we were going to spend outdoors.  

The fusion aspect of Blue Owl was what intrigued me but found out that my first choice of the red curry tofu and shrimp sandwich was medium on the spice level because of the red curry sauce.  Since I only tolerate mild, sweating more from spicy food was not a good idea eating outside when it was going to reach 100.  Womp, womp.   Although not fusion as I wanted, I did inhale a delicious eggplant sandwich with a Thai Ice Tea and had a bite of a just as delicious pork banh mi.  

What really impressed me was our server noticed me trying to fish out a flower that fell into my Thai Ice Tea from the tree I was sitting under and he actually offered to bring me a new one.  Since I was already halfway done, I did say half would be sufficient.  Now that is attentive service.

Walking in here yesterday took me back to my childhood.  A time when I gleefully said "Yes" when mom asked if I wanted to go with her to K-Mart.  I knew my reward for accompanying her would be, at best, a G.I. Joe figure, or a delicious Slush Puppy icee at the very least.  Prices didn't register with me since I was just a wee lad and momski was picking up the tab.  I can only assume the prices were decent because we drove over the Gandy Bridge into Pinellas to hit K-Mart, totally whizzing right by the Zayre which closer to home.  I suppose Zayre and K-Mart then is much like Target vs. Walmart today.  Pros and cons to each.

Literally, the last time I stepped into a K-Mart was 1996.  I was doing some price comparison on household items between K-Mart and the new-to-the-area Wal-Mart.  What I found was that Wal-Mart had much better prices, and a much larger selection.  So why did I stop in this location yesterday?  Convenience.  I was at Lowe's next door and figured it couldn't hurt to look for a few items I needed since it was right there.  Big mistake.  The store had a strong mothball aroma, the aisles were poorly stocked, selections were severely limited and the prices were far from a bargain.  I walked out almost as quickly as I arrived.

If they're still around in another 20 years, I might stop in to see if anything has changed.

I haven't eaten here again since Gorden Ramsay did his makeover but I ate here several times before then.  Nothing here was outstanding but nothing was terrible.  This is an unassuming typical Metairie strip mall type of place with pretty mediocre food.  The seafood dishes often seemed to be lacking and I generally opted for their other options which were alright but not quite worth the price.  The only thing I really liked about this place is the servers were generally very friendly and authentic NOLA Yat-tastic.  I might check it out again to see if Gorden was able to make any lasting improvements in the joint but my prior experiences left me very unimpressed.

I've been sitting on this one for awhile now...how much do I give to ambiance and a lakeside view?  Does it trump over an average meal?  

Rick's is the only place in Indy where you have a pseudo-feeling that you're dining in a lake town.  It's a pretty awesome sight to take in, and I wish the food reflected that.  I settled on the Spicy Plum Glazed Jumbo Shrimp, which was served with coconut rice.  It was pleasant-tasting, but there wasn't anything in particular that had the foodie in me spazzing out.  Perhaps the plum sauce needs an extra kick.

Also, with all of the ingredients and variety of dishes, I'm curious as to where Rick's gets their stuff from.  I know they claim it's fresh, but I'm the type of consumer that wants to know where my food is coming from.

I'm undecided if I would come back or bring friends here.  With all of the terrific options in Indianapolis, a view simply does not trump over flavor.

I had hoped to walk here from my hotel - a nice 2 mile stroll.  Exercise, sightseeing, and art; perfect right?  Except for the rain that foiled my one woman parade.  Instead I got a quick cab ride with a blink and you'll miss it view of the Rocky steps (you know I was going to run up them and do big champion arms at the top, right?), some streaks of green lawn, and a few fearing for my life "Philly drivers are insane" moments.
The museum was well worth it.  The lobby reminded me of the one at the Met, while the museum itself could've easily been one of the dozens I visited in Europe.
I agree with Heather wholeheartedly on her advice for the special exhibits - although I'll warn that weekdays are no better.  The exhibits should really be limited to  a certain number of people at a time rather than a flow, and I think if they changed the way they sold tickets they could manage that.  Say, only 30 people can buy tickets for the 1pm slot, and they have, oh 20 - 30 minutes to go through, and then the next group can go at 1:30 and so on. . . . life would be grand.  Shoving past people once you'd like to move on while they look at you like you're the rudest thing they've ever seen (as they shove back to try to take the space your body left open before someone else can) is not my idea of fun.  I love Frida's work and it is so detailed sometimes that I really want to get up close.  Plus, I'm not a huge fan of crowds.  That said, the exhibit was great, and I even bought a bunch of souvenirs at the end which I don't typically do. 
The rest of the museum was lovely, although I only had about 15 minutes to kill before it was my turn to line up for the special exhibit so I didn't get to see as much as I would've liked.  
** aside - Thanks to David for noticing (as always) that this is review #500.  Thanks to the museum and its kick ass Frida exhibit for making such a happy review memory.  I'd also like to thank my mom and dad, without whom none of this would've been possible.  Thank you to my . . . * music swells and drowns out typing . . *

This place is a find and a steal.

Who knew that there is a fully functioning restaurant in HCC's Dale Mabry Campus? Only tell your really good friends, because seating is limited and I want to always be able to get a table.

There are very narrow windows when this "restaurant" is open. It makes sense, because these are students getting experience, not workers making a living. Look on their website for the hours. We went on a Thursday and it was open from 7 - 8 p.m. That meant that by 8 p.m. everyone was done and getting out of there (though that could be because we were all there at 7 p.m. On the website it says they seat people at 7:45 p.m.) I thought this might end up feeling rushed, but since it is a set menu, food is out quickly so you don't feel rushed at all!

You can go to their website to see past menus and upcoming ones (for the upcoming dishes, they usually only post the next one). All their menus are themed by country. We were there for Moroccan night. This included Moroccan Farro & Lentil Soup and Feggous & Watermelon salad with Pistachio, Chicken Tagine served over Moroccan Couscous, and Milk Bastilla. Obviously, I just looked at the menu because there is no way I would have remembered all that. The highlights for me included the watermelon salad, which was wonderfully sprinkled with feta. I also enjoyed the Milk Bastilla. It wasn't overly sweet. There are no substitutions so make sure if you have allergies you check the menu ahead of time.

Our waitress was a hoot and a holler. She was super friendly and if she wasn't going to be a chef (which I'm just assuming based on what she is studying), I would suggest she choose a job where she interacts with people on a regular basis.

You get all of this for only $7! That is insane to me. Bring a $10 bill (they only accept cash or check), leave the change as tip, because honestly, you know it is worth it, and pat yourself on the back for finding this place. You won't regret it.

Soy & Pepper is the latest Korean place to open, although this was a few months ago. Right along trendy Jasper Avenue, I'm pretty curious to see how they will fare with the likes of Joey's, Earls and Cactus Club Cafe chains surrounding them.

The inside is warm and inviting with clean, modern white walls and comfy seats. Loving the Casa and Soju bottles lined up atop their bar/kitchen.

The menu is small but I like the logo and play with the salt & pepper shakes. Clever. Lunch specials (11:00am to 2:00pm daily) seem to be the best way to go at S&P. Not sure why but their menu seems overpriced to me.

Interesting that they charge you for banchan if it's not part of one of the dishes you ordered. Can't say I've seen that on a Korean menu before. Dessert! Ooo, another place in town that does pot-bingsoo. And hoddeok is one of my favourite Korean snacks! Must try it next time.

- Banchan - beans was one banchan. The other was kimchi. Stingy portions kind of defeats the purpose of banchan.

- Kabocha squash jeon ($12.00) - shredded kabocha squash, onions, green onions, soy sauce and vinegar dipping sauce. Lightly pan fried, nicely crisp, can't say I've ever had kabocha before. A nice change up from the typical seafood pancake but we wanted more kabocha-like flavour.

- Bulgogi ($16.00) - thin slices of marinated beef, green onions, onions and cabbage. Tasty, well marinated bulgogi. The sauce was excellent. Perfect to soak up in your rice. Only issue we had with this dish was that the small portion size, given the $16.00 price point.

- Roasted bossam ($22.00) - slow roasted marinated pork belly and pork shoulder, ssamjang (gochujang and doenjang) sauce with daikon wraps. Both cuts of meat were tender but the daikon wraps just weren't doing it for me. The traditional method with lettuce wraps is much more satisfying. The dish was beautifully presented but that seriously affected the quantity of meat that you get. $22.00 for that much? You've got to be kidding me.

It's nice that there's finally a spot downtown to get Korean food if you don't feel like heading all the way to the south side. That being said, you're paying for the prime location and portions are not what you would call sharing size. We shared all three dishes and was nowhere near being full. Probably not my first choice when I think of Korean but the food was better than I expected.

One thing I noticed about St. Petersburg is that there are more ice cream stores than people it seemed, but they were all busy. Weird.
I walked in initially because it had a serious Italian feel, and I thought maybe there would be some pizza in there too. ha! 
Not my lucky day.
This ice cream shop had wonderful flavor choices, and a sweet, funny staff. I appreciated the independent shop feel. Great location and a great people watching patio.
I am not a fan of ice cream, but if I was this would be where I would always find something good.

I'm not a bar person.  Even casually, I don't remember the last time I was in a bar.

I was doing some business with Roberts Camera across the street and was looking around the downtown area, taking some photos, and thought about getting a snack to hold me until I could stop for a real meal.

I had returned from Monument Circle and Circle City Mall, etc. and remembered something about Union Station being a big deal.  Forgive me, but I was out of state for 22 years.  Things change, right?  I walked past many doors that seemed to be forever closed.  At the end, the door worked and I entered.

I didn't see much but a large restaurant/bar.  I talked to the person out front of the place.  He told me that everything else had closed a long, long time ago.  He also told me that they had appetizers for half price, $1.00 beer, and they were not busy.  It seemed perfect.  (Not that I like beer, but everyone made it out like I should be happy, so I smiled.)

Jason brought me a menu, introduced himself, and as I looked over the appetizers, I ordered an iced tea and the mini fish tacos.  I was in the San Fran Bay Area in August and didn't get fish tacos but every other kind.  I was in Philly/New Jersey in June and got some fish tacos that made me sick so I was interested to see what this restaurant had.

The iced tea wasn't bad--typical of what you get in most of the states.  It could have been from Kroger or Marsh.

When the fish tacos arrived, I was psyched.  If you haven't tried Rubio's in Southern California or Beto's in Orlando, Florida, you don't know what you're missing.  They may not even be the best.  The fish tacos here were really good.  They didn't seem to have the mayonnaise/chipotle sauce that some places have but they had a cup of red salsa on the side.

Now, if I was paying full price, I might be more critical, and with the tip, it ended up being priced like a meal at a cheap chain restaurant but it really was good and I would certainly return.

There are several things I love in this world. Three of them are: yoga, being outside, and free stuff. Yoga on the Pier combines all three! 

Here are the details:

+ Class every weekday day (except Wednesday) at 7am, 
+ 6pm class Thursday. 
+ Saturday and Sunday weekend class at 9:30 am.
+ FREE! There's a donation bucket at the end of class, but it's pretty low pressure which I really appreciate.
+ Malik Wilson, the instructor I've had twice now. is AWESOME. Great hands on assists and great classes.
+ Get there 10 minutes early or so to get a good spot, it can be harder to hear if you are further away (although they often have over instructors walking around to give directions.
+ 10% discount at Cafe Ole for mentioning Yoga on the Pier.
+ BYO Mat, towel, water, and SUNSCREEN. Downward Dog=Awkward sunburn
+ All levels classes that are still a great workout.

Head on over to their fb group and like them for updates!

ALSO Yoga on the Pier got me on TV! Basically I'm so famous that coworkers' husbands and people who I went to high school with's moms are calling them being like, didn't you go to high school with that girl Melissa P? She's on TV at some obscurely late night time talking about how awesome free outdoor yoga is. Ok so it was two people and someone's instagram. ok it was my instagram. Still counts!

Definitely check it out!

Ok. So there are nice, modern baby/care for baby items, but the prices are ridiculous.  I mean the mothers that are shopping here have babies & babies themselves are expensive... Soooo there's no need for their prices to be astronomical as well. Sheesh!!!! Helllllo #onlineshopping but I know sometimes you just gotta have what you gotta have, but my goodness!!!! 

I don't really care for the store itself. Full restock baskets everywhere. 10.5 people (.5 = babies & other little people) in line 1 cashier open. I mean for the prices, they should be able to have each register manned & ready to checkout patrons with these grossly overpriced "i gotta have it for my baby" baby items. 

We asked a floor person for helped & she merely "pointed" us in the direction... I mean really ma'am, you're not that busy you could've walked us where we needed to be in this cluttered store!!! Helllllo. Afterall we're paying $50 for a nursing pillow, hello!!! 

Parking is shared with 3 other stores, but the lot is ample, no problems.  I do like the expecting mothers "reserved" parking as indicated by the sign; should be 2 rows of these. 

I'll try not to come back. Try other places before returning to the scene of a crime... The crime being #highwayrobbery.

My sister & I visited this place we found on Yelp.   We had just missed the last free table.  The hostess was very friendly, wrote our names down and told us come back in 30 min and we would be at the front of the line.  They don't take your names down but you just wait in line until a table is ready.  While you wait, you get live music to listen to and samples of appetizers.
