We finally got situated.  The ambiance was fun & lively.  Not a quiet place to go if you want to be more romantic.  Our waiter was o.k.  I saw some great reviews but ours was just ok.  We got the scallops dish was yummy and also the Blackened Salmon which had lots of flavor!  Not the biggest portions but enough!  

Of course we saved room for the Bread Pudding Souffle which was excellent!!  Though we realized at the end, our didn't have raisins.  It was very tastey though!    

Very fun, great decor, and fun place overall!

Pho Country 2.  Came in for the Banh Xeo.  Very few places serve this Vietnamese Crepe.  So my wife gets what she wants and she wanted this.  I had to try the Pho because of a number of other people recommended it on Yelp.

Banh Xeo was an 8 on my wifes scale.  It was a little less "homemade" taste but was still very good and crispy.  Additionally it didn't have what she expected in pork inside.  It had the BBQ pork instead.  But still very good.  My daughter had the Sweet and Sour pork.  It was ok.. a little overdone.  My son devoured his Orange Chicken.  The sauce was good.  But if you go to a Vietnamese place for Chinese.  You really shouldn't complain about it not being perfect.  My rare beef pho was good.  But it was lacking in flavor a bit.  Sure I still hit it with the pre-requisite fish sauce, hoi-sin, rooster sauces.  But the broth was just a little light for my tastes.  Also they have GREAT Cha Gio (vietnamese egg rolls).  So good my daughter loved them.

So next time I will try the "dry" rice noodle bowls.

One thing I really didn't like was the blandness of their nc mm and would really hope they would change this one up before my next visit.

Delicious buffet, and at $8-9 (lunch/dinner), it's hard to beat for a price. Come for their staples, including chicken tikka masala, basmati rice, naan, fried chicken, salad, mutter paneer and more... they have a split of their menu between the vegetarian and non-vegetarian options at the front so you can tell what's what.

The buffet comes with tea/coffee afterwards and a choice of dessert - I always enjoyed the gulab jamun, which was a honeyed milk dessert... so hard to find the same thing anywhere else!

They do rush you through eating and clearing your table if it's busy, though.

One of my favorite places to dine near-campus.

Homegoods, so much fun stuff. Any theme of your house is here, and they organize it so well. 

This homegoods has two aisles of dog stuff, what a surprise.

There decs for the wall are plentiful too. I have so much fun checking this place out whenever they go.

There are also nearby restaurants in this plaza too!

I was really excited when the street car had a stop by here because I love going to breweries.  But this was not what I thought at all.  We walked in and the place was really quiet, with a couple of people.  We sat at the bar, and started to look over the menu, but couldn't find any of their beers on the list.  And when we looked at the taps, they all were all beers from different breweries.  When I asked the bartender what Jackson Brewery beers were on tap, he said that the Brewery stopped making beers years ago and it no longer exists, only the building is left for other businesses.  Instead, they serve local craft beers from all around Louisiana.  Having never had beer from Louisiana I did a flight, which came with four samples.  I tried the three IPAs that were available and a coffee porter.  Unfortunately, all of the IPAs were really weak and not that hoppy, which was disappointing since IPA is my favorite kind of beer.  When I asked the bartender about what are some popular IPAs from the state are, he told me that not a lot of people like IPAs; but more breweries are starting up around the area, and they always carry an IPA just to have one.  Okay... Maybe I am too Pacific Northwest, but it was still disappointing to learn of the beer scene in Louisiana.  The bartender was friendly though hence the two stars.

Well, when I say this place is noisy, dirty, and packed, I'm not kidding. Lots of local kids at the arcade and in the theater, and plenty of local families.

There's minimal parking in the front, much more in the back under the I-95 elevated highway. Theaters themselves are okay, speakers are middling quality, screens are digital finally, and a few selections at the candy counters. Sticky floors, and hard to clean when they rush people in and out of the theater.

Recently someone was shot here (someone complained at someone else for being noisy, ironically, during a movie).

As a coffee shop, it's not terribly warm and cozy.  But there are lots of tables, which is a good thing in a college neighborhood.  I've always been able to find a place to sit.  (I do agree, though, that coffee shops shouldn't be study hall.  Coffeehouse owners are trying to make money, and you don't have a right to sit for hours, use their electricity to run your laptop, and create a trip hazard with your cords because you bought one cup of coffee.)

The coffee is not bad.  I don't go out of my way for it, but it's a nice alternative to Starbucks.  Green Line is a better option just up the road, but if you are in a hurry and need caffeine this will do.  The pastries weren't very good.

Next stop on the Kirkwood Romp (since I didn't buy anything at Strange Doughnuts, but I went in and smelled). All of my girlfriends bought doughnuts. I declined. That is the smallest store I've ever been to in my life. Meaning Strange Donuts.

Dang, I like Cornucopia. I've been here before, but I was not on Yelp then.

They've got so many kitchen utensils and great vessels, not to mention the gadgets, sauces. An amazing amalgam of offerings. But there are a lot things in here that you can get cheaper (same brands) at Target or Bed Bath and Beyond.

I got 1/2 pound of four coffees. I let them do the grinding, though I've got a grinder.

The grinder man told me I could get 2 pots from each 1/4 pound.

The coffees: 1/2 pound each -- decaf southern pecan, decaf vanilla nut cream, crème brulee and chocolate raspberry. $32.28. I can still smell them.

A decent spot for tacos, burritos, and bowls just steps away from all the theatres on Broad Street / Avenue of the Arts.

If you choose a taco plate, you can mix and match certain meats, so I chose the carnitas, pastor, and barbacoa. All these meats had a good amount of flavor to them and came reasonably portioned. You can also choose from a variety of add-ons like lettuce, cheese, and sauces. 

It's sort of like Chipotle, but locally run and reasonably fresh. Seating is communal, and even though the staffers appeared to be dissing patrons right in front of them, I didn't have the energy to summon my college-era Spanish-language skills and listen closely to what they were really saying.

It's Tuesday and on Tuesday we eat tacos! We found Anas and could see we had the real deal, very authentic. 2$ per taco, we ordered 4...chicken, fish, carnitas and carne asada. Very good street tacos, double tortillas and no skimping on the fillings!

The carnitas and the carne asada were the best!  If we weren't going out to dinner in a few hours we would have doubled down on some more!  They offer Mexican coke and other soft drinks. Also they have four varieties of beer.

Anas has a couple of patio tables for two which was perfect for us with our two fur babies. They also have inside dining available. 
Quick and fast service and very friendly.

I attended Taste of Old Town Goleta today and LOVED Woodfire Catering's pizza! I tried the tomato basil option and it was fantastic. 

I really loved their set up too. The oven was easily moveable but safe. They were professional and got the pizzas out fast!!  

Woodfire Catering was definitely a fan fav at Taste of Old Town. They had a line almost the entire time, but Woodfire kept that line moving. 

Great job and Thank you!!

Who would have thought that one of the best tasting meals I've ever gotten from Santa Barbara would be from this local deli? With so many positive reviews, Pickles & Swiss had to be one heck of a meal - and it was! 

Pickles & Swiss is pretty tiny. There are a few tables and chairs located outside the restaurant, and a big communal table and some window seating inside. Order at the front and they'll hand you your order when it's ready. They have a good number of sandwiches on their menu - from paninis, to P & S Favorites, to cold and hot sandwiches, whatever you crave, they probably have it! They also have soups, sides, salads, and wraps. We ended up ordering a tuna melt sandwich and a roasted chicken and walnut pesto panini with a side of chicken orzo soup. 

Tuna Melt: $9.95 My sister said this was the best tuna melt she'd ever had in her life. It was that good. The sandwich came with cheddar, tomato, bell peppers, and mayonnaise on wheat bread. Even though the sandwich sounded quite simple, the taste was powerful and super satisfying. If you're a fan of tuna, you need to try P&S's tuna melt. The side of pickle was the perfect compliment to the sandwich. 

Roasted Chicken and Walnut Pesto Panini: A bit pricey at $10.75, but it was worth the money! The sandwich came with housemade roasted chicken, provolone cheese, roasted peppers, and fresh walnut pesto on brioche bread. Amazing right? It really was. My sister, who isn't a fan of trying new things, found herself really enjoying this sandwich. That nutty pesto and juicy chicken had such amazing flavor that worked so well together! And having it in a pressed panini with the pickle - really, really good. I personally would order this sandwich again. 

Small side of chicken orzo soup: $3.95 the soup was really tasty as well! My parents both found themselves really liking the rice in the soup. Flavor was spot on, and there was a good amount of ingredients inside the soup. 

And that dill pickle popcorn dispenser allows you to get a handful of dill pickle popcorn to try while you're waiting in line. And if you happen to like it that much, you can even buy a bag to take home! 

The workers here were super friendly; I think we even got to talk with the owner himself as he made sure everything was going well and the food was good. 

tl;dr - Definitely a must try if you're visiting Santa Barbara and looking for a good place to eat. The sandwiches here are solid (from what we tried). Love the friendly atmosphere - the fact that the restaurant always had a line (and offered complimentary water) was awesome. Will be back to try more when I am in the area!

This is certainly worth a visit if you're in the area.

It's a fascinating museum.  Just about the time I start taking for granted the tiny little art on my money, and figuring it was created by some laser machine, I'm introduced to the machines that made it possible in the 19th century.  It finally dawns on me we didn't have those micro machines with laser cutting and yet those tiny little pictures were still extraordinary.  It was a very labor intensive task made obsolete by modern technology.  

The upper floors of this museum are filled with memorabilia about Preservation Hall.  The small gift shop on the first floor has some souvenirs to remind you of one of those things that makes New Orleans so memorable.

Unfortunately, there are no souvenirs of coins from the NO mint, but there are plenty on display as you walk in the front entrance.

You'll never look at your money the same way again.  And if you're timing is right, in visiting the music hall history, you'll catch a nice concert.

And if your timing is really perfect, you'll have the security guard regale you with tales of the building, the displays and the best nearby  sites.

How have I not yet reviewed the Yellow Porch?! This is very unlike me. I digress. The Yellow Porch is a lovely spot for dinner or lunch and recently I got a to-go order from the bar during my lunch break. Parking is a nightmare, however, they have a parking attendant outside who helps you figure out the parking situation. I appreciate that! 
The black bean burger was fantastic; I love the texture of the burger, it was unlike any that I've had before, and I have eaten a lot of black bean burgers people. I also got a side of potato salad that was delicious and some greens for heath reasons. 
Last year I had the Restaurant Week menu and remember it being tasty, but can't elaborate on it too much since it's been a minute since the dinner and I'd rather review something closer to my experience. 
Love the Yellow Porch, it's a Nashville staple that is solid!

Easy in. Easy out brushless car wash with it's Best @ $14 is a no brainer. 

Needing a good, strong but more importantly fast car wash to wipe the road trip off the grill, Gas House fit the bill. Pay at pump or inside is a drag but just plan on filling up first but expect to pay a few cents more per gallon. There was no line and I was out in moments. I only go to brushless and these jets did a good job of removing all the bits and pieces accumulated. The dry did it's job to about 90%. I was impressed. A quick towel off at any of the meriad of vacuum stations will help.

For the ese of convenience (as long as you're getting gas) this "House" is good but I'm disappointed I can't stick a card in at the kiosk and roll.

While not the Ritz, this functional hotel does the trick for the non-internet generation. The room was clean and the service, through a window at 2am checkin, was friendly. Unfortunately, for this rating, I expect the wifi to actually work. It didn't.

Yep, I said it...5 stars for this outstanding cafe because they knocked my socks off during this first first.

My expectations were nowhere near what I received and I am ashamed lol.

I love small businesses, I love coffee, I love Clayton and I love crepes so it was important that I pay my respects to City Coffeehouse & Creperie.

The exterior can be missed if your driving more than 5 MPH so pump your brakes and look for Oceano.  City Coffeehouse & Creperie is next door.  The inside is intimate enough for a date yet open enough for a nice group get-together. The employees were welcoming and helped me order.  I watched the guys prepare my crepe in an open kitchen setup which was cool.  The menu boards are super cute and colorful.  The crepe variety here is serious.  Buckwheat batter is an option for .95 cents additional cost.  

I tried the lemon curb with fresh blueberry crepe....jaw dropping delicious.  Hands down best crepe I've had in the St. Louis Metropolitan area.  The whip cream was hand made; I can tell by the texture this didn't come out of a can.  My dark roast black coffee complimented the sweet (not too sweet) crepe.

Free Wi-Fi, beautiful enclosed patio for window seating and people watching make this place a winner.  I'll be back!

Christy loves ya City Coffeehouse & Creperie.

Raw food is really hard to find. And as a vegetarian this is a little jam that I discovered one day when trying to find raw food places. Even though it's a bit out-of-the-way whenever I am traveling that way towards Oldsmar always make it a point to stop in. My favorite is the KEY LIME SMOOTHIE. Since the menu is constantly changing I cannot exactly say I have a favorite however if you get the RAW TACOS  those are absolutely amazing! Honestly it's raw food. All of it is healthy and has so many textures and flavors that you cannot go wrong with anything you order!

Great spot to have brunch. 
Love how all their dishes have a catching name to it
This is what we ordered for four of us!

Yolo! - Gravy served with buttermilk fried chicken & grilled buttermilk biscuit and poached egg on top! It was pretty good. The biscuit did seem a bit dry but the gravy helped~

Salmon in yo face - cured salmon on top of a toasted bread. The put some spread on top of the bread along with red onion and capers.

Tugboat -Pretty much its an eggs Benedict. Comes with two biscuits, poached eggs, hollandaise, ham and avocado

Also ordered mimosas and chardonnay!

Loved the vibe and food. It's outdoor seating so you can bring your dogs with you!
I would recommend this place to anyone who is visiting SB and looking for a brunch spot. Walking distance (well when I mean walking distance, you are going to have to walk ab it but not bad, since you can digest before you start wine tasting!) to all the major wineries too!

Now the only Indian restaurant remaining in the Goleta area, this one does not disappoint. You can smell the delicious aroma even outside the restaurant. 

I love Indian food and I have thought the food was very good here since I tried it my first week as a student. No fancy artwork or service here, but c'mon, it's a pick pick. They actually have made some upgrades interior-wise.

The naan yesterday was not bad, a little thin and could have had more garlic. 

The tikka masala had huge chunks of juicy roasted chicken. It was creamy but still had lots of spice. 

The samosa was filled with flavorful spiced peas and potatoes. It had been sitting out a while and wasn't hot but the filling was really tasty.

Something felt lacking in the chana masala, too much of a tomato sauce. I recommend the saag paneer; it was mild and had a thick texture with chunks of the curd cheese.

This is a good option for IV and Goleta residents who want a quick Indian entree.

It's been a few years since I visited this historic location.     There seems to be a lot next door but I parked on the street.

There is one line to order which goes pretty quick.   

There is indoor/open dining but looks like they can pull down the sides to keep the dining room enclosed.  I don't know if they have air conditioning or just didn't put it on but it was 92 degrees with hot outside air blowing.  I'm not sure how people were enjoying their meal with the sweaty conditions.   Waiting for my food I was ewwww.. 

The fries were tasty.   Hubby got a roasted pork which he liked although he only ate half of his $10 sandwich.   

I got the cheesesteak ($11) and I only took a very small piece.  The poor sandwich was starving for meat as it was mostly bread.   $30 for two sandwiches.. fries and sweat.. ugh... 

I won't be back.  Definitely not a pleasant experience.

What has happened to my beloved Maoz? The last two times I have stopped by to get my falafel fix have let much to be desired.  The first recent encounter was pretty gross.  It was obvious that the tables hasn't been wiped down in quite a while, and there were little corn kernels all over the place.  I ended up taking my falafel to go because it was nasty.
Then, today at 10:10 pm I stopped by again in hopes that my last experience was a fluke.  Well, I wish I could tell you that it was cleaner, but they were closed! The sign on the door clearly state they are open till 1:00am, so I'm not sure what the problem was. The little hipster on the other side of the door just shook his head no until I gave up and walked away.  
I will probably give Maoz one last chance since their food is pretty tasty. But as of late I have been very disappointed with what used to be my old stand by.

We were a little reluctant bringing kids to a restaurant on a Friday night, but it worked out well.  We never order off kids menu and just let them eat the same thing as adults.  Pace doesn't have a printed kid's menu, but they can accommodate requests for kids meal.  The kids behaved really well, maybe they were mesmerized by the live cello and guitar performance or maybe because the food was to their liking.  My three year old kept requesting more prime rib and my 1.5 year old was dipping her finger into the sweet chili sauce after she ran out of calamari to dip.  

Service was warm without being overly attentive.  Most importantly, the food was delicious.  Calamari fries was crispy on the outside and surprisingly tender on the inside.  The strips of calamari had a good marinate to tenderize the meat before being coated with panko and dunked in hot oil.  The sauce on the side tasted like a thick spicy nuoc mam.  The prime rib was seasoned perfectly and cooked to the right temperature, although the dish was old school and not at all inventive.  Its understandable that a new restaurant in a small city can't afford to push the boundaries like in LA or NYC.  

The pork tenderloin was perhaps the best dish of the night.  Thick medallions of pork and 3 large shrimps were pan seared and topped with a sweet sake sauce flavored with thin slices of shitake mushrooms and pickled gingers.  The sauce was savory and sweet, but not cloyingly sweet.  This dish fused well executed western technique with eastern flavors.  Both dishes were served with sauteed asparagus tips and mashed skin on potato.  Again, very standard sides, but executed well that the asparagus tips were slightly crisp and the mashed potato was creamy and perfectly seasoned.                       

The restaurant was about 2/3 full during dinner time on Friday night and started to wind down around 9:30.  Its evident that good words have gotten out, but a restaurant located on State could do much better than this.  Come on people, what are you waiting for?  Give Pace a try and you will not be disappointed.

Ok, ok, it's a little pricey but some how, worth it. I find that the quality of the produce, deli and meat department are really excellent. I love that in the deli department there are so many delicious, unique and varied options of pre-made salads, etc. The cheese selection is excellent. I love all the super yummy gourmet sauces, crackers, oils, vinegars and other culinary treats that are found up and down the isles. And unlike large grocery stores you can can find everything you are looking for (and more) very quickly and easily because the store is small, filled only with quality foods, no processed, sugar filled U.S. boxed items that are chemically engineered and utterly lacking in nutrients. 

Sunterra is easily accessible from the Whytmud, with lots of parking and going "green" seems to be quite important to them. They also source quite a lot from local farms and ranchers. There is a little cafe in the market so you can pop in and buy something from the deli and have lunch or dinner. The only thing that I find can be somewhat of a problem is that sometimes they have inexperienced people working in the deli. So, you have to be patient and wait.

I stopped by for a tour and a wine tasting on a Saturday.  I was able to grab a parking space in one of the nearby lots and hopped on one of the tours.  The business is a production facility for the wines as well as a showroom, so tours are only conducted on weekends for safety reasons.  The tours are free and only take between 15 and 30 minutes, depending upon the number of questions people ask along the way.  During the tour, you see the machines used from receiving the grapes, through processing and fermentation, to storage and bottling.  It's pretty interesting, but lacks a "wow" factor since they aren't running the machines during the tour.

I also tried the "tasting" of seven wines for $5.  I had to sign up for the tasting and wait for the appointed time.  Fortunately, since there are three counters running at a time, tastings start every 15 minutes.  I liked that they gave me a checklist that describes the options in each  "barrel" (round) and I was able to pick from either of the columns.  The guy behind the counter was friendly and seemed pretty knowledgeable of the wines, giving even more information about each of the choices before serving.  The tasting started off with some dry options and moved through semi-sweets and sweets, ending with the most popular "Reggae" line of wines.

If you are interested in picking up bottles of wine you enjoyed during the tasting, they sell both chilled and at room temperature.  For those not wanting to wait, a patio with umbrellas is just outside the entrance and makes a nice place to enjoy your purchase.  I am not sure about the arrangement for glasses and if any food is available to munch on while sipping.

Overall, I enjoyed most of the wines that I tried during the tasting.  I think for its size, it is a nice business, one of Indiana's oldest wineries.  

Review #268

A Nashville staple in most coffee shops and around town is the fabulousness that is Las Paletas! They offer cream and fruit based flavors, and their storefront is in 12th South in a random building with almost zero decor (found that a bit odd) but I guess the product speaks for itself! I finally made it to their storefront this weekend and they were just as good as always. 

Some personal favorite flavors:

-Mint Lime
-Spicy chocolate
-Peanut butter
-Berry (cream based)

Fun fact, Bobby Flay did a popsicle "throwdown" in Nashville against them and lost. That tells you how amazing they are! 

Stop in for a treat or look for them around town. You will not be sorry you did!

Very classy and tasteful boutique...it's completely different from places like Naughty and Nice. Penny is very nice and not pushy, and she don't mind taking the time to inform you of things if you have questions, so don't be afraid to ask for help. This boutique carries corsets, hosiery, lingerie, top of the line products and even a few mild 50 Shades of Grey items. Check the store out, you won't be disappointed.

Just OK - we've had better and worse teppanyaki meals in the past.  My husband and I were squeezed in at 5:45 (the last seating for the "early bird" prices with 8 other local-yokels including a well behaved 5 year old.

The room was already steamin' hot from the other teppanyaki table that had 3 kids - one of whom (maybe age 2) screamed every time a fire was lit.  That sucked - because that was almost our entire meal.

Meanwhile the act is pretty typical with the onion volcano (if and when we come back our 8 year old will love it) a big pile of so-so fried rice and OVERCOOKED steaks and shrimp.  The shrimp were nearly rubbery and my "rare (I always ask for rare at a teppanyaki and it always comes out over done) steak cubes were medium to medium well.

Oh well.

It was an experience. Oh and the guy ext tome ordered a sushi meal with pale tuna and blah looking fish.  No way I'll get sushi here.

Not thrilling - but it's an option in the land of suburban chain restaurants.
And kiddos LOVE the show.

Cajun BLT, Cajun BLT, Cajun BLT. 

I'd like to say I've tried other items on the menu, but I can't. I'm hooked. Pathetic, I know. 

9th Steet Deli is a cute spot in a historic building in Soulard. Overall,the atmosphere is nothing exiciting, but they recently got a facelift with paint and some exterior upgrades. 

Did I mention the Cajun BLT?

The food options were limited at terminal 3 where I was traveling. I didn't feel like Chickie's & Pete's or any of the available few fast food. La Tapenade looked so promising, until I received  my less than average croissant. I was sitting on the bar, and the travelers next to me were totally unhappy with their $11 "brick" sandwich! As this is a relatively new Mediterranean Café, it has potential but not there yet!

Three Yelps!

Salt.  Mountains and mountains of salt. Hell even the salad dressing has a sea full.  

We went because my daughter finds the fettuccine alfredo to be fetching. She played her last soccer game that day and I guess we lost our minds. Pasta for me is rare treat.  I usually save up my pasta splurges for a fancy pizza or a few other local places. But sometimes a dad is just a sucker for his daughter. 

Olive Garden has been reviewed tens of thousands of times over the years.  If you have read those reviews.  Good for you.  But why in the hell are you reading this one then?  

Anyway. Our server was great.   Our food was fancy!!  I mean Sous Vide to order for $11!!  Some Foodies have paid WAAAAY more than that to have their food boiled on a bag. 

One "pro" to eating at a chain like Olive Garden?   No need to take pics of the food.  They already did that back at the factory.

So it was really, really cold yesterday. Luckily, I had appointments all in one area (124th street-ish) and Steeps was the perfect place for kill some time in between dates.

The location is awesome. It's near all kinds of restaurants, shops, and salons.
The wireless is problem-free, and they even have a few plug-ins if you look hard enough.
My two London Fogs were pretty tasty indeed. I ordered LFs because they're my go-to tea drink, and I was really intimidated by the wall of tea near the front door. After sitting for a while with my Fog and computer, listening to the cashier teach customers about different tea blends, I realized how kind and totally non-judgmental she was about tea newbies. I'm definitely going to get more adventurous next time and get a small pot of something bizarre.

I come here to get my car maintenance done and they usually do a pretty good job, although the wait can be sometimes painfully long, even in the early mornings on work days, probably thanks to it being on Adamo, a major road in Brandon. Usually I will take a courtesy truck to the Brandon Mall to wait while they repair my car. One of their salespersons tried to pull a fast one me once, but my uncle caught their scheme. I suppose that is just the job of a salesperson though, to make as much money, even if what they sell is not exactly what you need. Most workers are very friendly though and try to take care of you while you are there.

What a gem you have here in downtown Reno!

I came here to attend a Yelp event in their upstairs room, but couldn't resist a little pre-dinner shopping.  I was so impressed with the thoughtful selection contained in this gem of a co-op.  At first I thought they didn't have any personal care items--but they do!  The personal care items are upstairs!

I was absolutely delighted with their selection of ginger items.  I'm on a major ginger kick and they have ginger beer, pickled ginger, crystallized ginger, and the piece de resistance:  Ginger Syrup.

My people! 

Don't question it--just buy it.  

Put it on pancakes.

Or waffles. 

Or ice cream.

My heavens, yes!  Ice cream!

Or...pour a skosh on your plate and taste a little that way.  

You're welcome.

Get to it!

They have the second best roast beef Po Boy in Mid-City and their other sandwiches are pretty good too with their Peacemaker po boy being a good highlight.  Their boiled shrimp and crawfish just aren't as good as my other preferred spots and on my last visit the crawfish were really undersized compared to several other places I had recently eaten some bugs.  The seating can get pretty hard to find on the weekends in here but during the week it is usually easy enough to grab a spot at the bar.  Sometimes you can order from the bar but when it's crowded you just have to stand in line and order at the front register and then hope a seat clears out after you have paid for your food.

One of the highlights of my trip...a must! The only downside for those staying in the French Quarters or Garden District will have to uber over - probably 10 minutes to an area called Bywater but you won't regret it. I have to admit I'm very picky about wine bars, lounges, etc., because I live in Los Angeles with some great options. Bacchanal Wine quite possibly may have topped my list. 

Note: this is not just a wine bar.

There are 3 areas. The front is the wine bar with a little shop. You go to the back to find a very large outdoor patio with live music (an actual stage). The lightening, the seating and the whole makeup was so appealing to the eyes. I went on a Monday night around 9pm and it was PACKED! The third area was upstairs - a bar serving amazing craft cocktails. 

Most people seemed to get bottles of wine along with charcuterie plates. 

I loved everything about this place. I will 100% be back the next time I'm in NOLA.

Every frequent Yelper has experienced the disappointment of researching a new restaurant to visit in a unfamiliar city, then pulling up in the parking lot only to be confronted with something completely different than what they imagined.  When this occurs, you must resist the urge to turn and run.  Trust the Yelp.

At 7:15 pm in the dark, I drove right past what appeared to be just another gas station on the corner of nowhere on the outskirts of Tucson.  Where was Papa Loco's - all I saw was a Conoco?  We pulled a U-turn and drove by again.  I still didn't see anything but my wife thought she spotted a sign for Papa's.  We pulled into the parking lot and drove up to a small restaurant taking up about 1/3 of the gas station convenience store.  I was initially concerned that this was not the type of place I was seeking.  Then a soothing voice whispered in my ear, "Trust the Yelp."

You've already read too many words that have nothing to do with the food, so I'll simply say this - fresh, homemade, authentic, fun, and delicious.  I have no idea if Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives has ever featured this little restaurant, but it's exactly the type of place that warrants that type of recognition.  The prices are right, the salsa bar has a ton of variety, the restaurant is clean, there is a nice patio that wraps around the little restaurant, and after the closing time the kitchen crew sings loudly in Spanish to the radio - not in an annoying way, but in a "we really enjoy working here and we all like our coworkers" kind of way.

If you're driving through Tucson, put this place on your itinerary.  It's definitely on mine when I return.

Friends and I met here for a late lunch. The restaurant's popular, so reservations are the way to go. Luckily, we only had a 20-minute wait.

Belgians sure must love to drink, for Monk's is known for having an extensive beer selection, one that fills multiple pages. Beer drinkers, this is your heaven. (Since I'm no beer expert, my eyes glazed over in confusion; I ordered a shot of tequila instead.)

Their Spanish Flies ($8.50) - chicken wings - were decent. The chipotle pepper sauce they're dry rubbed in was supposed to be "incredibly hot", but I only detected a wee kick. For my entree, I had the curry mussels ($9.95; small pot) which were simply wonderful: Rodenbach Red Ale, Thai red curry, basil, garlic, coconut milk, and tender mussels, all in a bowl. The string fries on the side were surprisingly crispy and went well with the dipping sauce.

I know they're a Belgian cafe, but if they tossed ramen noodles into the curry, they'd make a killing.

This is my favourite OJs by far! I can always find a spot here even on Friday and Saturday nights. The place is clean and trendy. They always have a variety of games playing too. I can catch football and hockey in the same place which is cool. Servers are always happy to change the channel if it isn't too busy to show different games. 

I come here quite often because I like the atmosphere and service. 

Half priced bottles of vino on Thursday (Thank God).

Two of my favourite dishes are the butter chicken and the jambalaya! They're both yummy and come with naan or garlic bread. For appys I like the bruschetta.  

The only thing I don't really like is how dark it gets in the evening. It's SO dark. I'm half blind and I need someone to read the menu to me.

Green Eggs Cafe is a local chain that serves breakfast and brunch daily. It's a cash only and bring-your-own-beer establishment. You could pay $30 for a bottle of Prosecco with free corking service if you want a mimosa with brunch.

Since they did not have a Chai Latte, I ordered a Tropical Smoothie, which consisted of a blend of mango, pineapple, banana, orange juice, and ice. It was topped with diced mangoes and kiwi. It was a bit tart. Towards the bottom half of smoothie, it had a strong banana flavor.

For brunch, it was hard to decide what to get because everything sounded and looked so delicious. I ended up getting the Smoked Lox Benedict, which consisted of toasted rye bread, topped with cream cheese and smoked lox, topped with two poached eggs, hollandaise sauce, red onions, and crispy capers, and served with potatoes sauteed with rosemary (instead of peppers due to pepper allergy). It was just as I expected it to be - fresh, delicious, hearty, and filling.

I honestly don't know how I haven't reviewed this yet as I go here quite often. It's near my parents and Fenton/Valley Park is kind of a culinary desert. When we're in need of something open later (especially on a Sunday) this is pretty much your only option. But that's not a bad thing, because it's darn good. 

Sugarfire serves amazing BBQ and plenty of non-traditional options that most BBQ places don't serve. Like salmon, burgers (topped with brisket), and a fleet of delicious sides. I'm a huge fan of their burger but most recently I got their fried chicken on a biscuit. As you can imagine, it was delicious. Crunchy but not greasy and sandwiched between a wonderful buttermilk biscuit. My wife got their salad that had BBQ mixed in. It was huge and probably the best salad you can get at a BBQ restaurant. 

To put things in perspective, Sugarfire is so good we had them cater our wedding.

PM was a definite regular spot for us years ago and always fit the bill when in the mood for sushi. We were in the hood for the evening and were on the lookout for something vegetarian and, of course, up pops PM on our yelpy radar. It was a pretty busy night but we were sat immediately inside at a table. There's no mistaking that most are looking for an al fresco dining experience in Nashville. It's gorgeous. 

I think we missed the boat a bit with our order, unfortunately. I do remember loving their sushi and especially going nuts over their veggie burger. We went a bit of a different route --

Veggie Fritters - These were a little bland on our end. Not sure if we just got a weird batch? They did have some visibly delicious veg within, but the flavors were a bit flat. The dipping sauce was interesting, too. A different take on honey mustard. Not my favorite. 

Veggie Mu Shu - Where the veggies were pretty good, the crepes, which are typically softer, chewier, and a bit more structured, were pretty bad. They fell apart and had a really bad texture altogether. I forewent them and just ate the veggies, which again, were fantastic. 

Veggie Lo Mein - Holy sesame oil, Batman! That's really all I can say. It was so overwhelmingly sesame-laden that it was a bit hard to eat bite after bite. My wife only ate about 1/3 of it. 

The setting of this place is just awesome, though. Killer place for a drink on the patio or even at the bar. I'd definitely recommend the sushi and veggie burger, but the items we had are a little less-than passable. Either way, still a huge fan of PM!

I haven't been in a Swatch store in what seems like forever, probably in Franklin Mills way back in the 1990s.

I liked the watches back then because of the colorful looks and precise time.  The Swiss were trying to save themselves after Pulsar and Seiko had cleaned their clocks.

I stopped today mostly because of nostalgia, and talked to Patrick who was helpful, and wanted me to try every watch in the place.  The only thing is, I don't think I've worn a watch since 2004, and I have several somewhere, including a Swatch or two.

Interestingly, the Tag Heuer store was just as empty as Swatch was.

Careful, you may just walk passed this restaurant since it's sandwiched in between two other establishments but once you find it you will want to come back. 

The cocktail list has a decent selection, as does the wine and beer list with happy hour specials as well. I was slightly confused by their Thursday $8 cocktails stated on the menu since we were still charged full price the Thursday evening that we went but our cocktails were great either way. I ordered the Secret Garden with gin, creme de Violette, rosemary syrup, and club soda. It was a beautiful and refreshing cocktail. 

As our appetizer we ordered the buffalo cauliflower and the bistro steak as my entree. Both were delicious! We tend to order cauliflower if it's offered as an appetizer and we have yet to be disappointed and 47 Scott's was no exceptions. The batter was crispy and the buffalo sauce was light yet flavorful. The bistro steak was cooked precisely as I ordered it and was seasoned perfectly as were the truffle fries. The broccolini was slightly over done for my liking but not a deal breaker. 

The service was swift and our server was polite and inviting. The only recommendation I would make is to tidy up the back patio. Where we sat it, there were stacks of chairs, heating lamps, and a fan that just isn't eye appealing. Even leaving the heating lamps as is by the tables would be more appealing so that they could tidy up that space and add more greenery because the patio area is, for the most part, very nice.

After experiencing their awesome green tea yesterday for less than $2 (in a big beautiful glass on ice), I had to knock this review up to 5 stars.

Plus, these folks are SO friendly! You always leave wondering, "have I met him before? Because he definitely acted like he knew me?"

I really liked this place!  Although it is obviously a sports bar with multiple televisions on the front and back wall, I loved that they didn't have the volume blaring on any of them, so we could actually chat easily, plus seat groove to the cool, eclectic mix of music they were playing overhead.

Service was friendly and efficient.  I liked my drink but didn't love it - I had the Thyme Away, a gin drink with too much lemon juice flavor, and not enough cucumber and ginger beer.  Plus, almost a whole plant of thyme was stuffed in it. I wouldn't try that one again.

I did, however, love my hamburger.  It was a perfectly cooked medium rare, topped with onion strings, bacon, pickle slices, and bbq sauce. Delicious!  Plus, it came with a generous serving of tater tots, served nice and warm.

Parking was easy, bathrooms were clean, and the atmosphere was friendly and laid back - I look forward to returning soon.

This is a nice little gastropub on a quiet-ish street in Reno--far enough from downtown, but not a bad 20-minute walk from Circus Circus and such.

The food are drinks are delicious here.

I got this cocktail: THAI TEA - thai tea infused bourbon, coconut cream, lemon, turbindo sugar. And I tried the Shrimp Po-Boy and the Filthy Fries.

All 3 of these items were tasty and were presented in a unique way (refer to pictures I uploaded). I maybe could've done without the Shrimp Po-Boy but the visual of it made it taste better. The filthy fries had a lot of flavor, especially with those short ribs in it. If I wasn't so tired from partying the night before, I'd probably have enjoyed the libation and food more but they were good nonetheless. Other things on the menu looked amazing but I just didn't have the stomach the morning I went.

I'll likely be back here during my 2-year stint in this area.

ATPV. Average Time Per Visit. Some places are meant to be dashed in and out of. Others are overwhelmingly trying to get us to stay a long time. There are those stores where we love to linger, we touch everything. There are those stores where we wished they served a refreshment to keep us there longer. Mass Ave Toys is such a store. Why not a jug band in the corner? Why not a soda fountain the back? 

You don't need gimmicks though now do you. There was a rather pesky version of my former self who would not dare set foot in big box stores just to get someone else a necessity, let alone a gift. That former self... is really proud of my current self where each time I need to buy a toy as a gift I've been heading to this place. 

Today a random Saturday afternoon I dipped in thinking I'd be out in 5. I was out in 15. It was worth it. I found a safe for 7 year old fake archery set. Yeah, archery. Then I walked the 3 foot box of archery down Mass Ave like a proud champion of the marketplace. And, I kept it under my $20 limit for the gift (sorry $4 gift wrapping I wasn't giving into exceeding my limit). 

If you look close enough... say in the map section... there are things here for adults. 

When it comes to design, intrigue, assortment, vibe, lay out & flow, I don't know if there's a better store to keep us there just long enough it doesn't bother or beguile us but instead we stay there just long enough we've found *just* the gift in *just* the right store.

Well, I have to admit that this was a two-three star experience. We visited during Dining Out for Life which one expects to be busier than norm but it appeared that Lockerbie Pub opted not to prepare and staff up at all given how few people were working. Then in turn, said staff appeared to be stretched and not the friendliest in their resulting customer service. I was most impressed by the Damien volunteer who was not only hustling to help but offering up the friendliest vibes there.

I was digging the dive bar vibes and love this neighborhood bar's location within the Lockerbie Square and Mass Ave neighborhoods. Be prepared for a hazy hint of cigarette smoke smell from bygone years that is probably etched into the walls. It fits the overall vibe though. 

On the food and drinks front, we ordered an assortment of cocktails and craft beer. I was especially impressed that my ginger and Jameson was only $4.50- two! We ordered a plethora of dive bar eats like breaded tenderloins, patty melt, BLT, mozzarella sticks and a fiesta taco salad. I was really amped up for the fried pickle chips I've heard about but alas, they were out during our visit. Our waitress was gruff and hard to flag down for orders and the check and set the tone for the less than hot experience. I'll probably return one day for pickle chips and a mixed drink but won't be running back.

Ace all is back and as a kick off to a great Father's Day weekend my wife sent me, my older son and father in law to a game against the ABQ Isotopes and it was a blast.

The ballpark is so nice, spacious and clean with exciting eats, drinks and amenities around nearly every corner. Taking a 3 year old to the game means lots of up and down from the seats and I was so thankful for the great waking track that runs around the field and offers great views of the game from wherever you choose to stop. 

I was also super thankful for the outfield kids play zone complete with an Archie bounce house, an epic inflatable slide, play structure and pitching game! After a few innings my dude was itching to burn up the dippin dots he downed and this was just what the doctor ordered. 

The games themselves are fun to watch abd there really isn't a bad seat in the house. Big Shout out to Chris Payne the amazing voice of the Aces for several seasons running! His commentary in between play really brings the fun to the game and adds so much!

I'm grateful to live in Reno and have the Aces here as another fun highlight to the summer!

My fiance and I are so excited to have bought a house so close to Nolensville! Having so many good, authentic Mexican restaurants and food trucks makes me feel like I'm back home in Texas! We went to El Tapatio for a late breakfast/early lunch. I had Huevos a la Mexicana - eggs scrambled with tomatoes, jalapeno, and onion. It came with a side of rice, beans, and guacamole, sour cream, and lettuce. And FOUR tortillas (choice of corn or flour, not made in house). The food was pretty good, but not as good as some other places on Nolensville, so I don't think we'll head to El Tapatio too often. The coffee was instant (yuck), but the service was great. All in all, it was an okay, but not great Mexican spot on Nolensville, but it has so much competition!

I was killing time and decided to check out Cabela's.  WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOW!

I've never seen anything like this store.  This place is HUGE, it address all your outdoor needs; camping, hunting (guns, bows, knives), and fishing, to name a few. 

They have exhibits for all types of things, one area showed the big game animals people hunt in Africa.  It was honestly like a museum exhibit.  They have a gun show room, which had all sorts of crazy things, they even have a taxidermy area - WTF!

My favorite area was the fishing tanks, they have HUGE tanks filled with different fish, and I'm talking big fresh water fish.  All the kids were going crazy, it was feeding time, and he fish were hungry, CHOMP, CHOMP! 

If I was with my kids, I'd go here just to kill time, it was honestly overwhelming with all the neat aspects that I don't get living in California.  I can't comment on their pricing, as I was here to gawk only, but I can assure you, their selection set is vast.

I love where I live. In front of me is majestic Lake Tahoe, behind me is the Mt. Rose wilderness. This is where I take my guests who are here for the first time and they want a little taste of nature without dying due to altitude issues. There are hikes galore in this area, from the very simple and accessible mile-long loop (perfect for after dinner exercise) or the more strenuous trails that lead to ridge tops with fantastic views of the valleys and lake. During the summer, come early to avoid crowds. During winter, snow shoes are a fun activity. Very dog friendly. Oh, and let's not forget Chickadee Ridge where if you come with some bird seed, those chirpy little buggers will come and sit on your hand.

Small neighborhood bar with decent food, cheap drinks and new owner and chef. Pool table, juke box and nothing fancy just folks enjoying themselves. All starters, soup, salads and sandwiches are under $10.00. Dinners range from $9.50 - $20.00.

Lunch not as rowdy or loud as evening. Bartender was friendly and prompt with our orders. Fried Pickle Chips were great...not greasy and large basket  for $4.50. 

Now for one of the Flag favorites. If you're looking for a heart attack on a bun or starving, or just need two meals, try "The Big Pig Sandwich" which is pulled pork, on top of smoked ham, on top of Bacon on a bun. BBQ sauce tasty! OH and it  comes with fries. All for $8.00. Takes 3 hands to eat even cut in 1/2.

"Rajun Cajun Chicken Sandwich", also a Flag favorite, is huge as well. Spicy blackened chicken breast topped with pepper jack cheese and cajun ranch sauce. LARGE, thick, tender chicken breast. Sandwich with french fries $7.50. I personally prefer withouth the ranch sauce only because it takes 10 paper towels to get through. I enjoy spice and blackend so I prefer just a bit more blackened which they will do if you ask. Either way, still a good sandwich.

Food is good and for those wanting healthier options try one of their salads. BBQ Pork Salad, Southwest Chicken Salad, Chef Salad or Chicken Caesar Salad.

The only problem I can see, and has always been a problem, is parking. The front (maybe 10 spaces) is for motorcycle parking and only few spaces on both sides of building for vehicles. It is what it is!!! but you can park in local business next door after their business hours.

Be sure to ask what Chef has prepared for the day. Food and drink specials daily. Fish Fry every Friday. Alaskan Walleye w/fries and coleslaw for $6.00 very popular.

Check the Calendar of Events times for Monday poker, Wednesday karaoke and Friday dart tournament.

Seeing Karen W's review posted yesterday for Treasure Valley Closets reporting experiences that mirror ours with this company, if misery loves company she and I are going to be fast friends.  Because having TVC work on the bedroom and storage closets in our new home has been a litany of incorrect drawings, sloppy work, missed appointments, late show ups without the right materials, promises to return without meeting those promises and damage done to other parts of the house by one their installers.

This closet work should have been completed by August 1.  It wasn't and since then it has been the same litany of lousy follow up by TVC management as Karen W reports for her project too.  We are still waiting on some of the work to be completed.  And these guys were not our choice.  New to the area we knew nothing about them and they were part of the custom home build contract as the closet sub contractor used by the general contractor.  

 The owner of TVC seems a nice enough guy, actually, and has himself been on site a couple of times always with the excuse that things went south on this project because "we are just so busy".  Which makes me scratch my head that anyone would use them now that I know better.   But since Karen W and I both know better, the question is why didn't the builder of this home. And as P.S. here I'll offer up that our experience with the General Contractor, Tradewinds, was chock full of lousy management examples...maybe water seeks its' own level in Tradewinds choosing sub-contractors like Treasure Valley Closets.

You win some you lose some. Was in the market for a good Philly cheesesteak sandwich but this isn't the place to go. I don't know if it was the garlic Asiago hoagie or all the cheese the ruined it. Probably the bread that doesn't go with a Philly cheesesteak, it was more like eating garlic bread - weird experience didn't even eat half the sandwich. Also the prices here should be a couple dollars lower they might get more business. Maybe I'll try the Greek menu next time...

After reading some friends' Yelp reviews, we knew we needed to come here and it ended up being delicious. I'm not sure if it's necessary, but we made a reservation (a lot of the timeslots were booked already). 

We ordered:
- Lobstercargot
- Truffled Lobster Mac & Cheese
- Guppy's Homemade Fish Spread
- Shrimp Tacos (appetizer)
- Fresh Mahi Tacos (blackened)

The Lobstercargot was on another level. If you do nothing else, make sure you order this. Ask for extra bread to soak up all the extra sauce. It's a small portion but it's 100% worth it. 

I also really liked the Lobster Mac & Cheese. It was perfectly creamy and they didn't skimp on the lobster. Between the tacos, the mahi mahi were better. 

This is a great stop for a meal while in Clearwater!

Yikes, New China gets a one star for their version of bun thit nuong cha gio.  The only upside of this dish was the generous serving size, other than that, the herbage was sparse, just shreds of lettuce and a few specks of cilantro with a huge mound of rice noodles.  The cha gio was ok, but was also tiny.  The pork should have being grilled until the sweet marinade caramelizes and the fat drips onto the fire and perfumes the meat with a light smokiness.  Here, the pork was instead fried ahead of time, so the meat was bland, dry, and shockingly bad.  Perhaps, they have better dishes, but do not get the bun thit nuong or you will regret it.

So I went back yesterday & finally ordered the fabled Port Richmond platter, a delightful saurkraut, keilbasa, latke and pieroge medley.  I immediately knew I had to upgrade a star, because a kitchen that creates anything this delicious cetainly deserves it.  
I always looked at MTR as a sandwich type place, but after ordered a platter & enjoying it as much as I did, I am defintiely a convert.  
I must also mention that I sampled one of my husband's wings & they are definitely the best around.  Suicide rings are delicious too.

5 stars all around. Christine was extremely pleasant in person and guests LOVED the cake. One friend commented that the cake was better than the one at his wedding (and jokingly asked me not to tell his wife). I heard nothing but people raving about the cake. Christine's cake was wonderful. I liked the passion fruit and the chocolate layer the most.

Okay this place is great due to their selection of beers on tap. I love having a huge variety of beers to choose from from all around the country and world. They also have a 2 for 1 special. As a few other yelpers have mentioned, that means you buy one beer for yourself and you get one free no matter if you have another person in your party or not. Our bartender was very nice and had no problem striking up a conversation with her. The bathroom is gross here and you might have to worry about catching something.

Average Pho at above average prices.  Ok, that may be a bit rough, but seriously the pho doesn't compare to what you'd get on Washington Ave. Of course, as they say in the real estate biz, location location location.  

Let's start with location.  Old city has its share of bars, restaurants, and clubs.  However, Pho has been absent from the mix.  If you don't have a car or don't feel like giving up your spot, MTQ would probably do the trick.

Now on value.  The all-in Pho is $10 while other varieties are offered for $9.  However, the bowl size is about the same as a regular pho on Washington Ave ($6-7).  The fixings (bean sprouts, lime, etc) were fresh.  No tripe in the Pho which disappointed me a bit (to be clear, their menu does not list tripe, I'm just used to Pho having tripe).

Service was good.  The ability to sit indoor or out was nice.  And they accept credit. Overall, A-Ok!

Duffy's Sports Grill staff offered amazing service and really hooked it up! Duffy's has a whopping 81 TV's for watching all the games and football helmets everywhere including a Gators and Bucs helmet! Duffy's has a 2 for 1 happy hour all day everyday on everything except for shots and jai lai. Duffy's house sauza blue margaritas go for $6, so with the 2 for 1 deal, it's only $3 per margarita! For an additional $3 you can make any of the margaritas into a Corona-rita with the addition of an upside down Corona bottle in your drink with a holder to keep it in place! Calling the menu "the playback" is a pretty nice touch for a sports bar that I've nver seen before! Duffy's also serves a deluxe patron margarita and a strawberry margarita with fresh island oasis mix. I got the Korean beef taco trio for the appetizer and the blackened grilled Mahi Mahi w corn and black beans and rice for the entree. Both were quite tasty. The Mahi Mahi came out a little salty but I was still able to eat it without any problems. In my picture the Mahi Mahi dish doesn't look the most appetizing. Something as little as a garnish on the fish or sauce put on in an artistic manner would definitely dress up these dishes since they're trying to be an "upscale sports bar". The sides that Duffy's offers were a little disappointing- No macaroni and cheese, no au grautin potatoes, or no asparagus like Grill Smith offers. Terry said their mushroom bacon burger, baby back ribs, and shrimp scampi pasta are also pretty popular at their other locations. On my second visit to Duffy's, I had their full rack of baby back ribs with a loaded baked potato and the ribs were fall-off the bone tender, with the right amount of BBQ, and quite delicious!  The decor of Duffy's is upscale with dark woods, 81 TV's, football helmets, and sports memorabilia all over the walls. They have a frequent visitor program so for every $100 you spend you get $10 off and you get a Free appetizer for signing up for emails so you know I signed up! We sat at the bar and got too meet bartenders Terry, Lexi, and Desiree and they were really nice and cool. Service couldn't have been better. I rarely give out 5 stars so really there's no knocks against this place at this point. I could go to a 5 star after another couple visits maybe. Highly recommend! Duffy's is located right off S Dale Mabry next to the interstate exit in the big shopping plaza with the Target, Rooms to Go, DSW shoe warehouse, Alfred Angelo Bridal, Total Wine, Whole Foods, PetSmart, Home Depot, Nordstrom Rack, and HomeGoods. There is a large parking lot on site with plenty of parking available. Sometimes it can take over 20 minutes to get out of this Plaza. It would be awesome if this Plaza could get another exit. I Look forward to coming back again soon to try their ribs!

When it grew cold outside on Tuesday I had a serious hunger that could only be quenched by a huge sandwich. So I braved the wind and a 5 block out of the way walk to Primo's only to find that they were closed. Rather than shed a tear I went with the next best option - a semi out of the way train ride and a long walk back home after hitting up Lee's. Good thing it was worth it!

I remember Lee's back when it used to be in Wynnewood and how it always hooked up a monster sized Hoagie. It was a sad day when that one closed and I was hoping for the West Philly one to at least provide sandwiches that were equal in size. So when I found out that they did and also hooked up all kinds of chicken wings, finger foods, and breakfast sandwiches - Needles to say happy days were here again. I picked up a monster sized turkey Hoagie and loaded it up with hot/sweet peppers, lettuce, tomato, and sharp provolone and t sent me to flavor country. It's good to get reacquainted with old places!

In the past if you mentioned pizza and vegetarian in the same sentence, I would have looked at you as if you were crazy. By in the past, I mean before  April 14, 2016. Now, I totally get it. The pizza at Pizzeoli, it truly top notch and worthy of a spot on my Yelp List - Pizza with Pizzazz. 

When it was announced that the April gathering of ISC (International Supper Club) was going to meet at Pizzeoli, I rolled my eyes. I love my group of ISC diners, so I put my diet aside and my distaste for vegetarian pizza. Besides, Ian had them on his STL 100 and said i "must order" the Bianca. 

My Bianca was a wonderful choice. It has no tomato sauce, instead it is Béchamel Sauce with extra virgin olive oil, fresh mozzarella, garlic, rosemary and parmesan. With it being wood fired it had the perfect amount of char on the outer crust. I never knew a pizza without meat could taste so good. 

The surprise and most popular pizza of the night was the nightly special - Brussel Sprouts. We all wanted to try it, but were hesitant to try it as our only pizza. So Sarah S. treated us all to one & we got to experience a slice. Once I tried it - I wish I had ordered one entire pizza for myself. It too was, Béchamel Sauce, mozzarella, garlic and then roasted brussel sprouts on top. It was pure heaven! As we were leaving we told the owner - he had to add it to the regular menu. If it's on the menu when you visit, order it - I guarantee you'll love it. 

Our server, Kevin was a real trooper. Taking care of 9 diners all with separate checks is no easy task and he did it like a champion. 

I'll be back, hopefully for another Brussel Sprouts pizza. 

When: April 14, 2016
Why: International Supper Club

This place is a perfect example of why Yelp needs half stars. This was more of a 3.5 star experience, but I'm rounding up.

We stopped in here a little before 8 on a Friday night. To our delight, the place was pretty empty and only a few tables were seated. We were lead to a table in the back and given menus. We ordered our drinks and our appetizers and both came out fairly quickly. I ordered a cup of the crab bisque and I really enjoyed it. After finishing the soup we were ready to order entrees, and the waitress was no where to be found. Actually, she was on the other side of the room helping everyone but us.

Let me be clear here: I don't blame the waitress for being slow to take our order. I think the blame here lies in the kitchen. I am more than positive that the kitchen told the waitress to only send back one or two orders at a time. After waiting a while, the waitress came back over, apologized for the wait and took our order.

I was really in the mood for a cheeseburger and fries, so that's what I got. The burger was HUGE, thick and cooked perfectly. It's not the best burger I've had in my life, but it was good and I had leftovers, so I was happy. 

The yummy burger and the nice waitress are why I rounded up on the star rating. Maybe it was just a bad night and they were understaffed. Everyone I encountered was super sweet and helpful. The restaurant itself is very nice and makes for a perfect date spot.

A trip to Whole Hog Cafe, at least on a Saturday night, is an adventure. It's also one big lesson in patience and control.

When we walked in tonight, the ordering line was stretched to the door. It inched forward, but it moved, so that was good. When it was time to order, I forgot to add that I wanted ribs with my pulled chicken. Am still cursing myself for that! Now, the food itself was fantastic, but..

Well.

Okay. When the clerk said that our meal number was 71, the counter girl announced, "Number 40!" And, unfortunately, they moved in order. Slowly. Around the counter, a herd of hungry humans hovered, staring her down (myself included, admittedly). I respect her for not melting down under the pressure. I probably would! Drinks and silverware are also self-serve.

After nearly an hour of waiting at the counter, standing, shuffling, etc., my number was finally called. The food was really good, and I really enjoyed BBQ sauce number 5, but the chicken was a tad cold, which was confusing to me. Still, the flavor redeemed it.

The meal also came with chips, a side salad and a dinner roll. Good deal! I also bought a brownie, mainly because, really, who can pass up on a brownie when it's sitting right in front of you as you pay?

Whole Hog has an interesting, communal concept, and is vastly different from most places you'll find in the Cherry Hill area. The diverse clientele proved as much. Still, unless I'm in absolutely no rush at all and am not dying of hunger, I would probably order take out from this place in the future! Mainly since I lack patience and what-not.

Oh my God I do love a dive bar. A friend decided we should head here after some Cinco de Mayo margaritas and I was excited to check it out. 

So I guess it is really a biker bar of sorts. When you walk in head straight across to the bar and grab a seat. Or maybe you prefer a table - grab one of those. Got some dollar bills? Hit up the jukebox and play your jams. Out back there's also a patio so I hear. Smoke 'em if you got 'em. Ladies bathroom had shower curtains for doors but they were pink and had fun girly patterns so that's fun.

Clientele were all over the board. Some bikers and just regular people like us too. The bartender lady was the best! Friendly, chatty, and fun. Plus she informed me that there's karaoke every other Friday. Oh how I love a dive with karaoke! 

I loved it too much I had way more than just one beer and may have stayed out way past my bedtime but it. Was. Totally. WORTH. IT. I will be back!!

The Hyatt Regency at the Arch is a standard Hyatt.  Hyatt is my favorite hotel chain, though I can rarely afford to stay at them.  This hotel was no different.  The beds were very comfortable, the pillows were nice.  The shower was fine, and the room was a fine size for a city.  I was disappointed to overlook the city and not the Arch like my colleagues, but we cannot win everything.  The front desk texted me when my room was ready early, and the bag check people were lovely and easy.  The fruit water as you walked in the door was always delicious.  If I had just stayed in the hotel, it would have been an easy 5 stars.

The conference spaces were nice but freezing beyond the point of acceptable.  Everyone I talked to was complaining about the cold temperature.  It happened to be a cool summer week in St Louis (High in the 70s and low 80s), and it was air-conditioned like it was 100 degrees outside.  It was miserable.  This wasn't a deal-breaker, but it was not five star quality.

The Brewhouse Restaurant was convenient and very reasonably priced so I did spend a good amount of time here.  I was shocked by the massive portion of the Smoked Chicken Quesadilla ($10), and it easily lasted two meals.  The service was painfully slow and poor, but the food I ordered and tried was good.

My largest objection with this hotel is that the Brewhouse bar over-served a man pretty severely.  I was having a drink with a friend around midnight, and a very drunk and large man came up and stood directly next to me in a creepy way.  The bartender noticed but kept trying to look away.  The man eventually tried to pick up three drinks off of the bar, tripped, and sent them everywhere.  One ended up on me, one across the whole side of the bar, and another broke on a chair and all over the floor.  It was a mess, and every server and bartender kept walking past it and did not ask the man to leave or even clean up.  It was completely absurd.  The other hotel staff was great, but this was just unimpressive.

I'd come back to this hotel, but I would not pay top dollar after seeing that bar incident.

I was looking for a place to watch the Super Bowl so I headed out a few days prior for my own personal "pub crawl" that included 8 or so bars along State Street.  Sandbar was highly recommended as my criteria was that they needed plenty of TV's, Coors Light and the ability to sit outside.

Well, two out of three isn't too bad, I guess!  First of all, no Coors Light (I learned it is hard to come by in this town).  Secondly, while there is outside seating (I would like to go back when I am only looking to eat and drink and not watch TV) there is no way to watch the TV's from the outdoor seating.  So if it is a game you want to watch- you will be indoors.  But once inside- there are plenty of places to catch your favorite game!

At the bar- the clientele is a little collegiate for my taste, but the bartender was friendly and a couple of the locals took pity on me and gave me a better list of places to check out, than that which I had gotten from my hotel.

And know that if you stay later into the evening- Sandbar becomes the place to "see and be seen" as it transitions from a bar/restaurant to Santa Barbara's version of a nightclub.  What was a causal place earlier in the night draws an interesting crowd as the shadows lengthen.

Service was spot on and any place I can sit outside in February gets at least a couple of  more stars from me.  My advice?  If you go . . . .go early (at least if you are older than 25!)

Very tasty fudge and ice cream joint located outside of Busch Stadium. The workers here were very friendly and more then accommodating to my children and there taste testing. Kinda pricey but you expect that with a fudge place in a tourist type spot. Overall was a very good experience.

2013 is an awfully weird year to open up a video rental store given the current climate of Netflix, On Demand, and Redbox. But if anyone can pull it off its a ragtag bunch of TLA Video alum who are full blown cinephiles!

Rather than be an average rental store Viva really does strive to win its customer base over with a full blown cinematic experience, and you'll know that once you realize that each and every movie display they have laid out contains at least 5+ Criterion Collection DVDs. The owners worked at the TLA Video store in Bryn Mawr for several years before it became the final TLA to close down, and they have become experts in helping people find the rare movies they've never heard of that cater exactly to their preference in genre.

Whether your a sci-fi kung-fu fan who's looking for movies that feature ninjas battling cyborg samurais, a comedy drama fan who's looking for quirky romance stories, a documentary fan who's obsessed with scandal, someones who likes Hollywood legend debut films, or is someone who just likes to walk into a store and carry on a conversation about zombie movies; they are fully able to help you out. And you can even rejoice if you're just looking to catch up on an old standby of yours, because there's a good chance that they'll have the very rare special edition that you never knew existed.

We were staying at the Ace Hotel just a couple of minutes down the street and were starving past midnight on a Friday. We thought Seaworthy looked like a nice little spot to duck in, though it was obviously a cocktail bar and we weren't sure if they were still serving food. Lucky for us, they had a late night food menu available from 11pm-1am.

We actually didn't order any drinks, and instead got a half a dozen raw oysters and split the burger. The oysters were very fresh from the east, west, and gulf coasts, and average about $3 each, which I found to be higher than what's typically charged at home. The burger was 8oz of half brisket, half beef chuck, which I asked for mid-rare. It was cooked perfectly and had fontal cheese, roasted ham, and garlic aioli in a brioche bun, with a side of seaweed seasoned fries and spicy pickles. It was absolutely delicious, and the fries were crispy, well-seasoned, and actually ended up being a larger portion than we thought. We asked for some garlic aioli on the side for dipping for fries, and it made our meal all the more droolworthy.

Unexpectedly fantastic meal, friendly service, vibe is trendy, and extra points for the late-night mood lighting.

Hold the phone! Union Trust is offering a $7.17 lunch menu!! While I had trouble choosing between the three options: Duck salad tossed with cranberries and candied walnuts, fish and chips, and the Kobe beef burger, I ultimately caved into my beef calling. Delicious brioche bun, perfectly seasoned meat topped with melted American cheese. Simple but awesome.

To think you can now experience UT without have to dive deep into your wallet. Wonder if Tommy Up's going to pull another receipt stunt.

I have been meaning to visit Bubbles & Blowouts sooner, but I rarely get dressed up since "date night" is usually Netflix and take-out. Other than highlights and a haircut every 7-8 weeks I do not  indulge in any salon services so it was such a treat to have my hair washed and styled by someone else. I love that Bubbles & Blowouts offers a childcare area if I cannot get my husband to watch our toddlers.

After an exhausting Thanksgiving I decided that I could use a little pampering and treated myself to a blowout before our family Christmas pictures. I had heard great things about Bubbles & Blowouts from the Moms of South Tampa so I checked out the website and to see their hours and discovered I could book an appointment online. I really liked that I could book an appointment online instead of calling because I rarely get a minute to pick up the phone with my clingy one year old. Not only was I able to book my reservation quickly and quietly after I put my toddlers to bed, but I was also able to score a morning appointment before nap time!

The location on South Dale Mabry is super convenient to my house and there was plenty of parking spots available. Loved the fun and modern decor and music. Did I mention the awesome childcare area?! The owner obviously gets that busy moms want to get pampered, but do not always have access to a babysitter. My stylist Dali was so sweet and friendly and did an amazing job with my hair! I decided to pay a little extra and added beach waves to my blowout. The result was so pretty and she added enough hairspray so that my hair still looked fabulous five hours later at our photoshoot!

The highlight of my visit to NOLA. My two favorite things are biking and eating and the culinary tour combined both of those loves into one beautiful afternoon. 

I would highly recommend to do this on your 1st full day in NOLA. We signed up ahead of time easily by email. The tour met at 1230 and it was an easy walk from the french q.  The afternoon was a little overcast and chilly but our tour guide  Victor was great about seeing where the storm was heading and we barely got sprinkled on in the 4 hr trip. 

Victor was a great guide and a NOLA native. He started the tour talking about himself and credentials and he really knew his NOLA food history. It was very enlightening. Some other tour guides may approach food history in an irreverent way, but not Victor!

The tour changes every time and we ate a ton of good food amongst 4 spots. All food was shared amongst the group we had 6 total. We ate : plantains with yummy red sauce , ginger spiced spinach, fried oysters in a blue cheese sauce, fried green tomatoes,  praline crusted bacon, Boudin, Boudin balls, cheese curds, cracklins, king cake and bourbon bread pudding!  I'm sure I forgot something but all the bites we had were amazing.

Biking gave us a great perspective of the city and naturally you can cover more ground. Also you feel a bit better about stuffing your face but as their motto says "it's not even close to exercise".

Thanks CoC and Victor for a great afternoon! When in nola I will be back to try out another tour.

Thai in name and while serving Thai food options in the main, this is one of the many Treasure Valley Thai restaurants that also squeeze Chinese and Vietnamese items onto their menu.  Service is friendly and sometimes, as in our most recent visit, even splendidly so but better organized at some times than others.  Knowing that going in to set patience expectations in advance may make the dining experience more enjoyable.

Owners are the same who own Pad Thai House in Boise and while we have had really poor experience for food and service and facility there, we have had good ones here for the same.  During the 2014 - 2015 years we ate here scores of times but it fell off our radar after that until recently given the discovery of better Thai food elsewhere in the Boise area.  I note the review I posted back then is missing, although the photos posted with it survive.  Having recently reacquainted ourselves with Thai Basil, it seemed worthwhile to review it again.  Falling between 3 and 4 stars based on umpteen visits were it not for the fact they denied access to the bathroom for two women in our recent dining party, we might have rounded up. 
 
VIBE:   Located in one of Meridian's woeful strip malls, the interior is welcoming with Asian décor, including a fish tank at the door, faux bamboo plant accents, dark red walls and interesting lights.  There are comfy seating options at all standard height tables with chairs.  And here I add "yahoo" while noting 70% of Zagat surveyed diners said in the 2018 released summary that they were "so over" high stool seating and yet so many Treasure Valley eateries rely on them.  Hooray too that there is for the most part ample space between tables to not feel as if one is in a sardine can, as is the case in many other local eateries.  And we appreciate every time we've dined here, even at full house, noise is contained at a level that makes conversation possible.

MENU & FOOD: This is a pretty safe bet for anyone across ages and experience with Asian food, from people whose frame of reference is Americanized Chinese food Sweet and Sour dishes or egg rolls...they have 'em...to people who want a bowl of spicy Thai Green Curry or the stand by dishes like Pad Thai.  There are better options in Boise for Thai food (Thai Cuisine as the leader and Siam Orchid as worthy contender) but this will do for good eats if you know what to order. We like to stay in the Thai lane, but also appreciate the Chinese lacquered duck served here.  Hard to find that cut up with bones in it delight.  Nearly all their Thai dishes are things we'd happily order again.

There are specials at lunch time, if that's your thing, for under $9 or you can order off of the standard menu then too.  Menu prices run about $6 to $20ish.

SERVICE:  Our most recent visit included people across three generations, some of whom knew nothing about Thai food and little about Chinese food.  The server was a model of grace for explanation and assistance.  Well done.  At peak times, like lunch hour rush, the only couple of cooks in the relatively small kitchen can lag behind and being prepared for delays then is a good idea.

ACCESSIBILITY:  It is more than disappointing, it is actually illegal, that they have put barriers in the way of equal access to the women's loo by people who use wheelchairs and walkers.  The ADA has been law since 1990 and this restaurant launched around 2014.  They should know better.
