They need to remove the chairs stored in the hall outside the ladies' loo door that make the entry too narrow and also remove the piece of changing table furniture in the loo itself.  It is not optional to provide equal access to bathrooms for all people.  It is Civil Rights law. This is the business owner's failure.  The structure of the building is right.  Impediments  added by the restaurant owner are in the way.

PARKING:  Private lot parking is a big advantage here.  But the ADA parking is not laid out for either design nor for the minimum numbers required by both law and Idaho building code.  This is the strip mall owner's failure not the restaurant owner's.

HOURS:  Open Lunch and Dinner but NOT straight through.  Note they are closed from 3:00 - 5:00.  This seems pretty common practice for smaller, owner operated ethnic restaurants as it gives time for "family meal"' and for the kitchen to refresh for dinner service.

Okay all right, this place is a little pretentious, especially by New Orleans standards, but it's a nice little option for college kiddos and others hoping to spice things up with something a little different.  

Monkey Hill is still very attracts a younger crowd so do bear that in mind, but since it's a more refined loungey atmosphere, everyone seems more inclined to restraining their inner frat boy or sorority girl.  But there will be sporadic bursts of dancing, especially should the crowd reach a critical drunken mass.  

The venue itself is moderately spacious and there's a fair amount of seating for actual lounging around and chatting it up. The bartenders are all right enough, drinks are a little pricier.
 
There's nothing too exceptional about this place and I can admit that had I actually frequented this place more than twice, I might be more inclined to give it two stars.  It's not my type of crowd, so to speak, but I think it's a great getaway from the typical Magazine bars.

Poppo's Taqueria let's you make your custom tacos with more toppings and options than any other taco place I've ever seen at a suprisingly better value than many other taco shops in the area. Poppo's Taqueria is open late and is a perfect late option after a night out on the town. Poppo's Taqueria is located in the west side of Downtown St Pete, off Central Avenue North and 11th Street North next to Sweet Stack Shack, Italy  Bottega, Copa, Independent Bar, Pin On Cafe, Cake Drip, & Chai Mixology. 

Poppo's Taqueria serves "make your own" custom tacos, burritos, big bowls, baby bowls, Quesadillas, or house favorites that include th recommended fillings. Poppo's Taqueria allows patrons to see and pick their toppings out as the tacos are made. Poppo's Taqueria is a fast casual restaurant with no table service and no liquor or wine but there is beer. You have to go to the register to order. There's a big seagull on the back wall with the words "more love, more tacos" to give the place a laid back hippie beach vibe which is fitting. 

Hot fillings include Ancho chicken, Carnitas, Morito Steak, Tempeh, black beans, pinto beans, white rice, & brown rice. 

Cold fillings include Pico De Gallo, honey-lime slaw, Jalapeño relish, pepper Jack cheese, feta cheese, red onions, pickled onions, cilantro, baby arugula, salsa Verde, sour cream, guac, & lime wedges. 

My Custom Morito Steak & Carnitas taco came loaded with Morito Steak & Carnitas and all the cold fillings I could possibly fit into this huge taco. I particularly liked the feta cheese, arugula, and honey like slaw which I've never had in a taco before! The unique cops fillings offered at Poppos gave the taco a unique delicious taste with Greek vibes that I've never had before. The steak and Carnitas had a great marinade & flavor. 10/10 

If you're in Downtown St Pete and craving some late night gigantic tacos burritos or Quesadillas with some great and unique flavors at an incredible price, definitely check out Poppo's Taqueria!

Driven past this so many times as the St Rose trail with the parking lot on the opposite side of the road attracts the street attention.

A 1.5 mile easy, almost flat loop trail that surrounds the boggy middle meadow.

Very well maintained trail with a couple of toilets available to use in the large restroom building there. Didn't see any sinks so bring hand sanitizer.

I appreciated the nature made stone love seat at the shaded half point mark of this relaxing loop trail.

I'm definitely getting these cupcakes for all my special occasions... And come back on a regular day! Infused with booze, these are some of the most incredible cupcakes ever! I found came here after trying a flight at Saarloos and Sons and just had to come back the next day! The consistency was spongy and can get heavy because there's filling inside. Don't let those little things fool you! It was not overly sweet considering how much frosting was put on it, but was packed with flavor. 

They rotate flavors every Thursday so when I went the next day, they still had the same flavors, but I got to choose my favorites of mango lime chardonnay, salted chocolate brown peanut butter, and strawberry sweet corn and honey. 

I can promise you won't regret splurging and I can guarantee you'll be running back for more!

Warning: eat them within a day. They still taste good the next day, but way more moist when eaten the same day. ENJOY! ;D

Oh, Treno, what happened to you?

My last in-love review doesn't hold true anymore, so I figured it's time to update. After a couple years of bliss with the four cheese pizza, Treno up and decided that the recipe wasn't working. Not only for the four cheese (which they re-branded), but for several other pizzas. They changed the menu entirely and, for that matter, increased prices. The margarita pizza went up in price as well and became greasier and lost flavor. Pizzas are now separated as "brick fired" and "wood fired."

But... to go back to the new quatro fromage pizza -- up in price by $2 to compensate for the new dough-style. The cheese on it? It's bland. It used to have this beautiful, distinctive flavor that brought me back again and again. It was to the point that I couldn't wait for the leftovers because I knew that the flavor would still hold. Now it's all just boring and plain and nothing to write home about. I don't know what happened or why, but it's a huge bummer and it makes me extremely sad. 

I raved about this place for so long and loved introducing friends to this spot. I won't be doing either anymore after experiencing these ill-advised changes.

I wake up in the morning feeling like P.Diddy and my tum tum gots a cravin for a big brunchin...when yr tum tum is in trouble, grab that phone n lauch that Yelp app yo!

4.5 star rating for a breakfast placed called Peg's Glorified Ham N Eggs?!?...Look at the pics and I gots-to gots-to check this spot out yo!

Get here on Saturday morning and the place is packed but the wait was only like 10mins, get seated, and the tables are kind of small and the dishes they are bringin out are huge.  Service is really good here, but let's breakdown the food yo!

Pros:
-Parkin (they have a garage and they comp)

-Eggs and Sausage Patty (best tasting eggs, no idea why they taste so good, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/J0joPXxmN-_9Lzafspqdbw?select=2LO9SZlSX7IjBD9tvOXhMA)

-Huevos Ranchero (Signature Breakfast Plate, so good check out the pichttp://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/J0joPXxmN-_9Lzafspqdbw?select=4FRufe-KiwY_ZhWdALMwfg)

-Short Stack Pancakes with Banana Foster add-on (really good, could not even finish the short stack, so big (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/J0joPXxmN-_9Lzafspqdbw?select=KLFdujsp9Y_Cn_Gy8mX-yw)

Cons
-usually a wait in the mornin
-orange juice (it was warm and super pulpy just order coffee or stick to the ice cold water)

Really a must place to have breakfast if you in Reno Yo!

I have no idea how it took me so long to get to Felix's. I stopped by for lunch not knowing what to expect, and walked out with a huge smile on my face. This place is so ridiculously cozy and comfortable, and while I'm sure it's a blast at night, I'm going to keep it on my list of places to eat lunch. Before I go any further, I didn't try the pizza. Please do not throw rocks at this review while you're reading it...

I called to see if they were open for lunch (had to correct the hours on Yelp!) and the guy who answered the phone was SO nice and told me to come right in for "amazing pizza, wings, and more." Sweet! We grabbed a cute little spot in the front room that was stationed right in front of the TVs so we could watch the Cardinals game. There was hardly anyone in there and it just felt so casual and relaxing. Their coffee machine was broken which made me a little sad, but I was alright with my water with lemon. We ordered the hummus and vegetables and the veggie grinder for lunch... The hummus came out and the only vegetables there were green peppers and tomatoes, and on the menu it listed broccoli, celery, and more, so that was kind of a bummer. The veggie grinder was SO good! It was spicy and full of cheese and veggies, and was served with Billy Goat chips. 

After our lunch was over I was tempted to go get my computer out of the car and work at the table with a glass of wine (they have free wi-fi!) but I decided that wine during a workday wasn't the best idea I've ever had. I seriously could've sat there all day though. They have Golden Tee & Big Buck Hunter for those of you who like games, and I seriously can't wait to go back for a relaxing night out and some New York Style pizza!

It's weird I haven't reviewed this location of Jeni's before, because I've been several times. Look, a Jeni's is a Jeni's. Some people love them, some people think they're overrated. Personally, I'm just not a frequent ice cream eater. This location has a good selection of seasonal ice creams (and some of Jeni's staples that stick around year-round), but it's in the Nashville Farmer's Market, which means it's tight. The line kind of wraps and you block people trying to get to other food stands. But it was HOT last weekend, and I was showing some friends around Nashville; we were in the Farmer's Market and I NEEDED something cold. Jeni's frose sorbet hit the spot.

A dive bar and a shrine to Elvis? Yes please.

King Pin is a great example of a New Orleans Dive, but with a great selection of beer. In particular, they offer Magic Hat #9 which I thoroughly enjoy.

The bar is extensively decorated with Elvis memorabilia. I found it very hard to not think about the King, or plan a new trip to Graceland while sitting around drinking. For anyone who has not plotted a road trip while sitting in a bar, you're missing out.

The bar was really dark. In fact, it may have been too dark especially when you consider that I had to use the flashlight on my phone to read something on the bar. Despite the lack of light, I did really like the bar. 

I hope to come back soon and drink some more Magic Hat in absolute darkness.

I had been hearing wonderful things about Kumo and their sushi definitely lived up to my expectations! I enjoyed it so much that it was just a couple weeks after my first visit that I found myself back for another sushi dinner!

The restaurant is very open, clean and spacious. The floor to ceiling windows bring in so much light. I've been seated at tables right near the windows during both of my visits but I can't imagine any table not having that same bright light. 

I've tried a few of their speciality rolls so far and all of them have been delicious. Although every roll I ordered was made with rice, I really appreciated that the seafood was definitely the main component rather than the rice. I hate when restaurants go heavy on the rice. In my opinion, the fish should always be the stand out in the roll!

Service was great when I was there and the servers were quiet, but friendly. Prices are reasonable considering the portion sizes and the amount of fish that goes into the rolls. I'm also a huge fan of the presentation!

Happy to make Kumo my sushi restaurant of choice when in Collegeville. I'll be rollin' in frequently with my bottle of wine -- did I mention it's BYO?! :)

Vietnamese Food Truck was a super perfect dinner for me tonight! I saw they were in the nearby neighborhood today, & I immediately went online to order.

Since it is a chilly winter night, I knew that Pho was perfect for me. I ordered the beef and meatball pho and it was a great amount of meat to noodle ratio. It was super tasty. 

I also ordered the bbq Pork banh mi. It had tons of flavor with it and the bread was a nice texture, not too hard and still nicely toasted.

Lastly, I ordered the Vietnamese wings with fries. The flavor is good for the wings and the fries were okay, they are the skinny ones. That was my husband's order.

When I ordered it online I received an update through text of when it would be finished and I drove across the street to get it. So super simple and convenient. 

I'm super happy to have their leftovers tomorrow!! So so good.

Thanks for coming out to the area! So nice not to go far and leave the neighborhood!

In search for a quick coffee while picking up items on Magazine street, I finally had the opportunity to come by the younger sibling of District Donuts Sliders Brew. 

A little bigger than a food truck with only outdoor seating; this is a great spot for a grab 'n' go coffee and bite to eat. The interior was nice and toasty while I waited, and has cute references to pi (as in 3.14). I grabbed my usual, a mocha, and their Kung Pao Chicken hand pie. The jury is still out if I think the hand pie was worth $5, but it is damn delicious in my opinion. Hand pies start with the breading, and they're nailing it. Perfectly flaky, warm, and not stale in the least bit. I like the kick to the chicken, and they give you a little side of cabbage/green onion to enjoy with it. I only needed a bite, and this was great to hold me over for the day when I usually eat a bagel. 

Their mocha...I had to go back to make sure it wasn't a fluke. I really really enjoy their mochas. Like dangerously so. They're not syrupy in the least bit. I think they make them with chocolate milk, but not the heavy whole milk kind, but like a perfectly blended chocolate milk. It wasn't overly sweet, and I could still taste hints of the espresso. I may be hooked because I know I'm going back today for another one. 

The seating outside is cute, but more intimate so I wouldn't necessarily meet here for an interview or meeting with someone you wouldn't know. They also have a really cute dog watering hole as well. 

Don't think I'm crazy, District Hand Pies, I'm coming back in today for the third day in a row...

July 23, 2011 Saturday - lunch 12 noon
2 adults and 1 kid

Atmosphere - 5 stars
Food - 5 stars
Service - 3 stars

Atmosphere - Clean fast food restaurant located in a larger strip mall.  You walk down the counter as the employees ask how you want them to build your sub sandwich.

Food
Appetizer - none today.

Main Course - I ordered the No. 1 on wheat medium (8 inches).  The No. 1 has Ham, Salami, Capicolla, Pepperoni & Provolone Cheese, and I love a good Capicolla.  As their slogan states "Sliced Fresh Sandwiches!", and they do slice their meats and cheese in front of you and it really does make a difference.

Dessert - not a big dessert fan during the lunch hour.

Service - They had four people working the counter and were the only ones there.  It was if they were trying to rush us through.  The person working the slicer was hard to hear and prying to get our orders from us.  At the other end of the line was the cashier.  She wanted to take the order complete order from me, but all I could give as we were spread out was each order as we completed.  Because the way we exchanged information, I ended up with a drink short.  So I had to pay cash for that drink after charging the rest of the meal.  Yeah I know I could have charged the drink and ding them for a small transaction.

Many folx don't know this, by St. Louis has the second largest Mardi Gras celebration in the United States. New Orleans obviously takes the king cake for the number one celebration, and after touring Mardi Gras World, it's clear why this city has the best parades! 

Mardi Gras World is a truly unique experience in New Orleans that I cannot suggest enough. Located in the Warehouse District, you get the opportunity to get a taste of the Mardi Gras season no matter when you're visiting the Big Easy. Mardi Gras World was created as a tourist attraction to provide visitors a behind-the-scenes look at the work of Blaine Kern, one of the most popular float studios in the city. The experience of Mardi Gras World is top notch! You begin your tour with an informative video about the history of Mardi Gras and also the history of Blaine Kern. It gives a great starting point to understand what you're going to see inside their workshop. (Side note, you also get a slice of king cake to nibble on while you're watching the movie. While you may feel weird taking it... DO IT BECAUSE IT'S TASTY!)

Once the movie is over you get to take a self guided tour through the facility. I cannot tell you how cool it was! There were artists stations where you could watch floats being sculpted and painted. It was amazing to watch these skilled craftspeople create beautiful pieces that will adorn floats in future Mardi Gras parades. The warehouse is also home to old elements of Mardi Gras floats that can be repurposed on new floats. My boyfriend and I loved being able to snap selfies with the outrageous pieces throughout the tour. They had everything from Disney characters to creepy creatures to Egyptian gods and goddesses. If you could dream it up, they probably had it sitting there. Initially I thought we would be done with the experience very quickly but because there was just so much to view, we spent about 45 minutes looking through Mardi Gras World. 

Other things to note about the Mardi Gras World experience... Firstly, they have a free shuttle to the venue! This was a really nice perk as we were staying in the Central Business District and walking would have taken a pretty long time. The process of booking the shuttle was a little confusing as you had to call Mardi Gras World and identify the nearest shuttle stop to your location. We waited about 15 minutes for the shuttle to get to us. The other thing of note is the warehouse is hot and humid (depending on the time of year you visit I suppose.) I was slightly uncomfortable at times because I was slightly overheated. But you're in a warehouse. If you go into the experience knowing it's going to be warm, you won't be upset!

F&M is one of the few Jewish Delis that delivers to me through an app. I may just hold on Jewish Deli ordering until I can go in person. 

I recently placed a fairly large order and most of it was pretty meh. The potato pancakes tasted like they had been frozen and pre-heated. The matzah ball in my soup tasted like it had some sort of weird chemical in it. I ordered bakery cookies and received 2 old, small chocolate chip cookies.

The giant pickle was great though.

My lean corn beef and pastrami sandwiches on rye were tasty as well. I've had sandwiches pop more with meat, but they met standard expectations. They also came with small pickles. 

For what we paid, I'd rather just spend it somewhere that really impresses me. There was nothing totally wrong, but I've had better.
Went running here while staying at the Lafayette Hotel right next door! Simple but pleasant hotel right on the streets of New Orleans. Good stuff!
One of the best baseball teams that nobody has heard of.  They are in the toughest division in major-league baseball.  They definitely played their hearts out every year.

loved it, sign me up for nodding head summer camp. i don't think there really is such a thing but let me make it an official suggestion. not crowded (unfortunately). great jazz trio playing; they announced that they play sunday brunch too. loving the old church pews to sit in. there is a large dr. office type scale, not sure if patrons really want to eat and drink then see how much they weigh, but it was a talking point for sure. well loved dart boards that you don't have to play to use. staff friendly, didn't eat, but drank every beer they made and had on tap. we ordered some pints but go for their flight 8oz of each for inder $3.00 a glass. 

i'm not sure if the other posts here are submitted by craft, micro or even brew fans. i, ladies and gentlemen love it!

700 level
light bodied blonde ale with a soft hop finish (4.75% abv)...in celebration of the spirit of the departed vet's upper deck
we thought, very light, almost a chardonnay or riesling 

grog
english-style brown ale... malty with a medium body and hints of chocolate... makes for a great dark session beer
we thought it fantastic, kind of a molasses aura 

fisticuffs
golden hued ale (5.25%abv) with an aggressive hop character... it'll hit you right in the taste buds 
ha ha, can't remember what we thought

enigma (6.5% abv)..."dry hopped with coffee beans....a paradox in color, aroma and flavor
we thought, hello cup o joe

wet chinook double ipa (8.5 abv) a single hop variety double ipa brewed with fresh chinook hops and dry hopped with even more chinook...a citrusy, piney, resin laden annual treat
we were big fans, hoppy but not bitter

60 shilling (cask)
lighter scottish-style ale ale (4.75% abv)...amber and malty... sometimes there are not enough o's in smooth
we thought it was one of the favorites undertones of vanilla for us

Finally tried the pasta in the upstairs restaurant and was very very happy with the Tagiatelle with cream and speck and the Mushroom Gnocchi.  Both are made with a cream sauce and the pasta is incredibly tender and the toppings ratio just right.  The speck was flavorful and crispy and perfectly balanced by a sprinkling of fresh peas.  The crab linguine was solid but the cream-based pastas were definitely the highlights.  The bread presentation with an individual plating of EVOO, pepper, and Parmesan was also great - plus the panne was incredibly soft and fresh with a flavorful crust.  Of course, the desserts were amazing.  Try the banana bread pudding with fior de latte gelato - the pudding is tender with a crispy crust and a great combination with the creamy gelato.  Service was fantastic and among the best in Phila.  Definitely a must-visit!

Great little neighborhood bar with a great little courtyard for music and entertainment. The food here is good and above all are the wings. The cajun wings are some of the best wings I have ever eaten. So good.

Vacation in Edmonton?  Yes, my wife and daughter made me go to the West Edmonton Mall not once, but, twice during our recent vacation.  Yes, we have our share of malls in Southern California.  But, none of them can compare to the size of the WEM.  At 3.8 million sq ft, the WEM mall easily beats South Coast Plaza and their measly 2.7 million square feet.  

You want shopping?  They got it!  They have all sorts of shops from high end retailers to stores like Dollarama.  Restaurants?  They have restaurants from fast food, to sit down fancy restaurants.  You can even be like me and bring your stash from Dollarama into the Halley's Club without getting a snarky attitude from the staff.  You need entertainment?  This mall has an ice skating rink, a replica of the ship, the Santa Maria, an amusement park, movie theaters and a water park.  If you need something more adult, they have a casino and casino related restaurants for you.  Let's not forget your Asian groceries from T&T Market. It's Dynomite!  My parents and in-laws definitely would stop at T&T, but, you would never find me in there as long as I am on vacation. They even have the Fantasyland Hotel here if you don't want to drive back home or to your hotel. 

Edmonton people are so nice!  My daughter left her brand new iPhone in the bathroom stall of the Hudson Bay Department Store.  What was she doing with the phone in the stall, I don't know.  But someone found the phone and gave it to lost and found.  If she left the phone in a bathroom stall in California, the phone would never be returned.  

It's ginormous, and is larger than any other mall I've been to.  Even though we went there twice, I know there are places that we missed.  Why do I have to go shopping while on vacation?

I feel like I have to update my review after having gone through a one-month intro membership with the Hot Room.

Simply put: I loved it. The instructors are amazing, which is the reason why I loved it the most. They're personal, there for YOU and your health, and put a smile on my face every time I attended. 

Outside of the Hot Room, I usually tend to go to vinyasa yoga as Bikram usually isn't my style. However, I would say that I completely switch my go-to at the Hot Room. The vinyasa is very challenging in my opinion and the sweat dripping from your personal bits into your face is never a good feeling as you're in downward dog. 

I LOVED bikram mostly because it's the same thing every time so you're able to 1) see your progress being made and your growth; and 2) you can make it a meditative state. 

I went 20 times in my first month (short because it was February) and I loved it. I felt great, but towards the end of my month, I could tell that going that often was not good for my body. I could feel exhaustion at all times of the day and towards the end, I felt that my body needed like 24 hours of solid sleep, so the intro month was a perfect amount for me.

My reason for the lower stars: the price. It's insanely expensive and not accessible at all to me at my current income/expenses, which is unfortunate. That being said, don't like that deter you from trying it. Buy the intro month and check it out for yourself. I believe that if you sign onto a membership after your first month, you can get the 2nd month for $59 (or $69?) and then the 3rd month for $89 and then it jumps to the normal $99 a month. 

After the intro month, I could see and feel changes in my body, so I knew it was working. 

Notes/tips/comments: 
- take your shoes off before you head back to the locker rooms
- try out the intro month (or there's currently a Groupon)
- download the app - it made booking and cancelling classes insanely easy
- consume electrolytes basically 24/7. Even with that, my body still didn't feel back to its normal self
- check out their social media pages: they have lots of free community classes throughout the month
- be ready to do lots and lots (and then some) laundry

Overall, a great experience and I LOVED doing it during February when the winter gets me down the most. But sadly, the price is just not worth it. Maybe for $50 less a month, I'd consider it, but at $99 a month, it's just not feasible.

Great brunch spot, especially for the morning where you woke up after drinking ridiculously too much the previous night. You'll get all the carbs here you need to soak up that leftover alcohol and get that belly ready for more debauchery. Had some awesome sausage gravy biscuits and some fried chicken. Definitely worth the wait outside. If you are lucky, you may have Darth Vader entertain you with his music and cool dance moves.

Wow, I came to this gym as my girlfriend's guest to take a zumba class.  All I can say is that this is the creme de la creme of gyms!  Of course the price reflects the amenities of this gym so there's that.  But my girlfriend works with one of the partnering Elmwood groups so she gets a discount.  Plus, if she works out a certain number of times during the month then she gets an additional discount!  Too bad my job doesn't have that relationship otherwise I would seriously consider switching!

This seems to be a very family friendly gym with kid rooms, indoor swimming kid classes, families in the pool together etc.  I didn't even go upstairs but seriously this gym has everything.  There is a lounge area where you can get coffee or food, there is a gym shop in the front, they let you use nice fluffy towels as soon as you walk in, there is a HUGE weight/cardio room, a nice size indoor pool, the women's locker room is posh with lockers made of wood, showering facilities.  It's frigging amazing!  
If I had a family I would definitely sign up for this gym because there is so much for the kids to do.  

As for the zumba class, it was awesome!  We went on a Wednesday night and the instructor was on a platform so it was easy to see her.  Plus there were other instructors in the front on both sides so you could follow them as well.  It was an awesome workout and the people in the class were very nice in helping us pick up the steps for the routine!

Happy Working Out!

I had been given a recommendation to see Alyssa for a hair cut and style. Oh my goodness, I had not been given such a great style in years. I  was so impressed I gave a cut and color to my girl friend as a gift. Her reaction was the same as mine. Best cut and color in several years. Besides being extremely talented she's just a pleasure being around. Just the way she carriers herself, she's  just the absolute professional. I absolutely recommend doing yourself a favor to visit Alyssa for your hair care needs.

I know someone is totally going to call me out on this, but I love love love Le Madeleine's Chicken Caesar Salad and, short of someone making the dressing fresh in front of me, it's the best I've ever had. 

I am also head over heels for their potato soup with cheese and bacon. And it's not fake old bacon bits, it's real bacon. I use the complimentary bread and basically eat the entire thing by bread dip instead of with a spoon. 

This La Madeleine is small and parking can be a little bit of a stink, but I don't mind coming here by myself to enjoy lunch. I also do to-go often from here, though the salad isn't a quarter as good as when they make it in the restaurant. 

I've considered buying the dressing to take home, but again, I fear it will lose it's Caesar dressing luster if I try to recreate what I love so much. 

The staff is always pretty sweet too, even when I order take out 10 minutes before they close. ;)

Cheap and good.  I got a lamb tikka on pita, and it was very flavorful, although a little on the dry side.  The pita was soft and chewy, and the tahini was very good.  I am still loyal to Meze but this is a decent option for kabobs downtown (only $6 for a pita!).  I'll be back to try the chicken next time.

We stopped in for lunch today after a last-minute dash to The Honeybaked Ham Company, and it was very quiet.  I got the Dynasty Seafood lunch special, which was decent, with a quarter of a lobster tail, 2 jumbo shrimp, and 2 jumbo scallops, along with celery, snow peas, corn, bamboo, water chestnuts, and shitake mushrooms in a light sauce.  The sauce had a bit too much starch in it, though, as some of the vegetables were coated unevenly.  The dry pot style fish fillet was decent although it is no Han Dynasty.  The stir-fried kidneys was also okay, but nothing too special.  Both were only mildly spicy.  Service was just barely passable, as our waiter pretty much scowled the entire time, not just at us, but at everyone.  The other servers appeared to be much more pleasant.  

It has been well over a year since I have last been here, and it's not the Lai Lai that I remembered.  The food quality and definitely the service is not what it used to be.  Hopefully, they realize this and can turn things around, as it really does not seem to be nearly as busy as it was in the past.

I went to Green Lemon this past Taco Tuesday with a couple of Yelpers and some new friends. I have been here before but I don't think I have ever visited on Taco Tuesday due to the long wait times and hectic environment. Our party of five had a 45 minute wait for a table. While I would have loved to have a drink while waiting, the bar is nearly impossible to access since there is seating there as well. Since it was hot, humid and about to rain out we opted to stand inside near the doorway and dodge the passersby. We were seated at a table for 4 and pulled up a 5th seat from a neighboring table to make it work. 

I must give kudos to our server, Dustin, who was working many tables and got our orders completely accurate. He was attentive and friendly despite the chaos of Taco Tuesday. He was also responsible for fulfilling our secret request to give the birthday girl a sweet surprise. It's those little things that go a long way.

FOOD: On Tuesdays, all Street Tacos are $2 all day. The selections have recently been updated, but there are still plenty of choices. Chicken, pork, beef, mahi mahi, tuna, and even cauliflower as a vegetarian option are available. I opted for a Grilled Mahi Mahi and a Kung Fu'd Tuna wrapped in Bibb lettuce instead of a tortilla (you can choose hard or soft if you want more of a shell). I must say that they are very well stuffed with fresh and flavorful ingredients! Probably the best $2 Taco Tuesday deal I've had in a long time!! Someone at our table was also celebrating a birthday and the waiter brought out Churros with ice cream for dessert. They were warm and crispy...I'm not a sweets person but they were delicious! In the past I've had the nachos during Happy Hour which are $5 and they are also very plentiful and delicious. The food here is very good. 

DRINKS: Taco Tuesday offers up $3 Coronas, $8 Skinny Margaritas, and $20 massive margaritas. Drinks are made well and as expected. The other drink prices are comparable to the area. I'd say an average of $8-$12 for cocktails. 

Parking during high volume times can be very frustrating. There is a designated lot across the street which fills up fast and is hard to access due to tight spaces. Side streets also offer limited parallel parking due to recent building of apartments nearby. Prepare to circle or walk from another location. 

Overall, Green Lemon is a great little trendy Mexican place on South Howard. While I wouldn't consider it true Mexican cuisine, they do a great job of satisfying the locale with a trendy menu and a party environment. Prices are good and it's a nice place to check out. If you are fine with large crowds, tons of noise and are patient...give Taco Tuesday a try! It's a great deal and your hunger will be satisfied.

You can never go wrong at a Starbucks, they are always consistent. Since this place is on Canal it gets crowded, but the line goes fast. There is an assembly line attitude here and the employees are hustling.

Cute coffee shop with excellent iced coffee and great pastries. I enjoyed a ham and cheese croissant which was flaky, buttery deliciousness. 

I read something on their website about how tables can be reserved for $10/hour. Since I was meeting with one of my team members I decided to reserve a table for two hours. When I arrived on that weekday morning, the coffee shop was empty save for one or two other people. So, I most likely wouldn't formally reserve a table again unless I was going at a peak time - seemed like kind of a waste of money. Although, your reservation does get you a 20% discount on all food and drink orders. And I suppose if you really needed to guarantee a table for a work meeting, it's good to know that Rally offers this, since I can't think of a single other place that does. So there's pros and cons to that. 

I am looking forward to returning!

Absolutely the best pizza this side of Naples, not to mention, exceptional service, chill ambiance, great wine list & other Italian specialties... WINNING combination!

Simply can't get enough of Domenica!!!

So, this was kind of weird. Rated on food alone this restaurant is DEFINITELY 5 stars. I had the BEST hot pastrami sandwich and Caesar salad IN THE WORLD. But something my guest and I witnessed was disgusting and turned us off to this place for a second visit in the future. 

We were greeted by a woman (assumed) to be the owner. I was correct on that assumption. She was rude and grumpy to us as we entered. Not a smile from her, not a welcome. Nothing. 

The young man who took our order was very good. After our food was served my guest and I observed this woman (owner) berate another staff person right in front of us. She yelled at the employee, "this isn't your job. Go over there." (The young employee was at the bar working - at least she was staying busy and doing something!) 

It was a horrible display of unprofessionalism by that owner and I was embarrassed for that poor girl. I really doubt I'll be here again.

I don't come here as often as I'd like simply because of the location. This place is located on a very busy intersection, and the parking lot sucks! Very limited spots and not to mention a tight squeeze. 

If you don't know the area then I recommend parking on the street but that's only if you're lucky to find a spot. Weekends are usually the best to get parking. 

Aside from that this place is a must try if you're craving authentic Mexican food! They offer burritos, tacos, sopes, alambres, etc...

My fave has to be the chicken Tinga sopes which is shredded marinated chicken and the gorditas! The sope and gorditas are both handmade with masa. What I love about them is the thickness is made just right and not too much. I can actually finish them without being overly stuffed. 

I've also had the chicken taquitos plate which was a good deal under $10! Very yummy and satisfying. 

The carne asada burrito was good but the amount of meat was lacking yet again! Another restaurant that skimps on the main feature. 

Overall this place is legit and I look forward to trying more items on the menu.

After much positive press I finally was able to venture over to Continental Provisions and it was a great experience. I ordered the pimento cheese sandwich and it was great. As a fan of pimento cheese this is ridiculously good. and at under $10 in one of the most touristy places you can find in the world this huge sandwich on artisan bread is a great deal. Arugula, sliced apples and fresh jalapeno along with pimento cheese and artisan bread makes for a great lunch and its actually big enough for two people.
Was very happy to see this place open up in downtown SB or funk zone. They have fantastic beer selection, good food, great bartenders, great atmosphere and a fun outdoor indoor location.

When I learned that the pastry chef who made my wedding cake was taking over a local bakery in Wayne, I immediately marked my calendar for a visit! Marqessa Gesualdi is not only extremely talented, she's also lovely to work with and truly cares about creating the best experience possible for her clients. 

Alisha S and I popped into Aux Petits Delices for some morning sugar. We shared the flaky napoleon and the ultra rich delice - both were incredible! The delice put me into a near sugar coma, but the combination of dark chocolate and hazelnut were irresistible. 

The bakery also sells baguettes, croissants and chocolates. They have some seating, and serve La Colombe coffee, so you can enjoy a sweet treat right in the shop. I am so happy Marqessa has landed in her very own bakery and cannot wait to commission her for a (smaller) replica of my amazing wedding cake sometime in the future!

Why 4 stars? Because it's another solid ice cream option in our 'hood.

   ---   ---   ---

Twistee Treat is one of those places that's located super close to my house, but somehow, I've spent years driving right by it without stopping in. But recently after a fun dinner out with the wife, we were both craving ice cream and TT came right to mind!

The menu is so vast that it's almost overwhelming. I'm usually a very quick decision maker with these kinds of things, but I was really feeling the pressure of having to decide on something after starring at the menu for a couple minutes and having no idea what to choose. 

I saw in another Yelp review that someone really enjoyed the butterscotch shake, but I also saw that marshmallow was a flavor you could order in shake form, which is always a favorite of mine. So I decided what seemed most natural - a shake that was half of each flavor to combine the best of both worlds!

I have to say that I thoroughly enjoyed this concoction! I'm not sure if I would have liked a full butterscotch or full marshmallow shake even more, but the blend of the two was great. 

My wife ordered a sundae and it was pretty much your average sundae. I thought the nuts were the best part, but once those were gone, I was a bit bored as I was trying to help her finish it.

We will definitely think of Twistee Treat in the future when we're craving sweets!

Royal House is located just off bourbon street and offered a high end feeling dinner for an affordable price. We opted to sit upstairs and we're seated by the window for an incredible view. 

Thanks to Yelp, we cashed in our free appetizer and enjoyed spinach artichoke dip in the house. It was hot, cheesy, and delicious. 

Our meal did not let us down either. The seafood was incredible fresh. Being from Dallas, I could taste the difference. 

If you are in the area and want to venture away from the craziness of bourbon street, Royal House offers a great ambiance, delicious food, and southern hospitality.
We had the bibimbob and the pajeon (korean pancake). Those 2 dishes for 2 people were just enough and the price for it all was awesome.

Become a member of the club, you'll get money off gas for your first 30 days. Plus with every fill up you'll get a special offer, You really can't beat that.  The representitives inside are pretty awesome, very friendly and they have almost every soda known to god at their soda bar in the back. 

The gas pumps are clean and shiny, very comfortable to use.

The name says it all!

Their initiatives help our community SO much and if you haven't volunteered with them before, you should. Their work so directly affects our community and therefore it's so fun to get involved, especially when the initiatives come to your neighborhood. They have neighborhood-based initiatives and 'clean ups.' 

They do everything from planting trees, to providing recycling bins for events. They fix-up murals, add flowerbeds, mulch, and so much more. 

Check them out: there's tons of new projects that are always updated on their page.

Who does not love this place? Every corner is filled with food and things to drool over. I've been here a couple of times and each time you end up trying something new. Sometimes I wish I lived nearby so that I could take advantage of all their fresh produce. 

I highly recommend Bassetts. DiNic's was pretty good too. The Spice/tea/coffee shop near the bookstore is really of great value!

Why 5 stars? Because you'll pay for it, but it's hard to imagine the quality being better with any other fence company.

   ---   ---   ---

We bought our house a few years ago and one of the first things we planned on doing was upgrading the existing fence. Unfortunately, we spent our money elsewhere and found ourselves making due with a pretty beaten down fence since we moved in. But after about the 15th time where some boards just fell down, we decided that it was finally time.

I walk my dog a lot through the nearby neighborhoods and every time I see a super nice fence that really stands out, it's always a Redman Fence. And I've had Redman bookmarked on Yelp for years because of the great ratings. So maybe this wasn't the smartest decision, but we had Redman come out to give us a quote and the next day and quickly opted to put down a deposit without getting a quote elsewhere.

When I've mentioned to people how much our fence cost, the reaction is usually that we paid a bit more. That may be so, but I think it was worth it for three reasons:

1) The quality of the product is top notch.

2) Reliability of the installers - they actually showed up when they said they would every day, which is a rarity in this industry, sadly.

3) They offered financing for a low fee.

I'll nitpick here and mention a few things I didn't love, just to give the full spectrum of our experience:

1) We were told by the owner that it would only be one day that our fence would be down before the new one would be up enough to keep pets in. That ended up not being true at all - the project started on a Monday and by the end of the day on Thursday, the perimeter with the other houses was secure enough for pets, but our gate was the last thing to be put up, which did not happen until the following Monday. Now that I've seen a fence install from start to finish, the owner quoting us "one day" was very unrealistic.

2) The guys cleaned up a bit, but also definitely let some trash scattered around. They also left some yard debris and it would have been nice for them to either take it or at least offer to put everything in our yard trash can that was sitting empty in the backyard.

That's really about it, though. Overall, the product turned out great. The installers were here every day but Sunday and they'd work from around 10:30a-5:30p, seemingly without a break. It was about one month from the time we put down a deposit until the install began. 

The quality of their work is top notch and I'm really happy that I will not even have to think about my fence for the rest of the time we live in this house.

Pan D'olive was recommended to me by a few of the local guys I work with in St. Louis.  The first time I came through, I just missed happy hour, which happens to be VERY popular here.  The bar was crowded, but I was able to snag a seat!  I was glad I did, because Tony, the bartender, was truly entertaining!  He was a super cool cat and remembered me the next time I came through!

Anyway, I was starving on my first visit, so I ordered snails for the appetizer and a whole branzini.  Both dishes were excellently prepared.  The snails were sitting in a creamy sauce that was delectable!  And the branzini came as a whole fish, I have to be honest, I was expecting a filet.  But I have no qualms about eating the whole fish, and I basically ate it down to the bone!  Since I was at an establishment, I didn't get down and dirty with the fish head, if I was in the comfort of my own home, it's a different story...

The second time I came around, I ordered the lamb shank.  It was falling off the bone, and simply divine!  I highly recommend ordering the lamb shank, I wish I had done this the first time!

So, if I were in the St. Louis area, I would come for the food, stay for the company!

Simply stunning!  George Baker provided all the floral arrangements for my former law firm - and also sent arrangements to all new hires (nice touch!).  The floral choices were always high-end and fresh.  No carnation and babies breath here.  

Fresh Delphinium, Alliums, Bells of Ireland, Lilies, Rare Orchids - the works.

I love George Baker.  Pricey - but so worth it.

Elegance in a glass container!

It's really hard for me to give a spot a 1 star rating, I reserve that for a truly awful experience. Cosi was bad. 
I was on my way to see a movie at the Ritz Bourse (a very entertaining movie called "Kill The Irishman") and I was early so I walked across the street to Cosi for a quick bite. Well it wasn't quick and I miss a couple of minutes of the flick. 
There was only I guy in line, but I still had to wait 10 minutes to order my meal. I chose the Buffalo Bleu sandwich, a bowl of Tomato Basil Soup and a cup of Coffee. It took awhile to order because the cashier was busy doing everything else but taking orders. She repeated "I'll be with you in a moment 3 times. They give you a numbered place card that you have to display on a wired cardholder so one of the server can locate your table. 
The restaurant wasn't crowded at all (hint, hint) and I could of sat anywhere, I was going to sit in one of those odd shaped booths, but they looked dirtier that the backseat of a Bronx Taxicab on a Saturday midnight run, so I sat in one of the small table for two feeling like I was sitting at a third grader sized school desk & chair. 
The food came and it was so bland-how can you call something Buffalo Chicken with absolutely zero spice? And the bread was some fake rustic, gummy square that was totally tasteless. The soup was OK and the coffee was average at best. And to top it off, I really had to go to the bathroom and my teeth were floating, but the way to the men's room was like a freakin maze! I counted 5 turns till you reach the toilet, bloody hell!!

I love my Marriotts! Let's start with my seamless check-in. Rhia was so sweet. She was able to quickly find my mobile check-in. She even walked around the corner to give me my keys. 

Our room was on the 28th floor. Loved the view of the Mississippi view. Our room was giant, but the bathroom was pretty small. The light in the bathroom was bright! I called the lighting "the hangover fixer". It's soooo bright.

For you platinum elite and higher Marriott rewards peeps, the M lounge is great! Breakfast includes made-to-order omelettes and fresh made beignets. There was a huge spread, including exotic fruit. Loved the papaya and dragonfruit.

The location of the hotel was great. We were literally 2 blocks from Bourbon Street. I have stayed at the Ritz Carlton and the Saint in NOLA, by far this Marriott is the best location for easy access to the French Quarters. 

NOLA was a success and would definitely stay at this Marriott again!

I'm updating my review to 4 stars from 3.

Since our last visit, U Play has changed their pricing to include unlimited trampoline time with their play.

This makes soooooo much more sense and I can say we will definitely be back soon!

Pro Tip - cone early on Saturday or Sunday and play.  Leave and then come back in the evening for more play!  Skip middle of day rush and chill out at home and fuel up!

The renovated Fenway Hotel is a nice addition to the area.  One of the best parts is this new rooftop bar.  The have cocktails, wine, and a good selection of craft beer.  I had the burger and fries.  It was delicious and a huge portion.  Try to get here at sunset and you'll definitely enjoy your visit.

Nicks is fried seafood place. They have good deal on fried shrimp. The place look like a take out place. They do have a few table if you want to dine there. Parking is available on the plaza lot. 

We got seafood combo with fried tilapia and shrimp. It come with 10 shrimps and two pieces fried tilapia. You can choose different types of fish. The coating is crispy. It is also light seasoning. We also got 1/2 pounds fried gizzards. The coating is medium seasoning. I actually like their gizzard seasoning. Both dishes are good to have. Love munching on the gizzard. 

Wait time is bearable from the start of order. You can call in to save time.

Santa's Naughty Little Yelpers decided to meet up for an Unofficial Yelp Event at The Shops at Wiregrass in Wesley Chapel to enjoy the spectacular Christmas lights. But first, we elected to stop for dinner at 900 degree Wood-Fired Pizza at the mall.

Unfortunately many of our naughty little elves were home sick, nursing colds and assorted ickies, but Erin P, Robbie C, Joel H and I forced ourselves to party like rockstars and enjoy some outstanding pizza and great laughs.

The temps were a bit chilly that night, but we were able to sit outside on their covered patio right next to a big ol' propane gas heater. The patio was enclosed on three sides with heavy canvas siding, and the heaters were pumping out the BTU's all evening, so we were quite toasty.

900 Degree Wood-Fired Pizza is family owned pizzeria restaurant that serves both Neapolitan-style wood-fired pizza and the traditional thin-crust NY-Style pizza. I read about the two different styles of pizzas and opted to try one of the smaller Neapolitan pizzas. These are made with Antico Caputo "00" flour imported from Italy, and the sauce is made from crushed San Marzano DOP tomatoes with basil. Nothing else. I read on the menu that the cheese is fresh, imported mozzarella and all of their toppings are cooked and prepared from scratch. YUM!!!!

I started with their Mista salad which was mixed greens, tomatoes, onions, and homemade Italian dressing, and followed that with a 12 " Capricciosa wood-fired pizza that had the San Marzano tomato sauce, fresh mozzarella slices, artichoke hearts, ham, mushrooms, Kalamata olives and fresh basil. Seriously amazing!

The menu has a wide variety of suggested specialty pizzas, or you can choose to build your own, and add whatever toppings you like. They also serve salads, calzones, pasta dishes, and dessert pizzas made with Nutella and other yummy stuff.

The four of us had a great time enjoying our food and socializing next to the space heaters. We declared the restaurant a big success, and I'll gladly make the haul from Carrollwood up to Wesley Chapel to try another one of their pizzas.

By the way, the lights on the Christmas tree at the mall are synched to Trans-Siberian Orchestra's music, which made for a great show. They also had two vocal groups who were belting out the Holiday hits and Christmas standards. We thoroughly enjoyed our informal get-together of excellent pizza and Christmas cheer with good friends.
This place is mediocre at best. The menu isn't anything special, the food is very okay...when you have so many other tasty options in the neighborhood, wouldn't you want to strive to stand out more?

I think I'm hooked. I've been itching to go to one of Ballet Idaho's shows for years, and I am thrilled that my first experience was with the Christmas classic, The Nutcracker. 

There were so many components of this performance that won me over--the combination of professional dancers performing with children from Ballet Idaho's Academy, the live music played by the Boise Philarmonic, and the contrast of beautiful dancing paired with humorous bits that got the whole audience chuckling. 

In my opinion, the first act is mostly storytelling, whereas the second act features the more complex dance pieces. I enjoyed both parts equally and thought that they combined to make for a dreamy entertainment experience--one that was both intelligent and humorous.

The entire show had me pulled in with the same wide-eyed wonder my friend's three-year-old daughter had. I think that is perhaps my favorite part of this whole experience, the feel in the building is so child-like. Before and after the show and during intermission, the lobby of the Morrison Center was buzzing with people of all ages. And during intermission, the top balcony overlooking the lobby outside of the auditorium had a group of grade-school kids singing Christmas carols. 

To put the cherry on top of an already amazing evening, as soon as we stepped out of the building, we experienced our first Boise snowfall of the year. Talk about magical, eh?

Pro Tip: If you are parking in the garage right outside of the Morrison Center, try to get there a little early and get a space on the first floor. We parked on the second floor and it took us about half an hour to get out. Eeeeeep.

The hotel itself is beautiful and a very nice place to stay. Service was also up to par. They remembered us throughout our stay, which was a nice touch. I would highly recommend spending a night here (I loved the style of the rooms and the fireplace!). The views outside are gorgeous and they have a state of the art fitness center. 

We also came for afternoon tea, which I would not recommend. The tea was great but the food was either very dry or sweet. We have had better experiences at Mandarin Oriental and Four Seasons. Not worth the $$$ in my opinion.

My review is strictly based on visiting the Campus and the beauty it holds.  

This campus is truly one of the most appealing around.  The Swarthmore campus is nestled in the middle of a residential neighborhood with exquisite mansions.  The campus has old stone buildings and never ending paths that take you on a journey through the manicured gardens with older trees and native plants to Pennsylvania.  

The campus offers some picturesque scenery perfect for events like weddings or some breathtaking photography.  Touring the campus is the perfect way to spend the afternoon with family or a romantic stroll with a loved one.

The new MD Oriental Market in Brandon looks amazing. Shopping at the one on Fowler will be so much harder after experiencing this MD. The walls shine brand new. All the aisles are perfectly clean, busy workers keeping them up for shoppers. The place is large and big enough for it's clients. They have some sweet deals on food if you're hungry...I can't remember the exact price, but I'm pretty sure it was under $5 maybe even under $4? The roast duck looked really good. It is so clean it reminds me of a Publix actually and they even have these little stands with recipes so you can find what you're looking for or maybe decide what to buy with their help. The workers are were friendly and the selection of things to buy was great as well. I found all my favorite Asian snacks. So happy to have this in town :)

I always stop at this rest area because of three key features...

Clean facilities. 

A fresh ocean breeze. 

An amazing view of Tampa Bay. 

I always feel refreshed after stopping here and ready to finish the journey home via the skyway bridge. Drive safe!

More like St. Loose Bubble Tea if the bathroom activities are anything to go by.

OK, I can't back that up.

But I can back *this* up. (Pulls Down Pants)

What to get: This is just a wild guess... but maybe some Bubble Tea.
What not to get: Any more Loose than you already are, while in here.

Really nice place, and I got to know it well as I hung out here for a few hours. The one big problem was that people inside were asking me for money and asking me to buy them things. It's a tough city, STL, indeed. 

The products were pretty good. Not amazing, but then I'm very spoiled by very good bubble tea. Employees were generally really nice. Bathrooms were gross but at least they had them. And I absolutely love the writings in the bathroom.

I would give this place three stars but the bartender Ryan was nice and made an awesome chocolate martini so I'll give you four stars.

My friend and I ordered the oyster duo which tasted good but Drago's is still my favorite. For my main dish I ordered the shrimp and grits which were meh. I've had better. My friend ordered the fried shrimp platter and thoroughly enjoyed it. It came with hush puppies and fries as well. But the creme de la creme was the bananas foster cheesecake! Man, it may not look good but it is party in your mouth food! Oh yeah!!

I won't mention names but our waitress was kind of ditzy and didn't really check on us. I had to flag her down for things which I hate doing. Maybe she had an off night. 

My friend told me there is balcony dining upstairs which would be great for daytime people watching. 

Oh and check in because Yelp has a free appetizer with purchase dealio!

Happy Quarter dining!

I've rented from Budget dozens and dozens of times literally all over the world.  I got a great experience as usual.  Fastbreak reservation - which meant I just got to skip the line and walk upstairs and get a car.  The person who handled my pickup, Lowell, served up some great and friendly conversation while my car came around.

Thanks, as always, guys.

Really really enjoyed our meal at Commanders. I thought it was reasonably priced, well portioned and the atmosphere in general was elegant and poised. Alot of what I expected given the dress code restrictions but overwhelmed in general rather than underwhelmed is always good. I kept my eyes peeled for Sandra Bullock. This was a random weekday dinner in her neighborhood and I figured a Thursday night seemed like an ideal day to visit if I were a celebrity....but she wasn't there. Some of her friends may have been but I wouldn't have recognized them. 

We had multiple wait staff taking care of us...so many I lost track but overall good service. The french potato puree was exceptional and very memorable ( I can close my eyes and remember the taste). I also ordered the Pecan Pie just because it's a personal favorite but I've heard the bread pudding is their staple and also the people's choice. I'm not a fan of raisins in my bread pudding so that lured me astray. 

Overall a really good choice. Would definitely recommend and come again.

As an avid lover of books, I'll admit that I've been spending some of my recent driving time in the community checking on the welfare of our local, indie bookstores and doing what I can do to support them as they work to survive what has been a challenging pandemic for even the sturdiest of businesses. 

Books on Sale is a little gem that has, I think much to the surprise of many, survived several years now since it first opened in 2008 in its nondescript corner of Southern Plaza across a rear parking lot from the AMC Showplace 17. 

Books on Sale is a sister store to Red Dog Books. It looks and feels like a non-corporate Half-Price Books because that's essentially what it is. Books on Sale offers a Buy 3 Get 2 Free deal and it's hard to imagine visiting here and not finding 5 books, or many more, that you would want. 

Books on Sale offers new, used, and remainder items. They nearly always have sale tables. I would note that they are "disorganized" in the sense that they do not electronically catalogue their books and they do not have a logged inventory according to their website. They do have some awareness of what they offer, but this is a used bookstore at its heart and you're going to have to do some scavenging. Personally? I enjoy that. 

Books on Sale offers books, CDs, DVDs, journals, vinyl, audio books, and they have an entire room at 50% off. This place is surprisingly huge. 

While Books on Sale is relatively disorganized, it's also surprisingly well kept and neat. As a wheelchair user, I had little difficulty with most of the aisles and there's accessible parking and easy curbs at Southern Plaza. Southern Plaza went through a renovation a few years back and has a weird vibe that is both contemporary and retro. 

Vinyl prices start at $1.98. All single DVDs and CDs are $1.98. They have collections of TV series marked at $3.98. I mean, seriously. Their prices are easily better than chains and some of these prices are better than what you'd find at a garage sale. 

Employees are always friendly, though you should probably not expect them to know the exact location of that 13th copy of Twilight that you need. Generally, they can point you in the right direction and you'll need to do some searching. 

I love bookstores like Books on Sale. It's cozy, warm, has a bookstore feeling, and is locally owned and operated. Prices are fair and they have a little bit of everything. This is one of Indy's true gems and I was so relieved to return last evening while at a promo screening across the street and see that Books on Sale continues to survive and thrive in its corner as a beacon for indie bookstores here in Indy.

A beautiful independently owned studio in the heart of Ewing!  Empower Yoga is a breath of fresh air, just like the owner, Keri, is herself!  

Walking into the studio, you can tell it was a labor of love - every detail had been pre-planned and thoughtfully implemented; from the colorful organization/storage for guests' belongings, to the aromatherapy diffuser, multiple benches, and even the bathrooms with a shower (yes, a SHOWER) stocked with soaps and amenities for those who need to shower before work/leaving yoga.  Everytime I walk in, I'm welcomed with a smile and a genuine conversation from either the owner herself, or one of her amazing staff members.

I've taken a variety of classes from different instructors, and each one is better than the last - some of my favorites include Hip Hop Yoga (get ready to sweat your booty off in this one!) and any class that Keri teaches (she's going to challenge you).  Most classes are intense Core Power Yoga, and the owner is an amazing yogi/marathoner/crossfit coach/ironman champion - she's usually found before class happily chatting with her students discussing safety while working out or ways to make adjustments in order to avoid triggering injuries if you're struggling with something.  It's very comforting to know that she's conscious about this, and looking out for her students! 

The studio is a feature in the relatively new Campus Town at TCNJ - there (at this point) is usually available parking outside the studio doors, or around the corner.  Parking is free (bonus!)  There is one studio room, but it's very large (with super high ceilings).  There are 2 doors into/out of the room, which adds to great air flow and helps rapidly cool the room from the ~93 degrees in which we practice.  

One thing to note, the studio does hot yoga, which I've never experienced but I am now a total convert.  The studio is complete with a humidifier to maintain a healthy heat for the yogis.  Despite everyone dripping sweat by the end (or to be realistic, within 3 minutes of class starting), the studio smells clean and fresh - there is a lot of attention to keeping the studio clean and smell free, which is greatly appreciated!  The scents are never overpowering or artificial - despite it being a yoga studio, it feels a little bit like walking into a spa.  Each class is finished with an eucalyptus-scented cold damp towel, which is provided during savasana - a blissful way to end an amazing workout! 

Empower Yoga is committed to being part of the community, and often has multiple community events going on - from community fundraising classes, to trainings, and even promotions.  This month (October 2018) she's running a challenge for her students, anyone who comes 3/week for the entire month is entered into a raffle to win prizes, gift certificates, or experiences from other local Campus Town businesses.  Work out more to win prizes - sounds like a win-win!

Prices are pretty competitive for the area - and discounts are offered the more often you attend.  Currently there's a $40 unlimited for 4 weeks pass offered to new guests only.  Regular drop-in classes are $12, but class packs are offered at an even lower rate: 5 class pack- $55, 10 class pack- $100, and 20 class packs- $180.  Online lists discounts for student/military/seniors and monthly/annual auto-enroll as well.  

Come check it out - you probably won't want to leave!

First Person Arts is a first class organization. Their events are meaningful, well-run, well-staffed and always a great time. I attended my first Story Slam last week and it happened to be a Grand Slam - pretty much a guarantee for great narratives and funny deliveries. 

Before the Slam was an optional pre-party barbecue catered by Sweet Lucy's and Victory Brewing Company. I cannot say enough great things about Sweet Lucy's and their delicious smoked meats and hearty sides. Experiencing them once again only reminded me that I need to return to the mothership soon, likely with a sixer of Victory brew.

The Slam took place in a large, air-conditioned theater with better than average folding chairs and the right amount of leg room. Every participant followed the rules and the time guidelines, and the event moved along seamlessly, with a short but necessary break for intermission. 

If you haven't yet seen or participated in a Story Slam, they take place about once a month and they provide a fun, different kind of night out.

There's something about seeing a show at IRT that brings out an unexplainable, intense need for hot chocolate afterwards.  Good thing I can get my fix at nearby South Bend Chocolate Company, which uses real chocolate in every cup.  My go-to is their Mexican hot chocolate, in which cinnamon and cayenne are added to the beverage.  That little bit of spice is just the kick I need in order to enjoy a rich, comforting cup of cocoa.

Please keep in mind this was my first time here and I have minimal experiences with horse tracks. I am not a gambler. I came on a week day. I was able to park easily and quickly get inside. I can see on a busy day how this might not be the case. They do offer valet. I went on a Wednesday and entry was free. On other days it is a few dollars. The facility had a dirty rundown feel to it, to me. I have not been around so many people who smoke in probably 20 years. Smoke happens to really bother me so I had issues being comfortable breathing!! Lol. You may stand outside along the track to watch the horses race. We sat in the box seating area. This was not any nicer other than the fact it was covered and you had a seat. Visually I could see just fine. Drinks were cheap. Thank goodness they had alcohol to ease my discomfort  in being here! They do have a limited menu, however I only got popcorn. Food prices were inexpensive. I understand they do have lots of activities on weekends that are family friendly. In one review, I read that they will open up a gate where you can picnic and bring lawn chairs. I might like to try this so I can soak up the sun. I found the experience to be underwhelming. Years ago I went to a track in New Jersey that was much nicer than what I observed here.

What deserves 5 stars:
- the amount of options of food
- the menu changes weekly  
- the beautiful view outside 
- the concept of donating money back to the Patachou Foundation (its biggest selling point in my opinion) 
- the source of the food
- the decor and atmosphere and design of the restaurant 

What deserves 3-4 stars:
- the actual food was good, but nothing I would die for 
- the pricing is a bit high BUT it mostly goes to charity so the price is okay with me

Overall, I'll be back for sure since the menu changes so often. A good restaurant all in all. 

I need to try the desserts the next time I'm there!

One of the more popular spots in St. Petersburg (obviously) since it took us quite a long time to get a table. We were able to enjoy some drinks at the outside bar while we waited for a table indoors. They have a nice outdoor patio but on this particular evening, it was a touch too chilly to eat outdoors. The sangria was okay.

We were a fairly low-maintenance 6-top but since our server would disappear for semi-long periods of time, when she would reappear, we'd have a lot of requests. Like trying to get 6 drink refills or order a single basket of chips and salsa. Which by the way- the chips and salsa you have to pay for. Hm okay. Most places at least give you the first basket for free but that is not the case here.

I had the duck torta with yucca fries. Pretty delicious actually though I kind of wished I had gotten the duck tacos instead. The insanely strong (but awesome) strawberry and pineapple caipirinha was also great. Everyone else seemed pretty happy with their food options. We were just very unimpressed with the service.

ISC met June 29. Thanks, Sarah S., for your continual spot-on restaurant selection.

El Agave is in Watson Plaza, a large, C-shaped shopping center, with Kohl's at the top (facing west), Shop 'n Save facing Watson and El Agave at the bottom (facing east). Just turn in when you see Kohl's.

This may be the largest Mexican restaurant I've ever patronized. There's a lovely separate bar and numerous smallish dining areas.

Our server was pleasant and knowledgeable of the menu. I asked him for a recommendation, and that's what I got. But I don't know its name. The menu is sporting a picture of it. Nopales are involved.

And this massive, wonderful dish was served in a huge black "pottery" footed bowl lined with foil. Besides nopales, there was chicken, shrimp, pico, sour cream and vegetables . . . no doubt other things.

This was the first time in my life I've had a Mexican dish that didn't include tortillas. And that includes Mexico City, Puerto Vallarta, Cancun and all villages down the road from Cancun to Tulum and up the road from Mexico City to Taxco.

And I was more than ecstatic with that.

Dang-bang it, was that good and continued to be fabulous with the abundance in my to-go vessel.

It was a fun evening with fellow Yelpers. Service was just right. Water was replenished in a timely fashion. And it seemed like everyone was pleased with their selections.

Check my reviews, I eat at a LOT of poke places.
Now, to be fair, the poke here is good.  
But the issue is they charge extra per scoop of ahi tuna.
Ahi is the main staple of a poke dish, you don't charge a per scoop extra fee for the main ingredient and punish people for going with the standard.
I wanted a large bowl and asked for ahi, they told me on top of the $17 price for the bowl it would be an extra $3.  I had to make them explain it to me because I was so confused.  It's just a ludicrous policy.
And no kimchi...  

On the plus side they had some Gluten-Free sauces.
The fish was fresh, and the topping choices were pretty good.

The kids working here were not super great, but did the job.
I was really unhappy with the way the menu prices were setup with the agi, no one does this...

The poke was good, but I'd suggest 'Ono Poke on 104th St over this.

THIS IS MY FAVORITE TARGET IN THE COUNTRY! Ok, I apologize for the shouting but I needed to express my pure, unadulterated love for this Target! Now I grew up in NOLA ya'll but have lived in Chicago, Long Beach and L.A. and have sought out the nearest Target in all of these places. I have also been to The original Target store in Minnesota (no, I'm nuts, my ex was from Minnesota and it happened to be their neighborhood store) so I consider myself a Tar-jayyyy expert (fancy pronunciation for Target! Hehe).

I remember my first experience at Target in Burbank, CA when my older cousin brought my Mom and I there to pick up some stuff while we were on vacay. I had no idea that this store would be so clean, pretty, and relatively inexpensive. I was a kid back then. It that experience stayed with me forever.

Then I remember when BatonRouge got their first Target and my friends were telling me how they would drive just to go to Target. I understood what they meant. I kinda feel that way about Trader Joe's too but don't get me started.

Anywho, Target is better than Wal-Mart hands down in terms of shopping experience. But Wal-Mart does seem cheaper and they are my go to for cheap meds and are closer to me). This particular Target has two floors and is bigger than the one on the wank. It has parking in the front and multi-level covered parking in the back (hint, there is parking that is connected to the second floor which is convenient if you want to shop there then watch a movie afterwards in Clearview).

There is a full size food section although not as much variety as Rouse's. I am happy they have a decent wine selection as well.  

Keep in mind that I can literally go up and down each aisle and just meander around and have a good time. I love how the store is well kept, well-lit, and aisles are big and spacious (unlike Wal-Mart where I try to get in and out ASAP). I also appreciate that Target has big-name designers (read Michael Kors and even Neiman Marcus Wow!) come in and do a Target line. Isaac Mizrahi did great stuff, Mossimo is standard, etc.

I also love the cheap bins up front where I find cute little gifts for my nieces which I spoil bc every time I see them I have a little cheapie gift for them (yes I spoil them. It  what favorite aunties do when they co-babysit!)! They love Hello Kitry, Disney and princess's stuff so it's a win-win situation!

Plus they are open later for holiday hours. Keep in mind I love Target so much I can also bring my recycling there (only place to my knowledge where I can recycle glass). I have also been known to close down the store and go to the same Target two days in a row (don't judge dammit!).

It was dangerous when I had a Target card so had to get rid of that! Hehe...plus Target donates to local schools. And they great their employees better than Wal-Mart treats their employees.

Happy shopping ya'll'

Trattoria Il Mulino is an upscale Italian restaurant on the first floor of the Hilton in downtown Nashville. The restaurant has locations in New York, Atlantic City and Orlando in addition to this Nashville location. My friend and I chose to come here because we were going to a concert at the Ryman and this is right down the street from the venue. We got lucky and managed to grab 2 seats at the bar since we did not have a reservation. 

Ambiance: 4/5

The restaurant is dimly lit and the feel is modern and elegant. The main dining room of the restaurant has a huge wine cellar that is backlit which makes for quite a sight as there are hundreds of bottles. Even being seated at the bar, all the places were set and wine glasses were set out as well. 

Service: 4/5

Our server was pretty attentive even for a busy Friday night. I did have to ask for the check since she was busy mixing drinks and running around but she brought it within 5 minutes after I asked so that was good. Other servers are walking around with the bread and looking to take dishes away as well. 

Food/Drink: 4/5

We kicked off our meal with a couple of cocktails. I got one called the Casino which has gin, orange bitters, simple syrup and lemon. It also had a skewer with 2 maraschino cherries on it. The drink was strong but slightly sweet which I really enjoyed. I would absolutely come back just for drinks as the cocktails are great.

They bring out a complementary appetizer which is a soft eggplant dish with breadcrumbs and salami circling the outside. Surprisingly this was my favorite thing I tried--the appetizer was so delicious! Throughout the meal a server will come by and offer you your choice of bread from a large basket--they have Italian, ciabatta, mini garlic bread and multigrain. I tried one of each and they were all excellent! The bread was soft and fresh and was a really nice touch. For an appetizer my friend got the Caesar salad which we split. The homemade dressing was super good and this was a nice and simple dish to get our meal started.

For the main entree we both got pasta. The server came around and grated some fresh cheese for the top which I love about Italian restaurants because I could have a mountain of cheese on there before I stop them. I got the gnocchi which comes in a bolognese sauce. This was a huge dish and I could not finish it. It came out piping hot so I had to wait a few minutes but this was a really delicious dish. My friend got the ravioli which are filled with arugula and goat cheese and topped off with a vodka sauce. The portion isn't a lot because it is a rich dish but the flavor and quality of the dish are there. 

The overall experience was great (4/5) although on the pricey side. Just a matter of personal preference that I'm more of a dive bar/ comfortable feel sort of place. This is definitely a great choice for dining downtown for the convenience and we had a good experience.

I know I'm not going to make many friends by bucking the consensus, but I have to.

I just don't get what the big deal is?  Maybe they didn't have their best stuff on tap when I was here?

The beer is solid.  It's good, but nothing here really blew my mind.  I didn't drink anything here that made me want to get 32 or 128 ounces of it.  I didn't regret drinking the beer here, but I didn't text friends saying "OMG U HAVE TO COME HERE" (I don't really text like that).

The best parts of this place are:

The ambiance: very nice-looking brewing setup, lots of friendly locals, and friendly bar tenders.
