The location: for the people that live near here. Although the Tampa Bay area has seen an EXPLOSION in the number of breweries ever since a millionaire owner of gentlemen's clubs started injecting money into the craft beer industry...this area is still a relative beer desert.

There weren't any foodcarts when I was here, but I love that setup!  We ate at Loli's down the street, which was incredible.

Walk-Ons has become a favorite lunch place for my team. Salads are great, different, and huge, especially fond of the zydeco with crispy shrimp with sweet/spicy sauce, pecans, greens, etc. they have a nice selection of poboys, sandwiches, and wraps from healthy to decadent. Appetizers are tempting and lots to share: super creamy spinach dip with fresh, warm chips to big, non-greasy onion rings that are excellent. 

The service here is good with waitresses willing to bring you ample drinks, extra dressing, etc. 

Always a solid lunch choice that makes a diverse crew happy with lots of choices.
Surprisingly hearty and tasty.  Very dense and rich flavored ravoli, warm bread, and bartenders that rock!

I love love their ice cream!! Comfort food when you are feeling down. 

I do not know why they do not have a location in San Diego! I love specialty ice cream places. There were many choices and they have a 3 scoop flight. You should get this! And also try as many ice cream as possible, doctor mcconnell's orders.

I got berry mix, raspberry and lemon, and the chocolate covered strawberry. My favorite was surprising the raspberry and lemon. I love the tanginess taste of it. The chocolate covered strawberry was right on to. It actually tasted like some strawberries covered in specks of chocolate. For someone who loves chocolate but not an overwhelming piece of chocolate! The berry mix was good but you know, normal. I would love to come back when I get the chance.

Iron Hill Brewery, for when you want to go out to dinner and none of you can agree on anything. They have a very large menu and their beer menu is definitely above average. 

The food is fine and the beer is fine. It is a large place that can accommodate a large party so that's nice. If you're looking for culinary innovation, this is not the place. If you're looking for an acceptable casual time with work friends, this is an acceptable place.

What a warm and inviting shop with several areas to hang out. I love how wide the main isle is that leads directly to the order counter. In the center, and to the right, are several racks of adorable gift ideas. Teas, tea pots, bakeware, coffee/tea mugs to fuzzy slippers are to cute to pass up.

As I approached the order area the server greeted me and my husband. Explaining this was our first time she answered all the questions I had. I ordered the Chai Latte and it had a lot of flavor. I also took advantage of the free lemon scone with the YELP check-in.

There are several drink categories from Loose Leaf teas, Tea Lattes,  Champagne Tea Cocktails by the flute, pitcher or flight of 4. Also they offer Bubbles and Wines, Beer, Coffee, Coffee Lattes and Hot Chocolate. 

They also serve Breakfast with Sunrise Sampler sandwich, egg and cheese bagel, muffins, oatmeal, baked goods and smoothies. They also offer lunch with 3 or 4 sandwich options.

Seating ranges from sofa and chairs to tables in three different areas. The shop has a lot of natural light and a great place to relax or get some work done.

I am tickled pink that Jug & Bottle Dept is finally open!  I have been patiently anticipating the opening for quite some time as I live 2 blocks from this store and I like my fancy beers and wines.  It exceeded my expectations!

There is just so much to look at in this store.  The drink selection is out of this world.  They also offer lots of snacks and fresh flowers.  The employees working were friendly as always (you may recognize them from The Independent) and they let us know that they are open to suggestions for items to carry, which is super cool!

I imagine that I will be in Jug & Bottle Dept pretty often.  Welcome to the neighborhood!

Although this place may not appeal to everyone, it must certainly be a favorite of those who are looking for uniforms and costumes.  I got a chance to chat with the owner who says that some of his pieces are used in plays, events, and even some museums in Chicago because of their condition.  There are some antiques like gramophones and oil lamps, even some antique guns/rifles.  But the mainstay of this place is the availability of clothing and hats that fit specific themes.  

Oh, and if this sort of thing interests you, I got a tip that they may only be around another few months before moving (and taking their collection) to Canada.  If you are interested in uniforms and related military items, get here soon!

Review #1937

Wow, it feels like ages since I visited this Hard Rock Café at Tampa International Airport on opening day, but that's what happens when you live your life out of a suitcase, and don't have enough time to sit down and write reviews.

The Hard Rock Café is a welcome addition to the restaurant options at the airport. You'll find the HRC in the east wing of Tampa International Airport's main terminal, between the shuttles to terminals C and A on the third (main) floor. The HRC Airport Café is the first time that the famed Hard Rock chain has opened a location inside of an airport. The restaurant / bar has 4,500 square feet of space, complete with a sound stage, roadie cases, and sound trusses; and they have seating for 120 guests. As with all HRC's, the restaurant has musical memorabilia located in display cases all around the dining room.

If you have time to sit down and enjoy your meal, the restaurant has floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking the airfield at Tampa International Airport, and it's easy to lose track of time as you watch the planes and ground crews scurrying around. Be sure to tell your server your "drop dead" time so they make sure that you receive your food, and get your check in plenty of time to catch your flight.

Right behind the hostess counter is the Hard Rock store, so if you want a collector's pin, or a t-shirt, or any of their other merchandise, you can stop here before dashing to your flight. The bar area is to the right of the hostess stand, and there are several high-top tables as well as the main bar in this section of the restaurant. The wall behind the bar is a huge video screen, overlooking a sound stage, and then the bar itself.

The restaurant menu will look familiar to frequent visitors of the Hard Rock chain, with the traditional appetizers, salads, burgers, sammies, smokehouse specials, and entrée specials. If you're in a hurry, grab a burger, or a wrap, or a salad; but if you have more time then sit back and order an entrée special as you enjoy the sights.

The food is good, and the servers were still learning the system on the day that I was there. I'm quite sure that they have this machine humming along by now, and would recommend that you give them a try on your next flight out of Tampa.

We'd the mussels to start, aunt ordered the lamb ossobuco I'd the fried chicken cutlet. I brought the wine - it was a sparking rose - it pared perfectly with both dishes. It's a dim lit and cozy place but very noisy.  The other customers are nice and it's not at all a stuffy atmosphere. I think it's because the staff is friendly.

They serve a small portion of bread which was fine; the main courses are huge. I couldn't finish my chicken cutlet with prosciutto, buffalo moz, arugula and tomatoes ( i asked them to hold the prosciutto and they accommodated my request). Everyone is nice, they know their menu and everything was very well prepared. I liked my aunt's dish - the seasoning and flavors were complex but I'm not a braised meat person and wasn't in the mood for pasta or fish. The chicken cutlet was delicious and juicy; I think it either had a light sauce or the chicken breast was marinated - either way it was special. 

My aunt ordered a single scoop of salted caramel gelato (off menu item) for dessert and decaf earl grey tea - it was Stash's! She really enjoyed everything! I enjoyed mine too but I agree with her - if you like braised meats order the Oasobuco it's a perfect cold weather dish!

It's BYOB and they take credit cards, what more could you want?

I've been to Johnnie's Dog House several times. Parking's decent: there are a few spots in front, and some above, next to the Berlitz office. Service has always been excellent. The place is modest, decorated like a miniature diner.

Hot dog snobs may turn up their noses at their dogs, but I'm no snob. Don't expect their dogs to be authentic copies of your regional favorites, and you'll be fine.

Their dogs aren't the biggest, which means you'll need to order more than one. On the bright side, that lets you try different varieties. The Boston style with baked beans isn't bad. The Texas Ranger with barbecue sauce and fried onions is tasty, as is their zesty Tijuana dog, with jalapenos, sport peppers, chopped onions, and a light hot sauce, one that only the weaksauce will find spicy. Their Chicago style dog is their weakest offering, sadly, as it doesn't use a proper bun.

Prices are such that you won't be eating here everyday. Besides, that's unhealthy.

Get fries and onion rings with your meal, and try their soft serve vanilla ice cream for dessert - with cones! Days they're open past 4:30 PM, you can even get a FREE BEER with your order. Try them yourself!

I've been here a half dozen times now and it's always good. The hummus and more dish: hummus topped with feta, olives, cucumbers, tomatoes, etc. is great and served with warm pita. The haloumi appetizer is served with this whipped garlic stuff that should be served on absolutely everything ever -it's so good! The pine nut salad with homemade buttermilk ranch is really good (I don't like ranch dressing but really like this). A great lunch place and good for groups too. We came here with 13 for a team lunch and they handle a big table well with great service.

Time warp. I guess I'm just accustomed to the contemporary. Upon entering the gate, you need your credit card or room key. The person that works the reception appears on a screen if you need any assistance at the gate.

Now, for checking in.. The same person on screen at the gate is at the front desk still.. ON SCREEN. A large screen is at the front desk interacting with you to get you checked in. She tells you where to grab your keys and where to pick up your parking pass. Hopefully the parking pass won't be jammed in the printer and you'll get the right one. We picked up the wrong one so we thought our room was someone else's. We tried entering the room and saw other people were already in it. So, we returned to the front desk and learned our real room number.

The room had a kitchen, bathroom, and living space downstairs that led out a sliding door to a small deck. The upstairs had two bedrooms with a bathroom in between, not adjoining. It's a serious throwback. Tiny TV from the 80's, no cable. They did, however, have a DVD player. The kitchen was fully equipped with utensils, pots, plates, etc. Some of the utensils were dirty. No sponge to clean them.. just the dishwasher but who wants to run the dishwasher for a few utensils? 

This place needs to be updated BADLY. And "resort" should be removed from the name.

The Mongolian BBQ line here has become one of my favorite places to visit; it is actually somewhat of a weekend tradition now between the SO and me.

I agree that you can find better Chinese entrees elsewhere, but the buffet here is actually really good compared to other offerings elsewhere. Someone I met today from San Diego said this is his favorite place to eat in town.

It's great because there is a wide variety of ingredients with lots of vegetables (bok choy!) and nine different sauces to dress up your creation. Peanuts for topping too. 

The meats are frozen thin slices so I pass on all of them except the pork; unlike the others it doesn't turn out dry and tough, I'm guessing because of the higher fat content. 

Shrimp is available too in addition to imitation crab and scallops at dinner.

The same chef ("wizard" as my SO calls him) has been here every visit of mine lunch and dinner except one time. I could really tell the difference that once. He does a really great job so I recommend bringing cash for his tip container. He's very nice too. 

There is another line of pre-cooked foods that rotate on occasion. See my photos.

TL;DR: Everyone has been friendly all my visits and the freshly cooked BBQ is the way to go. Will be back lots more.

This was my absolute favorite meal I ate in New Orleans, and trust me... I ate A LOT of meals. I love you, Gumbo Shop!

Our Lyft driver recommended this spot to us while we drove into New Orleans from the airport during our first afternoon in town. A few days later, we finally had some free time to stop in, and I was so satisfied with our experience. 

We arrived around 1:30pm, which I thought might be a good time to visit since it's a bit after the normal lunch rush, but there was still quite a long line in the foyer of the restaurant. Luckily, the line moved quickly and efficiently, and were seated in no less than 10 minutes. While we waited, I began to notice the gorgeous decor and colors inside, and that the shop features two all-gender restrooms.  There was also a specials board featuring some appetizers and a gumbo plate that wasn't on the printed menu.

Once we were seated, we had a chance to look at the menu, and our waiter reiterated the specials. Gumbo Shop offers plenty of gumbo options, of course, and at fair prices. I thought they might easily charge a good amount of money for a dish, since there are always long lines outside, but their low prices may be *why* the lines are so long. Who can resist a delicious deal? I am a big fan of seafood -- and since we're in New Orleans I trust the seafood will be amazing at most places -- so I ordered the seafood okra gumbo. My boyfriend decided on the creole combination platter. 

While we waited for our food, we each ordered a beer. Gumbo Shop features some rotating options, and on this particular day they were featuring two Abita brand pours: an amber and a blonde. My boyfriend ordered the amber, and I went with the blonde. Our waiter brought these out within a few minutes, along with some bread and butter. Who doesn't love some bread and butter to start off a hearty meal?! The answer is that everyone does. 

When our food was on its way out, I got so pumped, because this was my first time eating gumbo, EVER... and once I tasted this gumbo, I knew I'd been spoiled. I will never taste gumbo as good as the one I experienced here at Gumbo Shop. Please, please, if you visit New Orleans, you must eat here. I promise the wait is much shorter than you'll expect, because service is impressive and efficient here, and the prices are low. You'll absolutely love it. 

I can't wait to come back next time I'm in town!

First off, it's important to note that despite reports to the otherwise The Grub House is, in fact, open. 

I've always been curious about this restaurant at 20th and College. It looks like a comfort food joint. It's in a rather non-descript, somewhat divey building but I tend to love just this type of restaurant. 

My experience, however, is with delivery as I decided to take a day off work and ended up using a delivery gift card a friend had provided. I checked out my options and was delighted to see The Grub House as one of them. 

It does appear from social media that The Grub House went through a period of inactivity, however, I'm excited to report that it's back in action and the food itself was comfort food extraordinaire. 

I ordered a Grub Burger combo with a Sweet Tea. I was delighted that the burgers are made to order and I was even more delighted when my burger arrived medium well as I had ordered.  The burger was a decent size burger and it was awesomely prepared. 

I also ordered Grub Fries. These fries were absolutely delightful. They're uniquely made and perfectly seasoned. 

It's not the easiest thing in the world to prepare food for delivery, however, I was pleased that my food was still warm when it arrived at my south Lawrence home. 

The sweet tea definitely hit the spot, as well. 

I definitely don't know the full scoop behind The Grub House, but I do know that's where I had an absolutely delightful lunch today and I won't hesitate to order from them or drop by their College Avenue location again. The Grub House is a true Indy indie business with comfort food that really hits the spot.

I am laughing at myself for booking this hotel. The airplanes that pass by are super duper loud. Like it feels like they are flying right over the hotel. They do provide you with earplugs!

I do have to say if you are a light sleeper this is not the hotel for you. I'm a deep sleeper so I'm okay with the airplane noise.

Though I tend to gravitate towards local shops for bath and beauty products, I still think Lush is great. You can usually find one in any major city, which works when you need something in a pinch and prefer natural products. The packaging is fun and loud, and the names and descriptions are always creative. 

I find employees to be a bit pushy sometimes, however, I had an easy in and out experience this week when I recycled some old containers for a brand new face mask - brazened honey. I can't wait to try it! Because the products are natural, they often have a shelf life (some have to be refrigerated!), which is understandable but can be preventative when it comes to committing to a full-sized purchase. 

Finally, some of their bath bombs have left color behind on my tub. It's always removable, but that doesn't happen with the bombs from my local spot. Nonetheless, I'm still a fan and enjoy a lot of their products!

Um yum! When you're hungry but you want to be healthy, this is the perfect spot. 

It's an assembly line and you decide exactly what you want in your bowl. Hate cilantro, skip it. Love macadamia nuts, yep you can have those. Just beware that a few ingredients are an extra cost, avocado, crab salad and, of course and extra scoop of your protein.

I wasn't big on the spicy tuna (but then again I never am) and I thought the tofu could have more flavor. That's right, tofu so you can definitely have a vegetarian meal here. 

The space is light and airy but I usually get my bowl to go. Staff is friendly and efficient. And OMG the watermelon agua fresca is delicious!

Drive thru is fast and the outdoor lounge area is so cool. It's a good place to meet a friend or something.  If I lived closer to this location, I would be here daily. Also, parking is pretty good. Lots of spaces.

1702, aptly named for it's address along Speedway, is a pizza joint I've wanted to try for years. I set aside a special time to go, because, really, who can deny giant slices of pizza?

The inside of 1702 is a lot divey-er than I expected, however, it reminds me of a very popular pizza place in Salt Lake City, near the University, so it was almost like being back home.

I had previously checked out their menu, but still spent a few minutes deciding what type of pizza to have, as well as beer. The employees... seemed especially surly. The certain beer I was interested in (Almanac's Cherry Picker) did not have a price next to it, and when I asked, I got a response that was pretty much "It says it on the board". I pointed out that this was not the case, and after a solid minute, I finally got a price for it. $6 for a 10oz pour (so, fairly pricey, but I really wanted to try it.)

We ordered a single slice of the Presto to share between two. We waited a while for our slice to come out, but it was definitely worth it. The pizza slice is giant. It's definitely a meal for more than just one. They bring it out on a pizza pan, with your own pizza cutter.  I was in heaven, and very happy that I was sharing. 

Despite the surly workers and the long wait, I really feel like 1702 is a necessity stop if you are a student at U of A - especially because it is all too close to campus. In fact, there were even some students working on computers when we stopped in. I know this is exactly what I'd be doing if I were a student in Tucson: beerin and pizza-ing myself up. YUM!

A solid 4 stars.  We came here last week on our anniversary jaunt to Santa Barbara.  After a long day of whale watching and wine tasting, the last thing we ended up being in the mood for was a fancy dinner.  As it turned out, the Sage and Onion was absolutely lovely.  We were served an amouse buche of some kind of yummy thick blended tomato-y soup in a cute little espresso cup.  The truffled white cheddar souffle was a delicious beginning, and surprisingly light and fluffy, it didn't weigh us down but got us excited about the main course.  Our main courses were fantastic.  Mine was steak with scalloped potatoes and rapini that were to die for.  Hers was ahi perfectly seared tuna in a coconut curry lemongrass sauce, and she LOVED it.  The owner said hello, and even gave us some unbelievable cabernet (on the house, it was a 2003 Jordan Cabernet that was the best wine of the trip).  I was so full by dessert that I only ordered sorbet, which was as sweet and refreshing as I'd hoped it would be.  It was a wonderful night, and made our anniversary not just the special night it was, but special AND tasty!  And the waiter was adorable to boot (just look for the tall, dark, and handsome guy)!  We'll happily return next time we're in SB.

What an incredible experience!

Perfect for foodie, wannabe foodies, Top Chef lovers, and the adventurous diner!

My boyfriend surprised me with our anniversary dinner here for our 6th year after hearing it was on my Nashville bucket list. He was able to get a Wednesday night reservation with only a day notice. It may be more difficult on the weekends. 

They offer complimentary valet parking here. Situated underneath The Patterson House, we arrived a few minutes early and decided to head there first to grab pre-dinner drinks before we were allowed in. Come to find out, we could bring our drinks into the restaurant as well without rushing. 

Upon entering the main door, you enter a tiny holding area with an elevator that actually takes you up to the main restaurant area. Very incognito spy-like feels.

The restaurant itself is an open kitchen where you immediately see all the chefs and sous chefs plating each and every delicate dish. We lucked out by having the best seat in the house, right in the center/middle of the U shaped serving area. 

We were greeted by multiple chefs, sous chefs and other kitchen staff who made sure we had no needs that went unnoticed. Every course of thoroughly explained prior to being devoured by yours truly. 

In total, we had 10 glorious courses, 2 of which were dessert. I will spare you the details since the menu is always evolving and you may not get the same courses. Let's just I was able to try delicious cavier, sea urchin and a melt-in-your-mouth steak. Portions are small, but after eating 10 of anything, you will leave satisfied but not feeling uncomfortably full. My normally spam-and-eggs boyfriend thoroughly enjoyed all the courses and raved about many of them. 

We also opted for the wine pairing with our meal, one of which was actually sake. Since we already got drinks at Patterson House and my boyfriend doesn't care to drink wine, we opted for just one pairing to share. There were about 6 pairings with smaller than average pours. Definitely just enough to enjoy the course with but not enough to get you drunk. As a self-proclaimed lush, I was not even buzzed after all the pairings. I suppose if you're not a drinker, you may be more intoxicated. Sometimes having a high tolerance has its pros and cons. 

At the end of our meal, we got a Mr. Potato Head cookie jar with in-house-made cookies to enjoy. We were also presented with our own personalized menu detailing all our courses and drink pairing. Overall, I had a fantastic experience and would recommend this to anyone who is interested in more than just your average dining experience.

Please note if you are there on vaca, they do have a dress code.  We were a bit under dressed but we got on, lol.  

We walked through the kitchen on the way to the patio.  We were the 1st table out there under the stairs.  Luckily it was a nice night out. Lights stringed around the patio which was really nice.  

We decided to try the turtle soup and the got the 3 course meal set with gumbo, hake, and the bread soufflé.  I also got the turtle soup which we both thought was very salty!!  :(  The Gumbo we also thought was salty on this night.  The hake was very nice and flaky but very lightly seasoned.    And the bread souffle was absolutely wonderful.  

The service was nice but they didn't ask if we were celebrating something which it was my sister's bday.  I never could find our waiter to tell him. 

Overall, it was an enjoyable meal though definitely not my favorite from our New Orleans trip.

I love the opera... It's an ethereal dream like world where love, tragedy and comedy all collide under a spectacular symphonic canopy. Attending the opera just makes you feel grand, it's a way of connecting to the past. I love that feeling of knowing that centuries of people have sat down to watch the same performance I'm about to see. I've been to a good handful of opera's put on by the Edmonton Opera accompanied by the Edmonton Symphony Orchestra - I always leave with the best feeling; knowing that I have spent a wonderful evening full of magic, mystery and romance. I can't wait until the next one! 

Que le spectacle commence!

Originally built in 1773, this was the convening site for the Constitutional Convention, as well as the setting for one of George Washington's inaugural celebrations. The cuisine here is authentic early American, with many of the dishes adapted from 18th Century recipes. Veal sausage with  sauerkraut and mashed potatoes, honey-glazed duck with asparagus, and medallions of venison with leeks are among the traditional entrees served by a staff in period dress. A children's menu suggests this is an ideal place for family dining, but you may feel differently after seeing the prices.

Cuteness in every way! The macaroons are really good here. They can customize designs and they have unique flavors. After getting dinner, my hubby and I came here to fulfill our sweet cravings and this place did not disappoint! I also got a little espresso to go to counteract the sugar coma from eating the macaroons. 

The service is great here and so welcoming and I just loved the atmosphere. You should definitely come check it out if you're walking down University.
Ordered the cheesesteak with fries and a diet coke.  It was alright, a little dry with skimpy provolone.  I would stick with their pizzas.

The Mardi Gras pop up is all that. We enjoyed the cocktails especially the Zulu and also the food just reminds you of the good old days..gumbo, po boys and king cake. The decor is incredibly gorgeous. Check it out if you can.

Well I have to admit the hype was too big for this place. I was so disappointed when I went here. I was expecting this "Amazing, WOW" food and it was such a let down. I hate to write anything bad about a place. But, I am not a fan of buffet style food.  Too many germs, too many people letting their KIDS help themselves..I hate buffet food. 

Anyway, here are some pictures. I am not going to say anything more, you will have to eat the food for yourself and JUDGE it..good luck !!!

I used to avoid Hot Topic like the plague, but I've changed my ways over the years. There may be some weird shoppers there, but they have really cool retro stuff, especially t-shirts and sweaters that reeled me into the store. All the Star Wars, Sonic the Hedgehog, Mario, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle, etc. shirts have me feeling nostalgic all the time, and I would have never known there was a place in the mall that sold them if I wasn't brave enough to decide to enter Hot Topic one day. Prices for shirts run at about $20, Sweaters can go as high at $50, you can either buy it now and feel safe that you got your item or wait for clearance and pray they haven't all been sold away (normally I have to get it because I can't risk it).

Wind: 1
iPhone: 0

I have had a smartphone since 2005 (RIP Treo 650) and never broken a screen. Until the great epic tornadic windstorm of 2016 that is. There I was, minding my own business about to walk in to work. I open my door, the wind catches it flinging it open, and my precious iPhone 6+ falls to the ground. Oh dear, I exclaimed as I rushed to retrieve it from the concrete. But I was too late. The screen had shattered leaving jagged pieces of glass and my record of phone safety destroyed. It was so bad that I even put scotch tape over the glass so that I wouldn't injure mys of, but I knew it had to be fixed. 

I emailed a place back in Mandeville and their quote was $199 which was the same as my insurance deductible. I figured I was out $200 when I checked Yelp and found all the stellar reviews of myPhoneMD. Not only could they fix my phone in 45 minutes, but their quoted price was only $150. I jumped in my car and headed to Magazine. 

I lucked out and got a parking spot right in front of Lilly's after making the block a few times. Parking would be my one issue with this location, but it's Nola and street parking is somewhat expected. The staff were super friendly and the shop was very nice. There were couches and magazines to occupy my time since I couldn't play on my phone like normal. They also had drinks for customers as well as phone cases for sale. 

After 45 minutes my phone was as good as new plus I got 10% off for checking in on Yelp. If you break your phone, come here.

I'm not sure if this is good or not because it was my first time ever that I got a pedicure. I have nothing to compare it to... 

My experience was they did a good job scrubbing my feet and providing a comfortable relaxing environment! I love the way they have massaging chairs and they massage your leg and feet. My feet looks fine and it looked clean. The nail polish on my toes were a tiny bit messy (but better then what I can do). I'll eventually go to more then compare! But for a first time pedicare, this was good!

The cocktails here are delicious, the inside is super swanky, and the bar is located on Mass Ave, which is a fun and happenin' street in Indy. We had a big group, so we sat outside on their front patio so we could fit everyone. I got a cucumber-gimlet-type cocktail that was delicious, albeit quite sour. We had a good time within our group, but our server was incredibly rude. We were all very taken aback, as our group was being very polite, offering to help him, tipped well, were smiling, etc. He would NOT smile at us, so much so that it was like he was trying not to. He also made several incredibly slight and sarcastic comments and might have even been the manager, as he wasn't in a server outfit. It was a frustrating experience, as I know this spot is high quality and has a good reputation, but I was just sad that it tainted my friend's birthday a bit.

On arrival I was happy when they brought out a large decanter of salsa and a small container of bean dip with complimentary chips.  The salsa was rather unremarkable and sadly rather bland; while the bean dip was rather bean tasting.  My combo plate with a taco, burrito and enchilada all pretty much tasted interchangeably the same and uniformly bland.  It wasn't bad but it wasn't all that good either and just was an overall very bland meal experience.  I probably will not return as the food just lacked in the flavor department.

Perfect Nails isn't fancy! Definitely not one of those newer places where you get a fancy wine or cocktail while you get your nails done. But the people that work there are nice, and the mani/pedi I got (shellac manicure) was good. Solid job. 

Cons? They didn't have some of the brands of nail polish that I'm used to seeing at nail salons now. They had A LOT of colors and brands, but it was almost too many? I kind of panicked and just picked a color! And it wasn't expensive, but it wasn't cheap either. 

They did a good job on my nails - especially on the manicure! A very good job. I'd definitely go back, but next time I need to think about what colors I want first (or take my own polish with me)!

Magical and Whimsical definitely describe Bon. This lovely boutique has been in business for a long time and it's run by a lovely mother and daughter team.  Go there to find unique specialty items ranging from books to handmade jewelry, stationary, pillows, glassware and more. Make a morning of it and start with breakfast at the Five Points Market and then head two doors down to Bon and peruse this gorgeous gem!

I'm from the South and this is my General Robert E. Lee on his prime pedestal in the center of our Lee Circle looking defiantly Northward at you invading Yankees with your dirty hipster and sloppy tourist ways!  Verily I say unto thee bathe thouselves well and learn to behave in decent civilized ways to dress appropriately for dinner.  Truly do not arrive wearing shorts or jeans to present in our fancy eating establishments.  Do not whine, balk, or complain about not being allowed entry due to your lack of appropriate regalia when such dress codes are clearly posted on websites and the exterior of establishments.  

Appropriately honor our monuments to the War of Northern Aggression with due historical respect and leave your snide comments about Southern culture and peoples back in your frost laden Northern lands.  Repent of your Californian attitudes of despising our heavy use of butter, cream, and deep frying in making things deliciously decadent.  Imbibe in the holy consumption of alcohol to achieve the nirvanic state of inebriation so that you might fully embrace all that our Southern hospitality has to offer and join us in the revelry that we freely share.  Releasing your preconceptions and fully embracing living in the space and time that you're in New Orleans will unleash a multitude of  delectable possibilities.  

Now salute General Lee and march on to eat something scrumptious!!!

The two things that you want to see when you're attending an annual event: 
1) they grow in size and success and
2) they learn from their mistakes and improve. 

I've been going to this festival for the past few years since I started working downtown, and I can happily say that the Indy Strawberry Festival meets those two items listed above. It seems like more and more people attend every year, but the lines move fairly quickly, the volunteers are all friendly, and as always, it's for a good cause. 

The first year or so when I would go, you would wait in line for a very long time, the products seemed to be a bit overpriced, and they would always run out of products.

This year (2017) was great! The lines moved within 5-10 minutes, it felt like 5lbs of dessert, and I felt like I got my money's worth. 

Great event for a great cause. Always a delicious way to kick off the summer season officially!

Today was a special day.

For the first time since I learned about Burger Culture, I did not have to chase their truck. 

It was parked right in the courtyard of my condo starting around 5pm.

Gabe and company were busy for three hours making all the great burgers, grilled cheese sandwiches and fries that have made them one of the most popular food trucks in Tampa Bay.

As usual, my Cajun Burger was just perfect and even my property manager got a little nuts with the Belgium Waffle Burger. Another friend took one bite of a Grilled Cheese with Prosciutto and her knees almost gave out.

After running down that big orange truck at Cigar City, TGH and other locations around the area, it was a convenient treat to have Burger Culture bring all that good food right to my front door.

EXCEPTIONAL.

Commander's Palace is the gold standard for fine dining in NOLA and beyond. From service to ambiance to menu, it was nothing short of exceptional, and easy to see why this place has been internationally renowned for decades. Our team was seated in a back private dining area where we were delighted and dazzled us with humor, history and experience. Lorenzo was hardly a waiter, but more of a showman. We jokingly referred to him as the "most interesting man in the world" the entire evening, once learning that he had lived on over 3 different continents (Africa, Europe, NA), multilingual, and was raised in Paris but is of Italian and Cajun decent. The gracious owner also was on site and took time to pop in, and share her Texas (Dallas) ties with us. 


Food- EXCELLENT. There are over 2K reviews of this place, so here's another one telling you to try the turtle soup. Sounds gross, but tastes delicious. Another must-tries: crawfish bisque and the souffle' for dessert.

I always have a love/hate relationship with zoos. While I love seeing the animals, my heart does break a tiny bit knowing that this really isn't their natural habit and they're totally stuck in the cage for my benefit only, which really is kind of a bummer. But then if I don't go and see them, then they are sitting in there for nothing, right? It's lose/lose, but I go for a bit, try not to feel badly about it, and donate to the zoo when I can.

While in St. Louis I did stop by the zoo to check it out. The main reason? It was free. Who doesn't love a little free-ninety nine in their life? I know I do. First thing I thought was, "wow, this place is freaking enormous". Definitely grab a map because at first I didn't and found myself completely overwhelmed by the shear mass of this place.

The zoo host about 16,000 animals- that's a freaking lot. It's on a 90 acre lot and features over 600 species  of animals. From rare and even endangered and even my friends the sting rays. They have so much to look at! The zoo features animals like the Tasmanian Devil, yes, just like the cartoon, but without all the fun. It's got all of your favorites and more.

My one note is to be careful when the sun is out- it gets crazy hot here. Thank goodness they have those big mister fans. Think of those fans Beyoncé uses on her stage, but misting you with water. You're going to want to stand in front of one for a few seconds, or even a minute because the sun in the Lou can be a scorcher.

Prices on bottled water will run you $3-$4, but when it's hot like it was when I was there, it's totally worth every penny, plus, you didn't pay admission!

For me, it's a great place to do a nice loop. See what you can see and leave. Go say hi to some animals and keep it moving.

I came for the BBQ, but the sweet potato fries ended up being the wily, mistress on the side that really pulled on my heart strings.

Although the line was long (as expected) it moved fairly quickly and gave us plenty of time to decide what we wanted to eat. Overall, I let my friend lead the order, and I just chimed in with some steering opinions on the sides. 

The pork ribs were great, albeit a tad dry but with some supplemental baked beans it helped to balance things out. Them sweet potato fries doe? That right thurrrr, was what I was looking for in St. Louis!

Definitely happy to have experienced Pappy's even if I never return. It was a fun and tasty dining memory overall!

I'm pretty happy with my blowout from Dina! Not only was it super easy to schedule fairly last minute (a couple of days before the event), but they were open on Sundays, parking right out front unmetered was a cinch AND the price was right. 

I have super thick, longer hair, so it wound up being the "and up", but still pretty reasonable!

Also, I'll admit I left it in waaaay longer than I should've, and there were STILL some curls by the time I washed. 

The look wasn't as full of volume as I've gotten before elsewhere, but that's actually what I wanted, and what I had asked for...more beachy long curls than old school classic curls. Dina created that for me. 

Conversation was great and we had the place to ourselves on a Sunday afternoon. It was lovely! 

I'll definitely be calling Dina again for my next event. Everything was right on!

Hipster cuisine at its best. Protypical Fishtown eatery complete with mixologists and rich mahogany. The food and beverage options are top notch and priced fairly. 

Tuna Crudo
Broccoli Rabe
Cacio e Pepe
Bucatini
Margherita

All winners. If you don't know what to get on your first visit. Get that!

Can't go wrong with any of the tables either. They all offer a great view. Service is sweet and efficient as well. Parking will be tricky. 

Uber...

Empire State Delicatessen is located in the bottom of One Shell Square. It offers good food and fast service during the lunchtime hours.

Most of my experiences here have been when visiting people who work in the building, or on a break from something at the courthouse. It is very convenient to both locations and is frequently crowded at lunch. I recommend coming for 11 to avoid the rush.

I have had several of heir sandwiches, but my favorites are the club and brisket sandwich. They have some fancy baseball themed name, but that sport is lame so I don't care to remember the official title.

If you want some privacy, there is a table set inside of two walls. There isn't much room, but it is somewhat private. The other tables are set out in the open in the large dining area so privacy is difficult.

If you're in the CBD and want a sandwich, check this place out.

A teeny-tiny sushi-spot packed with goodness.
The platters are a good value and the fish is fresh and many varieties are offered.

My companion had a fresh lobster roll and the meat was sweet and plentiful.

I enjoyed my Hamachi nigiri and watching the big screen TV.
Sadly - that TV does overwhelm the tiny room and voids-out the "ambience".

In any case, the owners were there and the chef was friendly.
Plus, you can walk to the Franklin Fountain for dessert.
It's not Morimoto - but it's a heck of a lot better than Mizu down the street.

I live in New Orleans but I stayed here on business during a work conference. I am glad they chose a hotel that wasn't in the Quarter or on Canal because it was way easier to avoid the Bourbon St. madness. (Close enough for everyone else though!)

As far as the rooms go, I stayed in the renovated portion of the hotel. (Renovation is ongoing and you will see the crew around and in the elevators with equipment/materials, etc.) My room was pretty spacious and had a large desk and small couch. The bathroom was a good size as well. There is a small fridge which I always appreciate. 

The conference facilities were very good for our size group (50 vendors in a ballroom and 1 large room with 2 smaller rooms for breakout sessions for about 100 attendees). Catering for lunch and small snacks for our evening events was done well. Lots of New Orleans cuisine represented and enjoyed by attendees.

Staff was very accomodating - my room wasn't ready when I tried to check in but they called me as soon as it was ready (earlier than standard check in). They also allowed me to check out late.

I was very pleased with my experience here and hope that this conference I attended returns here next year.

We went today after caving into a perpetual craving I had for TA's pho mid-afternoon. In addition, I was excited to finally try some pastries as well. #proudfatkid 

The restaurant itself was pretty busy/active (but in a productive way as people were leaving and coming in) but the nicely shaded patio only had one occupied table. Being as we had our dog, we sat outside comfortably at a shaded table by the door. Perfect for our September evening prior to hitting the park so we could all get some exercise in ;) 

Service was efficient and cordial and our dog was treated to a styrofoam water bowl. I appreciated that they accommodated our pooch. 

We both had bowls of pho with rare meat on the side. The bowls came with a nice amount of garnish and a good presentation of meat, had a nice clean broth and were a hearty size--almost too much to eat in one sitting if you haven't eaten all day (like myself). I managed to do just fine. At $8, I feel this is a great value. I utilized some chili sauce and sriacha that were provided to me upon request. Yum! 

I attempted to order the special of the day that I saw on Instagram (if you're a user FOLLOW THEM to see daily specials and some serious food porn), but, wouldn't you know, and like it was suggested, they were sold out. I cried a little inside; IG rep wasn't kidding when we were encouraged to get it while it lasts. The crabmeat and shrimp toast looked divine and I'm sad that I missed it. Because I was in the mood for tofu, I got four pieces of their flavored house made tofu ($1 total) from the food bar to sample at the table. I really enjoyed the mushroom tofu and the lemongrass tofu very much; it was unlike anything I ever had and the tofu was inflected with vegetables and seasonings. 

Of course we had to get our favorite avocado boba to split. That was the icing on the cake.  A few pastries and treats from the food bar later and waddling away with a full belly it was a wrap. I wish I could say that I ate their dessert tofu with a delightful ginger sugar syrup but I was sooo full. I will dream about the next time I can visit. Thanks, Thinh An crew for an enjoyable experience!

This was our third stop on Burgerpalooza--in search for the best effing burger in B-town.  This review is for their burger/fry fare.  For a review of their shakes, I refer you to the review I did prior to this update.

Overall, a boring sort of burger and our lowest scoring one thus far (2.17 average star rating from participants).  Their fries did nothing to redeem this joint or their unimaginative interpretation of American fast food.  Even one of the participants who gave them higher than the average score (3 star) later notated on her scorecard "error!  must have been in a good mood!"  as in hindsight she felt she had been too generous.  

What we hated:  The fries.  The freshness (or lack thereof) of ingredients.  The overall quality.

What they have going for them:  They've been here for many years and that must account for something.  Their location is prime on the corner of 36th and State--a great location for grab and go for those returning from work to their home in the foothills or Northend.  They have a drive thru.  And, though they don't have indoor seating, they do have outdoor (limited) seating.

Overall, with so many other burger places nearby, I would probably drive the extra 1/2 mile for something a little fresher and memorable.

Perhaps it's the risqué name, the long line that this bar always has out front, or the fact that I go downtown maybe once or twice a year that has prevented me from coming here until now. At the ripe ol' age of twenty five, I have finally made my first trip to Humpin' Hannah's. I remember moving to Boise seven years ago, driving past this place and thinking to myself, "Nothing good could happen at a bar with that name." LOL. 

Don't let the name or bras hanging from the ceiling fool you, friends. This place possesses a peculiar class of it's own. Sure, its class doesn't look like a perfectly clean interior, modern design, or fancy glass-wear. But it looks like the bouncers smiling at you and telling you to have a good time when you walk in, music being played that reminds you of your childhood, and the fact the dance floor is occupied by people of all ages and from all walks of life.

Right when you walk in, there is a little bar set up to the left of the front door that offers $1 shots and $2 PBRs. The shots are served in those little test tube looking things. (This made me think of that scene from Miss Congeniality, so I had no choice but to try one hehe.) The shot was yummy and tasted like liquid candy more than anything. After trying one of these, my friends and I indulged in a "Purple Viking". This was good-ish, but not my fave. The mix of grape and vodka made it taste like cough syrup, IMO. 

Towards the back of the venue, they have a dance floor with a live band playing music (see my review for Simple Ruckus). When the band took a break, music was played over the loud speakers with accompanying videos projected on the back screen of the stage. This is probably my favorite place I've gone dancing in Boise! The music is fun, and people (for the most part) keep it classy in here and respect your personal space.

In addition to a fun dance floor and fun vibe, they have pool tables and lots of places to sit, sip on a drink, and enjoy conversation.

Divin' it up at Tick Tock Tavern is one of my favorite things to do. It is the chillest place on the planet and super close to my house. My favorite time to come? Around 9pm on a weeknight. Whether you're grabbing a drink by yourself or meeting with some buddies, it's easy on the wallet and a great atmosphere. Speaking of wallets, bring cash, they do not accept credit cards. 

I also don't mind coming for their happy hours: Monday all day and then every other day they are open until 7pm. Right now for happy hour, they do a dollar off their house special cocktails, rail liquor, and Logboat cans. Beyond that, they have an awesome draft list and a bunch of other domestic and local beer options. 

The music is always fun and on point, just like it should be at a neighborhood bar. Another thing you can't beat is it being next door neighbors with Steve's Hotdogs. Steve's will even bring your food to the Tick Tock side. Heck yeah!

Yes, it is just a "sandwich" place, but my goodness if it's not fantastically made sandwiches. And the peppers that they use there are potent; it cleared my sinuses so quickly that for a moment, it was like my own personal allergy relief commercial. I'm not disappointed with anything on the menu (that I have tried thus far). The cookies are delicious, and one of these days I'll try a milkshake with the sandwich (as long as I don't start counting calories in my head right before). And the prices are reasonable, especially when you consider similar restaurants nearby.

The 'Wreck' or 'Turkey' (I can never do "BIg") on whole wheat, with everything on it (yes, everything) = sandwich gold.

I'm sure there are better sandwich places, but I know I always leave Potbelly feeling satisfied in my fatbelly (You see what I did thar? Ok nvm).

Easy market and sandwich bar near the marinas and boat yards.  They carry a aood selection of beer, pop, waters, snacks and really good made to order sandwiches.  
We had turkey and Italian sammies and requested turkey to be warmed in the panini press (not a norm).  No issues and they were delish!  They use Boarshead spreads.  Sandwiches are under $10 each.  
Friendly and fast service!

While their are definitely some glaring flaws to Spruce Harbor Park during its first summer of execution, especially in the Blue Anchor pop up portion, Its pretty hard NOT to give five stars for the way that they transformed a simple Philly pier into a remarkable boardwalk wonderland filled with plenty of games, outdoor lighting effects, beer gardens, and an endless amount of hammocks.

Between Hyatt hotel and the dreadful eyesore that is the Christopher Columbus Memorial, this park resides in the area that was hands down my least favorite area of the waterfront. But in just a short amount of time Spruce Harbor has managed to become the perfect example of Philly Parklife during the summertime. After all, its not everyday that you can find outdoor games like bocce ball and shuffleboard, classic and new school videogames, and giant sets of chess and Jenga all in one park. While it can be a shit show with a long line and a burger that leaves a lot to be desired, it does speak miles that they brought in an Iron Chef like Jose Garces to set up shop on the parks first restaurant/beer garden pop up too.

Toss in the the many hammocks (one day I will find the opportunity to chillax and read in one), giant With Love Philly Chair, random lighting effects, and more that you may encounter in a visit, and its no wonder why this park may even succeed at being more of a people watching destination than Rittenhouse Square!

I don't know if I'm being stingy or if all this economy business has me paying more attention to financial matters, but lately I'm feeling like quality is declining and yet prices are crazy high!

Hang on.  Wait just a minute.  I think my micro and macro economics professors just got their wings!  Finally, five-plus years later, I get it!  

Joking aside, 2007's Best of Philly happy hour winner leaves A LOT to be desired.  They boast $5 wines by the glass-- but that's only for two selections, one red and one white.  The Cabernet they had on special was pretty beat, and since we didn't want to take a chance on the white, my friend and I ordered a bottle of chardonnay off the regular menu that was actually really good.

After a couple drinks, we ordered the tomato & mozzarella pizza and a wedge salad to share.  The pizza was good for sure but there was no substance.  A saltine is thicker than the crust used in this pizza, no joke.  As for the wedge salad?  I had to ask the bartender if he brought the right one-- it was a hunk of iceberg with some really random vegetables leaned up against it, and an unidentifiable gray substance on the side.  When the bartender confirmed that this was indeed the wedge salad, I asked where the Gorgonzola came in-- oh the gray stuff, of course!  The menu didn't mention that it would be presented in a baby poop-inspired way so that's probably why I didn't realize.  My bad!  

Rae is a cool-looking spot for sure, but I think they take advantage of the fact that they are the only real restaurant in the 30th Street Station/Cira Centre vicinity.  They miss the mark on "creative, complex and imaginative" because they try too hard to get overly fancy, which is just annoying and unnecessary (much like the 5 star reviews that are clearly written by Rae staff).  I can see why it's a popular spot, and the complimentary valet is definitely a bonus, but I don't think I'll be going out of my way to grab a drink or bite to eat there again.

Usually a Monday morning at any doctor's office is a mess - the vet is no exception. But today I was in and out at Millis within 45 minutes. Without an appointment! 

The vets here are so nice and considerate of your pets - even ones like mine who hiss and moan at the slightest move. Shayna is now good to go for another year and is already back to normal at home. 

Let's just cross our fingers that she and the new kitty get along!

Wonderful ginger chocolate cookie. 

I feel bad when someone asks what do you suggest and then goes rogue and doesn't listen. I feel like I usually ask what do you suggest in hopes that they will suggest something I was eyeing. I had just eaten an acai bowl at The Blind Tiger next door so I wasn't looking for something big. I jumped on it when the employee suggested the ginger chocolate cookie. It sounded delicious and I wouldn't pack on a million calories. 

This review is based solely on that cookie. They had a variety of other sweets and savory options - like savory stuffed croissants. As I was munching on the cookie, which I thoroughly enjoyed, I thought, well yes I like this cookie, but you can't really screw it up. Then I thought back to the many times I had that thought with something that a business had screwed up. Moral of the story is I'm not taking this cookie for granted and it's good to know they make one well. 

The ginger chocolate cookie is chewy with huge chunks of chocolate. I felt like $2.50 is fair for this cookie's size. 

If you have a sweet tooth and you're looking for a cute bakery to appease it, swing by here. I'm a fan.

I joined my hubby and his coworkers here for breakfast last Sunday. Even though it was 8a, parking was already getting crowded. But we did manage to get a table for eight with no problem and no wait!

After browsing the menu, I decided to go with the McGrittl This - an enormous pancake with cheese eggs and sausage topped off with another enormous pancake. The pancakes had the perfect fluffy texture - as did the eggs! However, the eggs, cheese and sausage weren't quite as flavorful as I wanted them to be. I would mostly blame the cheese - it was American. If I'd known, I probably would've asked for pepper jack or something else instead. I'd say that this dish is an awesome idea and gets major creativity points, but the execution could be improved. And that's the main reason I'm giving a 3/5.

I'll admit: I don't like chains. Very rarely do I visit them; I'd rather support a local business.

I came here before a local holiday event in Carmel with a friend that was craving sushi. I had never been before, so I was okay with checking it out. 

Reviewing the entire menu, there aren't a lot of vegetarian options (reason for 3 stars instead of 4 stars). I went with an odd variety of food: avocado egg rolls (free Yelp check in offer FYI), veggie sushi rolls, and tomato bisque soup. 

All of the food was delicious, especially those avocado egg rolls. The only food that I had that was just "okay" was the veggie sushi rolls. Nothing special about them at all. The soup was warming and perfect for a chilly, winter night. 

Be sure to check in on the Yelp app and get that free appetizer!

The decor, service and ambiance were spectacular, when we took at break from shopping to have a meal! We sat at the bar and the bartender was quite friendly and professional, getting us our drinks and letting us peruse the menu in an unhurried fashion.

As for the tacos, I honestly was a bit disappointed. The fish taco barely had any fish in it. The vegetarian tacos were missing ingredients like jalapenos even though they were listed on the menu. Everything was  generally flat in the flavor category.

I'd come back for a drink any time and we likely will!

This review is for the hotel only.  

PRICE:  Chosen for its reasonable rate, around $50, if I recall correctly.

ATMOSPHERE:  Oh dear god!  The room decor looked like it came from an 1850s mining town brothel - the print and flounciness and overall blinding colors made me want to throw up.  I must not have been in a recently renovated room because everything was just outdated and tacky.

The quality of the bedcovers and sheets was all cheap, polyestery and smooth and shiny (and not the sexy, satiny kind of smooth and shiny, either).  

My parents were in a room down the hall, and even though it was a non-smoking room, it smelled stale and stuffy in there, as if someone had just sneaked a cigarette in recently.  There was a problem with the toilet not flushing correctly, and it took a loooooong time for someone to come up and fix it, despite being told someone would be up "shortly."  Define shortly?  Thirty minutes?  An hour?  Try two hours.

No thanks - there are lots of different hotel options in this town (and really, I only stay in Reno hotels if I have out of town guests who have an early morning flight the next day - or if I have a morning flight myself), and I won't be back to this hotel any time soon.

Sweet and petite are two adjectives that come to mind when thinking back on meals at La Belle Epoque.  The small corner restaurant is decorated in a casual French Provencal style, with exposed wine racks, warm wood and giant Toulouse Lautrec prints.  It's not very original, aesthetically, but not too shabby for the suburbs. 

The food is the thing that keeps my Media relations coming back -- brunch is especially nice, with a range of breakfast-y egg dishes, generously filled crepes, salads, even a hearty burger.  I especially liked my La Savoyarde crepe filled with raclette cheese (medium-hard Swiss cow's milk), roasted potatoes, prosciutto and reduced leek sauce. It was a bit salty -- the prosciutto, I'd wager -- but I'm into that. 

Service is charming and attentive; the staff even remembers that my parents drink Diet Coke and club soda and serve it to them as soon as they sit down!  

A lovely neighborhood restaurant that always delivers a tasty meal.

I stopped here last night, after watching a movie at Channelside. I was drawn in by a sign saying that they had CHOCOLATE DIPPED FROZEN BANANAS. Do you know how hard those are to come by? Incredibly hard. Unless you're at a fair or some giant dessert factory. Either way, I grabbed a Chocolate Dipped Frozen Banana with Almonds (I LOVE almonds) to go, and I must say it was amazingly good, and four bucks isn't a bad price to pay for something so rare and tasty. I'll surely be going back soon.

The Sofitel Philadelphia is in a great location (Rittenhouse Square)!  It's walking distance from the Amtrak and steps away from many stores (lots of high end ones at that!), restaurants, and bars.  

The room is very welcoming, nicely decorated, and modern looking.  The bed is super comfy, although a little lumpy.  Enjoyed having the separate bathtub and shower.  Loved using the L'Occitane toiletries.  Turndown service (and free bottle of water for that late night drinking) was a nice touch.

The hand a 24 hour fitness center that was equipped with the latest equipment.  Loved being able to watch my own TV while running on the treadmill or using the elliptical.  Machines and free weights were plentiful for strength training.  

Staff was friendly and the housekeeping services were on point.

Hooray...I'm a fan of the Sofitel Philadelphia!

If I update this review from birth until I or Yelp is done on this earth, I can't believe I'll ever rate them less than 5 stars. If for some reason I had to, it would probably break my heart. I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this place.

Yesterday, was St. Joseph's Day and when fellow yelper, Lindsay A and I were talking about dinner, we didn't know what we wanted but we knew we wanted dessert here. We wandered in (and there wasn't too much of a line!) and ordered mocha gelato and a blood orange ice plus we each got the special for San Giuseppe Sfinge, which was puff pastry with cannoli cream with a cherry and candied orange. So much goodness. We got to check out their altar (which is much smaller these days than I remember it in the 80s) and enjoy all the passersby.

At Jazz Fest, Brocato's has a booth at Food 1 and sells spumoni and few other items so I always try to stop by. Back when I was a little girl and fest was MUCH less crowded, I was allowed to cross the fairgrounds by myself to buy myself a wedge (for $1) and then I would gobble it up as I walked back so I wouldn't have to share it with my brothers. 

In my family, the mango ice is one of the first real people foods that new babies are allowed to eat, ensuring that their taste buds are set for life. 

When they reopened after K, I cried and cried because I was so happy they were back. See it's just true love.

This review is from my July 2021 visit.

It wasn't a fun experience. 

We went there on a whim ( we found a parking spot near by). 
Service was borderline rude and very slow. Chips, which are NOT gratis, were stale, ice cold and  "flat ". The salsa was tasteless there seemed to be absence of flavor in everything we ordered. I'd the beef el pastor burrito bowl. Meh, it was very rice centric! Pineapple Margaritas were too sweet - there was no pineapple flavor evident just sour mix. 

Here's the kicker our server added a 20% tip (for a party of 2)  but didn't tell us and there's no warning on the menu. When we asked him why he didn't tell us (after we left an additional 25% tip before realizing what he did) he said it was because of "dine and dashers". If someone is going to run out on the check they will also run out on the tip! So that's just not a cogent explanation! Frankly, i could see why you wouldnt want to tip there but dining and dashing is theft. Ironically we were the ones  left feeling ripped off for sure. Since it was my first meal out in 17 months I didn't want to deal with confronting the server but I'll never go back there again. 

The overall experience was unpleasant. I have a hard time leaving less than 3 stars on any review but I won't be recommending this location. Evidently there are several in the area. 

So, after all that we discovered it's a crappy chain joint to boot!

I love it when a company's advertising is truthful!  The lovely wife and I have been using this chain for years but never this location until now.  Our car was in a major accident and this was the location closest to the body shop we were using.

These folks are famous for their "We pick you up" tag line at that is exactly what they have done for us at other locations and now here.  They picked me up promptly at the body shop as requested. They had a relationship with my insurance company and hooked me up with a clean, smoke-free, new rental car.  The paper work was straightforward.

Many days later I turned the car in and they drove me back to the body shop.  Throughout the process there were no surprises.  Enterprise employees Jon and Lilly both "touched" me and they were friendly and competent.  

The chain is a solid choice and this location is a solid choice.  Enough said!

The Gambit has always been a great resource when you're looking for stuff to do in the city. Especially if you don't have Internet access -- their print listings are definitely better than their online ones.

OK. Set aside your annoyance with emissions when looking at my 5 star review because no one wants to do it and curses to TN for requiring it! 

BUT. This was seriously my shortest wait EVER... and while I have to give myself credit for most of it (waiting until the week before the end of the month AND getting there at 11:15) I still gotta give the staff at this locations some mad props because they were fast, efficient, and I like that this location is removed from highly retailed areas, I believe allowing for faster service and less wait time. 

PLUS if you go to http://www.nashvillevip.org/ you can check out the current wait time with video. So as soon as I saw the wait time was 3 minutes around 10:45, I hopped in my car and INCLUDING travel time I was gone for 30 minutes, I was at the emissions location for under 15 minutes. Seriously. Crazy.

Most efficient station I've visited!!

Thai Cafe is another of the 4 family-owned Thai establishments that populate the east end of the Loop.  Thai Cafe is located east of Skinker, across from The Pageant.

Their menu is similar to Thai Country and Thai Gai Yang, while the decor is more reminiscent of Thai Country.  The food is good, with huge portions and a good amount of spice delivered with the curries.

On a recent visit, it seemed as though they were short staffed because we only ever saw one waitress throughout the whole restaurant.  So while service was a little slow going, it was still good, as our drinks were refilled regularly, and our food didn't take forever to make it out of the kitchen.

While I enjoyed Thai Cafe, I can only hope that on my next trip to St. Louis, Thai Country Cafe will be done with the remodeling and I can get my real STL Thai fix.

This is a chocolate boutique but not one of those stuck up places where the employees are staring at you and look intimidating. Instead, it's casual and friendly. Their chocolates have lots of detail to them. I had to get their highly popular buddah bead which is this red buddah figure that almost looks like a jaded jewelry piece. It's so insane and well detailed that I didn't even want to eat it. For $3 it was a steal and delicious.

If I see you shopping at Foster's, I can deduce a few things about you. 

You love design, you offer guests bathroom reading material, you love Chilewich rugs, you throw dinner parties and appreciate fun salad tongs, your salt and pepper shakers are little ceramic characters that hug each other, you put your organic fruit in an oversized but tasteful crystal bowl, you like when guests ask if they should remove their shoes when they enter your house, you appreciate minimalist decor, you special ordered the birds on a wire wall decal and all your friends ask if it's hand painted, your wine glasses don't have stems, you own a cocktail shaker, the list goes on folks.

What I'm trying to say is this people: if you're looking to impress your friends with your taste, buy them a present here.

Every time I step into Foster's I think on an old proverb: "if a tree falls in the forest and crushes a woman...why is there a forest in the kitchen?"

I can only comment on the nightlife here. I came here on a Saturday around 10:30pm

1) Long line- moved relatively fast
2) $5 cover

Most places in philly don't have cover unless it's a club or edm place so I was a little confused. It is PACKED in here. I like the 2nd floor- more top 40/edm music. It is pretty hard to get a drink here because it is so packed.

I ordered a grey goose shot ($10). I gave the bartender a 20 and he never gave me change....

I probably wouldn't come back because of the overall experience I had.

I feel like someone just plopped a bar from Universal CityWalk smack dab in the middle of the French Quarter. Yeah, yeah, yeah....New Orleans institution, Hurricane this and sing along that, fountain blah blah blah. 

This place is a crowded, overpriced, frat haven that not even a classic cougar pickup by an overly made up Texan on my half her age friend could save. 

If you like Fisherman's Wharf you should seriously put this on your "must see" list in New Orleans. If you have an affinity toward older drunken hot moms this place also can't be missed. However, if you are either of these things, be warned, you probably won't want to filter on my 5 star reviews for sound advice on places to go.

Dr. Sandilands is killing it, and of course, my hygienist, Soraya. They're always so pleasant! Today I went in and was told that I looked like the Princess of Spain! I mean who can resist the charm?

Due to financial/coverage constraints, I wasn't really able to afford going to the Dentist for about two years. It sucks but thankfully my teeth hadn't seen too much damage from the lack of dental care. I was really excited to go today and finally care for my teeth! Now that I have a bit of financial freedom, I'm just stoked to be able to sort everything out.

When I go there I feel well cared for. This includes the nice woman at reception, who got me in the day after I called for an appointment. 

I also didn't feel judged for not being able to come in for a while. This was great because I was a bit worried.

This is also a dental practice filled with badass women! That is always a plus for me. I made the change to all women health practitioners a few years ago and I'm very glad I did! If you're looking for a woman to take care of you, this is the place to go!

Thanks for the awesome care to everyone at Whitemud Dental.

I've never been to the Pour House when there was live music playing..until now!

This past Friday a couple of us friends got together. I tried out the Goose Island Urban Pale Ale with the short rib cheese fries (loved both!)..and then this band started to set up right behind us. Sure, you couldn't really continue any conversation at this point, but the band was awesome.

Always a fun time at the Pour House.

Customizable cheesesteak? Grilled onions? Where do you think you are? Burger King? In-N-Out? Starbucks? I told my cousin to not be the annoying tourist. My bad, after reading the reviews and listening to him order, apparently you can have it your way. Just tell the guy what you want. 

I just got a cheesesteak provolone. I'm not too keen on cheesesteaks and wanted to keep it basic. I should have added onions to mine because it was bland. We added salt and pepper to our sandwiches. The meat was chopped up this time (yay!) and not at all greasy (surprisingly). The bread was real good, soft and doughy. I liked the vibe at Jim's. It felt local as opposed to Pat's and Geno's which is like standing in line at a theme park or carnival. 

Jim's sandwiches are far better than Pat's and Geno's but still not what I thought cheesesteaks were gonna be like. As Mari H explains, maybe I just don't 'get it' yet. I also highly doubt my tastebuds are more refined than hers. After all, I am a Steak-umm kinda gal. So with that said, perhaps the city of Philly has more refined tastebuds than me.

And like a cheesesteak whore, I'm on to the next one. Hello Tony Luke!

PS- There is plenty of seating upstairs but they don't let you loiter.

Short and sweet review for my short experience.

One mission: two muzzles for my two dogs that will not get along no matter how.darned.hard.we.try.  I pulled up the Yelp app to find the nearest PetSmart and voila, this location saved the day for my quick mission. I enjoyed seeing more than three dogs roaming with their owners in the store during the five minutes I was there. The space was fairly organized and parking was easy. It also doesn't hurt that they have a craft store next door. 

This location also offers grooming services as well as puppy school and continued training.

I love this place. Trying to be healthier but not completely depriving myself, I usually order the Chinese chicken salad (with dressing on the side, of course) and my friends and I would order the lobster mac & cheese and share that.  The mac&cheese is a must for me everytime I come. The "mac" part is actually orzo pasta which makes it a little unique. The top also has crunchy bits (which I think are bread crumbs) that just adds a whole other textural element to the dish. 

Regardless of what you order, get the mac&cheese and share with your group!! You won't  be disappointed.

Try to come early because the wait does get long!

I appreciate Reno Bites Week- it reminds you of great spots that you sometimes forget to return to.  

I have hosted a Esteban HH here and have enjoyed a few special food events here over the last couple of years. I need to return more often to the downtown restaurant. 

During RBW the chef offered a three course pre fixe for $30. A full sized small chopped kale salad dressed with a bright lemony vinaigrette with roasted beets and crumbled goat cheese. A similar salad is on the regular- highly suggest you try it. The main course was a seared duck breast with cubes of roasted squash and a cornbread crumble. The overall flavors and texture of this plate shouted- "bring on the fall weather". I really loved the perfectly cooked squash cubes, but crunchiness of the cornbread crumble- scarecrows sang!!  Dessert was a surprise- not a slice of pie, but a small cute baby pumpkin pie on a stick. Perfect for me because I'm all about the flaky crust anyway. It was accompanied by a scoop of bourbon ice cream and a caramel drizzle. This meal included a glass of J Lohr Pinot Noir.  

They create a wonderful charcuterie and cheese plate to snack on with wine or cocktails for light dinner plans. 

Our service was good. Not rushed thru our meal even as the tables filled up fast. 
Sitting along the full windows is a combination- there are shades to block the full afternoon sun, they will open for fresh fall air, and the walkers by can be very entertaining.  

Remember to get your parking stub from across the street validated. Although I find it easier to park across the river at the courthouse parking lot for free.
